                             Yorkshire Evening Post

                                 April 22, 2008

Video: Leeds school opened by terrorist attack hero

LENGTH: 360 words


The brand new John Smeaton Community College in Leeds was officially opened
today by a modern-day hero of the same name who helped foil the Glasgow Airport
terrorist attack.

Scots-born John Smeaton was working as a baggage handler when he risked his life
to help police officers, staff and the public when terrorists drove a flaming
jeep into the airport terminal last June.

While most fled in horror, Mr Smeaton rushed to help a policeman who was being
attacked by one of the vehicle's occupants. He also helped drag an injured
colleague away from the Jeep, which was loaded with propane canisters.

The hero, who won the Queen's Gallantry Medal for his brave efforts, took time
out from saving lives to officially open the new John Smeaton Community College
in Stanks, which welcomed its first pupils in September.

The college is one of five completed under the £112m Combined Secondary Schools
Project (CSSP), a partnership between Education Leeds, Leeds City Council and
Land Securities Trillium.

Opening the school, Mr Smeaton said: "It's a great honour and I'm delighted to
be here.

"One minute you're a baggage handler and the next you're a national hero.

"You have a boring, normal life like everybody else and all of a sudden you're
thrust into this life that you read about in the papers.

"I'm just a normal guy who was in a place trying to do the right thing at the
right time. I'm nothing special."

The original John Smeaton, who the school is named after, was born in Austhorpe
in the 18th century and became the physicist and is regarded as the father of
civil engineering.

Among the state-of-the art facilities at the new school include a construction
suite, a hair and beauty salon and recording, dance and drama studios.

Headteacher John Daulby said: "Results are improving year on year and we now
have one of the best learning environments in the country to add to the
brilliant leisure and sports facilities which opened last year.

The other schools to benefit from the CSSP are Ralph Thoresby High, South Leeds
High and Carr Manor High, as well as the region's first ever learning campus for
two-to-19 year olds at Primrose High and Shakespeare Primary.

                            April 23, 2008 Wednesday

Russian pundit says terrorist groups planning attacks on Ukraine

LENGTH: 345 words


Russian pundit Aleksandr Zhilin has said that "three Islamic extremist groups"
are planning "a series of quite bold, major terrorist attacks against Ukraine in
response to Ukraine's NATO aspirations". Zhilin, who was introduced as an
independent military expert, was discussing the importance of a recent CIS air
defence drill on Russian Centre TV's "25th Hour" programme on 22 April. He said
that the groups were based outside Ukraine and that the Ukrainian authorities
had kept the information secret from the public.

"The scriptwriters for these barbarous acts have one aim, to frighten, overwhelm
potential partners and NATO members. Under one of the considered scenarios the
terrorists would strike from Moldova. For example, under the most simple of
scenarios a chartered aircraft would land in Chisinau and from there fly to
Ukraine. A very important facility, a very hazardous facility, for the entire
Europe, the South Ukrainian Nuclear Power Plant, becomes a target.

"We know the condition of Ukraine's air defence system; we know the condition of
our fraternal partners' national security system. Therefore all of this is very
serious, serious for Russia and all of Europe."

Zhilin was also asked about his views on a recent incident in the
Georgian-Abkhaz conflict zone in which a Georgian unmanned aerial vehicle was
shot done (by Abkhaz forces according to the Russian and Abkhaz separatist
authorities; by a Russian fighter jet according to the government of Georgia).
Zhilin described the incident as an "act of provocation" by Tbilisi and a
"poorly prepared PR" stunt, and ridiculed the explanations given by the Georgian
officials.

He said Russia should ignore them just as a doctor ignores a mentally ill
patient's "tantrums". "One should either administer shots or use a
straightjacket or do something else, but one should not take it close to their
heart. This will continue. And I assure you that the more good will on the part
of Moscow the more such acts of provocation there will be," he said.

Source: Centre TV, Moscow, in Russian 1950 gmt 22 Apr 08

                         Peterborough Evening Telegraph

                                 April 23, 2008

Long Causeway knife-attack terror: Man faces deportation

LENGTH: 571  words


A MAN who brought terror to the city centre when he ploughed his car into
shoppers before plunging a knife into a brave bystander who tried to stop him
could be deported.

Paranoid schizophrenic Mohammed Zouaoui (34) was told by Judge Nicholas Coleman
that what he did was so grave, he should be sent back to his Algerian homeland
after completing a spell in a mental health unit.

He was also banned from driving for seven years.

Peterborough Crown Court heard that Zouaoui, of Cromwell Road, Millfield,
Peterborough, had arrived in the country by claiming asylum.

But it was suggested this was done "for spurious reasons" by entering into a
marriage of convenience with a woman who now lives in France.

Zouaoui, who has been detained at the Norvic Clinic in Norwich, had admitted at
an earlier hearing to dangerous driving, attempting to cause grievous bodily
harm with intent, causing grievous bodily harm with intent, and wounding with
intent during the incident in Long Causeway.

At his sentencing yesterday, the dramatic details of Zouaoui's terrifying spree
on Saturday, January 5 were laid bare.

But what also emerged was an inspiring story of courage.

Nick Petruzziello (22) received 13 stitches after being stabbed as he tried to
usher his girlfriend and other shoppers out of harm's way.

Judge Coleman said: "What he did was quite astonishing. He should be commended
for his bravery and willingness to intervene and help others when confronting
someone who could have hurt him."

He will be awarded £500 for his selfless actions.

The court heard how a steward manning the barrier in Long Causeway saw Zouaoui
hurtling through it in his Citroen ZX.

A man and woman were thrown into the air before the driver pulled up outside the
Nationwide Building Society.

Also watching aghast at the unfolding events was Mr Petruzziello, who had just
picked up a takeaway with his girlfriend Jennie Westall.

Prosecuting, John Kellett said: "He saw the driver get out and decided he should
close him down in case he did anything else to anybody.

"He punched him to the face. At this point, he didn't see the knife.

"He thought he received a punch back, but when he saw the blood on his shirt, he
realised he had been stabbed.

"He should be commended for his public spirit in approaching him, considering
what he had just heard and seen."

As blood poured from his abdomen, Mr Petruzziello ran to alert others to stay
out of the man's path.

Zouaoui then jumped in his car and sped off. He was tracked by CCTV and picked
up by officers on the A1.

Sentencing, Judge Coleman said: "The whole episode, to those involved and the
witnesses, was no doubt terrifying.

"The public have to be protected from the danger you present.

"Although you have made a marked improvement, your mental state is still fragile
and will continue to be so.

"The right course is for you to be detained under the Mental Health Act.

"You should not be released until it is seen as appropriate to do so.

"What you did was so bad and sufficiently dangerous to warrant a recommendation
at the conclusion of your detention that you be deported."

The psychiatrist treating Zouaoui said he could appeal against his detention in
just six months.

Speaking afterwards, Mr Petruzziello said: "It won't be just us that is unhappy
at the sentence, it will be everyone in Peterborough.

"But I think the judge did everything he could.

"It's closure for all of us, even though it was not the outcome we wanted."

SUN HILL TERROR ATTACK;
SOAPER STAR - Cops face bomb hell

BYLINE: with Soaps Editor KATIE BEGLEY

SECTION: COLUMNS; 28

LENGTH: 255 words


SUN Hill's finest face their toughest challenge when bombs rip through central
London.

In a sensational threepart special, kicking off a week today, chaos reigns as
blasts leave scores dead and hundreds injured.

And as police struggle to cope, fans' favourite Emma Keane finds herself in the
middle of an attack.

Emma, played by Melanie Gutteridge, 34, is left fighting for her life when she
walks into a factory as another device explodes.

The storyline has been months in the planning and bosses of the ITV drama think
the time is finally right to screen the scenes after the real 7/7 attacks on
London in 2005.

The stars drew on experiences from the Tube and bus bombings to make their
scenes more realistic.

Sam Callis, 32, who plays Sgt Callum Stone, said: "It was very emotional.

"But I do think it's the right time to show it. People will be able to relate to
the story and the confusion caused by the explosions.

"I felt like crying at the end of filming, it was just so draining." The Sun
Hill team desperately try to work out who is responsible. And there is more
drama amid the madness as Stone discovers that a pervert is posing as a doctor
to molest injured women.

As he goes off to tackle the sick criminal, he leaves Emma alone and she
discovers another bomb in a nearby warehouse.

Sam added: "She manages to get people out but discovers there's three people
left, when she heads back inside the bomb goes off." Stone and fellow officer
Sally Armstrong (Ali Bastian, 25) race into the building to find Emma covered in
debris.

                                 Post Magazine

                            April 24, 2008 Thursday

Business Continuity Management: Terrorism - Planet terror.;
Actions in the face of terrorist attacks can often seem inadequate. But with 40%
of organisations likely to fail in the event of an atrocity, now has never been
a more important time to plan for all eventualities, as Sam Barrett discovers.

SECTION: Pg. 16

LENGTH: 2099  words

DATELINE: UK


A recent survey found that, in spite of the risk, many London firms have failed
to put any plans in place to deal with a terrorist attack. The survey, conducted
by Marsh, found that more than a third of the delegates at its seminar on
terrorism did not have emergency response, crisis management and business
recovery plans integrated within their business continuity management framework.

"We had representatives from 88 reputable companies and more than a third of
them said that, although they had BCM plans for other events, they had not put
anything together specifically for a terrorist attack," explains Robert Hall,
managing consultant at Marsh.

This is a worrying statistic. "BCM planning for acts of terrorism has become a
necessity. By having the proper systems in place an organisation is prepared if
the worst happens and this will mean minimal interruption to business," says
Mick Gritton, director for corporate consulting at HMS. He points out that
following the IRA vehicle bomb in Manchester in 1996, more than 40% of
organisations affected went out of business.

Abstract threat

There are all manner of reasons for the low BCM take-up. For starters, although
people are aware of the threat, they feel unable to do anything about it.
"Terrorist attacks can feel like a very abstract threat," says Liam Morrissey,
partner at BGN Risk, the security consulting division of Begbies Traynor. "They
don't happen every day and many firms believe they don't need to plan for it as,
if it does happen, the government will deal with it anyway."

Their potential scale can also be a deterrent. For instance, Peter Adlington,
manager of property and commercial reinsurance at Allianz, says that for small
companies with a single site in a target area it can be easy to be daunted by
the potential impact and take no action. "It is easier for international firms,"
he adds. "These are akin to a state in their own right. They have large and
spread resources, duplication of processes and over all a will to survive and
prosper. They also have the experience and manpower to negotiate with
authorities at all levels."

The state of the insurance market is also taking away some of the impetus to put
BCM plans in place. It has been softening for some time and this trend is likely
to continue for the rest of the year. "This has led to an increase in demand for
cover as existing clients feel able to purchase increased capacity at a
competitive rate while new clients feel cover is now more affordable as prices
have fallen," says Sandy Cheetham, terrorism underwriter at Arch Insurance
Company. She says that she saw business increase by 40% in March alone.

But while it may be cheaper than it has ever been to put cover in place, this
can make firms less inclined to put any BCM in place. This is especially the
case when the discipline of BCM is not properly integrated with insurance.

"There's still a disconnect between insurance and the risk management and BCM
industry," says Chris Rigby-Smith, partner in global risk solutions at Jardine
Lloyd Thompson. "From an insurer's perspective it can be difficult to determine
what makes a good BCM plan."

This will change, especially with the introduction of a British Standard for BCM
(BS25999) last November. "The new standard provides a framework to identify
risks and respond to them. As the standard becomes more widely known, with
accreditation available later this year, insurers may insist that businesses
receive it as evidence that a BCM programme is fit for purpose," says Shaun
Kelly, head of business solutions group at Crawford and Company.

Specific plans

As well as being lulled into a false sense of security by the availability of
cheap cover, some firms, having put together BCM plans for other potential
problems such as fire or flood, feel these can be adapted for any event,
including terrorism.

Martin Savage, managing consultant and business continuity practice leader at
RSA, says this can work. "If you have good wide BCM plans then they should apply
to everything. Scenario planning is too specific," he explains.

However, Mr Hall argues that this is not the case as terrorism is such a
different event. "Terrorism has unique features. There's the potential for mass
casualty, mass damage and mass disruption. This requires different planning to
events such as fire and flood."

As an example, while it makes sense to have alternative premises arranged for a
fire or flood, on the day of the terrorist bomb attacks in London on 7 July
2005, having an alternative premises in London would have been pointless as the
entire city ground to a halt.

And according to Doug Barnett, head of customer risk management at Axa
Insurance, many firms could be caught out by this. "For fire and flood it's
perfectly acceptable to move to alternative premises a couple of miles down the
road but, with a terrorist attack you need a disaster recovery centre in another
part of the country," he explains. "Many larger businesses will have regional
offices and they should think about whether they could use these."

Threats are also very different. Although there hasn't been an incident in the
UK, there is a threat of a chemical, biological, radiological or nuclear attack.

"Bombs involving conventional explosives have a comparatively limited
geographical impact and the damage can be seen. By contrast, CBRN contaminants
are invisible and are likely to render large areas uninhabitable and unusable
for a considerable period of time," says Mr Kelly. "Planning for this type of
event is, to say the least, extremely problematic and usually only within the
scope of international companies."

Even though there is little a business can do in the long term in the event of
this type of attack, their initial responses will need to be considered. Mr Hall
says: "With these types of attacks you'd need to take very different action to
those used when dealing with a fire or flood. Because of the risks involved with
going outside you'd need to look at safeguarding the building, shutting off any
air intakes and invacuating rather than evacuating."

Businesses also need to think about how they deal with employees in the event of
a terrorist attack. While employees can generally adapt quickly to new working
conditions or premises if a fire or flood occurs, a terrorist attack can affect
employees' psychological wellbeing. Further, even people who were not directly
involved in the incident can still be affected by it. To illustrate this, 7th
July Assistance, which was set up to provide counselling and support to people
affected by the bombings, recognises that the attacks can affect people that
were not even caught up in the incidents and will work with anyone affected.

As well as being compassionate towards employees' feelings, Mr Barnett believes
firms must consider their legal responsibilities. "It's worth bearing the
Corporate Manslaughter Act in mind," he explains. "If multiple attacks are
taking place then is it reasonable to expect employees to come into the office?
Or would you be putting them at risk if you insisted they came in?"

The scale of terrorism attacks also means it's essential to develop plans in
conjunction with other organisations. A prime example of this is a company's
employee evacuation plans. While the evacuation of one company's premises to a
particular meeting point might be possible, if every company in an area has to
evacuate its building there might not be sufficient space for all the employees.

"Businesses do need to work together to ensure their plans don't create new
problems," explains Mr Hall. He says there has not been much evidence of this
happening though. "Evidence suggest that where this happens it's down to the
person's initiative but I think this will improve with the education process,"
he adds.

Mr Morrissey would also like to see businesses taking steps to prevent attacks.
As an example he uses Israel. "There's always a reconnaissance before an attack
to make sure it's going to be possible. In Israel one of the prime targets for
bombs are the buses. They're easy for a bomber to board and other targets, such
as supermarkets, now have security in place so anyone acting suspiciously will
be identified and deterred quickly," he explains.

But, possibly more important than beefing up security and putting the plans
together, is the testing of them. "This is certainly an area where businesses
are failing to take action," says Mr Rigby-Smith. He believes that although most
businesses, especially in the city where BCM is more developed, will have
introduced some form of plan for a major incident, it's much less likely it will
have been tested.

Ideally a BCM plan should be tested as often as possible, although the
disruption this can cause to the business can prevent it happening at all. "You
could have a paper exercise every few months with a full test once a year," says
Mr Hall. "This will highlight any weaknesses in the plan."

Plan of action

Plans do not - and should not - be put together in isolation either. As well as
involving other businesses in the area, firms can turn to a variety of
organisations for advice and support. Mr Adlington says that the government,
local authorities, trade associations, unions and the local chamber of commerce
could all help. He adds: "In the recent flood events the Gold Commands worked
well, co-ordinating rescue and recovery especially to the infrastructure."

Insurance can also help. Although the low cost of insurance means it's often
being used instead of proper planning, it can complement good BCM as well as
being affordable. Given the softness of the market there is plenty of choice
available, with a number of new players entering the market in the last couple
of years. These include Hiscox's launch last year of a combined war, terrorism
and political violence policy.

"There's a huge amount of diversity when looking at intellectual capacity within
the market," says Ms Cheetham. "Some carriers have chosen to write in a
conservative fashion while others have deployed their capacity in a more
entrepreneurial way."

Whether going conservative or entrepreneurial, she does warn that it is not
always appropriate to buy off-the-peg cover. "Firms need to ensure they are
getting bespoke products to maximise protection of their assets," she explains,
adding that many clients are tailoring cover to their liabilities.

To illustrate this she lists some of the areas that can be covered. These
include physical damage, contents, pure business interruption and contingent
business interruption, covering named suppliers and buyers with sub-limits in
respect of increased cost of operating, loss of profits and so on. Given the
cheapness of cover and the willingness of insurers and other parties to provide
support on BCM planning, it has never been easier to prepare for the unthinkable
so maybe next time the figures will tell a different story.

THE TERRORISM THREAT

Being the capital city and a major financial centre, London has always been a
potential target for terrorism. According to MI5 there is a serious and
sustained threat from international terrorism with the current threat level
assessed as severe.

In recent years there have been a number of attacks, with the attack on London's
transport network on 7 July 2005 causing the most damage. This killed 52 people
and injured a further 800.

Since then there have been several attacks in the UK. These include a second
attempt on London's transport system two weeks later, failed car bomb attacks in
the centre of London in June 2007 and a burning car loaded with gas cylinders
driven into Glasgow airport later that month. Further, the trial of eight men
charged over an alleged plot to blow up passengers planes flying out of Heathrow
is currently underway.

Sandy Cheetham, terrorism underwriter at Arch Insurance Company, says the most
significant risk to London comes from domestic self-radicalising Sunni extremist
groups.

"Sunni extremists are likely to attempt to cause bomb explosions that maximise
human casualties by attacking crowded transportation assets, busy public spaces,
bars and nightclubs and tourist attractions in London's West End," she says.

She believes that some successful plots are likely to take place in the next
three years, with more plots and attempted attacks likely to be disrupted over
this time.

More information about the threats and advice about how to prepare for them can
be found on the London Resilience website (www.londonprepared.gov.uk), the MI5
website (www.mi5.gov.uk) and the Metropolitan Police Service website
(www.met.police.uk).

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political

                             April 25, 2008 Friday

China: PLA Olympic security forces take precautions against terror attacks

LENGTH: 728 words


Text of report by Chinese news agency Zhongguo Xinwen She

["PLA Olympic Security Forces Take Strict Precautions against Terrorist Attacks]

Beijing, 24 April (ZXS) - Under the unified organization and coordination of the
PLA General Staff Headquarters, the PLA Olympics security forces are making
elaborate preparations, undergoing intensive training, and making rigorous
battle preparations. At present, all items of the preparatory work for guarding
against terrorist attacks during the Olympic Games have entered the stage of
battle simulation training.

According to the briefing given by a responsible person in the Military Training
and Arms Department of the PLA General Staff Headquarters, counter-terrorism is
the top priority in the Olympic Games security work, and preventing and
combating terrorist attacks by nuclear, chemical, and biological means is the
critical and difficult point in the counter-terrorist efforts. Terror attacks by
nuclear, chemical, and biological means may be diverse and stealthy, and may be
difficult to prevent and cope with. So the counter-terrorist efforts are focused
on preventing and coping with terror attacks by nuclear, chemical, and
biological means.

As it is learned, to do the prevention work well, the relevant forces have
adopted concrete measures, including the measures of conducting accurate
reconnaissance, instantly controlling and intercepting intelligence, taking
preemptive actions to neutralize the enemies before they can launch terror
attacks; installing nuclear, chemical, and biological sensing and monitoring
devices and relevant security check equipment in the stadiums and other
facilities related to the Olympic Games; exercising rigorous security control
over the nuclear, chemical, and biological facilities and the production, use,
and transportation of poisonous and hazardous nuclear, chemical, and biological
materials in the cities for the Olympic Games; extensively conducting propaganda
to popularize the scientific knowledge about terror attacks by nuclear,
chemical, biological means.

In late 2006, the PLA Olympics security forces embarked upon making preparations
against terrorist attacks by nuclear, chemical, biological means for the
guaranteeing the security of the Olympic Games. Experts in nuclear, chemical,
biological protection were selected from various military academies and research
institutes in the whole PLA to set up an emergency expert consultation group for
preventing and combating terrorist attacks by nuclear, chemical, biological
means; force deployment and task assignments were made for all links of the
Olympic Games security; comprehensive training was unfolded; the "Manual of
Preventing and Coping with Terrorist Attacks by Nuclear, Chemical, Biological
Means" was compiled and printed; coordinated training, command exercises, and
joint professional drillings were organized to practice the counter-terrorist
actions against nuclear, chemical, biological attacks; the forces, the
armaments, and the construction of the means were strengthened; materials and
equipment were distributed and replenished; the nuclear, chemical, biological
sensing and monitoring equipment installed in the Olympic Games stadiums,
facilities, and other important targets was tested; the test of radiation and
biological samples was completed. At present, the PLA Olympics security forces
have built up the capability of, and attained the required technical and
tactical level of, accurately detecting, preventing, issuing early warning
about, and correctly judging the character and harmful effects of, a terror
attack, and taking timely actions to rescue common people and evacuate them from
the dangerous area.

At present, the relevant units have formulated a general programme and a set of
specialized plans and departmental plans for the Olympic Games security in the
aspect of guarding against and coping with terror attacks by nuclear, chemical,
biological means, and have formulated a complete set of plans for preventing and
coping with nuclear, chemical, biological terror attacks. In the meanwhile, they
have organized emergency forces, established professional contingents,
integrated all types of emergency forces, and clarified the command and
coordination relationships according to the division of tasks.

Source: Zhongguo Xinwen She news agency, Beijing, in Chinese 24 Apr 08

                           Evening Herald (Plymouth)

                             April 28, 2008 Monday

Sex attack terror

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 442 words


Detectives have appealed for the public's help after two 14-year-old girls and
an older woman were sexually assaulted at knifepoint in St Judes.

A major investigation involving more than 20 officers is under way after the
victims were attacked at 8.30pm on Saturday in the Lucas Lane area of Tothill
Park.

The incident began when two teenage girls were jogging along a cycle path close
to the park.

A man approached them, engaged them in conversation and jogged alongside.  He
then threatened them with what detectives believe was a Stanley or craft knife,
before sexually assaulting them both.

A woman cycling in the area heard the girls' screams and tackled the man,
allowing them to escape. The brave woman, in her mid 30s, was then also sexually
assaulted.

Two men, who live in the area, chased the offender but lost him as he made his
way towards Embankment Road. The girls and the woman escaped with minor injuries
in the attack.

Up to 24 specially-trained police officers were today expected to continue
door-to-door enquiries and searches of the area.

Detective Chief Inspector Iain Grafton, head of Plymouth CID, described it as a
"terrifying" ordeal, and urged people to be cautious if using the area.

He said detectives believe the suspect is a local man and had been seen in the
area in the days leading up to the attack.

Residents who might have seen the man are being urged to contact the police.

"It is a worry for local residents and clearly there is a concern for their
safety," said DCI Grafton.

"Anyone who uses the cycle path should take some precautions for the time being,
such as not jogging alone and telling someone where you are going.

"I would also urge them to carry a mobile phone.

"Although the girls did not suffer great physical injury, this was a terrifying
ordeal for them."

Detective Inspector Mike Cooper, who is leading the investigation, said: "It is
very unusual that three women should be assaulted in such a way in such a short
space of time.

"This man is a dangerous serious offender and we would urge anyone with any
information to come forward."

The attacker is described as having dark skin and being a mixed race man. He
spoke with a local accent and is believed to be aged in his mid-20s.

He is about 5ft 9in to 6ft 1in tall and of slim build and was wearing dark
coloured clothing and a grey hooded top which was up at the time of the
incident.  He also had a grade three hair cut.

Anyone with any information is asked to call the police on 08452 777 444 quoting
the crime reference number EC08 4448.

Alternatively people can call Crimestoppers on 0800 555111.

A 25-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the incident.

                             Paisley Daily Express

                             April 29, 2008 Tuesday
                                  1ST Edition

MAN IS RUN OVER IN TIT-FOR-TAT MURDER BID;
 Gunshot terror during gang's vicious attack

BYLINE: JOHN LEES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 516 words


A MAN was seriously ill in hospital yesterday after being run over by his own
car during a terrifying street attack in which a gun was fired.

John Burns, 44, suffered spinal injuries when a gang of thugs tried to murder
him in Tannahill Terrace, Ferguslie Park, Paisley, as passers-by looked on in
horror.

Last night, detectives said they had not ruled out a possible link with a second
attempted murder in the town which happened hours later and led to four men
being stabbed - with one of the victims left critically ill.

One underworld source told the Paisley Daily Express: "There seems to be a link
between these two murder bids and one line of inquiry being looked at by police
is that it was a tit-for-tat situation."

Violence flared in Tannahill Terrace at around 8.30pm on Sunday when a large
group of men and women were involved in a disturbance.

The source added: "A man who owns a 4x4 car was run over by his own vehicle but
I don't know who was driving it at the time.

"He suffered some nasty injuries, including damage to his spine.

"Someone also heard a loud bang and recognised it as a gun being fired but
no-one has any gunshot wounds so, clearly, the bullet didn't hit anyone.

"There is talk that there had been bad feelings between some of the people
involved and it has got way out of hand."

Last night, Mr Burns was being treated at Paisley's Royal Alexandra Hospital,
where his condition was described as serious but stable.

A stretch of Tannahill Terrace covering some 200 yards had been cordoned off
yesterday as cops continued to carry out door-to-door inquiries.

In an appeal for witnesses, a police spokesman said: "If anyone saw or heard
anything in that area of Ferguslie Park on Sunday night, ring the police on
01505 404000 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111."

The second attempted murder took place in Wellmeadow Street, Paisley, during a
fight involving four men, some of whom were armed with blades.

The melee is believed to have stemmed from a disagreement in the nearby Whisky
Joe's pub at around 10.30pm on Sunday.

That row led to trouble outside the pub, which then escalated across the street.

In the moments that followed, four men were badly hurt, with pools of blood left
at the scene.

The injured men - aged 34, 35, 37 and 50 - were all taken to the RAH suffering a
variety of wounds to back, chest and stomach.

The 37-year-old man is the most seriously ill and his condition was yesterday
said to be critical.

Detectives said the attack on the most seriously injured victim is being treated
as attempted murder, while the attacks on the other three men are being treated
as serious assaults.

One resident who lives near to the scene of the street fight said: "It was
bedlam. People were screaming and threatening each other.

"At least three men had blades and they were lashing out. One man came off the
worst. He lost a lot of blood and I know he was in a bad way."

A police spokesman said: "This was a serious incident which must have been
witnessed by many people. We urge them to ring us on 01505 404000 or call
Crimestoppers."

                                  Daily Record

                              May 2, 2008, Friday

TRIAL RUN OF TERROR ATTACKS ON CCTV

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 231 words


FOOTAGE showing three of the July 7 bombers travelling on the Tube in a dummy
run nine days before the attacks was shown to a jury yesterday.

The CCTV images show Mohammed Siddique Khan, Shehzad Tanweer and Jermaine
Lindsay arriving in London at 8.52am on June 28, 2005 - the same time they would
make their final journey just over a week later.

They were filmed arriving at King's Cross rail station before travelling on to
Embankment, South Kensington and Baker Street Tube stations.

They spent four hours in London, before returning on the Thames Link train to
Luton, Kingston Crown Court heard.

Nine days later, the three men and a fourth bomber, Hasib Hussain, would murder
52 people and injure nearly 1000 more when they set off their bombs on the
capital's transport network.

The clips were shown to jurors at the trial of Waheed Ali, 24, Mohammed Shakil,
31, and Sadeer Saleem, 27, who are said to have helped the bombers by scouting
possible targets during a two-day mission seven months before the attacks.

The court has heard traces of DNA from Ali and Saleem were found at a "bomb
factory" in Alexandra Grove, Leeds, while a key for a Mitsubishi belonging to
Shakil, was discovered at the address.

Ali, from Bow, east London, and Shakil and Saleem, from Beeston in Leeds, all
deny conspiring to cause an explosion to endanger lives or likely to cause
serious injury.

The trial continues.

                            Nottingham Evening Post

                               May 2, 2008 Friday

Learning how to deal with a terror attack

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 168 words


A Scheme to raise awareness of how businesses deal with the public, staff and
customers in the event of a terrorist attack took place this week.

Project Argus, a National Counter Terrorism Security Office  initiative, taught
30 delegates ways to prevent, handle and recover from a major incident by taking
them through a simulated exercise.

Led by Notts police's Special Branch, and supported by Nottingham City Council
and the Nottingham and Nottinghamshire Local Resilience Forum, the session asked
business managers and assistant managers a number of questions to challenge how
prepared they currently are.

Ian Morden, security systems manager for Nottingham Trent University, who
attended, said: "This has been a very useful  exercise. It has  provided me with
food for thought."

Mark Edis, security manager for Westfield's Broadmarsh Centre, said:
"Information like this is invaluable for companies like mine.

"I will be taking these messages back to my organisation to help build our
resilience in these areas."

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                               May 5, 2008 Monday

Police official warns about possibility of terrorist attack from Bosnia

LENGTH: 695 words


Text of report by Bosnian Serb privately-owned centrist newspaper Nezavisne
novine, on 3 May

[Report by Vesna Popovic: "Terrorists might attack from Bosnia-Hercegovina"]

Banja Luka - As a result of weak communication among the law enforcement
agencies, the decentralized nature of the state, and the political interference
in law enforcement, Bosnia-Hercegovina is vulnerable to exploitation as a
potential staging ground for terrorist operations in Europe.

This is stated in the US State Department's most recent report on terrorism. The
report says that "the dysfunctional Bosnian state government and the efforts by
the Serb Republic officials to undermine the state-level institutions
contributed to a slowdown, and in some cases, setbacks in efforts to improve
operational capabilities to combat terrorism and terrorism finance."

"The State Investigation and Protection Agency [SIPA] is the Bosnian agency with
primary responsibility for counterterrorism operations. The position of the SIPA
director was unfilled for most of the year and the agency's readiness and
capabilities suffered as a result. In addition, the B-H security minister
politicized the Ministry's terrorism threat analysis and counterterrorism
operations," the report reads.

Although Bosnian capabilities and potential for independent action were degraded
over the year, the report says, the Bosnian authorities were generally effective
and responsive to US counterterrorism cooperation requests.

Gojko Vasic, director of the Serb Republic criminal police administration,
warned that Bosnia-Hercegovina might be used as a base for training and sending
terrorists to Europe and the rest of the world. Vasic did not rule out the
possibility of terrorist attacks.

"There is always a possibility of terrorist attacks, particularly considering
the fact that Bosnia-Hercegovina went through a war, when people were trained to
use weapons and this knowledge can be used for terrorist purposes," he said.

He also said that the Serb Republic Interior Ministry [MUP] was collecting data
on the ground and submitted it to agencies that might find it interesting,
including even certain foreign agencies.

Vasic added that the Serb Republic MUP was submitting to the state service the
required data, but he warned that the Ministry did not have methods that secret
intelligence services had to use in fighting terrorism.

Serb Republic Prime Minister Milorad Dodik said in his comment on the State
Department's report that the B-H institutions were undermining the entities and
this had to stop.

He said that Bosnia-Hercegovina was a deeply divided multiethnic society, which
could not be based on the centralized foundations and the view that all the
institutions of authority had to be centralized at the B-H level.

Dodik emphasized that Bosnia-Hercegovina could preserve its international-legal
framework, and that its internal organization was a matter of the interest of
people who live here, and not the international powers.

We did not manage to get a comment by B-H Defence Minister Tarik Sadovic
yesterday, as he did not answer his telephone.

He had said earlier that according to the assessment by the
Intelligence-Security Agency, fewer than 50 people represented a threat to the
national security, but that none of those people were currently in
Bosnia-Hercegovina.

[Box] Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia-Hercegovina

The State Department said in its report that the Croatian Government had
increased its contribution to the international security forces in Afghanistan
from 150 to 200 soldiers, who were serving in medical support, force security,
military police, and the liaison and training roles.

According to the State Department's annual report on terrorism, Serbia
cooperated with the United States on a wide range of terrorism issues, including
border security and information sharing.

As for Kosovo, the UNMIK [United Nations Mission in Kosovo] continued to deal
with terrorist activities issues, and the officials believed that only a few of
the more than 400 non-governmental organizations in Kosovo were involved in
suspicious activities.

Source: Nezavisne novine, Banja Luka, in Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian 3 May 08

TAXI TERROR;
Court told of 'sex attack' on woman

BYLINE: GARETH LIGHTFOOT

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 411 words


A TAXI driver kidnapped and sexually assaulted a female passenger in an
hour-long ride of terror, a court heard.

Mohammed Saddique told his 23-year-old passenger he thought she was "up for
anything", a Teesside Crown Court jury was told yesterday.

Saddique, 29, picked her up in Middlesbrough after a night out at about 2.30am
on September 19 last year.

But then he took unexpected turns and instead of taking the woman home to
Billingham, drove towards Seaton Carew, it is alleged.

"She did not want to be in the car with him, but him driving away left her
little choice," said prosecutor Tina Dempster.

"She was in the taxi against her will for around an hour."

The woman told the jury: "I asked him where he was going. He asked me didn't I
have time to go for a drive. I started to feel really uneasy.

I said no."

She said she called a friend and dropped hints to him hoping he would look for
her.

"I was trying to get as much information to him without panicking the driver.

"I didn't know where I was going. It was pitch black. I was really scared of
what he was going to do.

"I thought if I rang the police and struggled I could anger him. There was
nowhere I could run to."

She sent her friend a text saying: "The taxi man won't let me out of the taxi. I
dunno where he's taking me. I just know it's the Seaton road. Will you help me
please?"

She said she secretly made more calls to him and left the line open as she asked
the driver about her destination.

The Crown say Saddique reached over to the woman three times while driving, put
his hand down her top and touched her breast and leg.

"I started panicking even more. I just had visions in my head if he was going to
touch me, he could try and do anything," said the woman.

"I looked at him. He was looking at me just as bold as brass as if it was the
most normal thing in the world.

"I considered just throwing myself out of the car.

"I was scared that he was going to rape me."

She said Saddique asked if she had any condoms as he drove to Seaton Carew,
Hartlepool, Newton Bewley then back to the Billingham area.

He eventually dropped her off at Wolviston Services at about 4am, when the woman
said she collapsed, hysterical, crying and breathless.

Her friend and the police arrived quickly and Saddique was arrested.

Saddique, of Crescent Road, Middlesbrough, denies kidnapping and three counts of
sexual assault.

He told police the woman asked to be taken to Seaton Carew and denied that
anything sexual happened.

Proceeding

                           Evening Herald (Plymouth)

                               May 9, 2008 Friday

Our sex attack terror

BYLINE:  CARL EVE  Crime Reporter

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 536 words


Two teenage girls  sexually assaulted in a terrifying knifepoint attack have
spoken of their traumatic ordeal - one saying she now feels 'violated'.

The two girls - whom The Herald is referring to as Charlotte and Rose to protect
their real identities - fell prey to the man while they were out jogging on
April 26 along a St Judes cyclepath.

Despite their ordeal, the girls - both 14 - remain remarkably upbeat, positive
and modestly brave, claiming it was 'lucky' they were the ones attacked because
"There were 10-year-olds around and they wouldn't have been able to defend
themselves".

The girls, who both live in south-east Plymouth,  had decided to go for a run to
blow away the cobwebs of the day. Charlotte said: "I was feeling rough, called
Rose and we decided to go for a jog.

"We expected to be out an hour."

Rose is quick to stress it was not dark; Charlotte adds:  "It was a nice
evening".

Both girls, despite fiddling with MP3 players for their run, spotted 'lots of
people' in the park, the basketball ground and the 'Tothill enclosure',
including some they knew.

As they approached the railway bridge over the cyclepath, near Lucas Terrace,
they saw their attacker whom they described to police as dark-skinned, in his
late twenties and 5ft 10in to 6ft 1in tall. His hair was cut to grade three
length and he was wearing a dark hoody-style top and dark trousers.  Neither
will speak of the attack, but despite their nervous jokes and giggles, it's
clear the assault was terrifying.

Charlotte said: "I feel violated; it's weird, really. I couldn't help Rose; I
felt so helpless, so useless. "I thought,  'What should I do? Should I hit him
with a bottle? Will that just make him angrier and will he kill me?'"Rose admits
she feels the same about her friend: "When you see it on telly you think, 'Hit
him' but when you're there, you freeze and don't know what to do."

"You think: 'He's going to kill me'", said Charlotte.

The girls had screamed for help, causing a woman cyclist to suddenly stop. The
attacker turned his attention to her, sexually assaulting her in his frenzy,
allowing the girls to flee and get help. "We had to run away from her," said
Rose quietly. "We felt really guilty for running away."

The pair raced 50 metres, screaming hysterically to a man they had spotted.

Charlotte said: "We were yelling, 'That man's just attacked us - now he's
attacking her. Try to help her - now'".

By the time the girls had run all the way home they were sobbing, shaking
wrecks, leaving Charlotte's mother to try to work out what had happened before
calling the police, who arrived within seconds.  Both girls bravely decided to
give video statements that same night, to ensure their freshness and detail.

Charlotte said: "I don't want one man stopping the rest of my life. I want to
get on with it."

Both agree the attacker needs to be caught and urge the public to come forward
with any information.

Rose asks simply: "Imagine if it was you - would you want him caught?"

Contact police on 08452 777444 or call Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555111
quoting reference number EC/08/4448.

A 26 year-old Plymouth man has been arrested in connection with the attack and
bailed until June 9.

ceve@theplymouthherald.co.uk

                  The Northern Echo (Newsquest Regional Press)

                               May 9, 2008 Friday

Benefit cheat claimed loved ones died in terror attack

SECTION: REGIONAL

LENGTH: 347 words


A BENEFIT cheat who said his loved ones had died in the 7/7 terrorist attacks in
London has been jailed.

Lieing Afzal Ramzan was told by a judge "you don't know the truth from fiction"
after he claimed his brother-in-law and nephew had perished in the terrorist
atrocity.

The serial crook was already legally claiming job seekers allowance in the name
of his jailed brother.

But he went on to make two bogus applications for Emergency Community Care
Grants.

The 27-year-old claimed in one of those applications he needed to flee as his
abusive father was about to return from Pakistan.

And in the other he used the terrorist attacks on the capital as part of the
scam, Newcastle Crown Court heard.

"You can make application for an award to cover emergency situations," said
Susan Hirst, prosecuting.

"The first he submitted was a claim for a grant to cover removal costs for his
sister in Leeds, falsely stating she had lost her husband and son in the London
bombings."

Ramzan, living in Rectory Road, Bensham, Gateshead, when he concocted the con,
was finally rumbled when brother Yasin made a legitimate benefit inquiry shortly
before his prison release in June, 2006.

"Routine checks carried out revealed job seekers allowance was already being
paid to someone using his name and had been since February 2005," Miss Hirst
told the court.

Ramzan, who had pocketed £2,387 from the fiddle, admitted 15 charges of making
false statements to get benefit.

He already has a string of convictions for dishonesty, including deceptions and
perverting justice.

Jailing him for 15 months, Judge Beatrice Bolton said only custody could be
justified and hit out at his cruel confidence trick. "You are an inveterate
liar," she told Ramzan.

"You don't know truth from fiction.

"This is a case where you deliberately went out to defraud the department by
pretending to be your brother."

Judge Bolton said the emergency grant applications had been sent using "very
unpleasant and unpalatable" lies.

She told Ramzan "This has got to stop and the time has come when you must
receive an immediate custodial sentence."

Text of report in English by Turkish news agency Anatolia

Ankara, 14 May: Turkey condemned the terrorist attacks which hit Jaipur, capital

                                 Irish Examiner

                             May 14, 2008 Wednesday

Seven bombs kill 60 in India 'terror attack'

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 393 words


The bombs, many of them strapped to bicycles, exploded within minutes of each
other in Jaipur's pink walled city, a magnet for foreign tourists.

It was the deadliest bomb attack in India in nearly two years. About 150 people
were wounded and local television stations broadcast appeals for blood
donations.

Police officers said no group had admitted responsibility for the blasts.

Television channels quoted government and intelligence officials as blaming
Pakistani or Bangladeshi Islamist militant groups.

"According to the information I have received, 60 people have died and 150 have
been injured," Rajasthan's Chief Minister Vasundhara Raje was quoted by the
Press Trust of India as saying.

"At around 7.30pm there was a big noise and suddenly I found people in a pool of
blood," said Govind Sharma, a priest at a Hindu temple, through tears.

"I've lost my father in the bomb blast."

Officials said the apparent motive for the bombs was to undermine a peace
process between India and Pakistan or foment communal violence in India.

Indian Foreign Minister Pranab Mukherjee is due to visit Islamabad in little
more than a week to review the four-year-old peace process, his first since a
new, civilian government took over in Pakistan.

Prime Minister Manmohan Singh appealed for calm. The British and US governments
said there could be no justification for killing innocent people.

At the main government hospital in Jaipur, more than 100 people crowded around
the doors of the emergency ward, many screaming for information about their
relatives. Police officers at the doors yelled for people to donate blood.

Police and state government officials say some or all of the bombs were left on
bicycles and detonated using timers. An eighth bomb was defused by police.

Officials said they were not aware of any foreigners being killed.

Two bombs were planted near Hindu temples, where large crowds gather every
Tuesday in honour of the monkey god Hanuman.

"It was obviously a terror attack," AS Gill, Director- General of Police in the
state of Rajasthan, told reporters close to the scene of one of the blasts.

The blasts come just a few days after fresh firing along the border between
India and Pakistan in disputed Kashmir. India said Islamist militants had been
trying to sneak in.

Alerts were issued in the Indian capital New Delhi and the financial capital of
Mumbai.

"Easily" accessible chemicals expose South Africa to terror attacks in 2010

LENGTH: 218 words


Text of report by South African newspaper Business Day website on 14 May

[Report by Wilson Johwa, Political Correspondent: "Chemical Attack 'Threat to
2010'"]

EASILY available industrial compounds made SA [South Africa] vulnerable to a
chemical and biological weapons attack during the Soccer World Cup.

Philip Coleman, the executive manager of Protechnik, a subsidiary of the
state-owned arms manufacturer Armscor, said chemical substances from the Cold
War were no longer a major threat. Many had been destroyed since the adoption of
the chemical weapons convention almost 10 years ago.

"Where we see a greater threat is from toxic industrial chemicals," Coleman said
yesterday. These substances, such as chlorine, were easier to get hold of and
were already widely transported in SA.

This is something a terrorist would find far more attractive than dealing with
chemical war agents in a clandestine laboratory, he said. Given better
technology, the gap between chemical and biological weapons was narrowing.

However, the military, with help from Protechnik, a specialised chemicals
company, was working at developing contingency plans that included acquiring
detection equipment to be used to protect soccer stadiums and fan parks, said
Coleman.

Source: Business Day website, Johannesburg, in English 14 May 08

                  UK Newsquest Regional Press - This is Gwent

                             May 15, 2008 Thursday

Boy in dog attack terror

BYLINE: Charles Booth

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 250 words

DATELINE: Campaign Series


A TEN-YEAR-OLD boy was bitten by a dog while he was riding on his bike and now
needs crutches to walk until the wound heals.

Danny Morgan from Heol Edward Lewis, Gelligaer was happily riding his bike and
the Alsatian cross jumped up and bit his leg.

The police were informed of the situation and the dog was destroyed after it was
identified.

Danny's mum Teresa said: "Danny is scared of other dogs now and is weary of
going out because of what happened to him.

"He is a very active boy and is a great drummer. He can't play now because of
his injuries and won't be able to go to his lessons."

Now Danny has had to take medicine to heal the gash and wear a bandage to stop
it getting infected.

He said: "I was riding along and felt the dog bite me but I did not realise it
was that bad until I rode off.

"I got to the play area where we go and had to lie down because of the pain."

His mum said: "Some of Danny's friends mums came out to help him and saw what
had happened to him so they bandaged his leg up."

Teresa Morgan had warned the authorities about this particular dog and was
concerned that is could attack someone.

She said: "Our dogs are kept behind a gate and can't get out. I am sorry that
the dog, which attacked Danny had to be put down.

"Danny is used to his own pet dogs but now he is very wary of dogs he doesn't
know. The bite will heal but the psychological scars will not go so easily. I
think my children should be able to play outside without having to worry about
getting bitten."

                          The Daily Telegraph (LONDON)

                              May 16, 2008 Friday

Bush is accused of attacking Obama over 'terrorist talks'

BYLINE: Alex Spillius in Washington and Carolynne Wheeler

SECTION: NEWS; International; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 395 words


PRESIDENT George W Bush stepped into a political row yesterday when he denounced
those who would talk to

"terrorists and radicals'' - a remark seen as an attack on Senator Barack Obama,
the Democratic presidential hopeful.

Addressing Israel's parliament, the Knesset, on the 60th anniversary of the
country's foundation, the president said: "Some seem to believe that we should
negotiate with the terrorists and radicals, as if some ingenious argument will
persuade them they have been wrong all along.

"We have heard this foolish delusion before. As Nazi tanks crossed into Poland
in 1939, an American senator declared, 'Lord, if I could only have talked to
Hitler, all this might have been avoided.' We have an obligation to call this
what it is - the false comfort of appeasement, which has been repeatedly
discredited by history.''

Although Mr Bush made no mention of Mr Obama, the senator interpreted the speech
as a "political attack'' on himself and issued a swift response.

"George Bush knows that I have never supported engagement with terrorists, and
the president's extraordinary politicisation of foreign policy and the politics
of fear do nothing to secure the American people or our stalwart ally, Israel,''
he said in a statement.

Mr Obama has urged unconditional talks with Iran and said he would be willing to
meet the leaders of Cuba and North Korea, two countries that America considers
rogue states.

The White House denied that the president's words were directed at the senator.
An official said Mr Bush had made similar comments before and there were several
people, notably ex-President Jimmy Carter, who recently met Hamas leaders, who
he could have had in mind.

In his speech, Mr Bush pledged America's eternal support for Israel.

"Some people suggest that if the United States would just break ties with
Israel, all our problems in the Middle East would go away. This is a tired
argument that buys into the propaganda of our enemies, and America rejects it
utterly,'' he said.

"Israel's population may be just over seven million. But when you confront
terror and evil, you are 307 million strong, because America stands with you.''

Mr Bush condemned Iran's nuclear ambitions and promised that al-Qa'eda,
Hizbollah and Hamas would be defeated "as Muslims across the region recognise
the emptiness of the terrorists' vision and the injustice of their cause''.

America had equipped this network with various terrorist items such as chemical
substances, explosives, and cyanide - a dangerous and poisonous substance for
the production of the cyanide gas - and had directly led and guided it inside
the Iranian territories. In one of its plans, this network carried out the
explosion in the Seyyed al-Shohada of Shiraz. In this brutal crime, a number of
innocent people of our country were martyred and injured.

We inform our dear fellow countrymen that their hardworking offspring in the
Ministry of Intelligence, by finding the first clues about this terrorist group
and with the cooperation of the Police force, in a complicated and extensive
intelligence operation, chased the members of the group. While this group
according to a devised plan in America intended, in the continuation of its
terrorist acts, to carry out some other terrorist attacks, such as the explosion
in the Tehran book fair and some other academic, scientific and religious
centres as well as targeting people in some crowded places in various cities of
the country, the anonymous soldiers of the Lord of the Age [twelfth Shi'i imam],
may God hasten his reappearance, by carrying out an accurate intelligence
operation on 18 Ordibehesht 1387 [7 May 2008] arrested the members of this
terrorist network in Fars, Khuzestan, Gilan, West Azarbayjan and Tehran
provinces.

During the operations, a member of this grouplet was killed. The rest of its
members are under arrest. The information gained during the confessions of the
suspects indicates that the American officers had set the main objective of this
obliterated group to create intimidation and terror among people in various
Iranian cities.

The terrorist attacks against Russian consulate in Gilan and the explosion in
the oil pipelines in the southern part of Iran were among other sabotage targets
of this group. Therefore, the American centres had provided scuba-diving
training courses for the members of this network in order for them to identify
the location of the underwater oil pipes in the Persian Gulf.

The equipment which have been seized from this group are as follows: Maps,
films, pictures and charts of important and sensitive centres of various cities
targeted for terrorist operations; a large number of weapons and detonators, a
considerable amount of chemicals with high explosive power, eight kilograms of
cyanide capable of being converted into destructive and fatal gas, and a number
of anti-chemical gas masks.

The Ministry of Intelligence is proud to announce that the anonymous soldiers of
the Lord of the Age, may God hasten his reappearance, while offsetting the
objectives of this terrorist group have gathered important information about the
body organizing this network inside America. In this respect, there are credible
documents available to the Ministry of Intelligence which link this network to
certain centres in the United States and the Zionist regime, and their relation
and cooperation with anti-Iranian terrorist groups. Complementary investigations
on the group - which officially holds anti-religious stances - is still
continuing, the result of which will be reported to the respectable people of
Iran in the coming days.

It is natural that parallel to the progress in the investigations and as the
information become more complete, international legal and diplomatic measures
will also be taken by the authorized bodies in the country against America and
Britain.

[Sign off] Ministry of Intelligence of the Islamic Republic of Iran

                              May 20, 2008 Tuesday

India police get letter threatening terror attacks on 23 May

LENGTH: 503 words


Text of report by independent Indian daily The Asian Age website

[By Amita Verma]

Lucknow [in Uttar Pradesh State, northern India], 19 May: After the serial bomb
blasts in Jaipur last week, the Jaish-i-Mohammad has warned of blasts in New
Delhi, Lucknow, Agra and Aligarh on 23 May.

The warning was sent through a letter addressed to the Government Railway Police
[GRP] in Aligarh. A GRP inspector opened the letter on Sunday night [18 May,
local time] and immediately informed senior officials about the contents of the
letter.

The letter, typed in Hindi, warns of "devastating attacks" on important places
and important trains on 23 May. It says that in New Delhi, attacks could be
carried out at Parliament House, Jamia Millia Islamia, the Akshardham temple,
Connaught Place and the Red Fort area; whereas in Lucknow the attacks would be
on the Gomti Express, the sports stadium, temples, the university and at railway
and bus stations.

In Aligarh, the letter warns of attacks at the Aligarh Muslim University,
Mangalatayan, Centre Point and railway and bus stations, as well as the Shatabdi
Express; whereas in Agra the target would be the Taj Mahal and the Red Fort.

The name of the terrorist organization Jaish-i-Mohammad is typed at the end of
the letter.

Though investigations into the origin of the letter have already begun, the
Uttar Pradesh police has started intensive checking of all important trains and
buses. Public announcements are being made at railway and bus stations, asking
passengers to remain vigilant and report any unattended baggage. They are also
being asked to cooperate with police personnel during search operations.

Police personnel in plain clothes and bomb disposal squads have also been
deployed at all vital installations.

"This is a holiday season and there is great rush in trains and buses. The
letter could be fake, but we are not taking any chances and are taking maximum
care to avert the possibility of an attack," said a senior GRP official.

Top police officials were tight-lipped on the letter but said that
investigations were on in the right direction.

In a related development, Muslims clerics have decided that after Friday prayers
all imams in Uttar Pradesh will make an announcement asking Muslims not to
provide any help, support or shelter to persons involved in terrorist
activities.

"We are sending directives in this regard to all imams in urban and rural areas,
asking them to plead with community members on this issue. Muslims living in the
rural interior are mostly illiterate and are easily trapped by terrorist groups.
We will be quoting from the Holy Quran that it is against Islam to target the
innocent," said Maulana Khalid Rashid Firangi Mahali, Naib Imam of Idgah and
convener of the "Movement Against Terrorism."

It may be recalled that the Darul-Uloom in Deoband had issued a fatwa against
terrorism in February this year, decrying those who indulge in mindless violence
in the name of "jihad".

                                Birmingham Post

                            May 21, 2008, Wednesday
                                  1ST Edition

The Bigger Picture: Birmingham's tall story;
Terrorist attacks have not curbed Birmingham's love affair with tall buildings.

BYLINE: Paul Dale reports

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 785 words


British Land Tower Corner of Colmore Row and Newhall Street Yet to get planning
permission 35-storeys 440ft

Landmark office development proposed to replace the NatWest Tower.

A pounds 160 million scheme to include high quality office space, retail and a
rooftop restaurant.

The sensitive location, on the Birmingham Ridge at the highest point of the city
centre and in the Colmore Row Conservation Area, has already provoked strong
opinions.

Birmingham Civic society says it is 90 per cent happy with the height and
design, but the Birmingham Victorian Society says the proposal is an
"incongruous leviathan "which will detract from the splendour of the Council
House and St Philip's Cathedral.

The structure will be 12 storeys higher than the existing NatWest Tower, making
it by far the tallest building in this part of the city centre. British Land is
promising the new tower will be a shining example of sustainability, with a
green roof to provide a habitat for protected bird species.

Ballymore Snow Hill Snow Hill Queensway Work about to begin 43 storeys 450ft

Described as the tallest purely residential block in Birmingham, the new tower
will have 330 apartments and will be linked to a 23-storey five-star hotel and
conference centre.

Both towers will open out onto one of five new public squares, forming
pedestrian links with St Chad's Cathedral, the Jewellery Quarter and the Gun
Quarter. Ballymore's pounds 400 million Snow Hill scheme, on a site which has
lain vacant for 30 years, also includes two large office blocks which are
already under construction.

V Building Suffolk Street Queensway Work may begin later this year 50 storeys
500ft

Part of the Arena Central development and designed by world-renowned architect
Eric Khune, the V Building will be the tallest habitable structure in
Birmingham.

Developers Dandara wowed city planners when they unveiled proposals for a pounds
150 million soaring glass-fronted structure that will include 600 residential
apartments, finedining restaurants, a sky bar and observatory.

Residents will be able to enjoy a library, a spa and a private club room.

Close to the Mailbox and Brindleyplace, and a short walk from the Bullring, the
V Building will "catapult Birmingham into a city of real international kudos,
such as Chicago or Barcelona", according to Dandara managing director Martin
Clancy. The ground floors will be public areas with a mix of bars, cafes and
shops.

Beetham Tower Holloway Circus Opened 2005 40 storeys 400ft

Postmodern shimmering glass structure forming a bold new gateway to the city
centre, Beetham Tower houses an SAS Radisson hotel and 150 apartments as well as
six fivebedroom luxury apartments with private balconies.

Originally planned as 44 storeys with additional spires shooting from the roof,
the project had to be scaled down following objections from the Civil Aviation
Authority.

Broad Street Tower Broad Street No date for work to begin 38 storeys 400ft
Developers Richardson Cordwell won planning permission a year ago for this
pounds 100 million scheme.

It will be on the south side of Broad Street opposite Sheepcote Street and the
Brasshouse pub.

The completed structure is likely to contain a 192-bedroom hotel, 342 apartment
and 339 parking spaces.

New Street Towers New Street Station Completed by 2013 30 storeys 280ft Proposed
entrance to the refurbished New Street Station, the two towers will be built at
the junction of Hill Street and Stephenson Street.

One of the towers will be largely residential and the other commercial.

British Telecom Tower Lionel Street Opened in 1969 35 floors 500ft The tallest
building in Birmingham and one of the city's best known landmarks.

Used for long distance communications, the tower supports are built over the
Birmingham and Fazeley Canal.

Alpha Tower Suffolk Street Queensway Opened 1974 28 storeys 328ft Prominent
Birmingham landmark, used largely as council offices.

Based on the Pirelli Building in Milan by architect Richard Seiffert.

Generally regarded as one of the more tasteful of Birmingham's post-war office
developments.

VTP200 Eastside Under discussion 656ft

Proposal for a vertical theme park which will, if it is built, be by far
Birmingham's tallest building.

The pounds 95 million structure would include a range of thrilling rides as well
as an observation deck, hotel, bars and restaurants.

                             The Gloucester Citizen

                             May 22, 2008 Thursday

Woman tells of her alley attack terror

BYLINE:  Ric Sumner

SECTION: Pg. 6

LENGTH: 316 words


A Woman has spoken of her terrifying attack in a Cheltenham alley.

The victim, who does not want to be named, was phoning her husband from outside
a club when the attacker pounced.

She was hit over the head from behind and dragged face-down into an alley.

Her husband had to listen on the other end of the phone as she screamed for help
and fought to break free.

Her attacker ran off.

The woman, in her 40s, is covered in cuts and bruises and unable to sleep or
walk.

But she is determined to warn other women to be on their guard.

She said: "I want this man caught because he is dangerous.

"He planned everything and it could have been anyone.

"Mentally I'm fine - it will take more than someone like that to knock me back -
but I don't want a young girl to be his next victim.

"Afterwards I had a few tears and wanted to stay in bed under the blanket, but
that's not me."

The attack happened near the Thirteen Degrees club in St George's Road at 1.50am
on Sunday.

The woman was celebrating her niece's birthday with family and friends when she
left the club to call her husband.

In her struggle with the assailant, she got a glimpse of his face before he fled
towards Bayshill Road.

The victim went back to the scene with her husband the next day and found her
earrings and watch in the alley.

At least one couple saw the attack and ran to help, and the woman hopes they
will step forward and give statements to the police.

Her husband said the moment he heard his wife scream and the phone go dead was
"hellish".

He said: "I jumped in the car and didn't stop for a single red light - it was
frightening and I hope I never go through it again."

The attacker is described as about 5ft 10in tall, of medium build, with short,
dark, wavy hair, dark trousers and a distinctive black and white
vertically-striped leather jacket.

Anyone with information should call police on 0845 090 1234, or Crimestoppers
anonymously.

                                   The Mirror

                             May 22, 2008 Thursday
                                 Ulster Edition

I FEARED HE WAS BOMB;
GUARD'S TERROR AT STONE ATTACK

BYLINE: BY MIRROR REPORTER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 389 words


THE hero security guard who stopped Michael Stone from getting into Stormont
yesterday said she feared he was a "human bomb".

Giving evidence at Belfast Crown Court, Susan Porter said she could feel
"something hard" around his stomach, adding that at the time, "I thought he was
a human bomb".

After being searched, it emerged that he was wearing a bullet-proof jacket when
he tried to storm Parliament Buildings in November 2006.

Stone, 53, of no fixed address, denies attempting to murder Sinn Fein's Gerry
Adams and Martin McGuinness, as well as 12 other charges including possessing
nail and pipe bombs with intent and three knives.

His defence case is that the incident was not an attack but part of an artistic
performance. Ms Porter told the court when she first saw Stone approaching, she
thought he was "frail" and went to give him a hand.

Asked if Stone said anything to her, Ms Porter told prosecuting QC Charles
Adair: "Yes he said 'love', it was quite timid at first, 'love' and then he
pulled a gun and held it to my face."

She said Stone told her to move back "or he would shoot me". Ms Porter "leapt
forwards towards the gun" and began to struggle with Stone.

Assisted by colleague Peter Lachanudis, the gun was eventually wrestled from
Stone and Ms Porter said she realised it was an imitation firearm.

She told Mr Adair that she asked Stone what was in the bag only to be told there
was "everything, grenades - it's going to go up, get out of here".

Defence QC Arthur Harvey told Ms Porter his instructions from Stone were that
throughout the incident, "you behaved impeccably" towards Stone, and apart from
a few "modest inaccuracies" because of the pressure of the situation, her
evidence was correct.

Ms Porter agreed with Mr Harvey's suggestion that Stone treated the security
staff holding him in a "polite manner" but that when he spotted the press and
media filiming him, "he shouted obscenities, sometimes about Sinn Fein and
Paisley, seeking to draw the attention of the press".

Mr Lachanudis also told the court that initially he believed Stone was a
"suicide bomber".

Mr Harvey suggested to Mr Lachanudis that Stone was not a suicide bomber and
that no tubes were strapped to his chest but it was "pure imagination at play".

But the guard was firm in his belief that they were on his chest.

The trial continues tomorrow.

                                   Daily Star

                              May 23, 2008 Friday

CAFE BOMBER IS ISL AMIC CONVERT;
Gentle giant held over 'terror attack'

BYLINE: by GARY NICKS and ANTHONY WALTON

SECTION: NEWS; 7

LENGTH: 415 words


ANTI-TERROR police were last night probing a botched suspected suicide bombing -
after an explosion in a restaurant toilet.

A Muslim convert with a history of mental illness was under arrest in hospital.

Senior police sources named him as 22-year-old Nicky Reilly.

He was seriously injured when one of two home-made devices went off in the
toilet in Exeter, Devon.

Police last night took the unusual step of releasing his picture, after Reilly
was earlier captured by a CCTV camera carrying a small black rucksack.

He had adopted the Muslim faith but police said had been "preyed upon and
radicalised" by extremists.

Devon and Cornwall police's Deputy Chief Constable Tony Melville said that
Reilly had been taken advantage of in his "vulnerable" state.

The bomb drama began yesterday lunchtime when terrified onlookers fled at least
one explosion in the toilet of the Giraffe restaurant.

CCTV pictures show Reilly in the street outside the restaurant carrying a small
black rucksack.

Large parts of Exeter city centre were evacuated as a major antiterror operation
swung into action.

Armed police and bomb disposal units swarmed the Princesshay Shopping Centre and
set up a huge security cordon.

Two explosive devices were found in the toilet. Reilly suffered cuts to his eye
and burns to his face.

Last night, his home in Plymouth was being searched by officers.

Neighbours described him as an "easily led" young man who lived for computer
games and his dog.

His nickname is the "Big Friendly Giant" but he changed his name last year
through deed poll to Mohammed Rasheed.

Witness Peter Lacey, who was in the restaurant with his wife, said: "There were
three explosions.

"They sounded more like gunshots than a bomb, like a light bulb exploding. They
came from a locked toilet." Thousands of office and shop workers left for home
when they realised they would not be able to return to work.

Many shoppers were forced to abandon their cars in the main car park inside the
cordon.

Juliette Joffe, director of Giraffe, said: "There was a very small explosion,
nobody was injured except the person who caused the explosion.

"It's now a crime scene and in the hands of the police." Mr Melville confirmed
that reports of other devices at McDonald's, Primark and another shop had proved
groundless.

He said: "We have found no other devices. A forensic examination has begun at
the restaurant." He said that 100 officers were deployed in the city centre and
the cordon will be lifted when public safety had been assured.

Bombscare bike wasnt terror attack

SECTION: Pg. 20

LENGTH: 113 words


A CYCLIST who chained his bike up at an airport was shocked when told he could
be a terrorist. Grampian Police moved in after Alan Craigie, 50, left his bike
at Aberdeen Airport because there are no bike lockers.

But officers removed it over fears it held explosives after similar stunts by
the German Bader-Meinhof gang in the 1970s. Mr Craigie had cycled to the airport
before flying to London.

Two days later, he discovered his bike had been taken away under heightened
security measures.

He said: My bike was not subjected to a controlled explosion, nor was the bomb
squad contacted. This potentially lethal device was kept in the police station.

Grampian Police refused to comment.
