                                  News Shopper

                              May 23, 2008 Friday

Man threatened Bluewater terror attack

BYLINE: Court Reporter

SECTION: DARTFORD AND GRAVESEND NEWS (DARTFORD AND GRAVESHAM NEWS)

LENGTH: 346 words


A 33-YEAR-OLD man has pleaded guilty to threatening to blow up Bluewater
shopping centre - despite not knowing its location.

Saeed Ghafoor, from Southampton, claimed he was plotting to pack three
limousines with gas canisters and detonate them at Britain's largest shopping
centre.

Former English teacher Ghafoor admitted a charge of threatening to destroy or
damage property when he appeared at the Old Bailey today (May 23).

The court heard Ghafoor was serving a 12-month prison sentence for trying to
strangle his sister when he made the threat to prison officers at HMP Haverigg
in Cumbria in February.

Ghafoor asked to speak to the prison liaison officer saying he had "information
about a terrorist threat".

When prison manager Dawn Pugh visited him in his cell, Ghafoor showed her a plan
written in Arabic and English. This detailed how he was planning to carry out
the terror attack.

Prosecutor Piers Arnold said: "He appeared calm, precise and focused.

"He repeated the threat he was going to blow up the Bluewater shopping centre a
number of times.

"Ms Pugh formed the impression he was an odd character, a loner with mental
health issues."

The court also heard that when questioned further, Ghafoor said Bluewater was in
Exeter.

Mr Arnold added: "He was asked why he selected Bluewater, to which he replied it
was the largest shopping centre in England.

"Ghafoor said it was in protest against American and British soldiers who should
all be blown up'.

"Mr Arnold also said the prison officer formed the opinion Ghafoor was capable
of carrying out the threat or was connected with others who were carrying out
the threat."

Ghafoor said he was motivated by something he saw on TV about the shopping
centre.

Mr Arnold added: "This was not a bomb hoax but the Crown says he made the threat
fully intending the recipient to take it seriously.

"'We are not in a position to know if he genuinely intended to carry out the
threat.

"There is no evidence to suggest he had the means or capability to do so."

Mr Justice Calvert-Smith adjourned sentencing until June 30 for background
reports.

                                  Morning Star

                             May 24, 2008 Saturday

World - Havana attacks US over 'terror funding'

BYLINE: Our Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 434 words


Havana challenged Washington on Thursday to launch a full public inquiry into
why US diplomats served as cash couriers between Miami-based "terrorists" and
counter-revolutionaries in Cuba.

Cuban Foreign Minister Felipe Perez Roque (right) urged President George W. Bush
and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice not to keep ignoring evidence that US
Interests Section chief Michael Parmly illegally ferried funds to anti-communist
activist Martha Beatriz Roque, who passed the cash on to other dissidents.

Mr Perez observed that Mr Parmly's acts violated Cuban and US laws, as well as
international agreements, including the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic
Relations that bans diplomats from breaking the laws of the receiving state or
interfering in its internal affairs.

Havana has released a slew of e-mails, letters, videos and audio tapes that
prove that Mr Parmly was involved in at least three cash deliveries to
dissidents, which were described by the government as "counter-revolutionary or
mercenary small groups" in the service of countries like the US.

Ms Roque received monthly payments of at least $1,500 (£750) from Fundacion
Rescate Juridica, a Miami anti-communist group headed by Santiago Alvarez, a
Cuban-US businessman once convicted in the US of conspiring to collect weapons
to overthrow Cuba's socialist government.

Another prominent dissident, Laura Pollan, has acknowledged receiving at least
$2,400 (£1,200) from Fundacion Rescate Juridica.

She says that she split the money among several members of the Ladies in White,
a group that demands freedom for Cuban "political prisoners."

The US Interests Section in Cuba "encourages, organises, funds and follows in
detail" the dissidents' activities "to destabilise the internal situation," Mr
Perez pointed out.

"We hope that Bush's government takes necessary measures to rectify the conduct
of its diplomats in Cuba," he said, adding:

"We expect a thorough investigation from the US authorities and the results
should be made public."

Mr Perez described it as "cynical" of the US government to limit family
remittances from the US, while at the same time playing the role of intermediary
for "terrorists" who send money to Cuba to support subversive actions by
mercenaries.

He went on to ask: "What would happen if Martha Beatriz Roque lived in the US
and was accused of receiving money from terrorists through Cuban diplomats to
act against the US?"

The State Department has denied wrongdoing, saying that it has long provided
humanitarian aid to opposition leaders in Cuba and it does not discourage
private US organisations from doing so.

                                The Western Mail

                             May 24, 2008, Saturday
                                 First Edition

'Suicide bomb plan' was intended to cause maximum destruction;
Terrified shoppers feared second terror attack as police arrest two

BYLINE: Jack Doyle

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 656 words


THE failed suicide bomb set off in a crowded cafe would have released a giant
fireball had it ignited, police sources said yesterday.

The device, made from sodium hydroxide and paraffin, was packed with nails and
designed to detonate when shaken.

Those who built the bomb, and two others found nearby, may have thought the
blast would have been powerful enough to blow out the front of the building,
according to those close to the investigation.

The revelations came as armed police seized two men in connection with the
attempted attack in a shopping mall in Exeter.

Terrified shoppers feared they were caught up in a second terrorist attack as
they saw armed police point their weapons "point blank" at two "dark-skinned"
men in a cafe in Plymouth, home of bomb suspect Nicky Reilly.

Reilly emerged from the Giraffe cafe on Thursday "covered in blood" but not
seriously hurt when the bomb failed to go off.

The 22-year-old received a text message of encouragement before WRECKED: Firemen
examine the bus that crashed into a pillar under a highway overpass in France's
Loire Valley yesterday he left on the failed mission, sources revealed. Reilly
carried the volatile explosive on the X38 bus from Plymouth with more than 50
passengers on board, arriving just after midday.

Investigators suspect the place where Reilly tried to set off the bomb, a
backroom toilet, was chosen to maximise the impact of the device and two others
found nearby.

Police believe extremists took advantage of Reilly's low IQ and history of
mental illness to radicalise him.

The Muslim convert, who recently changed his name to Mohammed Rasheed, had a
screen saver of the Twin Towers in flames from the 9/11 attacks on his home
computer, neighbours said.

Sources said counter-terrorist police were aware of Reilly and suspected he had
forged loose links to known Islamic extremists in south-west England.

The men may have met in an internet cafe close to the council flat he shared
with his mother.

Channel 4 News reported MI5 was also aware of Reilly but he was not the subject
of a live investigation.

Devon and Cornwall Police deputy chief constable Tony Melville said: "We believe
that, despite his weak and vulnerable state, he was preyed upon, radicalised and
taken advantage of."

At 3.30pmyesterday, at least 10 armed officers raided the Bagatelle Cafe in
Plymouth.

Eyewitness Paul Marples, who works in the HSBC bank nearby, said shoppers ran
into the branch fearing an explosion.

"Everyone thought it was a nail bomb like yesterday in Exeter," he said.

Rebecca Pope, 25, heard shouting and saw armed police pointing their gun at the
men, who were sitting at a table outside the cafe with a child in a pushchair.

She said both were searched, put into paper suits and placed in unmarked cars,
while the pushchair was taken away by a policewoman.

"Everyone was screaming," she said.

Police yesterday continued to search the cafe and the first-floor flat on King
Street which he shared with his mother, Kim and brother Elliott, nine. They left
the flat last night and have not returned.

Reilly's 20-year-oldbrother, Luke, is serving a six-year jail term in Portland
Prison for violence.

He saw the incident on TV.

Neighbour Ali Turner, 17, said Reilly was a reclusive loner who spent most of
his time online.

"He did not talk tomany people.

He was a bit of are cluse, he did not have many friends locally," he said. "If
you get brainwashed you get brainwashed. I do think that is what happened to
him."

Neighbour Scott Allen, 19, said Reilly was picked on because he was vulnerable.

"He had always been a follower and had always wanted friends."

Muslim leaders distanced themselves from the attack. Syed Rahman, chairman of
the local Islamic Centre, said : "Certainly no one who attends our mosque has
anything to do with extremism."

Devonand Cornwall Police said one man was arrested in the Plymouth raid. A
second was being questioned but, yesterday evening, had not been arrested.

                             The Observer (London)

                                  May 25, 2008

World: How America hailed cricket novel as a 9/11 masterpiece: An Irish-born
author of Turkish descent has used that most English of games as a metaphor for
the al-Qaeda terror attack, writes Peter Beaumont

BYLINE: Peter Beaumont

SECTION: OBSERVER FOREIGN PAGES; Pg. 40

LENGTH: 1152 words


IT IS A SUBJECT that has engaged some of the biggest names in international
letters: Don DeLillo in Falling Man , Ian McEwan in Saturday and Jonathan Safran
Foer in Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close

Each attempted to explain in imaginary terms that great reordering of Western
life that happened on 9/11, when New York's Twin Towers were destroyed by
al-Qaeda terrorists.

But it is the unlikely figure of a 44-year-old Irish-born sports enthusiast of
Turkish descent, raised in the Netherlands and educated in the UK, who is now
being hailed by some of America's most influential literary critics for having
produced a masterpiece on the subject.

Perhaps even more surprisingly, the metaphor that Joseph O'Neill has chosen for
his novel, set in post-9/11 New York, is that most un-American of pastimes -
cricket.

O'Neill's Netherland , published this month - the name a pun on the main
character's Dutch nationality - has been described as the 'wittiest, angriest,
most exacting and most desolate work of fiction we've yet had about life in New
York and London after the World Trade Centre fell'.

Those paeans of praise were delivered by Dwight Garner in the New York Times
Book Review , which featured the book on the cover under the heading 'The
Ashes'.

But it is the review in New Yorker magazine by James Wood - described as the
'best literary critic of his generation' - that has excited most curiosity about
O'Neill, who had written two well-received novels and a work of history, but had
remained far outside the ranks of the DeLillos and McEwans in terms of
recognition and earning potential.

In the current issue of the New Yorker , Wood ranks O'Neill's efforts alongside
a dizzying array of the greatest novelists: Gogol and Salman Rushdie, Saul
Bellow, VS Naipaul and F Scott Fitzgerald.

It is an unexpected triumph for a novelist and keen sportsman who took the names
of many of his friends - including this newspaper's sports journal ists Oliver
Owen and Will Buckley - to supply sly names for characters in his first novel.

An accomplished club cricketer who played for Den Haag in Holland and currently
turns out for a New York side, it is, however, O'Neill's reflections on the
texture and intimacies of the world post-9/11 - a peculiarly American cultural
moment despite its global resonance - that has attracted the admiration of the
critics.

O'Neill himself said yesterday that he was 'flabbergasted, amazed and shocked'
by the response to the book so far. 'When I told publishers that I was writing a
novel about cricket in New York people just shook their heads and walked away.
There was not so much a bidding war for it as a bidding peace. Only one
publisher was interested.'

The result of seven years of effort, the inspiration was driven by a series of
chance events - an encounter with a Pakistani seeking to build a cricket stadium
in New York, 9/11 itself and O'Neill's own involvement in playing cricket in New
York. The two ideas merged following 9/11.

'I was always aware of the metaphorical resonance,' he said. 'After the attack
on the Twin Towers I could not ignore what was happening in New York.'

The relationship between Netherland's two central characters - man and wife -
taps into the emotional rupture identified by Psychology Today magazine in the
aftermath of the attacks as a generalised anxiety that afflicted an entire
nation. 'There was a feeling of disorientation,' says O'Neill, ' that turned
into a sense that that feeling of threat was being exacerbated and manipulated
by the Bush administration.'

For Garner it was O'Neill's description of New York after the towers fell that
rang powerfully true. 'O'Neill writes beautifully,' he commented in his review,
'about what it sometimes felt like in the months after 9/11, when you couldn't
attend a dinner party unless you were intellectually armed for hours of bitter
debate: "For those under the age of 45 it seemed that world events had finally
contrived a meaningful test of their capacity for conscientious political
thought. Many of my acquaintances, I realised, had passed the last decade or two
in a state of intellectual and psychic yearning for such a moment - or, if they
hadn't, were able to quickly assemble an expert arguer's arsenal of thrusts and
statistics and ripostes and gambits and examples and salient facts and
rhetorical manoeuvres. I, however, was almost completely caught out." '

Commenting on his enthusiasm for Netherland yesterday Wood maintained his
enthusiasm, suggesting that the book deserved to be on the Booker Prize
shortlist at the very least. 'At his best he has the interest in the world,' he
said yesterday, 'and in the hubbub of American life of a writer like Saul
Bellow, combined with the elegant, restrained but lyrical prose (and humour) of
someone like Alan Hollinghurst.

'More than that, I like the way that what seems a very English eye (for all that
O'Neill is Irish and his narrator Dutch) is gazing on contemporary Manhattan,
and seeking out these seemingly marginal lives - the dark-skinned colonials who
live in the outer boroughs (Indians, Pakistanis, Trinidadians, Sri Lankans), and
doing this with a mixture of fascination and slight bemusement.'

But it is O'Neill's use of cricket to tackle post-9/11 Manhattan that has struck
Wood most forcefully as a metaphor for a series of important ideas.

'Above all,' he adds, 'the way he uses cricket to bind his novel together, and
to generate meaning in a post-colonial age, is wonderful. What his novel proves,
of course, is that "post-colonial", that academic term, is a terrible misnomer:
there is nothing "post" about these lives; these immigrants are both colonials
and colonists, and he uses the Dutchness - and whiteness - of his narrator to
comment on this.

'And all this is, on the one hand, done with a very light touch and on the other
hand is deeply ambitious: the book clearly has The Great Gatsby in its sights.
O'Neill should pack his dinner jacket for October. . . and the Booker.'

And if O'Neill's book proves to be the critical and artistic success that Wood
is predicting, it will have answered the question posed by the online journal
Salon , which has been troubling critics since the first batch of 9/11 novels
appeared in 2005.

Then Salon asked: 'What took so long? Has it really been long enough? Can
fiction redress the wounds of that day? Are we ready to even try? Is it even
possible to write a novel about 9/11 that is actually good?'

According to Wood, the answer is finally an emphatic yes in what he describes as
one of the 'most resounding post-colonial books I have ever read'. It is
fuelled, Wood argues, by the idea of cricket itself: a game whose
'un-Americanness' becomes for one of the characters 'an American dream, or
perhaps a dream of America. . . played in New York since the 1770s'.

Or as O'Neill himself has said: 'If George W Bush was interested in cricket,
everything might be different.'

Beijing police rule out "terror attack" over subway operation suspension

LENGTH: 176 words


Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News
Agency)

[Xinhua: "3rd Ld: Beijing Subway Suspends Operation for "Signal Failure""]

BEIJING, May 28 (Xinhua) - A Beijing subway line, the No 2 Line, suspended
operation twice unexpectedly in rush hour Wednesday afternoon because of a
signal failure.

Beijing police ruled out rumoured "terror attack" as the reason.

The loop line, which surrounds the downtown areas of Beijing, stopped service at
about 5:45 p.m. and re-opened half an hour later. It suspended operation again
five minutes later and re-opened at about 6:28 p.m.

Some passengers suspected that terrorist attack might behind the brief
suspension, which the subway company and local police denied.

"It can't be terror attack, or else, we wouldn't have resumed the train service
so soon," a man at the duty office of the subway company told Xinhua on the
phone.

He said that signal failure near the Xizhimen stop was to blame for the
unexpected suspension.

Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1121 gmt 28 May 08

School terror as kids watch attack;
 Man batters girl School terror as kids watch attack

BYLINE: Marie Sharp

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 277 words


TERRIFIED schoolchildren watched in horror as a thug brutally beat a young girl
in front of them outside a playground.

Pupils from the primary school in Leith ran to alert teachers after the violent
at tack on the youngster - thought to be aged just 10.

The attacker was seen pushing the girl to the ground, punching and repeatedly
kicking her as she lay helpless.

He then dragged the frightened youngster to her feet and walked off with her.

Police today made an urgent appeal for help to tracking down the brute and the
girl after the shocking incident.

A Lothian and Borders force spokeswoman urged anyone with information to come
forward.

She said: "A number of pupils were concerned and upset by what happened.

"We are appealing for anyone else who may have been in the area at the time and
saw this incident to come forward.

"We are also keen to talk to anyone who might recognise the description of the
people involved."

Children from St Mary's Primary, on Leith Links, saw the horrific beating as
they were out playing during their morning break at a round 10.40am yesterday.

They said the man was walking with the girl when he suddenly struck her.

The victim was just 5ft 4ins, slim with brown curly hair. She was dressed in
black and wore glasses.

Her attacker was in his 40s and 6ft 2ins with black and grey hair.

He was wearing a black jacket with red writing on the pocket, and was carrying
an orange Sainsbury's bag.

It's thought two other children may also have been with the man. The group were
seen getting on a bus in Links Gardens.

Anyone with information is urged to call police on 0131 311 3131 or
Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

TEEN STABBED AND LEFT TO DIE;
 Murder bid probe launched after terror attack TEEN STABBED AND LEFT TO DIE

BYLINE: BRYAN BROUGH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 419 words


A TEENAGER was seriously ill in hospital last night after being repeatedly
stabbed and slashed and then left to die on waste ground.

The 16-year-old victim suffered horrific wounds to his head, back and buttocks
during the frenzied attack.

His skull was also fractured and he has other internal injuries.

Last night, detectives revealed they are treating the brutal assault as
attempted murder.

Sources have said the young victim may have got caught up in a gang fight.

The badly injured teenager was found lying in a pool of blood by police, who had
been alerted through an anonymous phone call.

When paramedics arrived at the scene, which lies off a country road, they had to
carry out emergency treatment as they feared the victim might bleed to death.

One source said: "The youth's injuries were terrible.

He had blood all over his face and other parts of his body. His clothes were
covered in blood.

"I was told he had at least six stab wounds and umpteen slash wounds too. It's
incredible that he survived.

"It seems he was attacked by a gang. The place where he was assaulted has been a
meeting place for gangs from neighbouring communities over the years."

The vicious knifing happened on waste ground near a caravan park off Salterland
Road in Barrhead.

The victim was found lying on the ground and bleeding heavily shortly after
5.30pm on Monday.

At that stage, he was conscious and talking but, a short time later, his
condition deteriorated.

However, he has now improved and, yesterday, he was receiving treatment at
Paisley's Royal Alexandra Hospital, where his condition was described as serious
but stable.

"Police were alerted following an anonymous phone call," added one source.
"Officers from Barrhead were first at the scene but I don't know how long the
victim had been lying there for.

"The quick response and the urgent treatment carried out by medics may well have
saved his life.

"The wounds to his head looked to be the most serious but, initially, no-one
knew the full extent of his internal injuries. It's thought the teenager comes
from Barrhead."

Last night, police urged anyone who has information about the attempted murder
to come forward.

Detective Sergeant Craig Warren, of Barrhead Police Office, said: "Inquiries are
ongoing to establish the exact circumstances surrounding the incident.

"I urge any witnesses or anyone with information that may assist us to ring my
office on 0141 532 5600 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111, where anonymity can be
maintained."

                                 Sunday Herald

                              June 1, 2008 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

Goldsmith attack on terror plans adds to Brown's woes;
Former attorney general's comments bolster rebel MPs ahead of vote

BYLINE: James Cusick Westminster Editor

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 439 words


GORDON Brown's controversial plans to hold terrorism suspects for 42 days
without charge were attacked last night by the former attorney general, Lord
Goldsmith, who claimed that if the vote is won by the government in the Commons
in a fortnight, the new law will threaten Britain's "fundamental freedoms".

Goldsmith's timing could not be worse for the government. Last week a series of
potential compromises were offered to rebel Labour MPs by the Home Office. Up to
50 MPs have threatened to vote against the 42 day proposal.

The peer, the government's top lawyer until Brown became prime minister last
summer, has made similar criticism before.

His renewed attack, in an article for a Sunday newspaper, will reinforce the
rebels' credentials and remind the government whips that the vote this month is
likely to be a knife-edge decision.

While Lord Goldsmith has criticised the proposals before, his latest comments
are more severe and are specifically timed to influence a crucial Commons vote.

The 50 Labour MPs ready to rebel would wipe out the government's majority, a
defeat Brown and his already eroded parliamentary authority would find difficult
to survive.

Although Goldsmith's attack focuses on the legal principles behind 42 days, his
comments will highlight the hard reality that this is an under-pressure showdown
vote that Brown can illafford to lose.

Both the prime minister and his home secretary, Jacqui Smith, insist police need
more than the current 28day limit to deal with increasingly sophisticated terror
plots.

While Smith, working alongside the Home Office minister Tony McNulty, has spent
weeks trying to buy off rebels with a series of compromises aimed at increasing
parliamentary and judicial supervision of the increased detention period, it is
believed that Brown, at least in public, is unwilling to shift on the issue of
42 days. In private, however, the prime minister and close ministerial aides are
said to be prepared now for a last-minute compromise.

Goldsmith insisted the proposed new law would undermine the very values the
government was trying to protect. "Some supporters of 42 days say we have to
take this step to protect our values and our way of life, which terrorists
threaten to destroy, " he said.

"But we start, ourselves, to destroy these values and the very basis of the free
society which our ancestors fought hard to create if we readily give away
critical liberties, such as the right we all have not to be arbitrarily held
without charge."

He continued by saying that extending the period suspects can be held without
charge is a "very serious incursion on our fundamental freedoms".

                                Burnley Express

                                  June 2, 2008

Man in terror attack flees to Chinese restaurant

LENGTH: 464 words


A YOB who caused trouble at a house and then threatened witnesses has been
spared jail - after a judge said he was giving him a "last chance to grow up."

Burnley Crown Court heard how apprentice builder Matthew Dale had broken a
window at the property, barged in the door and took part in violence with
others. He threw a plant pot and a man there was so terrified he escaped to a
nearby Chinese restaurant but Dale followed him and lobbed a brick into the
premises.

While on bail, Dale came across two women witnesses when he was with others. He
encouraged the gang by shouting and threatened one of the victims, saying she
would die, in a bid to stop her giving evidence.

Dale (20), of Manor Street, Nelson, had earlier admitted affray and damage and
had been convicted by a jury of witness intimidation.

Sentencing, Judge Andrew Woolman told him: "In some ways, you thought you were
invincible and could do what you liked. You were no doubt drunk and behaved, as
your counsel has quite rightly said, in a yobbish way."

The judge said the defendant did not have bad record. He obviously had a drink
problem, but on the plus side had a job and was perhaps beginning to see the
error of his ways.

He told him: "You couldn't complain if I locked you up immediately. I had
intended to do that but have reflected on the matter and am prepared to give you
one last chance to reform."

Dale was given nine months in prison, suspended for a year, with 12 months
supervision, the addressing substance related offending programme and a
two-month curfew between 9 p.m. and 6 a.m.

The court was told the defendant was bailed after the incident at the house in
February last year. On June 29th, he approached a witness on the street, told
her she was going to die and said his sister would attack her.

When the defendant was interviewed by police, he claimed he had been visiting a
friend in the area and come across the two women by chance.

Mr Mark Lamberty (prosecuting) said after the incident the victim was upset and
felt unable to go out into the street.

Mr Tim Storrie (defending) described the offences as "spectacularly yobbish
events." Dale had the insight to acknowledge the offences had their roots in
alcohol consumption.

The barrister said the court would have a picture of a surly young man, who
behaved like a child when he did not get his own way. That was provoked by his
drinking and mixing with the wrong people.

The barrister went on: "He is young and for somebody his age it's very often the
case that 12 months can make a very significant change in their personality and
outlook."

He added Dale had a job, was attending college and his father, who he worked
for, had considered setting up a business in Cornwall to try to separate his son
from the influences he faced in East Lancashire.

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                        June 2, 2008 Monday 4:57 PM BST

TERRORIST ADMITS ATTACKING PRISONER

BYLINE: Kelly Macnamara, PA

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 380 words


A convicted terrorist admitted attacking another prisoner with boiling oil at a
high security prison, a court heard today.

Omar Khyam scalded armed robber Malcolm Cruddas during an attack at Frankland
Prison, Durham, on October 17 last year, Teesside Crown Court heard.

Khyam, 26, pleaded guilty to grievous bodily harm with intent.

Christopher Knox QC, prosecuting, told the court Khyam was already serving a
life sentence with a minimum tariff of 20 years for conspiracy to cause
explosions.

``The Crown takes the view that realistically the public interest is not well
served by going through the issue of what was in the defendant's mind at the
time he attacked a fellow prisoner by pouring boiling oil and water over his
head,'' he told the court.

``He has accepted that his intention was to cause really serious harm to Mr
Cruddas.

``It is self-evident that he did and his motive as far as the Crown is concerned
is not crucial.''

Khyam spoke only to confirm his name and enter his plea.

Wearing a pale blue sweatshirt and with a thick beard, he appeared calm
throughout the proceedings.

He will be sentenced at Teesside Crown Court tomorrow.

Khyam, originally from Crawley, West Sussex, was one of five men jailed for life
in April last year for plotting a series of fertiliser bomb attacks in the south
of England.

At his Old Bailey trial, the court heard the group planned to target London's
Ministry Of Sound nightclub and the Bluewater shopping centre in Kent.

Khyam, who was said to be the terrorist cell's ringleader, has been transferred
to Full Sutton Prison, York, since the attack at Frankland Prison.

Cruddas, 32, from Gateshead suffered burns to his head and upper body and
required hospital treatment.

He was jailed for 12 years in 2001 for conspiring to commit robbery and
possession of a firearm.

Last July al Qaida plotter Eesa Barot (formerly known as Dhiren Barot) spent
five days in hospital after he was scalded in a similar attack at Frankland
Prison.

Proceedings against inmate Gary Moody were later dropped at the request of
Barot.

Also last July, the jail cell of one of the plotters for the failed July 21
attacks, Hussain Osman, was set alight.

At the time Prison Officers Association chairman Colin Moses said more needed to
be done to prevent attacks on offenders.

                                   Irish News

                              June 3, 2008 Tuesday

Terror bomb attack kills six

SECTION: Pg. 22

LENGTH: 354 words


A massive car bomb planted in revenge for Denmark's continued defiance in the
Islamic cartoon row killed at least six people at its Pakistan embassy
yesterday.

It was the worst attack since Danish newspapers printed the caricatures of the
prophet Mohammed two years ago.

Prime minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen called the bombing an attack against
Denmark, but he said they would not be cowed by terrorists.

"Denmark will not alter its policy because of a terror attack. We will not give
in to terrorists. We will maintain the foreign and security policy line we have
been leading."

Earlier this year Danish intelligence officials warned of an aggravated terror
threat against Denmark after local newspapers reprinted a cartoon of Mohammed
wearing a bomb-shaped turban. Islamic law generally opposes any depiction of the
prophet for fear it could lead to idolatry.

The cartoon was one of 12 featuring the prophet - first published in Denmark -
that sparked riots in the Muslim world in 2006. Mobs attacked Danish embassies
in Lebanon, Syria and Iran to protest against publication of the cartoons in
European newspapers.

This year, Muslims staged peaceful protests in Pakistan over the cartoons. In
April, Denmark briefly evacuated staff from its embassies in Algeria and
Afghanistan because of terror threats related to the drawings.

Foreign minister Per Stig Moeller said the bomb killed an embassy cleaner and
injured three other embassy workers, none of them Danes. He said the government
did not know who was behind the blast.

Many in Denmark expressed concern that the attack was a response to the
publication of the cartoons - or the deployment of Danish troops in Afghanistan.

"What has brought Denmark so much to the attention of people's attention in that
part of the world are the Mohammed cartoons," Lars Erslev Andersen, a terrorism
expert at the University of Odense, said.

"But that led to people's attention being drawn to the fact that Denmark has had
soldiers in Iraq and that Denmark is on the front in Afghanistan."

Denmark withdrew its troops from Iraq last year but has more than 600 soldiers
serving in Afghanistan.

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                              June 3, 2008 Tuesday

United Nations: Security Council condemns in strongest terms Islamabad terrorist
attack, stresses need to bring perpetrators of reprehensible act to justice

LENGTH: 532 words


RDATE:03062008

The Security Council this afternoon condemned in the strongest terms today's
terrorist attack outside the Danish embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan, that had
caused numerous deaths, injuries and damage to buildings, including to a
building housing the United Nations Development Programme.

In a statement read by this month's Council President, Zalmay Khalilzad of the
United States, the Council underlined the need to bring perpetrators,
organizers, financiers and sponsors of that "reprehensible act" of terrorism,
and urged all States to cooperate with the Pakistani authorities in that regard.

The Council reaffirmed that terrorism constituted one of the most serious
threats to international peace and security and that any acts of terrorism were
criminal and unjustifiable, regardless of their motivation, wherever, whenever
and by whomsoever committed. It reminded States that any measures they took to
combat terrorism must comply with all their obligations under international law,
in particular international human rights, refugee and humanitarian law.

The meeting started at 3:40 p.m. and adjourned at 3:45 p.m.

Presidential Statement

Presidential statement S/PRST/2008/19 reads as follows:

"The Security Council condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist attack that
occurred outside the Danish Embassy in Islamabad on 2 June 2008, causing
numerous deaths, injuries and damage to nearby buildings, including a building
housing the United Nations Development Programme. It expresses its deep sympathy
and condolences to the victims of this heinous act of terrorism and to their
families, and to the people and Governments of Pakistan and Denmark.

"The Security Council underlines the need to bring perpetrators, organizers,
financiers and sponsors of this reprehensible act of terrorism to justice, and
urges all States, in accordance with their obligations under international law
and resolution 1373 (2001) and consistent with resolution 1624 (2005), to
cooperate actively with the Pakistani authorities in this regard.

"The Security Council reaffirms that terrorism in all its forms and
manifestations constitutes one of the most serious threats to international
peace and security, and that any acts of terrorism are criminal and
unjustifiable, regardless of their motivation, wherever, whenever and by
whomsoever committed.

"The Security Council further reaffirms the need to combat by all means, in
accordance with the Charter of the United Nations, threats to international
peace and security caused by terrorist acts. The Council reminds States that
they must ensure that any measures taken to combat terrorism comply with all
their obligations under international law, in particular international human
rights, refugee and humanitarian law.

"The Security Council reiterates its determination to combat all forms of
terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the Charter of the
United Nations."

                  The Northern Echo (Newsquest Regional Press)

                              June 3, 2008 Tuesday

Terrorist sentenced for boiling oil attack

BYLINE: Neil Hunter

SECTION: REGIONAL

LENGTH: 309 words


BOMB plotter Omar Khyam today denied scalding a fellow inmate to get a transfer
from a high-security North-East jail.

The convicted terrorist scalded armed robber Malcolm Cruddas with a boiling oil
and water at Frankland Prison, Durham.

Khyam, who is serving a life sentence with a minimum 20 years, yesterday
admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent.

The 26-year-old returned to Teesside Crown Court today to be sentenced by Judge
Tony Briggs for the October 17 attack.

Judge Briggs passed an indeterminate sentence for the protection of the public
with a minimum four-year tariff.

The court heard that the attack on Mr Cruddas, 32, from Gateshead, came after
two others at Frankland involving convicted terrorists.

In July last year, inmate Dhiren Barot spent five days in hospital after being
burned in a similar boiling liquid scalding.

His attacker, from Sunderland, had the case dropped when Barot - jailed for life
for a "dirty" bomb plot- refused to co-operate with police.

Also last July, the cell of Hussain Osman, one of the July 21 bomb conspirators,
was set alight.

Khyam's barrister, Sam Robinson, told the court that there was an atmosphere of
"fear and mistrust" among Muslim inmates.

He said Khyam heard of a plot behind bars to cause him harm, and struck first,
but accepted it was "excessive self-defence".

The court heard that Khyam had applied for and been refused a transfer from the
prison, which holds some of the country's most notorious criminals.

Khyam has since been moved to Full Sutton Prison in York and Barot has been
taken back to Bellmarsh Jail in London.

Mr Robinson denied that Khyam carried out the attack on Cruddas to get a
transfer after a judicial review into the refusal failed.

He said Muslim prisoners did feel abandoned, and he is now content at Full
Sutton even though he is still miles away from his family in Sussex.

                             PA Newswire: Scotland

TERROR ATTACK PROTECTION FOR BUILDINGS DEBATED

BYLINE: Hilary Duncanson and Louise Hosie, Scottish Press Association

SECTION: PA Newswire: Scotland

LENGTH: 349 words


Senior police officers and planning chiefs gathered today to work out how to
protect Scotland's buildings against terrorist attacks.

Around 50 architects, developers and designers joined the Association of Chief
Police Officers in Scotland (Acpos) at the Scottish Police College in
Tulliallan.

The event was the first of its kind north of the border and is hoped to be the
start of a series of gatherings aimed at ``designing out crime''.

The initiative was to encourage some of the top people in their field to
consider counter-terrorism measures at the initial stages of building design.

With the help of DVDs and video clips, delegates were asked to consider what
they could do to reduce the risk of a terror attack happening, while still
keeping new developments accessible for members of the public.

Chief Inspector Brian Connel of Acpos said those around the table found it to be
challenging work.

He said: ``I think it's taken people out of their comfort zone and that's a good
thing. What we've learned from the day, we'll take forward.

``All the people that need to work together in the real world were in this
training environment.''

Mr Connel, a crime prevention officer with Strathclyde Police, said such an
event was vital at a time of ``huge'' amounts of regeneration across the
country.

It comes in the wake of last year's attack on Glasgow Airport and the 2005
London Tube bombings.

``Unfortunately it's something we're going to have to deal with for a number of
years, if not generations.'' Mr Connel said.

He said he hoped that the police officers present at today's meeting would go on
to be part of future programmes along similar lines on a more local scale.

The gathering was run in conjunction with the Scottish Business Crime Centre
(SBCC).

Executive director Alan Dobie said: ``Today's event illustrates the important
role architects, developers and planners can play in minimising the effects of
terrorism within Scotland's built environment.

``Like many other aspects of crime, partnership between law enforcement and
business is the key to successfully tackling these challenges.''

LOAD-DATE: June 3, 2008

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                       June 3, 2008 Tuesday 12:46 PM BST

PRISONER ATTACK TERRORIST 'WANTED TO BE AT DIFFERENT JAIL'

BYLINE: Kelly Macnamara, PA

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 826 words


A convicted terrorist denied pouring boiling oil over another prisoner to ensure
a transfer, but blamed an ``atmosphere of fear'' at his high security prison for
the attack, a court heard today.

Omar Khyam was sentenced to four years imprisonment at Teesside Crown Court
today for ``calmly'' scalding armed robber Malcolm Cruddas on October 17 last
year at Frankland Prison, Durham.

The 26-year-old, who yesterday pleaded guilty to grievous bodily harm with
intent, is currently serving a life sentence for his part in plotting a series
of fertiliser bomb attacks in the south of England.

Christopher Knox, prosecuting, told the court today that Khyam had wanted to be
moved from the Durham prison from the moment he arrived.

``He made it clear by himself and his solicitors that he did not want to be at
Frankland Prison, he wanted to be at a different prison,'' he said.

Mr Knox said the attack on Cruddas was unprovoked and caused burns to 15% of his
body and had resulted in permanent scarring.

``The defendant approached him from behind and calmly poured a steaming liquid
over his head which was either oil or a mixture of oil and water,'' he said.

However, Sam Robinson, defending, said Khyam had attacked Cruddas in ``excessive
self defence'', citing other attacks on terrorist inmates at Frankland.

Last July al Qaida plotter Eesa Barot (formerly known as Dhiren Barot) spent
five days in hospital after he was scalded at Frankland Prison.

Proceedings against inmate Gary Moody were later dropped at the request of
Barot.

Also in July 2007, the jail cell of one of the plotters for the failed July 21
attacks, Hussain Osman, was set alight.

Mr Robinson said: ``There was the previous attack on Mr Barot which was of a
similar nature and resulted in similar injuries as those being discussed here
and the arson attack on Mr Osman so those two incidents, regardless of any
actions by the Prison Service, led to an atmosphere of fear and mistrust and a
sense of abandonment which was felt by the Muslim community at Frankland at the
time.''

Khyam, originally from Crawley, West Sussex, was transferred to Full Sutton
Prison, York, after the attack at Frankland Prison.

He was one of five men convicted last year of plotting bomb attacks on London's
Ministry Of Sound nightclub and the Bluewater shopping centre in Kent as well as
electricity supplies.

Mr Robinson said the publicity surrounding Khyam's Old Bailey trial, which ended
in April last year, and his friendship with Barot, made his client feel
threatened at the prison.

He added that Khyam was transferred to Frankland on June 30 last year, the same
day as the failed Glasgow Airport car bomb attack.

``He was transferred to a prison when tensions were high and you will also note
your honour that the first thing he asked for was to be segregated,'' he told
the court.

In sentencing Judge Tony Briggs referred to the description of Khyam by the
judge at his Old Bailey trial, Sir Michael Astill, as ``ruthless, devious,
artful and dangerous''.

He said Cruddas, 32, from Gateshead, had suffered ``quite horrific'' second and
third degree burns in the attack.

In an impact statement Cruddas, who was given a 12-year sentence for conspiring
to commit robbery and possession of a firearm in 2001, told the court that he
and his family were struggling to come to terms with his injuries.

Judge Briggs said he accepted Khyam may have feared for his safety generally,
but rejected any idea that Cruddas posed a threat to him.

``I regret that there are factors, even if you did fear for your own safety,
that indicate precisely how dangerous you are and there are certainly
appearances of someone attempting to stamp their own authority and exercise
their own control over events, and someone who was determined to have their own
way,'' he said.

Khyam, who again appeared at court dressed in a pale blue sweatshirt and with a
thick beard, was given a four year jail term to run concurrently with the life
sentence he is already serving.

Judge Briggs noted that the sentence would not affect the number of years Khyam
would serve, but suggested it could affect his chances of parole at a later
date.

Asked about the three attacks at Frankland, a Prison Service spokeswoman said
that while she could not comment on individual cases, the duty of care to
prisoners was taken ``very seriously''.

``Every effort is made to ensure that the rights of prisoners whatever their
religion, ethnic, or cultural background are respected,'' she said.

``All prisoners are able to register confidentially any concerns informally or
formally to staff on the wing, the Governor, the Independent Monitoring Board,
Prison Service Headquarters, the Prisons and Probation Ombudsman, their MP or
their legal representatives.

``All actions involving Category A prisoners are subject to continual risk
assessments to ensure safety and security for all. As part of that risk
assessment, any concerns raised by a prisoner would be taken into account.''

Russia: Militants detained, killed in Ingushetia involved in terror attacks

LENGTH: 176 words


Two militants that resisted police who were trying to detain them in the
Nazranskiy District of Ingushetia were involved in carrying out terrorist
attacks, the Ingushetia directorate of the Russian Federal Security Service
(FSB) has said, as reported by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax-Yug
on 4 June.

At 1530 gmt on 3 June, police who were trying to detain the militants came under
fire from automatic weapons. The policemen returned fire, as a result of which
one militant was killed and their car caught fire. The other man was wounded and
detained. An assault rifle, Makarov pistol and a large amount of munitions were
found inside the car.

The detained man, Mikhail Ozdoyev, agreed to cooperate with the investigators.
He told the police that the other militant's name was Rezvan Tsuroyev, born in
1985.

Preliminary reports say both men were involved in a number of terrorist attacks
in Ingushetia, including against employees of law-enforcement agencies,
Interfax-Yug reported.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0455 gmt 4 Jun 08

                             June 5, 2008 Thursday

Bosnian ministry devises strategy for responding to possible terrorist attacks

LENGTH: 657 words


Text of report by Bosnian edition of Croatian daily Vecernji list, on 5 June

[Report by Dejan Jazvic: "Air Traffic and Energy Sector Most Vulnerable"]

The Security Ministry has devised a special plan for civil-military cooperation
among state institutions in case of terrorist attacks on Bosnia-Hercegovina.
This means that the state finally has a well-prepared and well-thought-out
response to possible terrorist attacks. The plan has been approved by the
Council of Ministers and commended by the UN Security Council's
Counter-Terrorism Committee, whose experts even promised financial support for
its implementation. The purpose of the plan is to create an effective and
efficient state response to terrorist threats and consequences of terrorist
attacks against civilian targets aimed at achieving the goals of terrorist
organizations, groups, and individuals.

Five Phases

The security-related data gathered thus far show that air traffic, power plants,
and transport and communications infrastructure are "the most vulnerable"
sectors in B-H. This category also includes facilities that are important to B-H
and the international community security-wise and public places such as schools,
hospitals, and public transportation means. The Security Ministry in cooperation
with the Defence Ministry would play a key role in responding to possible
terrorist attacks in B-H.

The response would consist of five phases ranging from prevention to recovery
and rehabilitation. Each of these phases envisions close civil-military
cooperation and the use of all available resources. The first phase, so-called
preventative, includes, among other things, measures aimed at suppressing
radicalism within society, developing an evacuation plan, as well as video
surveillance and other forms of protection of the vulnerable infrastructure and
public places.

Responsibility

The B-H counter-terrorism task force, the protection and rescue coordination
team, and the Civil Defence headquarters in the entities and the Brcko District
would be in charge of coordinating the response to possible terrorist attacks.
The operational response to terrorist attacks comprises several measures,
including participation of the B-H Armed Forces. These and other activities
envision close cooperation among all levels of authority based on the principle
of subsidiarity, from the state to local levels.

The operational capacities and resources that would be used by each of the state
institutions in the prevention of and response to terrorist attacks were not
mentioned in the plan for the sake of confidentiality. The information of this
kind will be forwarded to the counter-terrorism task force.

[Box] International Assistance

The plan for civil-military cooperation in responding to possible terrorist
attacks does not rule out international assistance. Apart from local military
units, international forces may also be asked to provide support.

Their assistance would be welcome in situations when local forces are estimated
to be incapable of adequately coping with consequences of terrorist attacks. The
United Nations, the EU, NATO, and Interpol are among the international
organizations that would be informed first about incidents - that is, terrorist
attacks.

[Box] Initial Response Forces

The initial response forces are the units that arrive first at the scene of an
incident or attack. These include police forces, SIPA [State Investigation and
Protection Agency], and special units of the entity police forces when it comes
to responding to a terrorist threat, while fire fighters, the Civil Defence,
rescue teams, and the emergency service would be tasked with providing the
initial response to consequences of a terrorist attack. If necessary, support
units - that is, the OS B-H [B-H Armed Forces], can also be engaged. However,
they must first get approval from the B-H Presidency.

Source: Vecernji list (Bosnia-Hercegovina edition), Zagreb, in Croatian 5 Jun 08

BEAST ATTACKS 5 WOMEN IN 90min;
 Cops release CCTV photo after perv's trail of terror BEAST ATTACKS 5 WOMEN IN
90min

BYLINE: Donna Watson

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 33

LENGTH: 405 words


A PERVERT attacked five women within 90 minutes in a series of assaults across
the centre of Glasgow and the city's west end.

He pounced at different locations between 6.15pm and 7.45pm on Thursday.

Police hunting the beast - who indecently assaulted his victims in the street -
last night released a CCTV image of a man they want to trace.

The image, taken in the Cambridge Street area, shows a man officers said may be
able to assist them with their inquiries.

The sicko first struck at an underpass at the city's Cowcaddens Underground,
pushing a 26-year-old woman to the ground before carrying out a sex attack.

Just 15 minutes later, he carried out another indecent assault, this time on
Hope Street at Bath Lane.

The victim did not report the attack to police, who were informed by a witness.

The third incident was at 7pm on Bank Street in the Kelvinbridge area. This time
the pervert grabbed a 31-year-old woman from behind, dragged her towards the
junction with Cowan Street and threw her to the ground.

But she escaped and her attacker ran off.

At 7.15pm he struck again, this time on Great Western Road at the junction with
Kersland Street.

He came up behind a 30-year-old woman and carried out another vile assault.

He ran towards Hillhead Steps but returned five minutes later to assault the
same woman again.

The trail ended at 7.45pm in Lancaster Terrace Lane where he crept up on a
20-year-old woman and tried to drag her into an alleyway, where he pushed her to
the ground and attempted to indecently assault her. This victim also got away.

The man in the CCTV footage is described as around 5ft 8in and in his late teens
or early 20s.

He was wearing a black hooded top, possibly with some form of white lettering or
pattern, a beige or mustard T-shirt and dark trousers.

He was carrying a black bag or holdall.

Detective Sergeant Alan Brown, from Glasgow's city centre police office, said:
"As a result of our initial inquiries, I can confirm that we are treating these
as linked incidents and believe that the same man is responsible for each one.

"Although the nature of the attacks is a major cause for concern, luckily none
of the women assaulted by this man required any medical attention - but they are
all badly shaken.

"The woman who was assaulted in Hope Street hasn't yet come forward to report
any details of the attack to police and I would urge her to do so as a matter of
urgency."

                                South Wales Echo

                              June 9, 2008, Monday
                                 First Edition

'Cardiff hosts big events and has crowded places. It's perfect for terrorist
attacks';
S.Wales' top police officer reveals city evacuation plans

BYLINE: David James

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 357 words


CARDIFF'S top police officer has revealed he has prepared the first evacuation
plan for the city in the event of a terrorist strike.

Chief Superintendent Josh Jones said a recent terror bomb attack in Exeter had
prompted senior officers to re-evaluate the potential danger to the capital of
Wales.

Although there is no specific intelligence of a terror threat, Chief Supt Jones
said the city has to be prepared as it "fits the bill".

He said: "We can't get away from the fact that Cardiff is the capital city of
Wales. It hosts big events, it hasiconic locations, it has crowded places, which
is the preferred opportunity for current terrorist attacks.

"That causes me some angst, but what I am trying to do is reassure the community
thatwe are trying to work with them so as to prevent violent extremism."

He said a string of measures had been introduced to prepare the city, including:

Increased numbers of armed officers on the streets at major events to make
Cardiff "a hostile environment for terrorism and provide a visible presence on
the street";

The development of an evacuation plan for the city in the case of a terror
strike;

And training for officers to increase their awareness of the threat.

In the coming months, Chief Supt Jones also said that there would be
announcements about initiatives within communities aimed at preventing
radicalisation and violent extremism.

In the wake of the July 7 bombings, the attack on Glasgow Airport and the recent
bomb explosion at a restaurant in Exeter have persuaded terror experts that
tackling problems within communities is vital to preventing radicalisation.

Oneman, a 22-year-oldMuslim convert, has appeared in court charged with
terrorism offences following the explosion in Exeter.

Nicky Reilly, who appeared at City of Westminster Magistrates' Court in London
under the name Mohamed Abdulaziz Rashid Saeed-Alim, suffered serious eye and
face injuries in the blast at the Giraffe restaurant in the Devon city on May
22.

Reilly, of King Street, Plymouth, is chargedwiththree offencesincluding one of
engaging in conduct in preparation for committing acts of terrorism.

Russian security chief gives more details on averted terror attacks - TV

LENGTH: 232 words


Text of "Sobytiya" news report by Russian Centre TV, owned by the Moscow city

[Presenter] The Russian security services foiled a series of terror attacks
during the May public holidays [from May Day to 9 May Victory Day and subsequent
weekend], Aleksandr Bortnikov, the new head of the National Antiterrorist
Committee said today [10 June] at a session of the committee.

He said that as a result of joint work between Russia's FSB [Federal Security

plans to commit terror attacks on the capital's metro [underground] had been
foiled.

In addition, the activities of a criminal group that was preparing attacks in
towns of the [North] Caucasus Mineralnyye Vody [spa resort] region had been
thwarted.

[Bortnikov] A large quantity of firearms, ammunitions and ingredients for
explosive substances, and literature that is extremist in nature has been
seized. In this regard, I additionally draw the attention of members of the
committee, leaders of the anti-terrorist commissions and operational
headquarters in constituent parts of the Russian Federation to the need to
reliably ensure security for all the events dedicated to the Russia Day public
holiday [on 12 June].

Britain - MCB attacks terror law

Muslim leaders warned yesterday that holding terror suspects for 42 days without
charge would worsen relations between police and Muslims.

Muslim Council of Britain (MCB) spokesman Inayat Bunglawala said that members

                              The Sentinel (Stoke)

                             June 12, 2008 Thursday

Terror attack at city dog home

BYLINE:  Richard Ault

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 517 words


Rottweiler owners attacked staff at a stray dogs home when they were told they
would have to pay a fine to claim back their missing pets.

Staff at the City Dogs Home in Brookhouse Lane, Bucknall, say they are sick of
the constant abuse and threats they receive from dog owners reclaiming their
animals.

Police are now investigating after a family of four came to collect two
Rottweilers, which were picked up by the council dog warden in Chesterton.

The family objected to paying a £50 fine, issued by Newcastle Borough Council,
which needs to be paid before the dogs can be collected.

Vicky Phillips, who has been manager of the  home for 18 years, said: "They
broke in, knocked us about and stole the dogs back.

"A woman turned up and tried to claim the dogs had been stolen from her garden,
but they had been running about in the streets when they were found.

"She was shouting and swearing at me, then the next thing, a car turned up. They
climbed over the wall at the back of the home and cuffed us out of the way. They
got into my own bungalow, which is next to the home, and where my own little
dogs were. They took the Rottweilers through my home, I was trying to get my
dogs out of the way so they didn't get savaged.

"Then one of the women clawed my face and a man smacked my head against the
wall. A woman grabbed hold of a member of staff and another staff member had to
pull her off.

"It was quite frightening. We get a lot of threats and abuse from people picking
up their dogs, but I've never been attacked before."

Dogs found wandering the streets of Newcastle and Stoke-on-Trent without their
owners are collected by the warden and delivered to the City Dogs Home.

Fines are issued by either Newcastle Borough Council or Stoke-on-Trent City
Council. The dogs' home makes no profit from the fine, but they do receive a fee
of £6 per day to cover kennel charges, which is added on top of the fine.

Any dogs found which are chipped or have proper name tags are delivered home, as
long as there is someone in to receive them.

Ms Phillips said: "The fine is nothing to do with us, but we get the abuse. We
are providing a public service, and you would think people would be happy to get
their dogs back."

Gordon Oldfield, who founded the dogs home 20 years ago, said: "It is worrying
to think your staff could get attacked for doing their job.

"People are always slagging us off. They think we are overcharging them. A lot
of people seem to think it is us who are fining them.

"But we do it for the council and I want dog owners to realise this."

Newcastle Borough Council declined to comment.

Police are now appealing for anyone with any information about the attack on
staff at the City Dogs Home, at about 5.15pm on Wednesday, June 4, to contact
them.

A police spokesman said: "One of the members of staff requested help from police
after an assault. We sent patrols straight away.

"We are investigating at the moment, but we have not made any arrests."

Anyone with any information about the attack is asked to call Cheadle Police on
08453 302010, or call the Crimestoppers confidential hotline on 0800 555111.

LOAD-DATE: June 13, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             Paisley Daily Express

                             June 14, 2008 Saturday
                                  1ST Edition

CALL TO HONOUR ALL AIRPORT TERROR ATTACK HEROES;
 PM says trio's acts are highly regarded CALL TO HONOUR ALL AIRPORT TERROR
ATTACK HEROES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 346 words


MORE than 500 people have signed a petition calling for bravery medals to be
given to everyone who helped thwart a terrorist attack on Glasgow Airport.

Erskine man John Smeaton was given the Queen's Gallantry Medal for Bravery in
March for the role he played in the attack last year.

And now there is a campaign for the other three civilians who were identified as
playing a part on the day - Alex McIlveen, Michael Kerr, and Stephen Clarkson -
to be given the same honour.

John, 31, gained worldwide fame for his part in averting the terror attack and
the vivid interviews he gave afterwards.

The online petition, which is being backed by scores of Paisley folk, was
started by Annette Kerr.

It says: "We wish to register our support for equal recognition for all the
civilian heroes of the Glasgow Airport terror attack in June 2007.

"They all played their part in preventing the terrorists from carrying out their
atrocities, and they should all be awarded for their brave and gallant actions."

PM Gordon Brown e-mailed everyone who had signed the petition saying he was
aware of, and grateful for, the contribution of all three during the incident on
June 30 last year.

He explained: "The process for assessing gallantry awards has evolved over many
years, and is subject to constant checks for consistency in the award of medals.

"Recommendations for gallantry awards are assessed by the George Cross
Committee, whose members are experienced in considering similar cases.

"The evidence comes from the police and others involved in the management of an
incident. It is against this background that the incident in Glasgow was
considered very carefully.

"Decisions are made on the basis of the information available.

"If there is new information, preferably in the form of statements given to the
police, then the committee would be very pleased to look at the matter again.

"Once again there is no doubt that the actions of all three men were very highly
regarded.

"It is clear from the support for this petition how much the public appreciates
what they did."

                                   The People

                             June 15, 2008, Sunday

WILLS TERROR ATTACK;
 EXCLUSIVE SAILOR PRINCE IN AL-QAEDA PERIL CRUISE BRITS ARE BOMB

BYLINE: BY DAVID COLLINS

SECTION: 3 Star Edition; NEWS; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 483 words

HIGHLIGHT: TARGETS: Ocean liners could be terrorists' target; WILLS FRIGATE: HMS
Iron Duke will be Prince's home


AN evil al-Qaeda plot to kill thousands of cruise ship Brits could plunge Prince
William into the war on terror.

MI6 has discovered that fanatics planned an horrific attack on a huge holiday
liner in the Caribbean.

Passengers would be victims as suicide bombers intend to ram the ship in
speedboats packed with explosives - or plant saboteurs aboard to trigger an
engine room inferno.

Royal Navy frigate Iron Duke - whose 180-strong crew will soon include William,
25 - would be in a prime position to speed to the rescue.

The 4,200-ton warship, in the Caribbean to hunt cocaine runners, would run the
risk of being caught in follow-up blasts aboard the liner. The Prince has just
started two months with the Royal Navy as Sub-Lieutenant Wales after his Army
and RAF service.

The plot was uncovered on a jihadist website which British and American security
services have been monitoring since early this year.

The terror plan echoes an al-Qaeda attack on the US warship Cole in Yemen in
2000.

Terrorists loaded a small boat with explosives and blasted a 12-metre hole in
the ship's hull, killing 17 crew.

MI6 foiled a plot to blow up British ships off Gibraltar in 2002. Al-Qaeda's
plot to target a cruise ship may also have involved terrorists getting jobs as
crew members.

Fellow fanatics would then book cabins as passengers and link up with the rest
of the group once at sea.

They could scuttle the ship by opening underwater hatches or start a disastrous
blaze in the engine room. Some of the world's biggest cruise liners were picked
as possible targets.

The latest generation of ships carry thousands of passengers and British
tourists flock to go on sunshine cruises each year.

MI6 and America's CIA have warned operators to tighten up security on their
holiday ships this summer.

The security services discovered the al-Qaeda terror cell was discussing the
plans in a password-protected forum on a jihadist website. One terrorist offered
his expertise and boasted he already had experience of blowing up ships.

Terrorism expert Neil Doyle said: "Images of passenger ships, deck plans and
technical details were swapped between members of the group.

"They discussed whether to attack one particular ship while it was at sea or in
harbour and how the leader of the cell could get a job on board.

"The conversation ended when one member suggested they should carry on the
discussion elsewhere in case anyone was watching.

"Internet forums used by al-Qaeda are difficult to trace.

They use false names and keep their location confidential."

features@people.co.uk

HELP US DESTROY FAT BEAST

A CHILLING website in Arabic outlined the al-Qaeda plans to target a huge cruise
ship. It said: "A successful strike on this fat beast would fulfil a very
important objective." The message pleaded: "We want your darkest ideas."

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political

                             June 17, 2008 Tuesday

US offers India help in probing terror attacks

LENGTH: 316 words


Text of report by Indian news agency PTI

Ghaziabad (Uttar Pradesh) [north Indian state], 16 June: As probe into various
terror attacks in the country continued, the United States Monday [16 June] said
it was ready to help in the process even as the FBI [Federal Bureau of
Investigation, US] launched a programme to share its expertise with Indian
agencies.

"We are ready to offer any kind of help to Indian authorities in investigation
of blast cases if government wants us to do so," said Kathy Stearman, Legal
Attache in the US Embassy here.

She was talking to reporters on the sidelines of a conference - Evidence
Recovery, Preservation and Exploitation Course.

The FBI, which is jointly organizing the conference with the CBI [Central Bureau
of Investigation, India's federal probe agency], is sharing American expertise
in bomb blast investigations with Indian law enforcement agencies.

The programme would provide world-class crime scene training to Indian officials
based on post-blast techniques developed by officials of the US and other
countries.

The techniques include those relating to composition and effects of various
types of explosives, the procedure for processing a post-blast crime scene and
collection and preservation of evidence.

Stearman said joint efforts of Washington and New Delhi were necessary to curb
trans-national crimes like terrorism.

"Through such efforts, not only the US or India, but the whole world would be
benefited," she said addressing the delegates.

The US offer came at a time when the CBI and other agencies are still grappling
with probes into serial bomb blast cases, including those which struck Delhi,
Malegaon, Jaipur, Mumbai and the Samjhauta Express [India-Pakistan train]
explosion.

Stearman said many more joint security initiatives would be taken by both
countries in the near future.

Source: PTI news agency, New Delhi, in English 1938gmt 16 Jun 08

                                  FIN Edition

KNIFEPOINT TERROR;
Court told of 'pre-meditated attack'

BYLINE: GARETH LIGHTFOOT

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 316 words


A MAN barged into a neighbour's home and launched a "deliberate pre-meditated
attack" on him with a knife, a Teesside jury heard.

Daniel Hill, 37, is accused of assaulting Graham "Ginger" Puckrin, 36, causing
him serious injuries to the scalp and hand on October 10, 2005.

Prosecutor Jonathan Walker said Hill took a knife from his mother's home, went
to the home of "quiet mild-mannered" Mr Puckrin and aimed the weapon at his head
and stomach. He said Hill had aggressively questioned Mr Puckrin over his
association with Hill's ex-partner while both men lived on Barnaby Avenue,
Middlesbrough.

On the night of the alleged attack, Mr Puckrin was in his kitchen when he heard
a loud bang on his living room window, said Mr Walker.

Teesside Crown Court heard yesterday that Mr Puckrin opened his front door to
see Hill in his garden shouting and saying he wanted to fight.

Mr Puckrin told him to leave and tried to shut the door but Hill barged in and
pushed him, it is alleged.

"The two began to wrestle. Mr Puckrin, who is a small individual, tried to push
the defendant away. He (Hill) then knelt on the chest of Mr Puckrin having
gained strength over him and pinned him down. Mr Puckrin described him as
ranting and raving. He appeared to be making no sense whatsoever.

"He said, 'I want you to listen before I put this into you.' Mr Puckrin felt a
sharp pain."

This was the scalp injury, said Mr Walker, adding: "He saw the defendant had a
large serrated knife in his hand. The defendant swung in the direction of Mr
Puckrin's stomach in, the Crown say, a deliberate attempt to gore the stomach of
Mr Puckrin.

"Mr Puckrin grabbed the knife."

He said the knife broke, leaving the blade in Mr Puckrin's bleeding left hand,
and he pushed Hill away.

Hill, now of Marton Road, Middlesbrough, denies wounding with intent to do
grievous bodily harm. He claimed when arrested: "It was self defence."

Proceeding

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                             June 17, 2008 Tuesday

International: Embassy warns Britons in UAE of terror threat: Fear of
'indiscriminate' attacks on western targets: Foreigners make up 80% of 5.6m
population

BYLINE: Ian Black, Middle East editor

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 557 words


Britain has warned its nationals living in or visiting the United Arab Emirates
that terrorists may be planning indiscriminate attacks at any time.

A statement posted on the website of the British embassy in Abu Dhabi, the UAE
capital, said the country now faces "a high threat of terrorism". The previous
level referred to a "general threat from terrorism". The other categories are
"underlying" and "low". The alert level was under constant review, the embassy
said.

"We believe terrorists may be planning to carry out attacks in the UAE," it
added. "Attacks could be indiscriminate and could happen at any time."

The UAE, comprising seven emirates including Dubai, is home to 100,000 British
expatriates and is visited by a million holidaymakers from the UK a year. The
Gulf country's booming economy is a magnet for foreign investment.

The Foreign Office refused yesterday to elaborate on the reasons behind the
warning, which was issued on Saturday. It is assumed to refer to al-Qaida,
assessed to have suffered serious setbacks in Iraq but still seeking to mount
spectacular attacks against "soft" western targets. Al-Qaida is known to be
aware of revulsion at the killing of Muslims.

The change in the threat level was not a change to travel advice, the Foreign
Office insisted, and was based on advice from posts, intelligence and other
elements.

The UAE is a conservative Muslim country but has become a major regional hub
attracting millions of tourists each year, mainly to the bustling city-state of
Dubai - which is known for its liberal lifestyle.

It also hosts regular visits by US navy ships, and is likely to be the first
Arab country to send an ambassador to Iraq.

Possible targets include places frequented by expatriates and foreign
travellers, such as residential compounds, as well as "military, oil, transport
and aviation interests", according to the embassy. Its language suggests there
is no specific threat. In other cases of intelligence about terrorist attacks
embassies have been temporarily evacuated, relocated or closed.

The UAE does not have heavy security measures in place and it has not suffered
any serious incidents. No other western embassies in the country have issued
similar warnings.

Elsewhere in the Gulf, Saudi Arabia has fought a wave of violence waged by
al-Qaida since 2003, including attacks targeting foreign tourists, residential
compounds and oil installations. Its impoverished neighbour Yemen has also
suffered several attacks claimed by al-Qaida. In Qatar one Briton was killed and
12 people wounded in a suicide bombing at a theatre near a British school in
2005.

The UAE could be seen as a particularly attractive target for al-Qaida as more
than 80% of the 5.6-million population are foreigners. Many are poorly paid
construction workers from south Asia, but there are thousands of professionals
too. Dubai attracts huge numbers of Britons investing in its booming real estate
sector, including skyscrapers and luxury hotels. The UAE has the world's fifth
largest oil reserves.

Tristan Cooper, a risk analyst at Moody's Investors Service, warned the terror
threat could damage the UAE economy. "It could . . . be hit by a political shock
that slowed the inflow of expatriate labour or, in a more extreme scenario,
caused resident expatriates to leave the country," he told the Dow Jones
newswire.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              Lancashire Telegraph

                             June 17, 2008 Tuesday

Blackburn family's brick attacks terror

BYLINE: Emma Cruces

SECTION: BLACKBURN (BLACKBURN)

LENGTH: 317 words


A family has been left living in fear after two brick attacks on their home in a
week.

Yobs smashed the first of two windows at the house in Windermere Close,
Blackburn, at 10.30pm, when a half-brick missed hitting a 21-year-old woman by
seconds.

The Khan family were putting the incident down to random bad luck when another
downstairs room was targeted at the same time just days later.

Following the two attacks - on Monday, June 9, and the following Thursday - the
windows of two front rooms at the terraced house are boarded up and the family
is terrified the same thing could happening again.

Mrs Khan, who declined to give her first name, said: "The first time, we had
just started having our dinner when boom - it hit and the double-glazed window
just exploded.

"The half brick landed in the middle of the room.

"It's a really small room and the window is quite low. The brick would have hit
my 21-year-old cousin on the head, had she still been sitting by the window.

"She had got up and gone into the kitchen just seconds before. It was very
fright-ening, but we assumed it was a one-off and had the window boarded up.

"On Thursday, me, my son and daughter were going to sit in the room with the
boarded-up window but we changed our minds.

"We went into the other room to watch TV instead.

"When a brick came through the window there, we couldn't believe it was
happening again. We were very afraid.

"I am very concerned it will happen a third time and I want to know why it is
happening. We are terrified just to sit in our home.

"It's dreadful and my children are very scared.

"A brick coming through the window is so dangerous and we are just waiting for
it to happen again.

"I just want to feel safe in my own home but I honestly think it will happen
again."

A police spokeswoman appealed for anyone with information to get in touch.

She said: "These were very traumatic incidents for the family involved."

                            June 18, 2008 Wednesday

UAE editorial criticizes UK, US warning of terrorist attack

LENGTH: 208 words


Text of report in English by Dubai newspaper Gulf News website on 18 June

[Editorial: "UAE is the Safest Place to Live"]

The advisories issued by the embassies of the UK and the US to their nationals
of a possible terrorist threat in the UAE are routine and are within the right
of every country to ensure the safety and security of its citizens. It does not
mean that the UAE faces an imminent attack that deserves special precautions.

However, the way the two advisories were publicly announced and the vague
wording used to express concerns have created a rather uncomfortable situation
and helped no one improve his or her security.

Expatriates from the UK and the US and from everywhere in the world know through
first-hand experience that the UAE is one of the safest countries in the world
and the security of residents here, regardless of nationality, is given
paramount importance.

It would have been better for the UK and the US missions to share intelligence
information available to them with the authorities in charge of security in the
emirates.

The UAE has reassured residents that there is no credible information about any
terrorist threat and the UAE remains a safe place for living.

Source: Gulf News website, Dubai, in English 18 Jun 08
