                   UK Newsquest Regional Press - This is York

                             June 19, 2008 Thursday

Teenager knifed in attack terror

BYLINE: Nicola Fifield

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 363 words

DATELINE: York Press


A TEENAGER has been stabbed in broad daylight in a York street - sparking a
major armed police operation.

The 16-year-old boy, who was knifed in the abdomen at about 11.10am yesterday,
is understood to have been accompanying his pregnant friend to an ante-natal
appointment at York Hospital.

A large-scale police hunt was launched, and a 23-year-old man was arrested by
more than ten armed officers at about 12.30pm, in Clifton Moor.

The victim, who was attacked in a snicket between Maplehurst Avenue and Haxby
Road, has received treatment at York Hospital for a superficial puncture wound.

A spokesperson for North Yorkshire Police said: "The offender actually
accompanied the 16-year-old victim to the hospital before walking out of the
building at about 11.20am.

"He was located and arrested at 12.30pm by officers from the Firearms Support
Unit as he was walking near the Flying Legends pub, at Clifton Moorgate.

"He was compliant throughout and is currently in custody awaiting questioning.

"A knife has been recovered by the police."

Coun Ken King, who represents the Clifton ward, said he was horrified by what
had happened.

He said: "I'm absolutely appalled that a 16-year-old youth has been attacked in
this way.

"It is shocking that there are individuals in York who are carrying knives on
York streets and I hope that police are going to come down heavy on whoever
committed this crime.

"I also hope that the young boy who has been stabbed is recovering well and
isn't too badly injured."

Sergeant Shaun Page, of the Clifton Safer Neighbourhoods Team, urged residents
not to worry.

He said: "This is an isolated incident that is very rare and residents should
not be alarmed.

"You will see us patrolling the streets every day and crime in this area is on
the fall."

Jane Mowat, director of the Safer York Partnership, said: "This is a one-off
case and somebody has been arrested for it, so people should not be alarmed.

"When something like this happens, it is quite common that the victim and the
perpetrator know each other."

Police have issued a witness appeal and anybody with information should phone
York police on 0845 6060247 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

Russia's Northern Fleet practises responding to terror attack on oil tanker

LENGTH: 473 words


Text of "Novosti Dnya" news report by Russian Zvezda TV, Defence Ministry
controlled, promotes patriotic values, on 11 June

[Presenter] An exercise "Antiterror 2008" has been held in Murmansk. The
Northern Fleet, the Emergencies Ministry and border guards practised joint
actions to respond to an explosive device being planted on an oil tanker. The
reason for holding the special operation was real events that occurred in the
Kola Bay three years ago. [Our correspondent] Svetlana Demeneva has been
convinced that the environment in the Barents Sea is not under threat.

[Correspondent] An explosive device was discovered this morning on the
Belokamenka tanker in the Kola Bay. Specialists have confirmed that it is not a
fake. This is how the exercise "Murmansk Sea Port Antiterror 2008" begins, after
which the situation becomes more complicated. Two groups of terrorists take the
tanker's watch shift hostage. They capture and place a bomb on a diving boat.
With a suicide bomber on board, it tries to get through to the tanker.

The grounds for this exercise were real events in the Kola Bay. An attempt was
made to blow up a tanker in 2005 due to commercial competition. Investigation of
the criminal case is still continuing.

[Valeriy Fedorov, captioned as head of the Russian FSB directorate for Murmansk
Region] Following an order by a businessman, a resident of our city made
attempts to blow up a storage tanker on the in the Kola Bay.

[Correspondent] Heads of operational headquarters from all across Russia's
north-west are observing the exercise. New elements are being practised here for
the first time. Removing an explosive device from on board a floating oil vessel
and cooperation at sea between three agencies - the Emergencies Ministry, border
guards and the Northern Fleet.

[Vladimir Korolev, captioned as deputy commander of the Northern Fleet] The
naval group deals with tasks relating to blockages of the Kola Bay, the middle
stretch in this case, as well as with preventing terrorist attacks, detaining
small-scale vessels with terrorists on board, providing help to vessels in
distress, and organizing preventative underwater grenade launching for the
purpose of destroying terrorists who could escape under water when detained.

[Correspondent] The regional directorate of the Emergencies Ministry is using a
new mobile system for the first time at these exercises. On capturing the small
boat, the terrorists threw the crew overboard. Using a computer, an on-line link
is established with the crisis centre in Murmansk. There is also a link with
such centres in Moscow and St Petersburg. There is feedback during the exercise,
which will be discussed later. But on the whole, according to the preliminary
assessments of those in charge, all subdivisions worked well.

Needle terror attack of flats girl, 14;
 Hunt for addicts Needle terror attack of flats girl, 14

BYLINE: Amy Devine

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 273 words


A DRUG addict squirted a syringe at a terrified teenage girl after she caught
him shooting up in an Edinburgh tower block.

The 14-year-old was on her way home when she discovered a man and a woman
injecting drugs in the stairwell of a high-rise in Leith.

She challenged the pair and the man squirted a syringe of liquid in her face.

The young victim was taken to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary for treatment after the
incident at Inchkeith Court.

Police hunting the pair today branded the attack as "cowardly and vicious".

A Lothian and Borders police spokeswoman said: "This has been a terrifying
experience for the young girl and although she was not seriously hurt, she has
been left understandably shaken.

"She was within her rights to challenge these people and it was a cowardly and
vicious response from the man involved."

The pair seen huddled in the stairwell were both said to be in their early 20s.

The man is described as being white, 6ft tall and of slim build with a pale
complexion.

He had short dark hair, was unshaven and was wearing a dark top and jeans.

The woman was white and very skinny, with dirty yellow teeth.

She had dirty fair shoulder-length hair and was wearing a dark padded jacket and
blue jeans.

Detectives urged anyone who may know the pair to contact them.

The spokeswoman added: "We appeal for anyone who was in the area at the time,
and who recognises the description of the people involved, to get in touch with
us."

Anyone with information about the attack, which happened at 12.45pm on
Wednesday, is urged to contact police on 0131 311 3131 or call Crimestoppers in
confidence on 0800 555 111.

                             June 21, 2008 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Doctors deny plotting failed terrorist car bomb attacks;
Two appeared at hearing via video link from prison

BYLINE: MARTIN WILLIAMS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 429 words


TWO doctors yesterday denied plotting the failed terrorist car bomb attacks in
Glasgow and London.

Bilal Abdu llah, 28, and Mohammed Asha, 27, appeared at the Old Bailey via video
link from prison for a pre-trial hearing .

The men are charged with conspiracy to murder and to cause explosions between
January 1, 2006, and July 1, 2007. During a 30-minute hearing of mostly legal
argument, the two men formally denied the charges.

Mr Justice Mackay said a trial, expected to last 12 weeks, will begin on October
2 at Woolwich Crown Court.

Jordanian Asha, of  Newcastle-Under-Lyme, Staffordshire, who wore a white
opennecked shirt, took notes on a laptop computer throughout the hearing as he
sat beside Abdullah.

Abdullah, who is originally from Iraq, but was living in the Halls of Residence
at the Royal Alexandra Hospital in Paisley, was arrested after a Jeep vehicle
was driven into the doors of the arrivals hall of Glasgow Airport on June 30.

Asha was arrested on the M6 motorway near Sandbach in Cheshire later that day.
His wife, Marwa Asha, 27, was also seized by police at the same time but she was
released without charge.

The investigation was launched after two cars with makeshift bomb materials
including petrol, nails and gas cylinders were found in London on June 29.

The first device was discovered in a green Mercedes car parked near Piccadilly
Circus.

It was found when an ambulance crew noticed the car was filling up with fumes.

A quick-thinking police officer disconnected a mobile phone he found in the car
before bomb squad officers arrived.

The second lethal device was discovered in a Mercedes a few hundred yards away
which had been towed away after being found illegally parked. It was feared at
the time that wide-scale damage to people and property could have been caused if
the bombs had gone off The following day, a Jeep Cherokee loaded with gas
canisters and gasoline was driven into the main terminal at Glasgow Airport on
its busiest day of the year.

One of the men in the vehicle, Kafeel Ahmed, suffered 90per cent burns and later
died from his injuries .

Ahmed's brother, Dr Sabeel Ahmed, 26, an NHS doctor received an 18-month jail
sentence after pleading guilty to withholding information about terrorism, an
offence that carried a maximum sentence of five years.

The Old Bailey heard in April that the sentence was reduced because he did not
read an e-mail about the attack from his brother until after the attack had
taken place.

The case against Abdullah and Asha was adjourned until July 25 when a pre-trial
review will take place at the Old Bailey.

BECKS A TERROR TARGET;
PLOT TO ATTACK HOLIDAY ISLE

BYLINE: WORLD EXCLUSIVE by NEIL CHANDLER, Chief Reporter

SECTION: NEWS TYPE=ARTICLE LINK=1; 9

LENGTH: 443 words


BRIT spies have uncovered an al-Qaida plot to target David Beckham and other
England football stars.

MI6 spooks learned the terrorists were planning to attack a holiday paradise in
Dubai where Beckham and other stars have homes.

The news sparked a fresh security alert in the Arab Emirates state and the
Foreign Office has now upped its threat warning from "general" to "high". The
British Embassy in Dubai warned travellers: "There is a high threat from
terrorism.

"We believe terrorists may be planning to carry out attacks in the United Arab
Emirates. Attacks could be indiscriminate and could happen at any time,
including in places frequented by expatriates and foreign travellers such as
residential compounds, military, oil, transport and aviation interests.

"You should maintain a high level of security awareness, particularly in public
places."

Beckham and his fellow footballers Gary Neville, Michael Owen, David James, Joe
Cole, Andy Cole and Kieron Dyer all have properties on the artificial island of
Palm Jumeirah, known as the "eighth wonder of the world".

The millionaires' playground has been mentioned several times as a potential
target on al-Qaida websites monitored by the security services.

Also mentioned was the Burj Al-Arab, the world's tallest hotel.

Both potential targets featured in a video issued by the Global Islamic Media
Front - al-Qaida's media arm - in March 2006, which resulted in arrests in
Germany and Austria.

One lengthy online discussion on May 22 about mounting bomb attacks in Dubai
refers to "the towers and the islands" where many Brits are based, because "they
run the oil refineries and have the wealth". The last message posted on the
subject, dated May 30, says:

"We are ready but this matter requires good planning and direction."

Discussion of the subject ceased mysteriously two days later. There are 78
messages in total.

Beckham bought his house on Palm Jumeirah for GBP 800,000 in 2002.

It is now thought to be worth GBP 8million and is regularly used by his wife
Victoria's parents Tony and Jackie Adams.

Afghan president Hamid Karzai was recently rumoured to have bought a property
there opposite that of West Ham winger Dyer.

Islamists are outraged that troops from the United Arab Emirates are the only
Arabs serving alongside British and American soldiers in Afghanistan.

Al-Qaida is also reported to be developing a new tactic of seaborne raids -
increasing fears of an attack on Palm Jumeirah.

The palm-shaped island is four times the size of London's Hyde Park and will
eventually become home to 65,000 people.

Emirates chiefs hope the Palm will bring a tourist boom to the UAE to help it
cope when oil runs out.

                               The Times (London)

                             June 24, 2008 Tuesday

McCain aide says terror attack 'would help Republicans'

BYLINE:  Tom Baldwin, Washington

SECTION: OVERSEAS NEWS; Pg.35

LENGTH: 592 words


John McCain yesterday delivered a sharp rebuke to one of his most senior
advisers who had suggested that another terrorist attack on America could propel
the Republican nominee into the White House.

Charlie Black, a veteran Republican strategist who has already come under fire
for his past ties to lobbyists, told Fortune magazine that a terror incident on
US soil "certainly would be a big advantage" to Mr McCain.

He also cited the "unfortunate event" of the assassination of Benazir Bhutto in
Pakistan in December, shortly before Mr McCain staged his comeback in the
Republican primary contest. "His knowledge and ability to talk about it re
emphasised that this is the guy who's ready to be Commander-in-Chief. And it
helped us."

The sudden row over his adviser embarrassed Mr McCain's campaign yesterday, when
he had hoped to focus on energy issues and a headline-catching initiative to
offer $300million (£ 150million) to anyone who developed a revolutionary car
battery.

Asked about Mr Black's comments during a press conference in Fresno, California,
Mr McCain stated that he wished to "strenuously disagree" with them. "I cannot
imagine why he would say it. It's not true," he said. "I've worked tirelessly
since 9/11 to prevent another attack on the United States of America. My record
is very clear."

Mr Black, confronted by reporters outside a fundraising event, read from
handwritten notes. "I deeply regret the comments. They were inappropriate," he
said. "I recognise that John McCain has devoted his entire adult life to
protecting his country and placing its security before every other
consideration."

Campaign officials said that he did not explicitly remember the comment, but did
not dispute it. According to one source, he was trying to emphasise that Mr
McCain was favoured by most voters on national security issues.

The campaign of the Democratic nominee, Barack Obama, seized upon the comments
as further evidence of the type of politics that had been practised by the
Republican in previous elections.

Bill Burton, a campaign spokesman, said: "Barack Obama welcomes a debate about
terrorism with John McCain, who has fully supported the Bush policies that have
taken our eye off of al-Qaeda, failed to bring Osama bin Laden to justice, and
made us less safe. The fact that John McCain's top adviser says that a terrorist
attack on American soil would be a 'big advantage' for their political campaign
is a complete disgrace.

"Barack Obama will turn the page on these failed policies and this cynical and
divisive brand of politics so that we can unite this nation around a common
purpose to finish the fight against al-Qaeda."

Four years ago President Bush and other Republicans argued that his opponent,
John Kerry, was soft on terrorism while questioning the record of the Democratic
party record on national security after the 9/11 attacks. A tape from Osama bin
Laden days before that election suggesting that he wanted Mr Kerry to win was
widely regarded as having benefited Mr Bush.

Many measures taken by the Bush administration to protect the US, including the
Guantanamo Bay camp for terror suspects and domestic wire tapping - as well as
the war in Iraq - have become increasingly the focus of national or
international controversy.

Sunni group, al-Qaeda

Association to take a mobile phone call from his wife

Three Pakistan "terror suspects" confess to plotting suicide attacks

LENGTH: 210 words


Text of report headlined "3 terror suspects plead guilty" published by Pakistani
newspaper Daily Times website on 25 June

Rawalpindi: Three terror suspects confessed on Tuesday to plotting suicide
attacks at sensitive government buildings and to having links with militant
leader Baitullah Mehsud.

Civil Judge and Judicial Magistrate Chaudhry Taufeeq Ahmad recorded the
confession statements of Abid Khan, Muhammad Ishaq and Qamaruz Zaman. The three
were sent to Adiala Jail on judicial remand for 14 days and the case was
adjourned until July 8.

Court sources told Daily Times that the accused had also confessed to planning a
suicide attack targeting a "high profile personality". They said the three were
included in the nine people arrested in a large-scale raid in the city, and a
massive quantity of explosives was also seized from them. Their remaining six
accomplices were taken to the Anti-Terrorism Court (ATC).

ATC No 2 sent Zafar Ali, Muhammad Zameer, Tauqeer Ahmad and Muhammad Sajjad on a
14-day judicial remand for further investigation. Muhammad Kabir and Intikhab
Abbasi were remanded to the custody of Federal Investigation Agency (FIA) for
seven days. Their case was adjourned until July 1.

                                Scottish Edition

WE'LL STRIKE FEAR INTO ANYBODY!;
Naisy reckons Gers can put out attack force to terrorise every defence they face

BYLINE: By GARY KEOWN

SECTION: SPORT FOOTBALL; 55

LENGTH: 661 words


RANGERS ace Stevie Naismith reckons manager Walter Smith is ready to mix up a
potent attack force to get his hands back on the SPL title.

The 21-year-old, who looks like missing most of the campaign as he recovers from
cruciate ligament surgery, has seen the club spend GBP 6million on Kyle
Lafferty, Kenny Miller and Andrius Velicka to give themselves a barrowload of
striking options.

With a GBP 2.5m Cardiff bid for Kris Boyd being turned down and Nacho Novo and
Lee McCulloch likely to stay put, Daniel Cousin and Jean-Claude Darcheville
appear most likely to be on the way out in the summer.

Naismith believes all three of the new boys bring something different to the
frontline mix.

The ex-Killie man said: "I managed to see Kyle when he was in having a look
around the club and he is some size.

"It doesn't take a genius to work out that he'll win his fair share of headers
and, although he is still a young man coming through, he has shown his presence
in the English leagues.

"Kenny obviously does a lot of running and has proven himself with Scotland.

"He hassles defenders while I'd say Velicka is a bit of an all-rounder.

"He is big and strong and scored a number of good goals when he was with Hearts.

"The new boys are really good because all three have shown they are capable of
doing well with their styles of play.

"They are three good additions and it makes for more competition among the
strikers.

"They are big names and I hope they can help us push for the title after coming
up just short last season." Naismith has no idea which forwards will leave Ibrox
over the summer but he believes his former Rugby Park team-mate Boyd (left) has
a long-term part to play.

He said: "I don't think anyone's scoring record is going to be near Boydy's, but
it is going to be the manager's decision.

"There's no other league like this and the manager is right to rotate players.

"He said that to me last season. You could have a great game and be on the bench
the next week.

"It is not because you've been poor. It is just because he's resting you.

"He knows what he's doing and I am sure he'll know how many strikers he wants."
Naismith is also pleased to see the club keep one eye on the other end of the
field, though, by holding talks aimed at nailing centre-half Davie Weir and
keeper Allan McGregor down on new deals.

He said: "Huge credit has to go to Allan and Davie for helping the team get to
the likes of the UEFA Cup final because we put in some great defensive displays
during that run. In the game in Germany against Werder Bremen, Allan made one of
the best saves I have ever seen in my life.

"Big Davie and the other guys at the back such as Carlos Cuellar and Sasa Papac
did tremendously well, too.

"It is good to see the management trying to tie these players down."

Naismith missed the thrilling climax of last term after damaging his knee in the
Scottish Cup semi-final win over St Johnstone.

The Scotland Under-21 cap collapsed in a heap shortly after being trampled on by
opposition midfielder Martin Hardie.

Naismith, however, has shot down claims the Saints man deliberately stamped on
his knee.

Naismith recalled: "I landed awkwardly and it didn't help that I was falling to
the side before being taken off, but I think it was the earlier challenge that
did the damage.

"I don't feel angry about the tackle because you know injuries can happen when
you are a footballer.

"Martin was with me at Kilmarnock and texted me afterwards to say that he was
sorry. He didn't have to do that and I appreciated it. It also tells me that he
didn't mean it.

"I got injured at the worst possible time because the games were coming thick
and fast, we were getting into cup finals and fighting for the league as well.

"Going to Manchester with the squad for the UEFA Cup final was an experience
I'll never forget and that gives me the incentive to get back and play in big
games.

"Missing out that night was a massive thing and it gives me the hunger to do my
best when I get back."

                            The Independent (London)

                            June 25, 2008 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

Aide who said terror attack would benefit McCain faces calls to quit

BYLINE: David Usborne in New York

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 1970 words


A foreign policy adviser to John McCain is under pressure to quit after he
suggested that a terror attack on the US between now and the presidential
election would translate into a "big advantage" for the Republican nominee.

Charlie Black issued a statement regretting the remark, which came in an
interview he gave for the July issue of Fortune magazine. "I deeply regret the
comments," he said. "They were inappropriate. I recognise that John McCain has
devoted his entire adult life to protecting his country and placing its security
before every other consideration."

At the heart of the controversy was his suggestion that a terror attack would
"certainly be a big advantage to" to Mr McCain. He also said that the
"unfortunate event" of the assassination of Benazir Bhutto in December "helped
us".

Mr McCain was quick to disown his adviser's remarks. "I cannot imagine why he
would say it. It's not true," he said on the campaign trail. "I've worked
tirelessly since 9/11 to prevent another attack on the United States of America.
My record is very clear."

The Obama campaign directed reporters yesterday to Richard Ben-Veniste, a member
of the 9/11 Commission that investigated the terror attacks of 2001. He said Mr
Black's remarks were "a candid and very disappointing glimpse into the thinking
of one of McCain's closest advisers". While he did not flatly ask Mr Black to
resign, he added: "I think the remarks were so out of place that they call for
some recalibration in the thinking and perhaps a greater adherence to principle
here in staying away from the politics of fear."

The McCain camp has hardly made any secret of its interest in painting Mr Obama
as insufficiently experienced on foreign affairs and, by implication,
potentially less well prepared to protect the country from further attacks.
However, the attempts of Republicans in the 2006 US Congressional elections to
portray Democrats as soft on terrorists apparently had little impact on voters.

Earlier, Mr Obama's spokesman, Bill Burton, had characterised the remark by Mr
Black as a "complete disgrace" and "exactly the kind of politics that needs to
change".

*Former president Bill Clinton will support Barack Obama in the US presidential
election this autumn, his spokesman has said. It is the first time the former
president has indicated he would support his wife's former rival since the
Democratic primary battle ended three weeks ago.

["TERRORIST ATTACK ON VEHICLE KILLS ONE, WOUNDS FOUR IN DIYARBAKIR" - AA
headline]

LICE (A.A) -26.05.2008 -A terrorist attack on a vehicle carrying soldiers killed
one and wounded four in the southeastern province of Diyarbakir on Thursday.

The civilian driver of a minivan died and four soldiers were injured when PKK
terrorists opened fire with long-range guns on four civilian minivans carrying
soldiers in Diyarbakir's Lice town, authorities said.

28-year-old driver Mehdin Dogandemir lost his life at the scene of the armed
attack. The vans were carrying soldiers who were on a temporary duty in a
military unit in Diyarbakir's Tapantepe hamlet.

Security forces have launched a wide-scale operation in the vicinity.

                                  Burton Mail

                             June 26, 2008 Thursday

Pole attack OAP tells of his terror ordeal

BYLINE: JAMES BRINDLE

LENGTH: 346 words


A BURTON pensioner who was attacked with a metal scaffolding pole in his own
home by a burglar has spoken of his terrifying ordeal.  Dennis Sharp, 67,
suffered severe cuts and bruises to his head and face after the frenzied attack
at his home in Harper Avenue, Horninglow. The attacker used the pole to floor Mr
Sharp before stealing 90. Mr Sharp told The Mail that he knew 'very little'
about the attack, saying: "Somebody just burst in through the back door and
attacked me.

I remember being battered about the head while I was down on the floor and then
he robbed me.  "He had a metal scaffolding pole, but he didn't knock me out, he
just decked me. He must have hit me about half a dozen times. There was nothing
else done, no damage to the house. He just wanted the money, that was all." Mr
Sharp, who had to be taken to Burton's Queen's Hospital, said he had never
experienced any problems before.  He said: "I have been here 16 years and I have
never had a problem. I am satisfied living here, I know all the neighbours. "I
keep getting flashbacks about it every so often. I thought I was dreaming at the
time. I've never experienced anything like that in my life." Mr Sharp also said
he had one overriding emotion after the vicious assault, which took place
between 6pm and 8pm on Wednesday, June 18. He said: "I feel really angry. If I
had a pole I would do the same to him. I've no idea who it was, though. He was
completely covered up head to foot, so I don't know whether he was black or
white or anything." The level of violence used in the attack has shocked police.
Det Sgt Ian Fitzgerald, of Burton police, said the attack was 'extremely
unusual' for the area and appealed for witnesses to come forward. He said:
"Someone has got to know something. This type of attack is very uncommon,
particularly with this level of violence. The theft of a pensioner's very meagre
earnings makes this crime all the more callous. "We would appeal for anyone with
information to telephone Burton CID on 01785 234 971 or telephone crimestoppers,
in confidence, on 0800 555 111."

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 333 words


BOYZONE star Mikey Graham was recovering last after he was attacked by the
furious husband of a fan.

The Dubliner was jumped by a man who claimed Mikey hadn't replied to his wife's
mail.

Mikey was outside the band's Marcliffe Hotel in Aberdeen, Scotland, when the
no-warning assault was launched.

He said: "He shouted, 'You are a b****rd. You haven't written back to my wife.
I'll f***ing teach you a lesson'."

The attacker then unleashed a volley of punches to the singer's stomach and
head.

But Mikey landed two huge blows on the man and sent him reeling to the ground.

The star hit him so hard he required medical treatment - but the attacker fled
before Boyzone's security guards were alerted.

Mikey said: "I thought he had stabbed me because he punched me so hard in the
kidney.

"I didn't know what hit me.

"I had been signing a few autographs and taking a stroll and suddenly this guy
came out of nowhere and started shouting all this abuse.

"He was going on about how I hadn't replied to letters his wife sent. I always
reply to fan mail and I told him that.

"Then he just went berserk. I had no choice but to defend myself. I went into
autopilot.

"It's worrying that something like this can happen but there will always be one
idiot."

Yesterday Mikey was recovering from the ordeal and was seen at the hotel with
his arm in a bandage. CCTV in the area will be studied in a bid to identify the
attacker.

Two female Boyzone fans, who had been sleeping outside their hotel in the hope
of catching a glimpse of their heroes, witnessed the incident and will make
statements.

Mikey was so badly injured in the bust-up he had to be taken to a private
medical clinic to have his hand scanned for fractures.

He added: "They bandaged me up and told me not to do anything too strenuous but
I'm on tour so the show must go on.

"We have our homecoming gig at the RDS on Saturday and I wouldn't miss that.
Hopefully I'll be out of the bandage."

                             Paisley Daily Express

                             June 28, 2008 Saturday
                                  1ST Edition

EXTRA pounds 3.8M WILL TACKLE TERROR;
 Cash windfall after airport attack EXTRA pounds 3.8M WILL TACKLE TERROR

BYLINE: ANDY NEWPORT

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 491 words


COPS fighting terrorists are to get a cash boost to help them in the battle to
keep us safe.

The move comes almost a year after evil suicide bombers tried to blow-up Glasgow
Airport.

The terrorist plot on June 30, last year when a Cherokee Jeep packed with fuel
and explosives was driven into the Paisley terminal building - brought home the
reality that Scotland is now a target for extremists.

Now Holyrood chiefs have responded to that with the extra money.

They will give police forces an additional pounds 3.8 million over the next two
years to combat terrorism and protect communities.

The funding will enable the creation of more than 50 counter terrorism posts
across Scotland with the aim of making ports and airports more secure and allow
the police to work with communities to raise awareness of terrorism.

In particular, the Scottish Government is developing with the Association of
Chief Police Offers in Scotland and key agencies, a Scottish approach to
preventing terrorism as part of the UK counter-terrorism strategy CONTEST.

It will focus on improving communications, improving knowledge and understanding
and, through a new delivery unit, co-ordinating project interventions.

It has also been announced that the amount of police grant paid directly to
police authorities will increase by almost pounds 53 million over the next three
years.

Justice secretary Kenny MacAskill said: "All in Scotland, regardless of their
background, are united by their common humanity and Scotland came together a
year ago to stand united as a nation against terrorism.

"Our diversity gives us strength, and that strength was clearly demonstrated
when our communities united to show their disgust and contempt for those who
attacked Glasgow Airport so ruthlessly last year.

"As last year's attack at Glasgow Airport showed, terrorism respects no
boundaries. Terrorism is a threat to all of our communities. We all need to work
together to reduce the threat of another terrorist attack.

"The Scottish Government is fully committed to the fight against terrorism and
that is why we are equipping our police forces to tackle this menace.

"These additional counter terrorism officers will help to make our ports and
airports more secure and allow the police to work with communities to raise
awareness of terrorism and related issues to make Scotland a safer place.

"We will continue to work with other jurisdictions, south of the border and
elsewhere to ensure the safety of all our citizens and that those who seek to
disrupt our way of life to perpetrate terror are prosecuted for their crimes."

Counter terrorism is an element of National Security, which is reserved to
Westminster.

Since 2003, CONTEST has been the UK framework for countering terrorism. Many
aspects of prevention and consequence management are devolved, however, and the
Scottish Government plays a prominent role in delivering the CONTEST strategy in
Scotland.

                              June 29, 2008 Sunday

Pakistan court indicts five terror suspects for planning attacks

LENGTH: 619 words


Text of report by Ishaq Tanoli headlined "Five suspects indicted in terror case"
published by Pakistan newspaper Dawn website on 29 June

Karachi, 28 June: The additional district and sessions judge-II, Central, on
Saturday [28 June] indicted five suspected terrorists for possessing illegal
weapons and explosive substance and for planning attacks on mourning processions
during Ashura [10th day of Muharram].

However, pleading not guilty, the accused opted to contest the case. The judge,
Nelofer Shahnawaz, summoned all the prosecution witnesses directing them to
appear in the court on the next hearing to testify in the case.

According to the prosecution, five suspected terrorists identified [names
omitted] were arrested by the CID [Criminal Investigation Department] police
from North Karachi. The suspects were allegedly planning to carry out suicide
attacks on the processions during Ashura.

The investigation officer stated in the charge-sheet that acting on a tip-off
the CID police conducted a raid on a house in North Karachi on January 19. The
house reportedly served as the suspects' hideout where they also used to store
weapons and other explosives. During the raid, the suspects opened fire on the
police party but were finally arrested after a shootout. The CID police had
seized illegal weapons and explosives from the possession of the accused.

Six cases (FIR Nos 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 10/08) were registered against the accused
under Sections 324, 353/34 of the Pakistan Penal Code, 13-D of Arms Ordinance
and 3/4 of Explosive Act at the New Karachi police station. The court has fixed
July 12 as the next date of hearing.

Warrants re-issued

The additional district and sessions judge-VII, South, Irfan Hussain Siddiqui,
re-issued non-bailable warrants for the arrest of the former chairman of the
National Accountability Bureau (NAB), Saifur Rehman Khan, his brother, Mujibur
Rehman Khan, the former inspector-general of Sindh police, Rana Maqbool, former
DIG [Deputy Inspector General] Farooq Amin Qureshi and the former superintendent
of the Central Prison, Karachi, Najaf Mirza, in a case pertaining to an attempt
on the life of Asif Ali Zardari in 1999.

Earlier, on June 14 the court had issued non-bailable warrants for the arrest of
the accused and directed the investigation officer to arrest them and produce
them in the court.

However, the IO [Investigating Officer] in the case submitted a report in court
on Saturday stating that the police were still searching for the accused and
therefore, needed more time. He argued that some of them had left the country.

Appearing in court on behalf of Mr Zardari, Adnan Karim advocate accused the
police of deliberately avoiding arrest of the accused as some of them belonged
to the police force.

He requested the court to seek the help of the Interpol for the arrest of those
staying in foreign countries.

However, the court asked Zardari's counsel to submit an application in this
regard and re-issued non-bailable arrest warrants of the accused and fixed July
12 as the next date of hearing.

The judge directed the SSP (Special Investigation Unit) to arrest the accused
and produce them in court on the next date.

Earlier on June 14, the investigation officer, Inspector Tairq Ali had submitted
a charge-sheet in the court, in which he had also nominated former DSP [Deputy
Superintendent of Police] Amanat Javed and Naveed Saeed as the co-accused in the
case. However, the court was informed that both the accused had passed away.

According to the prosecution, the respondents had unlawfully obtained Mr
Zardari's physical custody from an anti-terrorism court on the night between May
15 and May 16, 1999.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 29 Jun 08

                             PA Newswire: Scotland

                        June 29, 2008 Sunday 8:06 PM BST

AIRPORT 'TRANSFORMED' A YEAR AFTER TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Hilary Duncanson, Scottish Press Association

SECTION: PA Newswire: Scotland

LENGTH: 620 words


Glasgow Airport has been completely transformed, one year on from the terror
attack which brought chaos to thousands of holidaymakers, its managing director
said today.

Speaking as the anniversary of the attack approaches, Gordon Dewar said £4
million has been spent in the past 12 months on improving the terminal and
carrying out repairs.

He also insisted it would be business as usual for the airport's 5,000-strong
workforce on tomorrow's anniversary.

``Glasgow Airport has incurred substantial capital costs as a result of the
attack on the terminal,'' Mr Dewar said today.

``Despite this, we have worked hard to deliver improved facilities, at no cost
to our passengers, or to the taxpayer.''

Since the attack, airport operator BAA Glasgow has spent £4 million upgrading
the terminal and forecourt, including repairs to the areas damaged by smoke and
water.

Door two - the point of impact - has been completely rebuilt.

The final phase of the investment will see 300 steel bollards installed along
the inner forecourt, replacing the temporary barriers introduced following the
attack.

Mr Dewar said: ``Today marks the first anniversary of the terror attack on
Glasgow Airport, but for the 5,000 staff who work here, it is just another
working day.''

He praised the ``tremendous courage'' of staff, passengers and emergency
services caught up in the events of the day and said it was thanks to their
support that the airport was able to reopen less than 24 hours after the attack.

The managing director added: ``This is a matter of real pride for the staff
involved. However, one year on, there is no triumphalism, just a quiet
determination to get on with the job and deliver for our passengers.

``We have worked hard over the past year to repair, and refurbish, the terminal
building and there are now few visible signs of last year's attack.

``I am extremely proud of the team effort that has brought us to this point.

``The response from everyone involved in the reconstruction effort has been
superb.''

John Smeaton earlier reflected on the ``crazy'' year he has had since he was
propelled into the public eye after helping police take on a man in a blazing
jeep which had been driven into the airport terminal.

In a TV interview broadcast around the world, he warned: ``This is Glasgow, you
know - we'll set about you'' - a comment which catapulted him to stardom.

And today he insisted: ``It is still surreal.''

Reflecting on the events of that life-changing Saturday, he said: ``At the exact
moment in time you were not frightened, but minutes afterwards you think, 'That
was quiet scary'.

``But it is just one of those thing you have to deal with, you have to get on
with it.

``It is just crazy that my life has just gone from one extreme to another.''

Now known by his nickname of Smeato, he has been feted from London to New York,
mingling with top politicians and celebrities at glitzy bashes.

The man who insists he is ``just an ordinary guy'' has met Prime Minister Gordon
Brown several times, and was publicly congratulated by the PM at the Labour
Party conference in Bournemouth last year.

At the start of December, he travelled to New York to receive an Everyday
Superhero award from TV news channel CNN.

Earlier this year he was given the Queen's Gallantry Medal, one of the highest
British civilian honours for bravery.

But the have-a-go hero's highlight was getting to train with Rangers Football
Club.

He said: ``Training with Rangers was something else. I've been to America and
won awards in America, but that was something else, it was brilliant, amazing.''

Mr Smeaton, who hopes to settle with his girlfriend in the USA, added: ``I don't
class myself as a hero, I don't see myself as that. I am just an ordinary guy.''

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                        June 29, 2008 Sunday 2:45 AM BST

HERO REFLECTS ON YEAR SINCE TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Hilary Duncanson, Scottish Press Association

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 471 words


Glasgow Airport terror attack hero John Smeaton today reflected on the ``crazy''
year he has had, as the first anniversary of the incident approaches.

The baggage handler was propelled into the public eye on June 30 last year after
helping police take on a man in a blazing jeep which had been driven into the
airport terminal.

In a TV interview broadcast around the world, he famously warned: ``This is
Glasgow, you know - we'll set about you'' - a comment which catapulted him to
stardom immediately after the attack.

Now, a day ahead of tomorrow's anniversary, he insisted: ``It is still
surreal.''

Reflecting on the events of that life-changing Saturday, he said: ``At the exact
moment in time you were not frightened, but minutes afterwards you think, 'That
was quiet scary'.

``But it is just one of those thing you have to deal with, you have to get on
with it.

``It is just crazy that my life has just gone from one extreme to another.''

Now known by his nickname of Smeato, he has been feted from London to New York,
mingling with top politicians and celebrities at glitzy bashes.

The man who insists he is ``just an ordinary guy'' has met Prime Minister Gordon
Brown several times, and was publicly congratulated by the latter at the Labour
Party conference in Bournemouth last year.

At the start of last December, he travelled to New York to receive an Everyday
Superhero award from TV news channel CNN.

Earlier this year he was given the Queen's Gallantry Medal, one of the highest
British civilian honours for bravery.

But the have-a-go hero's highlight was getting to train with his beloved Rangers
Football Club.

He said: ``Training with Rangers was something else. I've been to America and
won awards in America, but that was something else, it was brilliant, amazing.''

Mr Smeaton, who hopes to settle with his girlfriend in the USA, added: ``I don't
class myself as a hero, I don't see myself as that. I am just an ordinary guy.''

Gordon Dewar, the airport's managing director, looked back on the attack and the
damage that was left in its wake.

He said: ``It was an extremely busy day where we had to try and get everybody as
safe as possible, evacuate the building, and make sure we protected the building
itself.

``There was an awful lot of physical damage we had to repair.

``We had to replace the doors entirely and there was a lot of damage to the
front of the building and quite a lot of internal damage in terms of smoke
damage and having to rewire and relight.

``We still don't have full use of the forecourt back and there will be a project
that starts in the next few weeks which will make permanent the protection we
have that its there in the form of temporary barriers at the moment.''

A spokesman at Glasgow Airport confirmed no special events were being held at
the airport today or tomorrow to mark the anniversary.

I LOOKED HATE IN THE EYE ..BUT I'D DO IT ALL AGAIN;
ONE YEAR ON..FROM THE GLASGOW AIRPORT TERROR ATTACK HAVE-A-GO-HERO ALEX RELIVES
THE HORROR

BYLINE: BY STEVE SMITH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 706 words


A TAXI driver who was one of the unsung heroes of the Glasgow airport terror
attack says he would do it again if he had to.

Alex McIlveen was one of several have-a-go-heroes who thwarted the bomb attack
on June 30 last year.

Brave Alex has now revealed he's still haunted by the day a 4x4 jeep packed with
explosives was crashed into the terminal building.

But, despite the nightmares, he still travels to the airport every day to drop
off passengers... who have no idea about the vital role he played that
terrifying day.

Alex, 45, who tore a tendon kicking burning bomber Kafeel Ahmed, said: "Working
at the airport is when I think about that day the most - you can't help but
wonder what could have happened, and how lucky we all were not to have been
killed."

He added: "The neighbours still talk about it and it's good to be recognised,
but it hasn't changed my life.

I would do it again if I had to.

"But it's not something you will ever forget - see that guy melt away before me
and the hatred in his eyes as he just wanted to fight will never go away.

"Because of my job I'm at the airport all the time so that probably helped me
get over the attack. You just have to get on with life, but it's certainly
something that I think about a lot." Alex, of Drumchapel, By STEVE SMITH
Glasgow, was dropping off a fare at the airport when he watched in horror as a
green Jeep Cherokee ploughed into the terminal, where thousands of Scots were
checking in for their summer holidays.

In the terrifying minutes which followed, Alex joined holidaymakers, airport
workers and police as they wrestled with the burning terrorists who were still
snarling insults.

Kafeel Ahmed died of 90 per cent burns in Glasgow Royal Infirmary four weeks
later. Paisley-based doctor Bilal Abdullah, 28, appeared at the Old Bailey,
London, last week accused of conspiracy to murder and cause an explosion. He
denies the charges.

Recalling the moment he stared terrorist Ahmed in face, Alex said: "The driver
came out and I could see his skin melting away through to his flesh. You don't
forget an image like that. I stared him in the eyes and there was nothing there
- he was just ranting stuff about Allah. He was a total headcase.

I didn't want to help him - if I'd had a gun I would have shot him. He didn't
even flinch as we kicked and punched him - he didn't even notice he was on fire.

"I've been told that he was so pumped up on morphine that he was only two per
cent from an overdose - he was like a machine."

Stephen Clarkson, 41, was another passer-by who stepped in to help police arrest
crazed Ahmed yards from the burning Jeep.

He was praised for his heroics that day too. But his biggest test came six
months after the attack when he was struck down with a potentially-fatal brain
haemorrhage and faced months of treatment.

Last night he revealed he has only now been given the all-clear to Alex after
attack Taxi driver Alex tackled burning terrorist The explosives-packed 4x4
burns fiercely after it was smashed into the busy Glasgow airport building
return to work as a construction site groundsman.

Stephen, of Pennilee, Glasgow, said: "It has been a pretty awful year, but to be
honest suffering the brain haemorrhage was far more scary than the airport. I am
proud of what I did that day and it's always something that you think about -
you can't really forget getting caught up in an attack like that.

"I'm just glad I came through everything that's happened over the last year, and
I'm now looking to getting back to work and restarting my life."

After the attack, both Alex and Stephen were praised for helping police arrest
the suspects.

But, unlike airport baggage handler John Smeaton, both were snubbed for a
Queen's Gallantry Medal.

"Smeato" became a worldwide celebrity figure for his part in tackling the men.
His cult status has infuriated the other Glasgow airport heroes who earlier this
year questioned his role in tackling the suspects.

Alex said: "He's made a lot of money out of what happened. He knows what
happened and we all know - I'll leave it at that. John doesn't talk to me now
because I questioned his involvement.

"I just don't think it's right that only one person gets the recognition by the
Prime Minister and the top bravery award."

'WE HAVE LEARNED A HARSH LESSON';
ONE YEAR ON..FROM THE GLASGOW AIRPORT TERROR ATTACK

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 287 words


TERRORISM expert David Capitanchik said the events at Glasgow Airport were a
harsh reminder to Scots that they are not immune to terror attacks.

Mr Capitanchik, based at Aberdeen University, said the attack had made Scots
more aware.

He said: "At the time of Glasgow, there were a great number of counterterrorism
operations on the go, so the police and security services in Scotland will have
been aware we were a potential target.

"But for everyday Scots it was too easy to think we were immune to terrorist
attacks.

"There was certainly a public feeling that because we are so far away from
London, we were off the radar.

"But the airport attack changed that - I think that now people are far more
aware of what is going on around them and will report anything suspicious to the
police.

"It has probably helped the police because they would rather have a thousand
false alarms than one bomb going off.

"What was also very interesting about Glasgow is that a doctor has also
allegedly been involved.

"I am quite certain that in light of last year's attack anyone applying for jobs
in sensitive areas - such as the oil industry - from the Middle East especially
will be put under far greater scrutiny as to political views and security
background.

"Of course the Glasgow incident could have been much worse - if people had
wandered into the concourse with bombs hidden under their clothes the outcome
would have been an absolute disaster.

"Throughout the IRA bombing campaign Scotland got a bit too relaxed. Last June
was certainly a harsh lesson learned."

The Glasgow Airport terror attack came a day after police foiled a potential
double car bombing in Central London, having discovered explosives in vehicles
near Piccadilly Circus.

                              June 29, 2008 Sunday
                                Scottish Edition

Calm after the storm;
Last year's terror attack is just a memory as families pack airport en route to
the sun

BYLINE: By Paula Murray

SECTION: NEWS; 11

LENGTH: 376  words


IT was business as usual at Glasgow Airport yesterday as throngs of excited
families prepared to jet off for the first day of the school holidays.

The tranquil scene was in sharp contrast to the blind panic on the same day last
year when a burning Jeep laden with gas cylinders slammed into the crowded
terminal building.

But yesterday passed peacefully, and at 3.15pm, the exact time of impact, the
only matter appearing to trouble holidaymakers was making their flights on time.

And as Scotland prepared to mark the first anniversary of the terror attacks
tomorrow, the country's anti-terrorism czar called for parents, communities and
the authorities to work together to prevent vulnerable young people from
becoming extremists.

Allan Burnett, counter terrorism co-ordinator and Assistant Chief Constable of
Fife Constabulary, said: "One of the things we are trying is early intervention,
which we would use in other areas of behaviour to put a stop to it.

"I have no doubt that the answer to some of this will resemble what we do with
other addictions or perversions. There may be a larger religious input to it,
but religion often plays a part in helping with other addictions.

"It is all about getting them back onto a proper path. It might be about coming
face to face with a victim with something like restorative justice.

"Perhaps it would involve psychiatric help, an alternative faith message, or
just getting mum and dad to talk to them and ban them from using the computer."
He also called for parents, authorities and the wider community to work together
and trust each other in dealing with radical elements in society, admitting
prison was not always the right answer.

More attacks on the airport are also being prevented by a massive GBP 4million
security upgrade and refurbishment.

Since the atrocity, private cars and vans have been banned from getting close to
the terminal building, while temporary barriers introduced in the immediate
aftermath of the attack will be replaced by 300 steel bollards along the inner
forecourt.

The pick-up and drop-off point has been moved inside the multi-storey car park
in front of the terminal building, while a new bomb-proof, high tech security
zone called Skyhub, costing GBP 31million, will open in October.

                            Daily Post (North Wales)

                             June 30, 2008, Monday
                                 Mersey Edition

We need a fair deal for terror attack victims;
EXCLUSIVE Mersey casualty of London bombings leads drive for improved
compensation

BYLINE: ROB MERRICK Political Correspondent

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 892 words


A WIRRAL man who lost both legs in the July 7 London bombings is leading a
radical campaign to secure adequate compensation for all the "forgotten" victims
of terrorism.

Andy Brown, a facilities planner at Liverpool John Lennon Airport, will meet
Justice Secretary Jack Straw to press for a 5p-per-week levy on all taxpayers to
create an annual pounds 130m redress fund.

Father-of-three Andy, and his wife, Jan, believe such a fund would ensure future
survivors of terrorist attacks do not suffer their painful - and, so far,
unsuccessful - fight for full compensation.

The Browns asked for pounds 1.7m to reflect loss of earnings, the cost of
long-term care and of buying a new home adapted for a wheelchair user - but
compensation is capped at just pounds 500,000.

As a result, they still live in the same Victorian home in Oxton, where Andy
sleeps in the dining room because he is unable to get upstairs.

Now, in a meeting early next month, they will urge Mr Straw to look again at
their case and to explore the 5p-a-week levy, an idea devised with the help of
their Labour MP, Birkenhead's Frank Field.

Meanwhile, Jan received a personal telephone call from Gordon Brown, after she
wrote to the Prime Minister to praise his controversial Bill to detain terror
suspects for 42 days without charge.

In her first interview about the 2005 tragedy, Jan, aged 51, said: "We are
having this meeting for everybody who is a victim of a terrorist attack - not
just us.

"Everyone seems to have forgotten about the victims of the bombings and about
terrorism, which is wrong

"The injuries someone suffers when they are blown apart on a train or bus - by
someone trying to kill as many people as possible - are totally different to
having a car accident.

"Hopefully there will not be any more terrorist bombings, but I fear there
probably will be - so there needs to be a much better compensation scheme in
place."

Andy, now 52, was in London for a business conference - to discuss better
airport access for the disabled - when his lower legs were blown off by the bomb
blast at Liverpool Street Station.

He spent two months at the Royal London Hospital, before returning to Wirral
and, despite the need for constant further treatment, to his job at JLA.

Andy, described by his wife as a "very private man", declined to be interviewed,
but Jan said she felt so strongly about the issue of proper compensation that
she wanted to tell their full story.

She added: "The compensation we have received is simply not enough for the
severity of the injuries that Andy received.

"Andy really needs to be living in a purpose-built bungalow, where he can move
around, but that is very expensive to buy and something we simply can't do with
the compensation we have received.

"I had to give up work to be my husband's carer, which means I am on a pittance.
I had only just finished my degree and planned to become an art teacher if this
had not happened.

"Also there is the issue of what happens in 10 years' time. At the moment, I can
lift and move a wheelchair, but I won't always be able to do that and long-term
care is very expensive."

In his November award from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA),
Andy received pounds 111,635 for his injuries, the full amount he had claimed.

But the compensation fell woefully short for his care needs and for both his,
and Jan's, loss of earnings and pension. The scheme rules out any payment for
purpose-built accommodation, estimated to cost pounds 630,000.

The Browns have been able to put in a bathroom downstairs, but Jan added: "Andy
is still living in the dining room - three years on - because he cannot get up
the stairs.

"He is working full-time, but he still finds it very difficult. No-one can know
just how difficult it is to be disabled until they are in that situation.

"It is a problem just fitting through doorways. And, some days, Andy's skin
breaks down and he can't wear his prosthetic limbs.

"Just when you think you are over the worst of it, something else happens. We
are constantly back and forth to the limb centre at Clatterbridge hospital."

In one sense, the Browns are fortunate to have their compensation, because it
was revealed earlier this month that 70 survivors of the July 7 atrocities have
yet to receive their full payouts - despite ministerial promises to speed them
up.

There is anger that most awards are very small - some are as low as pounds 1,000
- when the victims of the September 11 terror attacks in America received
millions.

Mr Field has submitted a six page explanation of why the 5p-aweek levy on all
employers and workers is badly needed.

The MP said: "The events of 7/7 blew Britain into a horrendous new world, where
British terrorists were prepared to kill themselves and large numbers of
innocent bystanders.

"No financial compensation, however generous, can restore the lives of the
survivors to the position they were seconds before those deadly bombs exploded.

"What a civilised nation can do, however, is to introduce a compensation scheme
to enable a victim to restore as much of his or her quality of life as is
possible."

Days before the meeting with Mr Straw, Andy will - on July 7 - drive his adapted
car to London to meet with other survivors, as he has done on the previous two
anniversaries.

Jan explained: "On that day, he likes to meet with other people affected as he
was."

sufficient for the severity of her husband's injuries; One of the bomb-damaged
Circle Line subway trains, in London

Terror attack hero tells of 'crazy' year

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 168 words


A BAGGAGE handler who helped thwart a terror attack on Glasgow airport has
spoken of his 'crazy' year, as the incident's first anniversary passes today.

John Smeaton, 32, was hailed a hero after helping police tackle a man in a
blazing jeep which had been driven into the airport terminal.

Shortly after the incident, he gave a TV interview, broadcast around the world,
in which he warned: 'This is Glasgow, you know - we'll set about you.'
Reflecting on the attack, he said: 'At the exact moment in time you were not
frightened, but minutes afterwards you think, "That was quite scary".

'It is just crazy that my life has gone from one extreme to another.' Mr Smeaton
has been awarded the Queen's Gallantry Medal, one of the highest British
civilian honours for bravery.

He has met prime minister Gordon Brown several times and has been feted at the
Labour Party conference.

Mr Smeaton, who hopes to settle with his girlfriend in America, added: 'I don't
class myself as a hero. I really am just an ordinary guy.'

                             PA Newswire: Scotland

                        June 30, 2008 Monday 2:50 AM BST

BUSINESS AS USUAL ON ANNIVERSARY OF TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Hilary Duncanson, Scottish Press Association

SECTION: PA Newswire: Scotland

LENGTH: 295 words


Glasgow Airport bosses today insisted it would be business as usual on the first
anniversary of the terror attack which brought chaos to thousands of
holidaymakers.

Managing director Gordon Dewar said that while the events of June 30 2007 would
never be forgotten, the anniversary would be ``just another working day'' for
the airport's 5,000 staff.

He also praised the ``tremendous courage'' shown by workers, passengers and
members of the emergency services who were caught up in last year's events and
said it was thanks to their support that the airport was able to reopen less
than 24 hours after the attack.

``This is a matter of real pride for the staff involved,'' he said.

``However, one year on, there is no triumphalism, just a quiet determination to
get on with the job and deliver for our passengers.

``We have worked hard over the past year to repair, and refurbish, the terminal
building and there are now few visible signs of last year's attack.

``I am extremely proud of the team effort that has brought us to this point.

``The response from everyone involved in the reconstruction effort has been
superb.''

He said the airport has now been completely transformed, with £4m being spent in
the past 12 months on upgrading the terminal and forecourt, including repairs to
the areas damaged by smoke and water.

Door two - the point of impact - has been completely rebuilt.

The final phase of the investment will see 300 steel bollards being installed
along the inner forecourt, replacing the temporary barriers introduced following
the attack.

He said: ``Glasgow Airport has incurred substantial capital costs as a result of
the attack on the terminal.

``Despite this, we have worked hard to deliver improved facilities, at no cost
to our passengers, or to the taxpayer.''

It was a year ago today..and terror was on our doorstep...;
 THE PAISLEY DAILY EXPRESS LOOKS BACK AT THE OUTRAGE, FEAR AND LEGACY OF LAST
YEAR'S TERRORIST ATTACK ON GLASGOW AIRPORT It was a year ago today..and terror
was on our doorstep...

BYLINE: LYNN JOLLY

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 966 words


TERROR came to Paisley's doorstep exactly a year ago today.

And, 12 months on, the painful memories of that attack on Glasgow Airport remain
fresh in the minds of those caught up in the carnage.

Hero firemen, police, airport staff and ordinary holidaymakers were among those
who ignored the risk to their own safety in order to prevent innocent lives
being lost after a blazing Jeep was driven into the main terminal building.

The shocking events that took place at 3.15pm on Saturday, June 30 - and the
incredible twists and turns that followed as police investigated the airport
attack - rocked Paisley to its very foundations.

For most people in the town, terrorism had been a nightmare experienced only by
others on TV screens - but, that day, it was way too close to home for comfort.

The terrifying events brought the message home to locals that, in this dangerous
world we now all share, Paisley has become a target.

Firefighters from Paisley and Renfrew had arrived at the blazing terminal within
minutes of 999 calls coming in from terrified airport staff and holidaymakers.

Initially, the emergency services thought they were dealing with a
run-of-the-mill car accident but it quickly became apparent this was something
more sinister.

Off-duty police officer John Mullen was in the airport bar above the check-in
area with his wife Lorna, 36, and kids Sorcha, eight, and Eve, five, when the
attack took place.

They had been looking forward to a family holiday in Palma and were chilling out
ahead of their flight when all hell broke loose.

John, from Johnstone, said they could all see the Jeep Cherokee and a man
engulfed by flames below them as they dashed across the walkway to safety.

A year on, he told the Paisley Daily Express: "That was to be the children's
first holiday abroad and they were really excited about it but I guess you could
say that things didn't quite go according to plan.

"The kids could see the car and the guy on fire as we went over the walkway. It
was really upsetting for them.

"We headed outside to the Holiday Inn and had a coffee there. The kids were
crying. They were terrified."

Confused John said that, as it was the start of the school holidays, there were
lots of families around - and everyone was confused and upset.

"I heard a thump, thump, sound initially and thought it was suitcases down at
check-in," recalled 35-year-old John. "Then the alarm went off and we were told
to evacuate. That was when I heard screaming and people started running.

"I grabbed my wife and kids and went across the walkway. I decided not to head
downstairs because the stairs were a total bottleneck.

"When we got to the hotel, I tried to keep the kids' backs to the TV because Sky
News were covering the incident.

"I've seen all sorts of things in my days as a policeman, so seeing the man on
fire didn't shock me, but Lorna was upset because the kids were so scared.

"Even now, Sorcha won't go near the airport but Eve is OK about it.

"I just tell Sorcha that a silly man took a wrong turn and crashed his car into
the airport."

The Mullen family were able to fly to Spain from Prestwick Airport the following
night and were determined to enjoy their sunshine holiday - despite their
terrifying ordeal.

They were among thousands of people caught up in the drama of June 30 last year.

Also at the airport that day as they waited to board a holiday flight to Cyprus
were Johnstone couple Ian and Eileen Pennie.

They would have been just yards from the Jeep when it smashed into the terminal
doors if it hadn't been for a birthday present Eileen had bought for her
husband.

Under normal circumstances, the couple would have been at the check-in desks at
3.15pm - the exact time when the burning vehicle ploughed into the terminal
building.

But they escaped the worst of the carnage as Eileen had bought Ian tickets for
the airport's executive lounge as a birthday gift, meaning they had checked in
earlier than usual.

A year later, the dreadful events of that day are still clear in Eileen's mind.

She said: "The memories are still fresh. The black cloud of smoke was the most
dramatic thing for us.

"It was a giant cloud that came rolling towards us and, at first, I thought it
was a fire but I overheard staff saying there had been an attack on the airport.

"It was all very frightening and nobody could believe it. It was a horrible day
- very cold and wet - and, when we got outside the terminal building, we stood
in a shelter.

"Someone there said they thought a man had suffered a heart attack at the wheel
of his car and ended up crashing into the terminal. When I said I'd heard it was
a terror attack, nobody believed me."

Eileen describes the experience as "very surreal" and is only too aware that she
had a lucky escape.

But she said: "It hasn't put me off flying. You can't live your life like that.
You just have to get on with it."

The airport attack wasn't the end of the drama for Paisley people.

In the days that followed, there were a number of bomb scares that left folk in
the town nervous and on edge.

Bomb disposal squads raced to Paisley's Royal Alexandra Hospital, as well as the
Lagoon leisure centre, but the alerts turned out to be false alarms.

Kafeel Ahmed, 27, who was one of the men in the Jeep that crashed into the
airport, died of severe burns in hospital several weeks after being injured in
the attack.

Earlier this month, two NHS doctors pleaded not guilty in court to plotting to
explode car bombs in London and at Glasgow Airport.

Iraqi Bilal Abdullah, 28, who worked at the RAH, and Mohammed Asha, 27, appeared
at the Old Bailey by video link.

They are accused of conspiracy to murder and to cause explosions between January
1, 2006, and July 1, last year.

The two men deny the charges.

We must be so vigilant warns MP;
 THE PAISLEY DAILY EXPRESS LOOKS BACK AT THE OUTRAGE, FEAR AND LEGACY OF LAST
YEAR'S TERRORIST ATTACK ON GLASGOW AIRPORT We must be so vigilant warns MP

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 294 words


CONCERNED politician Jim Sheridan last night warned the people of Paisley they
must still be "on their toes" when it comes to security issues.

The MP for Paisley and Renfrewshire North has tabled a Parliamentary motion at
the House of Commons to honour everyone who responded so courageously to the
airport attack on June 30 last year.

So far, more than 50 MPs from various political parties have signed Mr
Sheridan's Early Day Motion to state that 'This House honours the staff,
passengers and emerg ency service personnel who responded to the attack on
Glasgow Airport on June 30, 2007, with bravery and compassion; welcomes the
significant capital investment and customer service improvements made by BAA
since the attack and congratulates the hard working security and customer
service staff at all UK airports for their commitment and professionalism."

Mr Sheridan told the Paisley Daily Express it is vital for ordinary people to
recognise the important role safety and security staff play at airports.

He said: "I want to remind people that, unfortunately, there are people out
there who want to destroy our way of life and that these incidents can happen
anywhere in the UK.

"We need to keep on our toes in terms of security.

"I also want to recognise the airport staff who live with this threat every day.
Most of us only go through the airport on an occasional basis - the people who
work at the airport have to face this threat every day they go to work.

"I want to give thanks to them for looking after our safety and security and the
professional way they do it.

"There were a lot of people involved in keeping us safe that day - ordinary
citizens and professionals - so I submitted the Parliamentary motion to
recognise that and thank them."

Glasgow Airport 'is fighting back';
 THE PAISLEY DAILY EXPRESS LOOKS BACK AT THE OUTRAGE, FEAR AND LEGACY OF LAST
YEAR'S TERRORIST ATTACK ON GLASGOW AIRPORT Glasgow Airport 'is fighting back'

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 505 words


BOSSES at Glasgow Airport have compared their recovery from the June 30 attack
with the mythical phoenix rising from the flames.

One year on, the airport has been given a pounds 4million upgrade, the pounds
31million Skyhub development is bang on schedule and it is business as usual for
the 5,000 workers there.

Managing director Gordon Dewar said that, although thousands of innocent
holidaymakers had to suffer chaos, the airport has been completely transfor med.

Mr Dewar thanked staff for their efforts as he said: "Today marks the first
anniversary of the terror attack but, for the 5,000 staff who work here, it is
just another working day.

"While we will never forget the events of June 30, 2007, or the tremendous
courage of our staff, passengers and emergency services, it is thanks to their
support that we were able to re-open the airport less than 24 hours after the
attack.

"This is a matter of real pride for the staff involved.

However, one year on, there is no triumphalism - just a quiet determination to
get on with the job and deliver for our passengers.

"Glasgow Airport has incurred substantial capital costs as a result of the
attack on the terminal. Despite this, we have worked hard to deliver improved
facilities at no cost to our passengers or to the taxpayer."

He believes that, since June 30 last year, the airport has "emerged from the
flames" thanks to the multi-million pound upgrade of the terminal and forecourt,
including repairs to the external structure and interior areas damaged by smoke
and water.

The point of impact during the attack - Door 2 - has been completely rebuilt.

New access arrangements have also been kick-started, with people no longer able
to pick up and drop off friends and family directly in front of the main ter
minal.

Instead, drivers can set down and collect passengers for free opposite the
terminal building at car park 2.

Over 150 parking spaces were removed to make way for the new drop-off and
pick-up area and St Andrew's Drive - the airport's secondary drop-off point -
has also been upgraded.

The final phase of the forecourt investment will see 300 steel bollards
installed along the inner forecourt, replacing the temporary barriers introduced
following the attack.

The first phase of the Skyhub terminal extension - a new two-storey domestic
arrivals hall with purpose-built security - will open on October 21.

Mr Dewar added: "We have worked hard over the past year to repair and refurbish
the terminal building and there are now few visible signs of last year's attack
.

"We are also grateful to our passengers for the patience they have shown over
the past year as we carried out these repairs. The good news is that the work is
almost complete.

"This week is one of the busiest of the year at Glasgow Airport, with thousands
of families flying out for their summer holidays and thousands more arriving in
Scotland from overseas.

"We wish them all a warm welcome and enjoyable trip and thank them for
supporting their local airport."

Farewell flight leads to terror attack fears

BYLINE: Graeme Baker

SECTION: NEWS; International; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 232 words


OFFICE workers feared they were under attack by terrorists yesterday as a
passenger aircraft swooped low over Sydney city centre followed by a fighter
jet.

Offices emptied as the aircraft, apparently losing altitude and with smoke
billowing from its fuselage, flew across the city's harbour area.

The flight was a "farewell'' for one of the Royal Australian Air Force's ageing
aircraft. Unfortunately, the military had failed to inform the

public.

The Boeing 707 made a circuit of the central business district and the harbour,
escorted by a Hawk 127 fighter.

Steven Gunther said he had run out of his office, fearing an attack. "I wasn't
the only one. There were some scared and bewildered people on the streets,'' he
said.

Phillipa Kelly, who works near the harbour, said the noise of the planes stopped
work at her office.

"It came very close to the building and we all stopped and said: 'Oh my God!
What was that noise?'

"There's this big passenger plane that has come very close to our building, and
it has a fighter plane following it.''

Raveena Carroll-Kenney, a spokesman for the government, said office workers had
no cause for alarm.

But Mr Gunther said: "To think that seeing a Boeing 707 being tailed by a
fighter jet flying at low altitude ... wasn't going to cause concern is
deplorable.

"In this age of terrorism the defence force should have known better. I have
never felt quite so scared.''

                         The Evening Standard (London)

                             July 2, 2008 Wednesday

Bulldozer in Jerusalem terror attack

BYLINE: ED HARRIS

SECTION: B; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 304 words


A PALESTINIAN man drove a bulldozer into buses and cars in a Jerusalem street
today, killing three people and injuring at least 40 more, before he was shot
dead by a soldier who climbed onto the vehicle.

The rampage caused panic in the city centre as the man used the bulldozer's
shovel to overturn one crowded bus and hit another, ripping it open down one
side.

Two cars were flattened and at least three other vehicles were damaged,
including a van which had its entire front crushed. Hundreds of people fled as
medics treated the wounded.

Eyal Lang Ben-Hur, 16, was on one of the buses in Jaffa Road when the driver
yelled: "Get out of the vehicle. Everyone out." Yosef Spielman said the
bulldozer picked up a car "like a toy", adding: "I was shocked. I saw a guy
going crazy. All the people were running, they had no chance." Student Yaakov
Ashkenazi, 18, said: "I saw the bulldozer smash the car with its shovel.

He smashed the guy sitting in the driver's seat." The carnage ended only when an
offduty soldier killed the man by shooting him in the head several times at
pointblank range, leaving him slumped over the steering wheel.

In a statement, police said a "terrorist" had carried out the attack but gave no
further details.

It was the first Arab attack in Jewish west Jerusalem since a gunman killed
eight students in a religious school in March.

The city's mayor, Uri Lupolianski, said his daughter was on one of the buses
rammed by the attacker but was not injured.

He said: "To our regret the attackers do not cease coming up with new ways to
strike at the heart of the Jewish people here in Jerusalem." The attack occurred
in an area where Jerusalem is building a new railway. The project has turned
many parts of the city into a construction zone. Palestinian workers are a
familiar sight on highway projects in Israel..
