                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                             July 2, 2008 Wednesday

Imports threat to food safety;
British food supplies could be at risk in the event of a terrorist attack
because the country has become too reliant on foreign imports, it was claimed
last night.

BYLINE: Matt Chorley London Editor

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 805 words


Former agriculture minister Angela Browning accused the Government of allowing
the proportion of homegrown food to tumble in the last decade, leaving the UK
more exposed to threats at home and overseas.

Terrorists could cause widespread disruption and potentially large numbers of
fatalities by polluting water supplies, destroying crops, poisoning foodstuffs
or cutting off the supply of imports, she said.

Mrs Browning, the Tory MP for Tiverton and Honiton, called for more creative
planning to ensure the nation has enough to eat, including a major drive to
encourage gardeners to feed themselves from allotments.

"We are an island nation and if we had a form of horrendous disaster we would
probably be dependent on in-coming food and that is a dangerous position to be
in," she said.

Mrs Browning, a minister in the Major government of  1994-1997, warned against
Britain becoming "dependent on other countries for certain staple crops" to the
same extent as the control Russia now wields over the nation's gas supply.

She added: "On a very small scale, I would like to see more people growing  food
on allotments. It's what my generation used to do as the norm."

The Tories point to figures which show of the food which could be grown in
Britain, the amount produced here has fallen from 81.8 per cent in 1997 to only
73.9 per cent last year. Shadow farming minister Jim Paice said it was
"laughable the Government claims we are somehow doing OK because we are doing
better than we were in the 1950s".

And the National Farmers' Union has said the industry has an "economic duty to
the citizens of Britain to optimise our production of food and bio-energy, so as
to secure their supplies". Such efforts could also help to keep soaring prices
in check, it added.

However, ministers insist the nation's food supply chain is resilient to the
threat of terrorist attacks, precisely because of the varied sources we buy
from.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs said that if a particular
link in the chain were  disrupted, other suppliers could step in and ensure
there was food on the table.

"The terrorist threat to the UK, including the threat to the food chain, is
monitored very closely by the Government and we and the industry remain
vigilant," a source told the WMN.

Ministers were forced to step in and give the public reassurance after it
emerged in a Commons debate this week that  former Environment Secretary
Margaret Beckett rejected calls from her own officials to consider how Britain
could feed itself in the wake of the 2001 terrorist attacks in New York. Civil
servants were told by Mrs Beckett that Britain's ability to provide enough food
for itself was not a "driving consideration".

Mrs Browning said this was "shocking", adding: "We know that areas of the
country could potentially be contaminated if they use some chemical pollutant
either in the drinking water supply or in the air. It is outrageous that was not
considered important after 9/11."

The attitude of ministers to the potential impact of a terror attack emerged in
a Commons debate on food security.

The Government admits although Britain has roughly the same levels of milk and
cereal production as 30 years ago, self-sufficiency in vegetables has fallen by
three-quarters to less than two thirds while imports have risen sharply.

But Environment Secretary Hilary Benn insisted: "Domestic production is
necessary for food security but it is not on its own sufficient. We export as
well as import food, and there are of course some things that we cannot possibly
grow ourselves that we need to buy."

However, Mr Benn appeared baffled by the revelation that his predecessor had not
considered the threat of terrorism to food supplies to be sufficiently serious.

Sir Brian Bender, the former top civil servant at Defra, told the Public
Accounts Committee the terror attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon
in September 2001 came as the finishing touches were put to the UK's Sustainable
Farming and Food Strategy.

He said the issue of Britain being self-sufficient in its food supply was "put
specifically to our ministers" because the attacks made it a "germane question".

"The direct answer to the question put to ministers 'should this be a
consideration?' in the run-up to publication of that document was 'no'," he
said.

However, particularly under Mr Benn's watch in the last 12 months, more focus
has been put on ensuring people have enough to eat and drink, even if terrorists
were to strike.

The Centre for the Protection of National Infrastructure advises people to
"review the security of your food and drink supply chains" in the event of an
attack. The department heads  the Food Chain Emergency Liaison Group (FCELG)
which meets every six months to discuss issues of concern to the food industry
in the event of an attack.

Terrorist Is Attacked In Fighting At North Jail

SECTION: Pg. 13

LENGTH: 336 words


FOUR prison officers were injured in violence between inmates and Muslim
prisoners at a high-security jail. Fighting broke out at HMP Frankland in Durham
after a cell was set alight and three prisoners attacked another inmate.

It is believed the cell was that of convicted al-Qaida terrorist Kamel Bourgass,
who is serving life for the murder of Special Branch detective Stephen Oake, 40.
The 34-year-old Algerian escaped injury in the blaze.

A British prisoner was slashed across the face with a home-made knife in
retaliation, it was reported.

Prison officers attempted to break up the brawl and several were injured as
fighting inmates turned on them. One suffered a broken arm.

The officers were praised for their bravery in stopping the brawl escalating.

A Prison Service spokeswoman confirmed there had been a cell fire and fighting
between prisoners at the jail. She said the fight had not been a riot.

She said: "We can confirm that an incident took place at 12pm on June 27 in
Frankland Prison.

"A fire was discovered in a cell. The incident was dealt with quickly, with no
injuries to staff or prisoners. We can confirm an incident took place in
Frankland prison at 5pm on Friday, June 27, when three prisoners assaulted
another prisoner.

"Due to staff's swift and courageous response, the incident was quickly
resolved. Four members of staff and two prisoners required hospital treatment.

"The matter has been referred to the police for investigation."

A Durham Police spokesman said: "Detectives from this force are investigating a
fracas among inmates at Frankland Prison, Durham, early last Friday evening.

"During the disturbance, one inmate was slashed across the face and another was
punched and kicked.

"A number of prison officers who intervened were injured, one suffering a broken
arm.

"Our inquiries into the incident are yet to be completed."

Prison Officers' Association spokesman Steve Cox said: "There is an ongoing
problem at Frankland borne out of terrorist prisoners being housed with other
prisoners."

LENGTH: 611 words


Text of report by Khaled Attaoui headlined: "Al-Qa'idah was preparing for a
bloody summer in Morocco. The search is still on for terrorists' leader Abu
Makhlouf, and terrorist preparations have reached the stage of pinpointing
targets", published by Moroccan privately-owned newspaper Assabah website on 4
July

Informed sources have revealed that the security services have been on a race
with time to arrest more than 20 accused, suspected of links to Al-Qa'idah and
of planning for terrorist operations in the summer.

The same sources say that preliminary investigations of a network members,
accused of recruiting and mobilizing Moroccan nationals to fight in Al-Qa'idah
ranks in Iraq and in Algeria have yielded grave information, including one to
the effect that Abu Makhlouf, who is the coordinator of the terrorist groups and
who is still on the run, has made arrangements with an Algerian terrorist to
resurrect terror cells in several towns.

The same sources describe Abu Makhlouf as the brain behind the recruiting of
terrorist elements. He travels between several Moroccan towns to recruit new
volunteers, and his movements have now covered towns which, until recently, were
out of reach to extremist organizations, such as El Hajeb and Taourirt, in
addition to other towns like Fes, Tetouan, Larayech and Oujda.

The same sources add that the setting up of the terrorist organization started
immediately after the return of some Moroccans from the fight on the side of
Al-Qa'idah in Iraq, that instructions had been given by leaders of the
international organization that the suicide bombers should return to their
respective countries of origin, and that international intelligence cooperation
has succeeded in getting the names of the returnees in question, who have been
given the task of setting up new cells to mobilize the already recruited
elements to fight in Iraq, in Algeria, in Morocco, in Turkey, in Syria and in
Lebanon.

The same sources point out that the members of the terrorist organization have
allocated roles to each of them, in a very meticulous way. One of them was
charged with recruiting those who wanted to fight in Algeria and others in Iraq.
It is estimated that he has been able to recruit about 33 persons.

The sources further say that the accused have travelled to several Moroccan
towns, following a plan not draw the attention of the security services and to
impede the latter's monitoring of their movements.

The same sources stress that the security services had been on the track of the
leaders of the organization for several months before the secret services
captured most of the members of the organization, while the search is still on
for the rest.

The same sources reveal also that the leaders of the terrorist cell were waiting
for the green light from the leaders of al-Qa'idah organization abroad to launch
bombing operations in Morocco, and that preparations for the attacks had reached
the stage of pinpointing targets. The terrorist leaders also received important
logistical means, including financial support.

The sources also say that the returnees from Iraq are considered as a corner
stone in the recently-set up cell because they have received training there, and
they have been trained also in Morocco, in preparation for terrorist operations
in the summer.

The same sources admit that the brain behind these moves, nicknamed Abu
Makhlouf, has made several trips to southern Morocco, and he has travelled also
to Mali and to Mauritania in order to coordinate action with the leaders of [the
Algeria-based] Al-Qa'idah in the Land of the Islamic Maghreb [AQLIM].

LENGTH: 379 words


Text of report in English by influential Indonesian newspaper The Jakarta Post

[Unattributed report from the "Headlines" page: "Capital warned of possible
terrorist attacks"]

Jakarta Governor Fauzi Bowo has warned residents in the capital of possible
terrorist attacks following the arrests of 10 terror suspects in South Sumatra.

He also asked residents to help authorities by sharing information of any
suspicious activities in their neighbourhoods.

"All citizens should stay alert because the arrests made in Palembang (South
Sumatra's capital) were based on information from residents there. They must
strengthen their security through routine neighbourhood security system
activities," he said Friday at City Hall.

"Hotel security guards must watch over their work environment and residents
watch over their neighbours, while a landlord should know well who stays in his
or her property because bombs can be made in houses or in a hotel room."

Early discovery, he said, was the most effective form of prevention.

A senior police officer at the National Police on Thursday told Koran Tempo
newspaper that the Palembang suspects were planning to "attack places where
there are many foreigners".

Jakarta is home to many embassies and expatriates, and has fallen victim to
terrorist bombings targeting places frequented by foreigners.

Chief executive officer of upscale mall Senayan City in South Jakarta, Handaka
Santoso, said the mall management would increase the number of patrolling
officers to meet any terrorist threat.

"We'll check every mall visitor more carefully in addition to our regular
security checks," he told The Jakarta Post on Friday.

Public relations officer of Taman Anggrek Mall in West Jakarta, Anastasia
Damastuti, said the mall management was always alert to threats. "This is not
the first time we've heard of the possibility of bombings."

Hotel Mulia communications manager Adeza Hamzah said the hotel in Senayan,
Central Jakarta, would stick to the standards of maximum security it always
applied.

Communications director of Shangri-La Hotel in Central Jakarta, Ratna Sjamsiar
Idris, refused to comment on her hotel's security pertaining to terrorism
prevention.

senior official said. "There have been times when there was nothing left in the
locker, when all of our assets were being used on one operation. At the same
time, we have to contend with the very real threat being posed by the
Russians.''

killer of Alexander Litvinenko should face justice in a British court, according
to a letter from David Miliband, the Foreign Secretary, to Mr Litvinenko's
widow, Marina.

Mr Litvinenko, 44, died in 2006 after being poisoned at a London hotel. Russia
has refused to extradite Andrei Lugovoi, a former KGB agent suspected of the
killing.

                              City Centre Edition

Silent tears for victims;
TRIBUTE: London remembers bomb terror attacks

BYLINE: Gary Marks

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 328 words


COMMUTERS and survivors stood shoulder to shoulder with the families of victims
today to mark the third anniversary of the London bombings.

Hundreds of people crowded into King's Cross station to remember the 52 innocent
people who were killed when four blasts ripped through London's public transport
network.

London mayor Boris Johnson joined Tessa Jowell, the Government minister for the
capital, and transport chiefs at the ceremony.

They laid flowers outside the station at 8.50am, the time when the first three
bombs went off.

The pavements around King's Cross, from where the four suicide bombers set off
on their terror campaign, were crammed with commuters as passers-by stopped to
pay their respects.

Relatives of victims and survivors also made personal pilgrimages to the sites
of the four blasts - Russell Square, Aldgate and Edgware Road Tube stations, and
Tavistock Square.

Heroes who helped in the aftermath of the Edgware Road bombing united with
relatives of victims to pay their respects.

Seven people were killed and 163 injured when Mohammad Sidique Khan detonated a
bomb in the second carriage of a westbound Circle line train at Edgware Road.

Survivor Jacqui Putnam, 57, said: "I return every year to lay flowers. It's very
important for me to be here.

"I was in the first carriage and the bomb went off in the second carriage. I
suffered concussion.

We were trapped for a while, I don't know how long but it felt like days.

When we evacuated the train, we had to go past the second carriage, past the
worst of the damage."

Tim Coulson, 53, was awarded a medal by the Royal Humane Society earlier this
year in recognition of his bravery on July 7.

He said: "My train stopped parallel to the attacked train. I broke a window to
get out of the train to get to the cries of human suffering.

"I was there for the end of a life of one passenger. It was important for me for
the family to know that he had not died alone."

A minute's silence was observed at the station.

                            Daily Post (North Wales)

                              July 7, 2008, Monday
                                 Mersey Edition

London recalls 'numbing legacy' of 7/7 terror attacks;
Survivors and relatives gather to remember

BYLINE: SAM MARSDEN Daily Post Correspondent

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 593 words


THREE years after four bombs ripped through London's public transport network,
killing 52 innocent people, survivors and relatives of victims will remember the
attacks tomorrow.

The third anniversary of the July 7, 2005, attacks will be marked with a low-key
ceremony at the railway station where the four suicide bombers set out on their
mission of terror.

London Mayor Boris Johnson will join Tessa Jowell, the Government minister for
the capital, and transport chiefs to lay flowers outside King's Cross station at
8.50am, the time when the first three bombs went off.

Many people will make personal pilgrimages to the sites of the four blasts -
Russell Square, Aldgate and Edgware Road Tube stations, and Tavistock Square.

There will also be a private meeting for survivors and families of victims who
want to share their memories and reflections.

Many of those caught up in the bombings did not want to talk about the
anniversary, saying they were trying to put what happened behind them.

Ra Babbra, 31, is using the occasion to premiere a film he has made about his
ex-girlfriend and best friend, business analyst Benedetta Ciaccia, 30, who was
killed in the Aldgate blast.

He hopes the 40-minute documentary - called 7/7: Life Without Benedetta - will
bring home to people what it meant to lose a loved one so violently.

Mr Babbra, from south London, said: "I wanted to make viewers realise these
aren't other people-this happened to people just like them.

"The fact that it didn't happen to them is more about luck than anything."

He admitted the first anniversary of the attacks was "extremely difficult" but
said it had got easier with time.

"This year, the actual anniversary doesn't mean the same to me personally," he
said.

"I want Benedetta's death not to become something that drags me down, but
something that brings the strength to make a difference and make a change in how
we are."

He will screen his film to a select group of the public tomorrow, after which he
hopes to sell it to film festivals to raise money for a charity in Ms Ciaccia's
name.

Suicide bombers Mohammad Sidique Khan, 30, Shehzad Tanweer, 22, Hasib Hussain,
18, and Jermaine Lindsay, 19, met at Luton station on the morning of the
attacks.

They took a train to King's Cross, then hugged and separated to carry out their
missions.

Within three minutes of 8.50am, Tanweer detonated his bomb at Liverpool Street,
Khan set his device off at Edgware Road, and Lindsay blew himself up between
King's Cross and Russell Square.

Hussain detonated his device onboard the Number 30 bus at Tavistock Square at
9.47am.

As well as killing themselves and 52 others, the bombers injured more than 700
people.

London returned to normal but the attacks left a legacy of physical and
psychological damage among those affected.

Concerns have also been raised about delays in paying compensation to victims of
the atrocities - which Mr Johnson has described as "unacceptable".

Three years on from the bombings, 73 out of a total of 647 claims are still
ongoing, and some of those injured have not received any money at all. Some
survivors have complained that the compensation system is overly bureaucratic.

Mr Johnson wrote to Ms Jowell calling on the Government to tackle the backlog
immediately

The Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority (CICA) said it had paid out nearly
pounds 7.5m to victims and relatives of those caught up in the bombings.

Some 89% of the claims have been fully resolved and 96% of those eligible have
received either a full or interim payment.

Concern over delays in payouts for victims

MP urges us all to dig for victory in war on terror;
British food supplies could be at risk in the event of a terrorist attack
because the country has become too reliant on foreign imports, says a local Tory

SECTION: Pg. 24

LENGTH: 376 words

New Zealand on global food production. British food production is back on the
radar."

A spokesman for the South West NFU, Ian Johnson, described Mrs Browning's
comments as "spot-on".

                                BreakingNews.ie

                      July 9, 2008 Wednesday 07:30 PM GMT

Six killed in terror attack on US consulate in Turkey

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 579 words


Armed men opened fire today on Turkish police guarding the front entrance to the
US consulate in Istanbul, killing three policemen in what Turkish and US
officials called a terrorist attack. Three assailants were also reported killed.

The US ambassador to Turkey, Ross Wilson, and Turkey's foreign ministry said
security around all US diplomatic missions in Turkey was immediately increased
after the attack, which began about 11am on the high-walled compound in the
Istinye district.

All US consulate staff were safe and accounted for, Mr Wilson said.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack. Interior Minister
Besir Atalay said police would not reveal the identities of the slain attackers
or their possible affiliations for the sake of the investigation.

Footage from a security camera at the site showed four armed and bearded men
emerging from a grey car to kill a traffic policeman, then running toward the
guardpost 50 yards away as other policemen fired back, the Dogan news agency
reported.

The shootout caused panic and scattered people waiting in visa queue, Dogan
said. US security personnel then ducked inside the compound since they are not
authorised to engage in armed action on Turkish soil.

Three of the attackers were killed in the shootout, US and Turkish officials
said. The video showed a fourth attacker jumping into the speeding grey vehicle
and fleeing, Dogan reported.

Police are pursuing an unknown number of attackers who escaped.

Istanbul prosecutor Aykut Cengiz Engin said the attackers were armed with
pistols and shotguns. Forensic teams later examined a shotgun on the ground.

Television footage showed four people lying on the ground at the foot of the
consulate's wall. The bodies were later removed.

"There is no doubt that this is a terrorist attack," Istanbul Governor Muammer
Guler told reporters at the scene, calling the three slain policemen martyrs.
Two other people, a policeman and a truck driver, were injured, he said.

Yavuz Erkut Yuksel, a bystander, told CNN-Turk television the gunmen surprised
the guard.

"One of them approached a policeman while hiding his gun and shot him in the
head," Mr Yuksel said.

Mr Guler said two of the attackers were Turkish, denying speculation that they
had Syrian passports.

The US ambassador refused to speculate on the identity of the attackers but
stressed that the US and Turkey would keep working together against terrorism.

"It is, of course, inappropriate now to speculate on who may have done this or
why. It is an obvious act of terrorism," Mr Wilson said. "Our countries will
stand together and confront this, as we have in the past."

He also praised Turkish police for responding quickly to the attack.

The secure US consulate building was built after homegrown Islamic militants
linked to al Qaida carried out suicide bombings in 2003 that targeted two
synagogues, the British Consulate and a British bank in Istanbul. Those attacks
killed 58 people.

Some of those suicide attackers had trained in al Qaida camps in Afghanistan.
CNN-Turk television reported that some of Wednesday's attackers had travelled to
Afghanistan previously, but police would not confirm the report.

Dogan identified one of the attackers as 26-year-old Erkan Kirgiz from the
south-eastern city of Bitlis. Police would not confirm the report.

The consulate occupies an imposing structure on a hill in Istinye, a densely
residential neighbourhood along the Bosporus Strait on the European side of
Istanbul.

United Nations: Security Council Press Statement On Terrorist Attacks In
Pakistan

LENGTH: 358 words


RDATE:08072008

The following Security Council press statement on the Pakistan terrorist attacks
was read out today by Council President Le Luong Minh ( Viet Nam):

The members of the Security Council condemned in the strongest terms the
terrorist suicide attack that occurred in Islamabad on 6 July, causing numerous
deaths among Pakistani civilians and police personnel, as well as numerous
injuries. The members of the Security Council also condemned in the strongest
terms the series of terrorist attacks that occurred in parts of Karachi on 7
July, causing multiple casualties.

The members of the Security Council expressed their condolences to the families
of the victims, as well as to the people and the Government of Pakistan.

The members of the Security Council underlined the need to bring perpetrators,
organizers, financiers and sponsors of this reprehensible act of terrorism to
justice, and urged all States, in accordance with their obligations under
international law and relevant Security Council resolutions, to cooperate
actively with the Pakistan authorities in this regard.

The members of the Security Council reiterated their concern at the threats
posed by the Taliban, Al-Qaida and illegal armed groups to peace and security in
the region.

The members of the Security Council reaffirmed the need to combat by all means,
in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations, threats to international
peace and security caused by terrorist acts. The members of the Security Council
reminded States that they must ensure that measures taken to combat terrorism
comply with all their obligations under international law, in particular
international human rights, refugee and humanitarian law.

The members of the Security Council reiterated their determination to combat all
forms of terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the Charter of
the United Nations.

Detica Group plc: Detica announces development of first 40Gbit/s StreamShield
cybersecurity sensors for large telecommunications operators and ISPs; Advanced
technology for securing the online environment against disruptive attacks from
terrorists and organised criminals

LENGTH: 786 words


RDATE:09072008

LONDON -- Detica Group plc (DCA.L), the business and technology consultancy,
today announces its plans to develop 40Gbit/s StreamShield cybersecurity sensors
for securing the online environment against disruptive attacks from terrorists
and organised criminals. Detica will be one of the first companies to offer this
high-speed cybersecurity capability to the telecommunications market.

Detica's new 40Gbit/s interface card for the StreamShield DCI-90 platform will
expand its current 10Gbit/s and 1Gbit/s StreamShield threat detection and
mitigation products. The DCI-90 provides the industry's most comprehensive deep
packet inspection capabilities, complementing the gigabit level streams-based
security provided by the CSG 3100. Detica expects to make the 40Gbit/s
Streamshield sensors commercially available in 2009.

Joel Bagnal, until recently Deputy Assistant to President George W. Bush for
Homeland Security and now Executive Vice President at Detica, says: "Securing
the world's information infrastructure from Internet-based threats is one of the
principal challenges today for both homeland security and telecoms operators.
StreamShield solutions such as the DCI-90 and the CSG-3100 will be critical to
securing the online environment against attacks being mounted by both terrorists
and organised criminals."

With the continued explosion in Internet traffic volumes, 40Gbit/s is rapidly
being deployed at the core of some of the world's largest ISPs and Detica is
committed to maintaining its lead at the forefront of high speed network
cybersecurity solutions.

Following the integration of the StreamShield business into Detica, the entire
StreamShield product line  incorporating DCI-90 high speed sensors and the
market-leading CSG 3100 platform for detection and mitigation of malicious
Internet content  will now be enhanced to provide 40Gbit/s interfaces to the
DCI-90.

Commenting on the announcement, Simon Reay, Vice President of StreamShield
Sales, says: "We are committed to developing the 40 Gbit/s sensors in response
to strong demand from the telecommunications and ISP market. Detica will be one
of the first companies to offer this kind of high speed cybersecurity capability
which we believe will play a key role in securing the online environment against
those who threaten the security of the state, the safety of the public, or who
seek to commit serious and organised crime."

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                             July 10, 2008 Thursday

Terrorists kill three policemen in attack on US consulate in Turkey

BYLINE: Graeme Baker

SECTION: NEWS; International; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 408  words


GUNMEN launched a raid on the American consulate in Istanbul yesterday, killing
three police officers before being shot dead themselves in a fierce gun battle.

In what Turkish and US officials condemned as a "terrorist attack'', three men
stormed a police post near the main entrance to the heavily fortified compound,
reportedly shooting the lone guard in the head. A gun battle then erupted as
Turkish police returned fire.

The attack ended with the deaths of three gunmen and two more officers. A fourth
assailant escaped in a vehicle which police said may have been laden with
explosives.

Two other people - a policeman and the civilian driver of a police truck - were
injured, said Muammer Guler, the Istanbul governor.

Witnesses said the battle began around 11am and raged for at least eight minutes
as the assailants apparently tried to gain access to the consulate.

Television images showed bodies lying on the pavement, surrounded by trails of
blood and weapons. Police said they had recovered shotguns, rifles and handguns.

The police post was outside the consulate's main public entrance, from which
steep steps lead up to the fortified building. A witness, Yavuz Erkut Yuksel,
said the attackers emerged from a white vehicle and surprised the officer at the
guard post.

"One of them approached a policeman while hiding his gun and shot him in the
head,'' he said.

Another witness described the attackers as "terrorists, with beards and long
hair''.

Enis Yilmaz, who was visiting the consulate for a visa, said: "There were four
people. Three of them got out of the car and fired at the police. I saw them
dead afterwards lying on the ground and many more dead among the police.''

Turkey has been targeted by a variety of groups in recent years, including
Kurdish separatists and Islamist militants.

No one has claimed responsibility for the attack. However, suspicion immediately
fell on Islamist militants who have launched a number of raids and bomb attacks
in recent years. The US consulate building was moved and fortified after
home-grown Islamists linked to al-Qa'eda bombed two synagogues, the British
Consulate and a British bank in Istanbul in November 2003, killing 58 people.

Abdullah Gul, President of  Turkey, said: "I strongly condemn such terrorist

acts. Turkey will fight to the end against those who are behind them.''

The attack was "an obvious act of terrorism'' aimed at America, the US
ambassador to Turkey, Ross Wilson, said.

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                       July 10, 2008 Thursday 2:09 PM BST

'DAFT AND DANGEROUS' TERROR DETENTION PLAN ATTACKED

BYLINE: David Hughes, PA Chief Parliamentary Reporter

SECTION: PARLIAMENTARY NEWS

LENGTH: 226 words


The Government was today urged to back down over plans to extend the terror
detention limit to 42 days after the ``monstering'' the proposals received from
former MI5 chief Baroness Manningham-Buller.

In Lords debate on the Counter-Terrorism Bill this week, the peer said the
proposals were unworkable in practice or principle.

In the Commons today, the SNP's Pete Wishart called on ministers to scrap the
legislation to extend the pre-charge time period beyond 28 days.

The controversial measure scraped through the Commons with the Government's
majority slashed to just nine votes in one of the stiffest tests of Gordon
Brown's authority.

In questions on future business, Mr Wishart (Perth and N Perthshire) said MPs
were looking forward to the Bill returning ``especially after the monstering it
received from the former head of MI5 Lady Manningham-Buller''.

He said there had been a ``chorus of disapproval'' about the proposals and the
public were ``overwhelmingly'' opposed to the measure.

``Will it take a Government defeat before these daft and dangerous proposals are
withdrawn?''

Commons Leader Harriet Harman insisted the Government's responsibility was ``to
make sure that everyone in this country is safe from terrorism and also that
civil liberties are protected''.

The Human Rights Act provides a ``backstop'' to protect people's liberties, she
added.

Gull attack terror like 'the birds'

SECTION: Pg. 16

LENGTH: 210 words


A Woman was left shocked and needed treatment for head wounds after an attack by
a seagull likened to a scene from  Hitchcock's chilling film The Birds.

The 36-year-old was walking along The Esplanade at Burnham-on-Sea when the  gull
swooped and started stabbing her head with its beak.

The woman, who does not wish to be named, suffered three puncture wounds and
heavy bleeding in the attack, near the pier, on Wednesday morning.

She stumbled home and was later treated at Weston General Hospital.

Mark Newman, chairman of Burnham Area Rescue Boat, said: "This was almost
certainly an adult trying to protect a young gull.

"The bird obviously thought this lady was walking a little too close to one of
its chicks.

"It was a terrifying incident for her although it only lasted for a matter of
seconds. She was very shaken up and taken to A&E.

"There was an awful lot of blood and she required a tetanus injection. Otherwise
she is OK.

"We all think of Hitchcock's film The Birds with something like this and here it
is actually happening.

"These incidents are rare, although not unheard of. I would say there are one or
two seagull attacks every couple of years in Burnham.

"I've never heard of anyone  getting injured before - usually people are able to
shoo them away."

President Le Luong Minh ( Viet Nam):

The members of the Security Council condemned in the strongest terms the
terrorist attack on Turkish police protecting the United States Consulate
General in Istanbul on 9 July 2008, causing death and injury to Turkish police
personnel. The members of the Security Council expressed their condolences to
the families of the victims, as well as to the people and the Governments of

The members of the Security Council underlined the need to bring perpetrators,

measures taken to combat terrorism comply with all their obligations under
international law, in particular international human rights, refugee and
humanitarian law.

The members of the Security Council reiterated their determination to combat all
forms of terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the Charter of

                             July 15, 2008 Tuesday

Russia: Three charged for allegedly preparing terror attack

LENGTH: 216 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Chelyabinsk, 15 July: Three members of the extremist organization Hezb-e Tahrir
in Chelyabinsk have been charged with preparing a terrorist attack.

The young people were charged under Article 282.2 Part 2 (organizing activities
of a terrorist organization), Article 30 Part 1, Article 205 Part 3 (preparing a
terrorist attack by an organized group) and Article 222 Part 2 of the Russian
Criminal Code (illegal purchasing, carrying, storing ammunition by an organized
group), the press service of the Chelyabinsk Region prosecutor's office said
today.

According to the press service, the accused "disseminated campaign literature of
an extremist nature, and tried to persuade the population to forcibly change
Russia's political and state system by means of jihad" in the region.

"Following searches carried out at the extremists' homes, nine grenades,
extremist literature and pictures of social facilities and the buildings of the
authorities and law-enforcement agencies have been discovered," the press
service said.

Two of the accused were convicted in December 2007 under Article 282.2 Part 2 of
the Russian Criminal Code. They received a one-year suspended sentence.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0448 gmt 15 Jul 08

Terror attack airport chief lands top job at city terminal

BYLINE: Andrew Picken Transport Reporter

SECTION: Pg. 6

LENGTH: 359 words


Acting MD Dewar aiming to shape up expansion plans

THE man who guided Glasgow Airport through last year's terror attack has been
appointed the new boss at Edinburgh Airport.

Gordon Dewar, 41, will take up his managing director role in September after
current boss David Johnston moved to a new job with airport operator BAA.

He is Edinburgh Airport's third managing director in 18 months, but Mr Dewar,
who has been acting MD for the past month, said he was looking forward to
shaping the airport's expansion plans.

Born and bred in the Capital, Mr Dewar today promised to build on the airport's
successes in establishing itself as Scotland's number one airport.

Before joining BAA in February last year, Mr Dewar worked for transport
consultancy group Halcrow and among the projects he worked on was creating the
city's road traffic greenways.

He said: "It has been a privilege to lead the team at Glasgow Airport over the
last 17 months, particularly in the immediate aftermath of last year's attack,
when the dedication and professionalism of our staff ensured the airport was
back in business within 24 hours.

"The attack underlined the importance of emergency planning and working with
external agencies.

"The day itself was obviously a challenge but it is only in the following days
that you appreciate the skills of your staff and the amount of work which was
put in."

He said he was looking forward to the challenges at Edinburgh and insisted the
airport was "crucial" to the Capital's future.

The previous managing director, Mr Johnston, was in the airport's hot seat for
less than a year having taken over from Richard Jeffrey, who had been in the
post for six years.

Mr Johnston was last month promoted to group procurement director for BAA and
one of his first jobs will be to help sort the aftermath of the Heathrow
terminal five debacle.

Edinburgh Airport is now Scotland's busiest, carrying more than nine million
passengers a year.

The growth has been achieved thanks to expansion of direct international links
from the Capital.

Colin Matthews, BAA's chief executive, said: "Gordon has been a key member of
the BAA Scotland team over the past two years."

POLICE DOG MAULS NURSE;
EXCLUSIVE Teen tells of terror attack

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 381 words


A TEENAGER today relived the terrifying moment she was mauled by a police dog as
she walked home after a night out.

Chelsea Birkenhead had 24 stitches in her left arm after she was attacked by the
German shepherd in Stoneycroft.

The police dog, which was not on a lead, pounced on the 18-year-old Dovecot
dental nurse as she walked along Albany Road to a friend's house in the early
hours of Saturday morning.

Speaking from her hospital bed, Chelsea said: "We came out of the pub at about
midnight and were walking down the road to a friend's house.

"There is a pathway which you can use to cut through. But as we went to walk
down a policeman came running out with a dog and shouted at us to stop.

"I stopped straight away but the dog ran over to my friend and jumped at him.

Then it turned on me.

"It had my arm in its mouth and wouldn't let go.

It was ragging my arm.

"The policeman was shouting at it, but it wouldn't let go. I was hysterical"
Chelsea was taken to a nearby house where she was cared for until paramedics
arrived.

She was taken to the Royal Liverpool Hospital where she had an operation to
assess the extent of the damage.

The teenager and her family said they were considering lodging an official
complaint with Merseyside police.

Chelsea added: "I have got 24 stitches in my arm.

At the moment I have no feeling in my fingers.

"I used to like dogs. But now I am terrified of them." A police spokeswoman
said: "At 11.30pm on Friday night we got reports of a vehicle being stolen from
Classic Road, Stoneycroft.

"The people who stole the vehicle then baled out of it close to the alleyway
where this incident happened. The dog section picked up the call and then set
the dog out.

"The handler and the dog had gone down the alleyway at the same time as this
girl and her friend.

"The dog handler warned them to stand still, but it appears the girl panicked
and started to jump about and the dog went for her instead and bit her on the
lower arm.

"The dog section has carried out a safety check and established that it was
appropriate for the dog to have been deployed in these circumstances."

The spokeswoman added: "The matter has been referred to the professional
standards department and the Independent Police Complaints Commission."

                                   The Mirror

                             July 15, 2008 Tuesday
                                 1 Star Edition

YES, WE DID PLOT BOMB ATTACK ON HEATHROW;
TERROR TRIAL TRIO'S ADMISSION

BYLINE: BY ADRIAN SHAW

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 236 words


THREE British Muslims yesterday admitted plotting to plant bombs at Heathrow
airport and the Commons.

They claimed they planned to detonate small devices in and around London in
protest at British foreign policy.

But they deny being part of a bigger conspiracy to blow up seven transatlantic
jets with liquid bombs hidden in bottles of Oasis and Lucozade soft drinks
bottles.

Ahmed Abdulla Ali, 27, Assad Sarwar, 28, and Tanvir Hussain, 27, are alleged to
have been the ringleaders.

A three-month trial at Woolwich crown court, South London, has heard how suicide
bombers were to board flights to America and Canada and detonate the devices in
mid air.

They and five other men deny conspiracy to murder between January and August,
2006, but they admit conspiring to cause explosions.

They also admitted, along with Ibrahim Savant, 27, and Umar Islam, 30, making
martyrdom videos.

In the tapes, played to the jury, the men vowed to fight a jihadi holy war on
the West in retaliation for the deaths of Muslims in Iraq and Afghanistan.

The court heard how the plotters were secretly taped at a flat they bought in
Walthamstow, East London.

Peter Wright, QC, prosecuting, said that the plot was smashed when Ali was
arrested with a blueprint for the operation recorded in a pocket diary and on a
computer memory stick.

Mr Wright said: "It was their chance to achieve immor-f tality and notoriety in
equal measure." The trial continues.

                            July 16, 2008 Wednesday

Algerian army repel "terrorist attack" east of Bouira

LENGTH: 277 words


Text of report by privately-owned Algerian newspaper El Watan website on 16 July

[Report by L. K.: "Bouira: Terrorist Attack Thwarted in Ahnif" - first paragraph
is El Watan introduction]

This past Sunday [13 July] night into Monday morning, at about 2200 hours, a
terrorist attack targeted a detachment from the municipal guard of the village
of Tikesrai, in the municipality of Ahnif, east of Bouira.

According to our sources, the terrorists tried to besiege the detachment by
first using sustained fire from Kalashnikovs followed by rocket fire, clearly
from an RPG7 or a homemade device, the impact of which caused no damage, with
the exception of the sentry box, which was reportedly damaged in part. Thanks to
the vigilance of the elements from this detachment, the terrorist group was
repelled after several minutes of an exchange of fire. Right after having heard
the first gun shots, the elements of the National People's Army [ANP] posted
several hundred meters from there arrived as reinforcements on the scene and
kicked off a chase to hunt down the attackers.

A search operation ensued. Moreover, it has been learned that the very next day
(Monday), an explosive device, the nature of which has not been determined,
exploded in the spot known as Taferkout (11.5 kilometres south of the main town,
in the direction of Ighil n'Ath Amer as a team from the Municipal People's
Assembly's [APN] technical agencies was going past that had been on an
inspection mission for the project to tap a spring in that place. Fortunately
the explosion caused no damage, it was learned from those present at the scene.

Source: El Watan website, Algiers, in French 16 Jul 08

                                  Oxford Mail

                            July 16, 2008 Wednesday

JR in terrorist attack exercise

BYLINE: Andrew Ffrench

SECTION: OXFORD NEWS

LENGTH: 450  words


More than 200 staff from Oxfordshire emergency crews took part in a terrorist
training exercise yesterday in which nerve gas was released on a coach on the
M40.

Although those taking part were not dealing with a real-life incident, managers
said lessons were learned from the largest exercise of its kind to take place at
Oxford's John Radcliffe Hospital.

Emergency crews worked alongside staff at the hospital in Exercise Orpheus II,
which was overseen by the Government's Health Protection Agency.

The scenario was a horrific one - patients had been exposed to the deadly
chemical Sarin which was used in an attack on the Tokyo underground in 1995.

Gas victims were brought to the hospital and staff were then asked to find out
what was wrong with them before providing appropriate treatment.

Rosemary Dooley, deputy director of operations at the hospital, said: "We are
the first trust in the country to look at how staff would respond to a nerve
agent attack.

"It's the biggest exercise of this kind in a working hospital and we tried to
ensure normal patients could come and go without their day being interrupted.

"This was an excellent opportunity for the trust to test the hospital and health
care staff's response to a major incident in real time.

"I was nervous at first about staging this, but as time went on I realised there
was lots to be gained from going ahead with it.

"We can refine our plans as part of the debriefing and learn much more than in a
paper exercise.

"I think the public will be reassured by that."

Fifty casualties were played by actors, medical students and hospital staff.
After arriving at the hospital they were "decontaminated" in specially-provided
showers.

Once they had been though that process, they were dressed in high-visibility
suits before being admitted to the hospital wards for treatment.

Ambulance teams, hospital staff and other emergency services were also dressed
in chemical-proof suits as part of the dramatic scenario.

John Simpson, deputy director of emergency response at the Health Protection
Agency, said: "Our field exercises give our colleagues in the NHS and the
emergency services the chance to practise and hone their skills in an
environment which is as close to reality as we can make it."

Mr Simpson said yesterday's "nightmare scenario" involved a terrorist travelling
on a coach on the M40.

He was carrying a bottle of the nerve gas Sarin which leaked - and the driver
and passengers were overcome with fumes.

There were further casualties when the coach lost control and crashed into a
service station.

"Sarin was a useful substance to use in this scenario because it throws up
symptoms we don't often see in clinical practice," Mr Simpson added.

LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

[" TURKEY CONDEMNS RECENT DEADLY TERRORIST ATTACK IN IRAQ" - AA headline]

ANKARA (A.A) -Turkey strongly condemned Wednesday's deadly terrorist attack in
Tal Afar town of Iraq.

Turkish Foreign Ministry stated on Thursday that the abhorrent terrorist attack

                                 The Cornishman

                             July 17, 2008 Thursday

Gay men's 'terror' after man's verbal attack in lay-by, hear magistrates

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 462 words


Two gay men were subjected to a frightening verbal attack when they were in a
lay-by near Truro, magistrates in the city heard.

The men, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were both upset by what
happened, said Sarah Topham, prosecuting.

One was said to be "absolutely terrified" and the other "unnerved".

Henry Bradley, aged 47, of Talland Court, Talland Road, St Ives, who works at
his father's garage at Scorrier, Redruth, pleaded guilty to two offences of
using threatening behaviour in November last year.

Ms Topham said both victims were gay men who on November 1 had been using  a
lay-by on the A390 between Tresillian and Probus known as The Truck.

The first victim frequented the area regularly, meeting a circle of friends,
some of whom were gay and some not.

At 8.30pm he was sitting in his vehicle and meeting with a friend, the other
victim, who was parked beside him, talking through the driver's window. Bradley
drove his Mondeo towards them at speed with headlights on and engine revving and
the victim braced himself for a collision before the car stopped about two feet
in front of him.

The car pulled alongside and Bradley screamed a torrent of abuse at them. The
first victim, terrified for his safety, drove away, noting the Mondeo's
registration.

The second found Bradley's actions sufficiently intimidating to drive away as
well. Four days later a victim was again in the lay-by and noticed Bradley's
car. Bradley got out with fists clenched, suggesting he was ready to fight.

The victim drove past and left. Bradley told the police a victim had driven past
smiling as he was parked and as he did not like gay men he had intended to be
insulting in response.

He had gone to the lay-by to meet with other straight men  to talk about women.
He had no intention of carrying out his threats, saying he was a wimp and had
been bullied himself as a child.  He said gay men had no right to be in the
lay-by, saying he would continue his actions in the future.

Ms Topham said the two victims regarded Bradley as being a threat to the gay
community.

Robin Smith, defending, said Bradley's behaviour was admittedly bizarre. He was
a man of very limited abilities, could not read or write and led a fairly
protected life working with his father, who could keep an eye on him since he
was prone to some odd behaviour.

He had difficulty in knowing what was appropriate and what was not.

He had stopped in the lay-by with engine trouble. When one or both of the
victims had attempted to attract his attention, it made him aggressive and shout
unpleasant things.

He was feeling intimidated himself because of it. The case was adjourned for a
full probation report to August 4.

A condition of Bradley's bail was that he should not enter any lay-by between
Truro and St Austell.

LOAD-DATE: July 18, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 60

                                 Llanelli Star

                             July 17, 2008 Thursday

Angler speaks of knife attack terror

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 219 words


A Fisherman has described his terror as a youth allegedly lunged at him with a
knife.

Clive Beckett (pictured) claimed he was confronted by two teenagers, one of whom
pulled a filleting knife on him while he was out fishing at Furnace Ponds in
Llanelli on Saturday afternoon.

Mr Beckett had been out with Llanelli Carp and Coarse Fishing Club.

The 58-year-old, from Stradey, Llanelli, said he feared for his life when he was
approached by the two youths.

He said: "What flashed through my mind was that I was going to be another
statistic."

The incident happened at  around 3.50pm when Mr Beckett was moving a trailer
with some of his group.

He had noticed one of the teenagers in the pond and said his friend had warned
the youth of the dangers of being in the water.

One of the pair then approached one of the youngsters in the fishing party and
Mr Beckett intervened.

The youth then started shouting and threw a punch at him, he claimed. The other
boy, meanwhile, allegedly pulled out a knife and made short stabbing motions
towards Mr Beckett.

A Dyfed-Powys Police spokesman said: "Two males in the area were approached by
another two males. Two males have been arrested and are currently on bail.

"A knife was presented. There were no serious injuries."

Police are appealing for witnesses to call them on  0845 330 2000.

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                              July 18, 2008 Friday

North-east oil worker relives terror attack on vessel

BYLINE: Ryan Crighton

SECTION: NEWS; 999; Terrorism; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 392 words


A north-east oil worker has told of his terror as six speedboats full of armed
militants attacked his ship 75 miles off the coast of Nigeria.

The man, who does not want to be named over fears for his job, said that workers
on board the Shell Bonga floating production storage and off-loading vessel
watched in fear as the militia used sledgehammers to try to smash in a door on
the huge vessel.

"They were smashing this door for ages with sledgehammers, but one padlock held
on - we are very lucky it did," he said.

The militants first tried to climb over the side of the vessel, but were unable
to because of the grease.

They then turned their attention to the rear of the ship, where there is an
entrance covered by huge steel doors.

The worker continued: "They were spraying the accommodation with heavy fire and
there are bullet holes all over the back end of the ship.

"One of the lifeboats is holed, but we survived them getting in the
accommodation, otherwise we would be captive."

Workers have since resigned over fears that the militants will return and attack
the facility again.

The Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta has accepted responsibility
for the attack, which happened last month, saying that they wanted to send out a
message to companies that offshore oil facilities are not safe from their
attacks.

The group says it is fighting for a greater share of the tens of billions of
pounds of oil revenue generated by their impoverished region.

Until now, the group has mainly blown up oil pipelines and kidnapped expatriate
workers in the shallow creeks of southern Nigeria.

However, it said the attack may not be its last in deep waters.

Earlier this month, the UK Government said it would be "reckless" for Britons to
remain in Nigeria without proper security advice.

The Foreign Office first urged workers to return home in June last year after
officials ruled the security risk in the trouble-torn Niger Delta region was too
severe.

Since then, some firms have withdrawn workers, but around 250 Scottish oil
workers are still thought to be in Nigeria, about half of them from the
north-east.

Kidnapping of foreign workers is common in the lawless delta, which produces
around 2.5million barrels of crude oil a day for Nigeria.

Since January 2006, some 36 Britons and more than 180 foreigners have been
kidnapped. One Briton was killed.

LOAD-DATE: October 13, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: PJ

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                              July 18, 2008 Friday

China: Security ministry issues manual on actions in terror attacks

LENGTH: 308 words


Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News
Agency)

BEIJING, July 17 (Xinhua) - China's Ministry of Public Security on Thursday
issued a manual to help citizens survive terrorist attacks as the country was
tightening security in the last-minute preparation for the Olympic Games.

Chinese police invited experts in this field to work out such a manual to teach
citizens how to discover possible terrorist attacks, to take proper actions in
face of such attacks and minimize damages.

The book included 39 scenarios of terrorist attacks including explosion, arson,
kidnap, shooting and even attacks of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.

It teaches people how to identify suspicious substances, for instance, a bomb,
and how to help themselves and each other in such dangerous conditions as being
kidnapped by terrorists.

"What to do after being abducted? Please try your best to stay calm. Don't fight
back, don't meet kidnappers' eyes, don't talk, move slowly and try your best to
hide your communication devices," the manual said. "Lie face down on the ground
when the police attack the terrorists."

"The book is practical. If correctly following its instruction, citizens are
very much likely to escape and even stop a terrorist attack," the statement
said.

Beijing and other Olympic co-host cities are stepping up security measures.
Airports in these cities will adopt twice security checks from July 20 and
passengers are required to show their IDs to buy bus, train and ship tickets to
these cities. The police have set up checkpoints along the highways in and out
of Beijing.

The police also announced awards ranging from 10,000 to 500,000 yuan (1,449 to
72,463 US dollars) for people providing useful tips to stop serious crimes
during the Games.

Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1409 gmt 17 Jul 08

                                  Morning Star

                              July 18, 2008 Friday

Feature - More slingshots at Davis;
Solomon Hughes on how a Tory advocate of 'civil liberties' used the terror
threat to attack unions

BYLINE: Solomon Hughes

LENGTH: 985 words


I am probably throwing small pebbles at a large train that has long since left
the station, but let's look again at David Davis's civil liberties stand.

Davis said that one of the most important issues that he managed to raise in his
by-election campaign was that innocent people can be held for 42 days without
charge. When the government says "terror suspects," it wants you to hear the
first word, not the second.

I think that Davis is right. This one simple, basic idea needs to be reinforced.

The government wants to play the "terrorist alert" card as its joker. Davis's
stand reshuffled the deck. The fact that Davis stood to the left of the
government on this issue is testimony to the rottenness of Labour's leadership.
In fairness, it is also testimony to Davis's genuine belief and commitment.

So, figures on Labour's left like Tony Benn and Bob Marshall-Andrews were right
to try to get involved in the argument that Davis started. But I think that they
were very wrong to endorse Davis as a candidate.

That's because Davis, very specifically, does not want trade unionists on board
his freedom train.

As I said last week, Davis wanted to ban public-sector strikes. Under the Davis
plan for freedom, the current strikes by council workers would be illegal.

Davis was also one of the government ministers who opposed trade union rights at
GCHQ.

Margaret Thatcher banned unions at the government communications centre in 1984
as part of her attack on labour rights. There was a widespread campaign to
restore this basic and historic civil liberty - there were rallies every year at
Cheltenham, home of GCHQ.

I was one of the many Civil Service union reps who organised a strike in 1988
when the government sacked the last GCHQ staff who had refused to give up their
union membership.

Davis's response to this grass-roots campaign for liberty was to oppose it and
play the "terrorist alert" card.

In 1994, Davis was minister for public service in John Major's Tory government.
Labour MP Jack Cunningham proposed a motion to restore union rights to GCHQ
workers. Davis told the Commons that GCHQ workers must not have union rights
because, among other things, of the danger of "rising state-sponsored
terrorism," a phrase that he used twice.

Davis also has links to an even more sinister attack on the unions.

After a long career in sugar firm Tate & Lyle, he became a director of the
company from 1987 to 1990. In those years, Tate & Lyle funded and supported the
Economic League, a right-wing organisation that kept secret files on union
militants and political activists so that employers could keep them out of work.

Perhaps Davis did not know, but his company was a prominent supporter of the
league. Sir Saxon Tate was both a fellow director of Tate & Lyle and the boss of
the Economic League.

Davis was in Parliament when Labour MPs attacked the league and its lists, but
he said nothing. His fellow Tory MPs defended the organisation.

But the league's files were not only wrong, they were also riddled with errors.
The Economic League's snoops and spies stuck anyone who wrote the wrong kind of
letter to the newspapers in their secret database.

Genuine union activists were kept out of work by this nasty bunch and so were
people who had only a tenuous link to the left. Those who were blacklisted had
no opportunity to challenge the league's secret files. Eventually, a concerted
campaign by MPs, trade unionists and journalists broke the league.

It seems that Davis doesn't think that civil rights include trade union rights,
although, in fact, authoritarian governments always go for union rights first.

For this reason, I think that Benn and Marshall-Andrews should have supported
the Green candidate in the Haltemprice and Howden by-election who ran against
both authoritarian and neoliberal politics.

Why another David shows up the rotten core of new Labour

The fact that David Davis was able to stand as a David against Labour's
authoritarian Goliath shows how rotten and right wing the party's leadership has
become.

Another David offers a reminder of Labour's grisly record in office - David
Manning, one of Blair's top advisers, is now employed by Goliath Inc.

Manning, a civil servant rather than party politician, was intimately involved
in planning the Iraq war. Manning has now taken not one but two jobs with
Lockheed, an arms-maker which profited from the bloody destruction of Iraq.

Manning was Blair's foreign policy adviser from 2001 to 2003. He acted as link
man with then US national security adviser Condoleezza Rice.

We know from the leaked Manning Memorandum that he "had dinner with Condi" in
March 2002 and told her that his boss Blair "would not budge in ... support for
regime change but you had to manage a press, a Parliament and a public opinion
that was very different than anything in the States."

Manning told Rice that Blair backed the war plans, but needed to work on his
pro-war PR in Britain.

We also know that Manning had discussions in July 2003, according to a memo from
Blair's private secretary, that concluded: "It seemed clear that Bush had made
up his mind to take military action, even if the timing was not yet decided. But
the case was thin. Saddam was not threatening his neighbours, and his WMD
capability was less than that of Libya."

Despite this, "we should work on the assumption that the UK would take part in
any military action."

Manning helped Blair get his war and Lockheed sold lots of bombs and planes to
help kill people. Lockheed's handy brochure on Operation Iraqi Freedom reveals
that the company made one of the biggest contributions to the bombing of the
country.

Manning was rewarded in 2003 with the plum posting of ambassador to Washington.
He has now retired back to Britain, but he clearly wants to keep active.

This month, Manning took two jobs with Lockheed UK - he will both sit on the
board and have a special job as adviser to its chief executive.

Knife Teen Jailed Over Terror Attack

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 300 words


A KNIFEMAN held a blade to a woman's throat during a terrifying attack in her
own home.

Teenager Carl Nesbitt turned up at the woman's house claiming to have a message
for her.

But then, for no apparent reason, he kicked the victim's door in and pushed a
knife into her throat.

Newcastle Crown Court heard the 38-year-old woman has been left so traumatised
by the ordeal she has been forced to move out of her home in Chopwell,
Gateshead.

Sending Nesbitt to a young offenders institute for 12 months, Recorder Dallas
said: "After a brief conversation you kicked open her door, grabbed her by the
throat and produced a large kitchen knife.

"You placed it to her throat. She was terrified and tried to telephone the
emergency services, but you cut her off.

"That woman suffered in her own home the most frightening experience and the
effect on her has been a long and lasting one.

"She no longer feels safe and she and her children have had to move elsewhere.
The consequences of your behaviour will live with her for many a year."

Nesbitt, 19 of Queen Street, Chopwell, had turned up at the 38-year-old
mum-of-two's home at 6.30pm on November 13 last year.

He claimed to have a message from a third party, but then began his violent
attack.

Paul Caulfield, prosecuting, said: "Events inexplicably took a worrying turn
when he kicked the door open, grabbed the victim by the throat then pulled a
knife from his back pocket which he pressed to the victims throat."

Nesbitt pleaded guilty to possession of a offensive weapon as his trial was
about to begin, having initially denied the offence.

Rachel Hedworth, defending, said: "He has personal limitations."

His parents have struggled to control his behaviour and he has struggled with
ADHD and was on Ritalin at the time.

"He has not coped well in custody," she added.

Livery yard owner speaks of terror at nunchuck attack

A Livery owner says she will never forget the attack she was subjected to by a

She dived out of the way and Granville's boyfriend Paul Bellingham got out of
the vehicle and threatened Lynda's friend with his nunchucks, a court heard.

Granville, 59, whose father Baron Granville of Eye is a life peer, was convicted
of criminal damage, for damaging a fence, and fined £1,000.

Bellingham, 37, was found guilty of possessing an offensive weapon and using
threatening, abusive and insulting words or behaviour.

He was given a two-year suspended sentence, two-year supervision order, 250
hours of community service and told to pay £625 in costs by Cheltenham
magistrates.

Mrs Rankine said: "The whole thing was horrendous, I'll never forget it.

"I feel a lot happier he has got a suspended sentence because it might act as a
deterrent to stop them doing this at other yards.

"We would like to thank the police and the court for their support."

The court heard trouble flared when Granville and Bellingham, of Moorend Road,
Cheltenham, went to collect their horse on January 25.

Mrs Rankine's husband John presented them with an £81 bill but they said it was
too much and should only have been £37.

The couple tried to leave but the Rankines locked the gate to stop them.

As he was sentenced, Bellingham said he was sorry for everything that happened.

Chairman of the bench David Harley said: "The abusive language and threats left
several victims in fear.

"The possession of an offensive weapon was premeditated, because it was carried
around with him for at least a week."

                            July 23, 2008 Wednesday

Woman's terror at car attack

BYLINE: Fiona Mcwhirter

SECTION: NEWS; 999; Others; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 315 words


A WOMAN today said she had feared for her life when a man in a car grabbed at
her.

The attacker followed her on a North-east road, passing twice before pulling up
beside her.

The 22-year-old told of her terror in the incident, which happened on the old
A96 road at Inverurie.

She was walking home from work between North Street and Drimmies Corner when the
incident happened.

The woman, who asked not to be named, first saw her attacker at a roundabout.

"He put his window down and put his head out," she said.

"He was sort of smirking and laughing, I was totally frightened."

Hurrying onwards, the woman nervously watched every car that passed and saw the
same one again.

She said: "It was really scary and horrible."

After driving past her, the man, who was in a small blue hatchback she believed
to be a Ford Ka, turned and went down the other side of the road.

But then he returned.

"He came back and slowed the car right down," she said.

"I was hurrying along, I could see the lights shining on me, I knew he was close
but I didn't know how close.

"I could hear the engine so I turned round and noticed he was right next to me.

"I turned to run but he opened the car door and grabbed my arm."

The woman was wearing a short-sleeved jumper at the time of the incident, on
Monday at 11pm, and said it was "creepy" to feel his hand on her bare skin.

She said: "I thought I was dead."

Running for her life, she made it to a nearby street but the first house had no
lights on.

She said: "I turned round and he was driving towards me again.

"I ran and hid behind some garages on that street and phoned my boyfriend who
came running down to get me."

The police were later called.

Although the woman was not hurt she was badly shaken.

Her attacker was in his 30s with blonde, spiked hair and blue eyes.

He wore a brown suit and waistcoat and it was thought the car may have been a
left-hand drive.

Digger driver in terror attack as Obama begins Israeli visit

CROWDS scattered in terror as a Palestinian driving a digger rampaged along a

The drama happened close to a hotel where U.S. presidential contender Barack

More than 20 people were hurt, including a baby, after the man roared out of a
building site and smashed into a bus and five cars.

shovel aimed at their heads.

killed three people and injured 60. Obama, who was due to fly to Israel last

their families'.

Speaking in Amman, Jordan, he said: 'Today's attack is a reminder of what
Israelis have courageously lived with on a daily basis for far too long. I
strongly condemn this attack and will always support Israel in confronting
terrorism and pursuing lasting peace and security.'

The Democrat senator, who will hold talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders
today, was due to stay at the King David Hotel, 200 yards from the scene of the
attack. Police said they had no evidence to suggest a link.

The attack happened less than half a mile from the official residence of Israeli
president Shimon Peres as he played host to Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas.

It was the first such visit by a Palestinian president.

WOMAN RUSHED TO HOSPITAL AFTER ASSAULT TERROR;

BYLINE: GARY FANNING

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 393 words


POLICE launched an investigation yesterday after a woman was viciously attacked
in the street while children played nearby.

The victim was taken to hospital following the frightening assault, which took
place in Morar Drive, Foxbar, Paisley, at around 11.30am yesterday.

Youngsters had been playing just yards away in the grounds of Brediland Primary
School when the attack happened.

It's understood the woman suffered an arm injury and was rushed to Paisley's
Royal Alexandra Hospital, where she received a number of stitches to her wound.

Officers were quickly at the scene and sealed off part of the pavement in Morar
Drive as they combed the area for clues.

One worried mum who lives nearby told the Paisley Daily Express: "I was watching
television and heard a commotion outside in the street but, at the time, I
didn't think it was anything serious.

"It was only when I looked out of my window later on that I noticed a lot of
police activity in the street.

"One of my neighbours told me a young woman had been hurt and there was blood
splattered on the pavement where the attack took place.

"I could see that the police had sealed off part of the street. They had put
yellow markers down on the ground and I guess that was to identify something
they might be able to use as evidence.

"It also looked like officers were taking photographs of the scene."

Police were yesterday hoping to interview the victim to find out what type of
weapon - if any - was used in the attack.

Annette Smith, 71, who lives near the scene of the attack was shocked to learn
that a woman had been assaulted in broad daylight.

She said: "This area is normally fine and most people just keep themselves to
themselves.

"I didn't see or hear anything out of the ordinary until I spotted a police car
in the street."

Another neighbour, who didn't want to be named, added: "I came back from the
shops and noticed the police car but I just thought they had pulled someone over
for speeding or something like that.

"I didn't think much more about it at the time but it's worrying to hear that
someone was attacked."

A police spokesperson said: "I can confirm that we were called to Morar Drive
after a woman was assaulted and our enquiries are continuing."

Anyone who has information is asked to call Paisley Police on 0141 532 5900 or
Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

                            July 24, 2008, Thursday

HIT-AND-RUN THUG TRIED TO KILL US AND OUR UNBORN CHILD;
EXCLUSIVE COUPLE TELL OF CAR ATTACK TERROR

BYLINE: By Chris Musson

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 435 words


A PREGNANT woman told yesterday how a hit-and-run maniac tried to kill her and
her unborn baby.

Caroline Bain was thrown over the bonnet of a car when the driver deliberately
rammed into her outside asupermarket.

She lost consciousness and when she came round, she had to endure an agonising
wait to find out if her baby had survived.

Caroline, who is four months pregnant, said: "The car bounced off a speed bump
and came straight up on to the pavement. I froze but I managed to put my hands
forward and on to the bonnet as it came at me.

"It hit me on the top of the legs and then I blacked out. When I woke up in the
ambulance, I was panicked. I just kept thinking about the baby."

Caroline's boyfriend Terence Harvey, who was with her at the time of the
hit-and-run, said: "I dropped to my knees. I thought I had lost them both -
Caroline and the baby.

"I've got no doubt that they tried to kill Caroline. They drove at me and missed
me, then revved up and went straight for her.

"It was like something out of a Hollywood movie. I couldn't believe what was
happening with this maniac speeding around trying to run people over."

Mother-of-two Caroline, of Milton, Glasgow, and Terence, both 32, had stopped
outside the Somerfield supermarket in the Gorbals to tell two of friends their
baby news.

A man and a woman in a burgundy Nissan Note stopped and asked them if they had
drugs.

When they told him they didn't, the man drove off - but came back and aimed
straight at them.

The attack was witnessed by a coach-load of players from Lancashire side Burnley
FC, who were on a pre-season tour of Scotland.

Terence, who lives in the Gorbals. tried to stop the coach, but it drove off.

He said: "The Nissan driver's eyes were bulging. We told him that we didn't have
anything and he seemed to be raging. He'd been around the side of Somerfield,
asking people for drugs. He started to drive away and the woman in the car was
screaming and telling him to go back."

The driver turned around in the middle of traffic lights, mounted the kerb and
steered towards the four pals.

When they scattered in different directions to get away, the Nissan careered
towards Terence.

It then drove at Caroline, flipping her into the air.

Fortunately, she landed on her side and her baby was unharmed.

But Caroline, who has two sons aged 14 and four, suffered bruising and grazes to
her back, arms and legs.

She said: "I am still in shock and really sore. But I feel lucky to be alive."

Yesterday, Burnley FC spokesman Darren Bentley said the club would be happy to
speak to police about the hit-and-run attack, which happened around 1pm on
Tuesday.

Sustrans' cyclepath, land and maintenance manager Paul Thomas said: "We work
hard to try and publicise the cycleway as somewhere great for families to go so
it's a bit of a worry."

A Sustrans warden will be checking the area regularly.

tracksuits, had shaven heads and slim builds - to come forward.

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                              July 25, 2008 Friday

Terrorists 'planned attack on Olympic football'

BYLINE: Richard Spencer in Beijing

SECTION: NEWS; International; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 510  words


CHINA claimed yesterday to have broken up an "international terrorist cell''
that was plotting an attack against an Olympics football qualifying game in
Shanghai.

"We obtained information that international terrorist organisations would likely
launch an attack against an Olympic venue in the city during the Games,'' said
Cheng Jiulong, head of the city's Olympic security bureau.

"We have staged raids and cracked a group of terrorists.''

In common with a string of such claims by the Chinese authorities in recent
months, no further details were immediately given, such as the number of
arrests, what cause the terrorists were representing, the nature, if any, of
weapons captured, or what the purpose of the attack was to have been.

But there has been an intensification of security in the last six months across
the country, and a number of "terrorist plots'' have been uncovered.

The most serious have been connected to the Uighur ethnic minority from Xinjiang
province in the far west, whose "separatist forces'' are said to be in league
with al-Qaeda.

In one incident in March, a girl found with a drinks can filled with a
suspicious liquid was said to have been plotting to bring down an aircraft in
mid-flight, possibly on Beijing's new airport terminal.

At the same time, the police said they had smashed a separate group in Urumqi,
the Xinjiang capital. A group of plotters was found with guns and homemade
explosives.

In total, 82 "Uighur terrorists'' have been rounded up in a series of arrests
across the province so far this year, with several more killed. Yet in at least
one case, residents disputed police reports of a gun fight between armed
militants and the security forces.

The most recent major incident involved police raiding the flat of a group of
Uighurs. They were said to have resisted arrest and five of the group were shot
dead.

Police reported finding a large number of knives - but no guns or explosives -
in the flat, and said in English language reports not repeated in Chinese
language media that those arrested confessed to plotting "Holy War''.

One difficulty in assessing such claims is that the government is deliberately
vague in distinguishing between violent attacks and protests, particularly by
those they accuse of being "splittist'', such as Uighurs and Tibetans.

In a typical speech, Meng Jiangzhu, the minister for public security, told
paramilitary police training for the Olympics this week to "resolutely prevent
severe violence and terrorist incidents, resolutely prevent severe political
incidents that could affect state security and social stability and resolutely
prevent large-scale mass incidents to make sure the objective of a safe Olympic
Games is reached''.

The football stadium in Shanghai, which will host 12 qualifying games, has been
closed to the public since Sunday. It was now "safe'' but threats remained,
according to Mr Cheng.

In Beijing, Olympic security officials confirmed this week that anti-aircraft
batteries had been placed near the Olympic green and security checks on vehicles
had increased.
