                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                             August 5, 2008 Tuesday

China on Olympic terror alert after border attack: Games organisers insist
stadiums safe as 16 policemen killed by separatists

BYLINE: Jonathan Watts, Kashgar and Tania Branigan, Beijing

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 703 words


Olympic organisers moved to reassure the public and athletes yesterday that the
games would be safe after China's deadliest suspected terrorist attack in more
than

a decade.

Sixteen policemen were killed and 16 injured in a raid on a paramilitary border
police headquarters, in the north-western Xinjiang region, by what are believed
to be separatists from the area.

Two men used a dumper truck to run down a group of police outside their station
in the city of Kashgar, before stabbing them and exploding

homemade grenades, the state news agency Xinhua reported.

After the attack, Olympic organisers indicated precautions were in place to
ensure the safe running of the games. "We are prepared to deal with any kind of
security threat and we are confident we will have a safe and peaceful Olympic
games," said Sun Weide, an official with the Beijing organising committee.

A security force of 100,000 is on standby in Beijing, 2,500 miles from Kashgar.
Security measures in the capital have included stationing anti-aircraft missiles
near the "Bird's Nest" Olympic stadium.

Yesterday's attack followed repeated claims from authorities that Uighur
separatists from Xinjiang were targeting the games. Details of the incident
could not be independently verified but witnesses reported hearing blasts and
seeing the aftermath of an explosion.

At the scene outside the Yiquan hotel yesterday, the only sign of what had
happened were three holes in the ground where trees had been recently uprooted,
and some broken windows at the travel agents next door.

A visiting British couple staying in a nearby hotel said they heard an
explosion. "I was having breakfast at about 8am when I heard two or three loud
bangs," said Sam Gunter, a tourist. "They sounded like a car backfiring so I
didn't pay much attention, until later when I heard some police had been
killed."

He went to the police station in the afternoon where he saw 13 large coffin-like
refrigerators, but he was ushered away.

Late last night there was a strong security presence at the scene, with several
police cars and a group of eight paramilitaries, but journalists were relatively
free to move around and report.

The Chinese authorities have identified the assailants, now in custody, as
Uighur men aged 28 and 33. Official media said local police suspected the attack
was a terrorist act and added that the public security bureau had suspected the
region's East Turkestan Islamic Movement of plotting an attack in the run-up to
the games, which begin on Friday.

"This is the most serious incident recorded in years," said Nicholas Bequelin of
Human Rights Watch. "Ahead of the Olympics, it is a very powerful symbolic
attack because security in Xinjiang is at an all-time high."

Turkic-speaking Uighur Muslims make up about 8 million of the 19 million
population in Xinjiang, a mineral-rich region more than three times the size of
France. Many resent controls on religion and Han Chinese immigration.

Human rights campaigners and Uighur exiles have argued that the government has
exaggerated the threat of violence and blurred the distinction between
terrorism, separatist arguments and cultural expression to justify repression.

Few analysts believe Uighur militants capable of launching a large attack on
Olympic venues, although they say it is hard to assess the extent of the threat
because the authorities rarely offer evidence for claims to have disrupted
plots.

The clampdown which followed violence in the 1990s has led to "nervousness and
tension" between Uighurs and Han Chinese, said Colin Mackerras, an expert on the
region from Griffith University, Australia. He added: "There's an independence
movement, but I don't expect it to succeed and don't expect many people will
want to take part, because they expect it to fail and know the result will be
more repression."

Last week, the Chinese officer in charge of Olympics security said that "east
Turkestan terrorist groups" represented the greatest threat to the games. But
others suggested it was too soon to label the incident as terrorism. Dr Andrew
Fischer, a specialist on western China at the London School of Economics, said
it could be a revenge attack by a tribe rather than a politically motivated
action.

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                       August 5, 2008 Tuesday 2:46 AM BST

TERROR DETENTION PLANS UNDER ATTACK

BYLINE: PA Reporters

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 460 words


Plans for an extension to the time authorities can detain terror suspects to 42
days have come under attack from a cross-party Lords Committee.

What are the proposals?

The Counter Terrorism Bill would extend the maximum period a suspect can be held
without charge from 28 to 42 days.

Detention can already be extended for an extra 30 days under the Civil
Contingencies Act, but ministers want to be able to give investigators extra
time without declaring a state of emergency.

How will the powers work in practice?

The Government initially included a series of safeguards to ease civil liberties
concerns. These were further bolstered in an effort to avoid a rebellion from
Labour MPs during a crucial Commons vote on the issue.

Under the proposals, a chief constable and the Director of Public Prosecutions
would go to the Home Secretary to request an extension up to 42 days in the
context of a ``grave exceptional terrorist threat''.

A parliamentary debate and vote must then be held within a week. If the
extension is endorsed, police have 30 days to use the powers.

Judges would also review the detention cases at regular intervals - scrutiny
which ministers claim upholds the principle of habeas corpus.

What stage is the Bill at?

Having scraped through the commons by the narrowest of margins - a majority of
just nine MPs - the Counter Terrorism Bill will now go to the Lords when
Parliament comes back from the summer recess. It is likely to face stiff
opposition in the Lords and could well be rejected. Former MI5 chief Lady
Manningham-Buller has described the measure as ``unworkable''. Other prominent
critics include Labour's former attorney general Lord Goldsmith and former Lord
Chancellor Lord Falconer.

What happens if Lords and MPs cannot agree on the issue?

If peers reject the Bill, it will return to the Commons. If it is again passed
by MPs but blocked by the House of Lords, the Prime Minister may be forced to
evoke the Parliament Act to force through the legislation.

What is the case for going beyond 28 days?

The Government says the growing complexity and international nature of terror
plots means that at some point police will need more time to question suspects
before charging them.

So far around half a dozen people have been held close to the 27/28-day limit,
but there have been no cases that have reached it.

Scotland Yard Commissioner Sir Ian Blair and Northern Ireland Chief Constable
Sir Hugh Orde have backed the extension, but other senior officers have
expressed reservations.

And against?

Campaigners believe the extension to 42-days is a further erosion of civil
liberties.

In addition, opponents say there is no need for the move, as legislation already
exists allowing detention to be extended by up to 30 days under emergency
powers.

                            August 7, 2008 Thursday

Kenyan premier, American envoy to mark 10th anniversary of terror attacks

LENGTH: 443 words


Text of report Daniel Luseno entitled "Remembering US Embassy bomb blast"
published by Kenyan opposition newspaper Kenya Times website on 7 August

Today marks the 10th commemoration of the ghastly 7 August 1998 bombing of the
United States (US) embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in which 250 people lost
their lives while thousands were injured. Prime Minister Raila Odinga is
expected to grace the occasion alongside representatives of the US government
led by Ambassador Michael Ranneberger.

The senior officials from the two governments will lead survivors and victims'
family representatives in commemorating the day. Today, 10 years ago, the twin
bombings took place within minutes of each other in Dar es Salaam and Nairobi at
around 10.30 am local time.

No-one claimed responsibility for the detonations immediately, but with time, it
emerged that the attacks were the handiwork of Al-Qa'idah under Usamah
bin-Ladin, who had established terror cells in within the east Africa region.
The first blast went off in the Tanzanian capital and the second, just five
minutes later, in Nairobi. The Nairobi explosion demolished a five-storey office
block sending it crashing onto the embassy next door.

The then US Ambassador Prudence Bushnell was meeting Kenya's then Trade Minister
Joseph Kamotho at the nearby Cooperative House at the time. They both sustained
injuries. The blast could be heard 10 miles (16km) away and caused total chaos
in the city centre. A cloud of thick smoke and clouds covered the entire city as
helicopters hovered overhead. The US embassy the target of the bombers was
virtually wiped off.

But within minutes of the ferocious blast, volunteers were working furiously,
pulling survivors from the rubble. US President Bill Clinton condemned the
attacks as "abhorrent" and said every effort would be made to catch the bombers.
"These acts of terrorist violence are abhorrent, they are inhuman," Clinton said
at a White House press conference and added that , "We will use all the means at
our disposal to bring those responsible to justice".

Last week, one of the most wanted criminals on whose head the US government had
put a bounty of 5m US dollars, Fazul Abdulla Muhammad - believed to be the
mastermind of the bomb attacks in Nairobi - slipped a police dragnet mounted on
the Kenyan coastal town of Malindi, and to date, a manhunt for him is on in
Nairobi and along the entire Kenyan coast.

It is understood that Fazul moved out of his hideout just minutes a head of the
hunting pack. Three members of a family who had hosted him have been charged and
several other arrests made.

in the western part of Bogota. According to the authorities, this man is a
member of the International Commission of the FARC, the organization's
ambassador to the Southern Cone, and a sort of public spokesman for the FARC
like Rodrigo Granda. He was reportedly sent by the FARC Secretariat to
coordinate various attacks that were to be carried out in Bogota during the
national celebrations on 7 August.

Four other persons were arrested in the city of Neiva as part of this operation.
They are members of the Teofilo Forero Column of the FARC and are explosives
experts, reported the police.

A statement released by the National Police reported that so far they have found
two "car bombs" in the cities of Bogota and Neiva, each containing 85 kilos of
explosives.

"The information obtained so far indicates that the FARC's plans included
carrying out a terrorist escalation in various points of the city against
targets like the Armed Forces Health Department, the studios of a well known
communications medium, and at least two nationally known public figures."

The plan uncovered by the authorities caused security measures in the capital to
be intensified. The police have issued an appeal for any suspicious situation to
be reported to 112 or the antiterrorist line.

Source: Radio Cadena Nacional text website, Bogota, in Spanish 7 Aug 08

Chinese experts link Xinjiang terror attacks to international backgrounds

LENGTH: 735 words


Text of report by Hong Kong newspaper Wen Wei Po website on 5 August

[Article by Wen Wei Po: "Be Fully Prepared to Handle All Kinds of Threats"]

At approximately 0800 on 4 August, a border patrol team in Kashgar in Xinjiang
came under armed attack from two Uighur males. As of this writing, 16
paramilitary policemen have died and 16 others were injured. Occurring on the
eve of the opening of the Olympic Games, this vicious attack again focused
public attention on security for the Olympic Games. "We are prepared to deal
with any kind of security threat and we are confident we will have a safe and
peaceful Olympic Games," said Sun Weide, a spokesman for the Beijing Organizing
Committee for the XXIX Olympiad [BOCOG].

After the attack, the officials concerned in the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous
Region immediately rushed to Kashgar to take charge of the rescue and security
work. Presently the case is under further investigation. Sun Weide, the BOCOG
spokesman, told reporters on 4 August that coordination would be stepped up with
the police in Xinjiang. According to Sun Weide, the Chinese government, the city
of Beijing, and the BOCOG take the security for the Olympic Games most seriously
and have created an effective command structure. Cooperation in security,
intelligence, and counter-terrorism has also been stepped up with countries that
have previously hosted the Olympic Games.

The Foreign Ministry of Spain has expressed its "strongest condemnation" of the
incident and its "full support for the Chinese people and government." It has
also reiterated its "strong condemnation of terrorist activities in any form."

Li Wei, director of the Centre for Studies in Counter-Terrorism at the China
Institute of Contemporary International Relations, said, "Judging from the
method of attack and the targets selected, the latest violent attack may be
related to the East Turkestan Islamic Movement [ETIM]. At a minimum it was
perpetrated by groups that support the ETIM." Li Wei said that Chinese police
had thwarted several violent incidents planned and carried out by ETIM,
including some targeting law enforcement personnel such as public security
personnel and armed police forces. He said that vehicles were easier to obtain
and harder to detect than other weapons. The latest attack was highly brutal in
that the alleged perpetrators chose vehicle as their weapon and caused heavy
casualties.

International Background, Olympic Games Targeted

This newspaper on 4 August interviewed Jing Tiankui, director of the Institute
of Sociology at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, about the latest attack.
He said that inter-nationality relations in China have always been very
harmonious and friendly. With the approach of the Beijing Olympic Games,
however, there has been a rash of violent incidents, a sign that the forces of
sabotage are going after the Beijing Olympic Games. And judging from reactions
of some unfriendly figures in the world as well as the incidents themselves, it
is clear these forces have an international background.

Xie Tongxiang, an expert in Chinese criminal matters, also told this newspaper
that Beijing has now initiated a variety of highly stringent security measures
to protect the Olympic Games, so he does not think that the plots of certain
international anti-China forces and national separatist forces targeting the
Olympic Games will succeed. However, security in China today must not be limited
to the Olympic Games but should also consider other cities in the country,
especially the Tibet and Xinjiang autonomous regions. The reason is that some
national separatist forces may make other cities the targets because of their
inability to engage in sabotage in Beijing.

Reportedly, 12 cells developed by foreign terrorist separatist organizations
such as the East Turkestan Islamic Movement, Turkestan Islamic Party, and
Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan have been cracked in the city of Kashgar in
Xinjiang this year. Meanwhile, police in the city of Urumqi arrested a total of
66 people of the "three forces" between January and June this year, cracked five
terrorist cells in Urumqi that were plotting to sabotage the Olympic Games,
captured 82 people alleged to have committed acts of terrorism, and destroyed 41
training camps that had been engaged in illegal proselytizing and the training
of jihadists.

Tanzanian terror attack victims demand compensation from USA government

LENGTH: 309 words


Text of unattributed report entitled "Victims of 1998 US Embassy blast approach
American Govt for fair payment" published by Tanzanian newspaper The Guardian
website on 9 August

Some victims of the 1998 US embassy attack on Thursday [7 August]emerged with
placards at the 10th commemoration of the bombing pressing the American
government to compensate them as it did for other victims of the 11 September
attacks.

The victims were among other sufferers who gathered at the US embassy in Dar es
Salaam to remember their loved ones who died during the attack.

They were holding placards reading: "We request the US embassy to compensate us
due to the attack of 7 August 1998. Why were Americans compensated but not us?"

One of the victims, Doni Akilimpapa, said he was working as an Ultimate Security
guard at the US embassy when it was attacked in 1998. "I was seriously injured
in my ear and on my head and received treatment like other people who were
injured during the attack, but I didn't get any compensation", he said.

"We have written to the embassy on several occasions requesting for compensation
but they haven't responded. We want to be compensated because I am still
undergoing treatment and sometimes I fail to afford the treatment costs", he
said.

When asked to comment on the matter, an official from the US embassy said all
the victims of the attack were compensated and those complaining were being
unjust to the American people.

However, Akilimpapa insisted that he was not compensated, although he admitted
that he was given treatment for the injuries.

On 7 August 1998, the American embassy in Tanzania was bombed and 11 people died
while 100 others were injured.

On the same date the US embassy in Nairobi was also attacked where 218 people
perished and 5,000 others were injured.

                                Birmingham Post

                            August 9, 2008 Saturday
                                  1ST Edition

Transport terror attack is biggest threat to Britain;
POLITICS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 601 words


Britain is more likely to face another attack on the transport network than any
other kind of threat, the Government revealed yesterday.

Previously secret information ranked a terror attack on transport as the most
likely risk faced by the country, raising the spectre of another July 7.

The second most likely form of threat is an electronic attack on IT and
communications systems, and the third most likely is a terror strike on a
crowded place.

The complex analysis in the Cabinet Office's National Risk Register looked at a
wide range of threats to the country, including natural disasters and industrial
accidents.

Different threats are ranked on a specially-devised graph according to "relative
likelihood" and "relative impact".

The document said: "Of the different malicious attacks outlined in this
document, conventional attacks on transport systems are judged to be some of the
more likely to occur.

"This assessment is supported by the many examples of this type of attack
perpetrated by different groups across the globe."

Railways, including underground train systems in UK cities, are "more vulnerable
to attack" than airlines because of different security levels, it said.

As announced by Prime Minister Gordon Brown in March, the document said a flu
pandemic was the biggest threat facing the country.

Such an incident would be the most damaging, claiming up to 750,000 lives.

But it is only the fifth most likely type of risk, according to the new
information, and is ranked as slightly less likely than a severe weather attack.

Coastal flooding was given as the second most damaging type of threat.

The document also provided advice to families and organisations on what they can
do to protect themselves.

It built on information contained in the Preparing For Emergencies booklet which
was delivered to every household in the country in 2004.

Yesterday's new information ranked a chemical, biological, radiological or
nuclear (CBRN) attack by terrorists as about as likely as a major incident of
inland flooding.

"The use of some CBRN materials has the potential to have very serious and
widespread consequences," it said.

"An example would be the use if a nuclear device.

"There is no historical precedent for this type of terrorist attack."

The document said the Government has stockpiled enough doses of the antiviral
drug oseltamivir, known as Tamiflu, to treat a quarter of the population.

"This should be sufficient to treat all those who fall ill in a pandemic of
similar proportions to those that occurred in the 20th century," it said.

"The Government is collaborating actively with international partners on
prevention, detection and research, and is taking every practical step to ensure
that the UK is prepared to limit the internal spread of a pandemic and to
minimise health, economic and social harm as far as possible."

Security Minister Lord West of Spithead rejected suggestions that publication of
the register would simply cause unnecessary alarm.

"I have great faith in the public and they would prefer to have information
because the thing that causes fear is ignorance of things," he told BBC Radio
4's The World at One.

"A thing like the flu pandemic, it's very difficult to gauge exactly what the
scale of it will be.

"We have done a great deal of work on it and I hope when people read this they
will be reassured by the amount of work that we have done within government."

Shadow security minister Baroness Pauline Neville-Jones said: ""We have been
urging the Government to be more open about the risks the UK faces for some
time."

BYLINE: LUKE TRAYNOR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

A MOTHER and her two young daughters woke in terror when a drive-by gunman
blasted two windows at their home.

Three shots were fired at the property in Lyme Grove, Huyton, at 3am yesterday
while the family slept inside.

Shocked neighbours said they heard one shot, followed by a 15-second pause,
before two more shots rang out.

No body was hurt in the incident, but the woman, said to be about 40, and the
two young girls, aged around six and three, were at home at the time.

Neighbours heard screams from the house, quickly followed by a car speeding away
from the scene.

Yesterday, a large downstairs bay window and an upstairs bedroom window were
smashed after being pierced by bullets.

A maroon 4x4 vehicle, which appeared to have suffered damage to its side, was
towed away by police.

Forensic tests will be carried out to establish if the car had been shot at or
was involved in an earlier crash linked to the shooting.

Residents said trouble had been "brewing for a while", with some claiming an
older teenager was the intended target of the attack.

They also said it was common for gangs of youths to be seen hanging around
outside the address. Others said a member of the family had been threatened a
few weeks earlier.

One woman said: "It was scary. The shots sounded like an explosion and everyone
was peering out of their windows.

"There are always people gathering either inside or outside the house."

A spokesman for Merseyside police said: "High-visibility patrols have been
stepped up in the area and crime scene investigators are at the scene, carrying
out forensic examinations."

Anyone with information is asked to call the dedicated police gun crime hotline
on 0800 458 1211 or Crime stoppers anonymously on 0800 555111.

                                 The Spectator

                                 August 9, 2008

A film that shows how gutless Britain has become;
Michael Prescott - who was a passenger on the King's Cross train on 7/7 -
applauds a movie inspired by the terrorist attacks. But why is nobody keen to
distribute it?

BYLINE: Michael Prescott

SECTION: Pg. 20

LENGTH: 979 words


The world has an estimated 798 billionaires. Thousands more people are each
worth hundreds of million. Any one of them is in a position to blow £8 million
on a whim. Only one of them has decided to gamble that amount on a film about
how Britain views its Muslims in the age of Islamist terror. Aron Govil is an
Indianborn Hindu who has lived in New York since 1970, gradually accruing wealth
through his activities in industry and the energy business.

Eighteen months ago a friend showed him a movie script set in London, inspired
by the 7 July Tube bombings and the shooting of the terror-suspect-who-wasn't,
Jean Charles de Menezes.

Mr Govil decided to make the movie. 'I felt this was a film with important
things to say, while Hollywood is busy making Hellboy II, ' he explains, adding
with unembarrassed candour: 'I have the money to make the film, I didn't need
support from anyone else, I decided to do it.'

Speaking to Mr Govil is what speaking to a BBC executive ought to be like. In
the coming months, this high-minded businessman will discover whether he can add
'movie producer' to his list of commercial triumphs.

We should all care whether he wins through, but frankly, the signs are less than
good.

No one wants to distribute Shoot on Sight, though it boasts a clever script, an
experienced director, high production values, a singularly topical theme and a
well-known cast which includes Greta Scacchi and Brian Cox. Mr Govil is trying
to break into the weird scene that is British and international movie
distribution, drawing strength only from his director, his cast and (here we
should all be grateful) his rather large bank balance.

'I have spoken to all the big distributors and at least they are upfront about
why they won't handle the film, ' says Mr Govil. 'They say it's too serious, it
deals with issues that are too sensitive. So my attitude is, I made the film -
if I have to distribute it myself then so be it. Obviously, after the cinema
release it will have a future life on television and on DVD.' There is more at
stake here, though, than a rich man's vanity. Something odd is going on which
surely begs profound questions about the cultural and political life of this
nation.

In the years since 7/7 we have had documentaries aplenty to probe the facts
about what happened, but a paucity of drama to examine the impact on how we live
and think in the new age of terror. Perhaps those in charge of our more powerful
cultural citadels - the BBC, Channel 4, the British film industry which they
help to finance - are frightened to venture into the thicket of sensitivity
grown in the dust of the Tube bombings.

Mr Govil and his friends have not feared to tread, yet scarcely a soul seems
interested.

True, the production team generated a few headlines by revealing that Tarique
Ghaffur, the senior Muslim officer at odds with his police employers, acted as
an informal adviser for the film. Against that, press screenings in London have
been thinly attended.

Happily, Mr Govil reports greater interest and even enthusiasm when the film has
been shown in Stuttgart, Dubai and Delhi.

Current plans are to force the movie into a few dozen British cinemas later this
month, try for a small American and Continental release and issue 270 prints to
the seemingly more vigorous Indian cinema market.

The film has been directed by Jag Mundhra. Like the film's producer, he is an
Indian-born Hindu who found success in America, first as a college professor,
then as a film-maker.

Staying in London in July 2005, he found a marked difference in people's
attitudes toward him after the terror attacks. Despite his conventional Western
garb and friendly demeanour, cab drivers were less likely to stop, passers-by
eyed him warily. It says a lot about the spunky attitude he brings to filmmaking
that his response to this sorry experience is to say simply, 'People viewed me
differently because of the colour of my skin and I can understand why.' The
director's experience was the seed from which Shoot on Sight was to grow,
nourished by other events which were to follow 7/7, notably the killing of an
innocent Brazilian by police officers who seemed to think they were tailing a
terrorist.

Mr Mundhra asked a friend with whom he had collaborated in the past to prepare a
script taking at its heart the aftermath of July 2005. Carl Austin, an
African-American based in Los Angeles, did him proud with the work which so
impressed Mr Govil when shown to him almost two years ago.

It is easy to see why Mr Govil took Mr Austin's work seriously. What impresses
most about this drama is its tough-mindedness. An innocent is gunned down on the
Underground. A senior Muslim police officer is chosen to be the face of the Met.

Like the real-life police adviser to the film, the fictional assistant
commissioner is called Tarique. His experience mirrors certain aspects of the
Ghaffur affair: yet another reason why limited interest in the movie to date
seems worthy of comment.

Perhaps one of the most curious things about Shoot on Sight is that it feels so
damned British. In terms of plotting, shooting and intellectual appeal, it feels
as if the folk who made Inspector Morse had reassembled for one last hurrah.
There is something curiously nostalgic about watching work of this type and
calibre. Whatever its cinema fate, the Sunday night schedulers from the main TV
stations would be well advised to start their bidding now.

Mr Austin's script lets no one off easily.

Police, preachers, Saudis, Brits, bus drivers:

everyone is affected by the shock waves from 9/11 and 7/7, and everyone is found
wanting.

Outside of the cinema, those in charge of our cultural and artistic life are
surely found wanting too. It has taken an LA script-writer and two Indians
resident in America to confront questions of what it means to be a Londoner in
the age of Islamism and the suicide bomber.

LOAD-DATE: August 10, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

                              All Rights Reserved

German police chief warns against terrorists attacks

LENGTH: 292 words


Text of report by independent German news agency ddp

Berlin (ddp) -The Federal Criminal Police Office (BKA) is proceeding on the
assumption that Al-Qa'idah and the Islamic Jihad Union (IJU) are planning to
carry out terror attacks in Germany. "In the light of the pronouncements by

the Jihad Union. Ziercke sees the main threat emanating from Islamist Eric B. as
the danger of his bringing about an attack on the Federal Armed Forces in
Afghanistan. He has already announced attacks on German targets in a video.

German Islamists' sojourns at training camps in Afghanistan and Pakistan are
being viewed with growing concern by the BKA. According to Ziercke, more than 50
Islamists from the Federal Republic have now undergone training in camps over
there. Up to nine of such individuals had already returned to Germany, he added.
These terror suspects are seen as forming part of almost 100 "persons rated as
dangerous," whom the BKA knows to be presently residing in the Federal Republic.
More than 200 investigations into Islamist terror suspects are presently
underway in Germany, said Ziercke.

Terrorist attacks in Russia on the wane - Duma MP

LENGTH: 288 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian military news agency Interfax-AVN
website

Moscow, 8 August: Head of the State Duma security committee Vladimir Vasilyev
has said that the number of terrorist acts in Russia falls by 50 per cent every
year.

"Whereas in 2005 there were 257 terrorist acts in the country, in 2006 there
were 112, and in 2007 - 48," Vasilyev said at a news conference in Moscow today.

He said Russia had developed a legal basis, taken the relevant organizational
measures, and drawn up mechanisms to prevent terrorist acts.

"We have fulfilled the task to stop and localize terror," Vasilyev said.
Currently, the question of prevention is coming to the foreground. He noted that
this is a more difficult task and it will be resolved as part of the Antiterror
programme.

He said Russia has a potential which allows it to finance to a large extent
antiterrorist preventive measures. Law makers also contribute to the process.
For instance, the Duma is now discussing two important draft laws: one on
binomial registration [Russ: binomnaya registratsiya] and the other one on
making deals with the law.

Speaking about the first draft law, Vasilyev said it would bring about a new
form of registration on the DNA level and a new database would be set up.

The second draft law will help prevent serious crimes, including terrorist acts,
through deals between the law and those members of criminal and terrorist groups
who committed no serious crimes and are prepared, in order to alleviate their
fate, to give up their bosses to police. Vasilyev said the law-enforcement
agencies and special services are pinning great hopes on the law.

Aug 08

                                 The New Review

                                August 10, 2008
                                 First Edition

Rising from the rubble;
Chris Cleave's debut novel, about a terrorist attack on London, was published
with horrific aptness on 7 July 2005. He talks to Christian House about his
equally controversial follow up

BYLINE: Christian House

SECTION: ARTS; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 1347 words


Considering the pivotal plot point of Chris Cleave's new novel, The Other Hand,
it's disconcerting to be flown out to the south of France to interview its
author. A trip down to the Mediterranean, where he has taken a summer house, is
far from a chore. Yet Cleave portrays two journalists on just such a
professional jolly who end up skewered by the sharp end of fate's stick.
Thankfully, as we sit out on a terrace restaurant in Nîmes, the only thing I'm
struck by is the searing Provençal sun.

Cleave navigates us smoothly through our order (his wife is French) with a jolly
demeanour that belies a keen intellect. He's full of zeal and brings to mind one
of those determined gentlemen code-breakers of Bletchley Park. It is this same
mix of affability and inquiry that infuses his fiction.

In The Other Hand, Sarah O'Rourke, a women's magazine editor, and her husband,
Andrew, accept a freebie holiday to a beach in southern Nigeria. There they
encounter two Nigerian girls, Little Bee and her older sister, victims of the
country's oil war. "What happened on the beach" (which I won't divulge here, but
is truly nightmarish) ultimately destroys Andrew. Three years later, on the day
of his funeral, Sarah and her four-year old Batman-obsessed son, Charlie, find
Little Bee on their west London doorstep. Now 16 and, having escaped a detention
centre, she's an illegal alien looking for a new family. One defining moment a
continent away triggers a comic tale of acceptance and a neat critique of the
British attitude to asylum-seekers.

"The Home Office aren't evil, there's no conspiracy," comments Cleave, although
he couldn't get anyone in the department to see him when researching the novel.
"There's just a general lethargy about the way these asylum-seekers are treated.
Which means no one gets exercised that they're put in handcuffs, taken on to
planes and deported back to places where they're going to die." He understands
that not all of the media are complacent. He refers to The Independent's
balanced look at "the numbers" and how the BBC "are making an effort". Yet there
remains a stubborn group that confuses asylum seekers with illegal immigrants.
"The Daily Mail can't say 'asylum-seeker' without saying 'foreign criminal' in
the same sentence. I'm sure it's practically editorial policy." Cleave points
out that Joseph Conrad, Sigmund Freud and Einstein were all asylum seekers and
that "John Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath is a refugee novel, just inter-state.
The same hate remains."

The ludicrous nature of two worlds colliding is tangible in the book. Sarah
reflects: "We looked as if we'd been cobbled together in Photoshop ... the three
of us, walking to my husband's funeral. One white middle-class mother, one
skinny black refugee girl, and one small dark knight from Gotham City. It seemed
as if we'd been cut-and-pasted."

Inspiration for The Other Hand came in part from an early childhood spent in
West Africa and, more importantly, from a chance holiday job during his
university years (Cleave studied experimental psychology at Oxford). "We painted
underpasses, we did gardening, litter-picking. All good fun and I was thinking
of writing a book about it. The last job of that summer was at Campsfield House
in Oxfordshire. Now they call it an Immigration Removal Centre; at the time it
was an Asylum Detention Centre," says Cleave.

"For three days I was serving this inedible food to people who'd come from
Somalia, Eritrea, the Congo, from the Balkans. From war zones. They'd fled for
good reason. I got talking with some of them and said why are you here? Why are
you in prison? It's not illegal and yet we concentrate them in these places.
It's a text-book definition of a concentration camp. The conditions are
appalling. I was shocked enough for that to be the end of my light comedy book
of my amusing summers working as a labourer." Yet The Other Hand is very funny
indeed: "So often what happens to these people is ridiculous to the point of
laugh-out-loud funny."

Cleave insists that he is not a political writer. However, he begins the book
with a quote from a 2005 UK Home Office publication entitled United Kingdom: A
Journey to Citizenship. "Britain is proud of its tradition of providing a safe
haven for people fleeting (sic) persecution and conflict." If a government can't
even successfully proof-read such a fundamental document, how seriously can we
take its asylum procedure?

After university, Cleave spent a decade jobbing around, first as an online
journalist for the Telegraph and then editorial adviser for the then fledgling
lastminute.com. "Everyone at lastminute seems to go on to do what they really
wanted to do," he laughs. Then his debut novel, Incendiary, exploded on to the
publishing scene. It detailed the aftermath of a terrorism attack on London and
was published by awful coincidence on 7 July 2005. "I don't think my book is
unusually prescient," he stated a week after the bombings. "We all knew this was
coming - but none of my months of imagining the horror prepared me for the
reality of it."

Full of rage and humour, Incendiary was an international bestseller but divided
opinion. "Dear Osama," it began, "they want you dead or alive so the terror will
stop. Well I wouldn't know about that. I mean rock *roll didn't stop when Elvis
died on the khazi, it just got worse." The New York Times called it "a simple
case of tastelessness", a judgement that Cleave absolutely rejects. A similar
salvo was directed at Jay McInerney when he published his 9/11 themed novel The
Good Life. However, both authors celebrate what Cleave calls the public's
"amazing refusal to bow". What rankles more are the snide comments on his
literary ventriloquism (he has created first-person narratives of a
working-class mother and a Nigerian teenager). "And I'm super posh?" he asks,
clearly annoyed. He dismisses it as easy criticism. "Other people would do it if
they were good enough."

Family life has been essential to the conception of both books. "I would never
have written either of the stories without having been a parent. I'm a much
better writer for being a father," says Cleave, who has two young children. If
parenthood provides the trigger to his writing, it also provides the target.
"You think, well look, I've changed your nappy, I've taught you how to swim, but
all of that means nothing if you're going to grow up into a world that is
callous and stupid. I do this," he says pointing to the copy of his novel on the
table, "for the same reason I change nappies."

Both books feature sassy, unfaithful wives and marital shenanigans of lad lit
proportions. "This thing with being lovers, it isn't like being married," states
Sarah. "To remain in the game, one has to be considerate." Behind the quips,
Cleave seems aware of the deeper motivations of infidelity. "When you are
choosing a lover," he says, "you're choosing a philosophy; it's not about sex,
it's not about marriage. With Sarah, her unfaithfulness is just one of the
symptoms of the fact that she's torn and is going to have to make this strong
moral choice."

Cleave is adamant that optimism and laughter are the necessary binding agents
for humanity to overcome catastrophe. "The reason why I love people, and writing
about them, is because they don't always respond with hate and anger. If they
did I wouldn't have a story to tell. Who wants to know about someone who was
brutalised and became brutal? I'm interested in the exceptions." Or as the
Nigerian proverb that ends The Other Hand puts it: "If your face is swollen from
the severe beatings of life, smile and pretend to be a fat man." n

The extract

The Other Hand By Chris Cleave Sceptre £12.99

'... I was still watching the girl. The wind blew at her yellow sari and I saw
there was a scar across her throat, right across it, thick like your little
finger. It was white as a bone against her dark skin. It was knotted and curled
against her windpipe, like it did not want to let go. ... She saw me looking and
she hid the scar with her hand, so I looked at her hand. There were scars on
that too'

                                   Daily Star

                             August 11, 2008 Monday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

Terror of teen attacks

SECTION: NEWS; 2

LENGTH: 91 words


TEENAGERS carry out 760 violent crimes every day, shock new figures reveal.

Although overall crime is falling, there has been a huge rise in crimes
committed by under 16s, including robberies, muggings and violent attacks.

Statistics from the British Crime Survey show that in the 12 months to March
this year, one in eight violent crimes were committed by school-age children.

Home Secretary Jacqui Smith has been criticised after telling MPs that the
chances of being a victim of crime were "at their lowest level since 1981", with
violence down by 8%.

                            Herald Express (Torquay)

                             August 11, 2008 Monday

Rail worker's terror at night time van attack

BYLINE:  STAFF REPORTER

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 300 words


A terrified rail worker cowered in his van in the early hours as youths launched
a sustained attack on the vehicle, and claimed they had guns.

He had been working on the track at Newton Abbot, and was sleeping in the Ford
Transit before driving home to Cornwall, South Devon magistrates, sitting at
Newton Abbot, heard.

Before them was one of the gang, Wayne Barlow of Church Street, Paignton, who
pleaded guilty to criminal damage.

Crown prosecutor Philip Sewell said that on July 13, the rail man was woken at
about 4.55am near the track, after hearing somebody walking around outside.

He thought it might be fellow workers, but suddenly there was a loud bang on the
van as if somebody was kicking or punching it, and he heard a voice say:
'There's somebody in there'.

There was another big bang, the sound of glass being smashed, and a voice
declared: 'There's five of us, and two have got guns', and adding, 'we need to
get home somehow'.

Mr Sewell told the court: "The worker was very worried for his personal safety,
and was shocked that his van was being smashed up for no reason whatsoever."

The man called the police on his mobile from inside the van, and they quickly
arrived and arrested Barlow near the scene.

Mr Sewell said that the  damage totalled about £1,700, but that Barlow had only
been responsible for smashing a side window.

In mitigation, Richard Porritt said that Barlow was out with friends and had
been drinking all evening, although he did not normally drink a lot.

He was 'profoundly ashamed', and would not do it again, Mr Porritt told
magistrates.

The bench told Barlow he had caused considerable fear to the man, who was very
shocked and frightened. It was a group activity and the damage was significant.

Barlow was fined £150 with £45 costs, and told to pay £32.99 towards the damage.

LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       BBC Monitoring Africa - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            August 12, 2008 Tuesday

Kenya: Man jailed for threatening Chinese embassy with terror attack

LENGTH: 125 words


Excerpt from unattributed report "Embassy terror fax lands trader in jail"
published by Kenyan newspaper Daily Nation on 12 August

A businessman was yesterday jailed for three years for faxing a message to the
Chinese embassy in Nairobi, claiming it would be attacked by terrorists.

Cornel Owama Chweya, a Kisumu-based trader [western Kenya], was convicted by
Nairobi Senior Principal Magistrate Cecilia Githua on his own plea of guilty.
Chweya, 26, said he sent the message "in good faith".

The prosecutor, lead by Chief Inspector David Wangai, said the fax claimed there
would be a terrorist attack on the Chinese embassy on 210 July 2008.

Chweya can appeal within 14 days. [Passage omitted: other trials]

                              Liverpool Daily Echo

                            August 12, 2008 Tuesday
                                  2ND Edition

My petrol bomb attack terror;
Landlady escapes blaze thanks to hero neighbours

BYLINE: LUKE TRAYNOR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 407 words


A LIVERPOOL landlady today told how she ran for her life after a petrol bomb
attack on her pub.

Jackie Disley was about to go to bed when the device was thrown through a top
window of the Oakfield, in Anfield.

The 44-year-old was only alerted to the spreading blaze by two heroic
neighbours.

Friends said they feared Ms Disley could have been killed by the thick smoke.

The landlady and mother told the ECHO: "I was watching TV with my dog, about to
go to bed, when I became aware of a lot of noise.

"I realised the pub was on fire and I just rushed down the stairs.

"It was very frightening. I don't know why anyone would want to do this."

The fire ravaged the recently decorated first floor function room and spread to
others parts of the building, causing damage estimated at thousands of pounds.

Ms Disley, who has run the Oakfield for the past nine years, said she rarely
spends the night in the top-floor living quarters.

And she has no idea why anybody would target the pub, which is popular with LFC
supporters.

The Oakfield, at the junction with Thirlmere Road, was sealed off by police.

Many of the windows were blackened and shattered by the heat of the flames.

Susan Elliott and her daughter Kelsey, 19, were upstairs at their home opposite
on Oakfield Road when they saw flames inside the pub.

Ms Elliott said: "Kelsey spotted something which looked like a ghostly shape,
before realising it was fire.

"We ran outside and were shouting up to Jackie and ringing on all the doorbells
until she finally heard us. When she came outside she was in a right state,
panicking and white as a sheet.

"Jackie is a lovely woman and it's terrible to think anyone should do anything
to try and harm her.

"Thank God she hadn't already gone to bed or who knows what might have
happened."

A Merseyside Police spokesman said: "We are appealing for witnesses following a
suspected arson attack at the Oakfield Hotel, Oakfield Road, Anfield.

"Officers were called to the scene just after 12.30am following a call from the
fire service.

"At this stage the investigation officers are treating the fire as suspicious.We
are in the early stages of the investigation and are working with Merseyside
Fire Service to ascertain how the fire started.

"We would urge anyone who may have seen anyone acting suspiciously in the area,
or who may have any information, to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555111."

luketraynor@liverpoolecho.co.uk

                            BBC Monitoring Kiev Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            August 14, 2008 Thursday

Diplomat warns Russian ships' role may expose Ukraine to "terrorist attacks"

LENGTH: 238 words


The Ukrainian Foreign Ministry has expressed concern that the participation of
ships of the Russian Black Sea Fleet in military actions against Georgia might
lead to terrorist attacks in Ukraine's Crimea, the Interfax-Ukraine news agency
reported at 1008 gmt, quoting the deputy head of the Ukrainian part of the
sub-commission for Russian Black Sea Fleet issues of the Ukrainian-Russian
interstate commission, Viktor Semenov, as saying on 14 August.

"The worst thing that could happen for Ukraine is that the use of weapon by the
armed forces of the Russian Federation from the territory of Ukraine against
third countries could lead to unpredictable terrorist attacks against the
facilities and forces of the Russian Black Sea Fleet based on the territory of
Ukraine and, consequently, against the population of Ukraine," Semenov told a
briefing.

At the same time, Semenov described as "groundless" Russia's complaints about
Ukraine's decision to demand that Russian warships based in Crimea's Sevastopol
should obtain permission for their movements outside Ukrainian territory,
Interfax-Ukraine reported at 1036 gmt the same day.

Ukraine proposed to discuss the issue of the deployment of the Russian fleet in
Crimea in July, Semenov said. "But the Russian side refused to meet," he added.

Sources: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kiev, in Russian 1008 gmt 14 Aug 08;
Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kiev, in Russian 1036 gmt 14 Aug 08

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                            August 14, 2008 Thursday

United Nations: Security Council Press Statement On Terrorist Attack In Lebanon

LENGTH: 267 words


RDATE:13082008

The following Security Council press statement on the terrorist attack in
Lebanon was read out today by Council President Jan Grauls ( Belgium):

The members of the Security Council condemned in the strongest terms the
terrorist attack in the Lebanese town of Tripoli on 13 August 2008, which caused
numerous deaths and injuries, including amongst members of the Lebanese Armed
Forces.

The members of the Security Council expressed their condolences to the families
of the victims, to the Lebanese Armed Forces and to the Government of Lebanon.

The members of the Security Council underlined the need to bring perpetrators,
organizers, financiers and sponsors of this reprehensible act of terrorism to
justice, commended the commitment of the Government of Lebanon to this end and
urged all States, in accordance with their obligations under international law
and relevant Security Council resolutions, to cooperate actively with the
Lebanese authorities in this regard. They also recalled the need to put an end
to impunity in Lebanon.

The members of the Security Council emphasized the importance of the unity of
all the Lebanese people. They also reiterated their full support for all ongoing
efforts in Lebanon to combat terrorism, solidify democratic institutions, engage
in political dialogue and pursue national reconciliation.

                                The West Briton

                                August 14, 2008

Scrutineer takes a look at life in the Helston area;
Terrorist attack... storms... fire hazards... threats from venom. Faced with
that apocalyptic list of possible fates you might think we were talking about an
end of the world-type scenario.

SECTION: Pg. 10

LENGTH: 527 words


Is Helston really that tacky? Some councillors think so. And they're right to do
so. Admittedly the town - whose main street was hailed by no less a person than
the late poet laureate Sir John Betjeman - is pristine compared to a couple of
north Cornish resorts we could mention.

At the very least, you could consider this was applicable to  the risk factor
of, say, the opening of the 2012 Olympics.

But no. These are just some of the possible hazards which might possibly befall
those attending... Helston Harvest Fair.

To be fair they have been chosen willfully and not in the least bit arbitrarily
by my good self from a list of possible occurrences drawn up in a draft risk
assessment form which has been studied by the Harvest Fair committee of Helston
Town Council.

Gone, apparently, are the days when someone could just turn up, bung up a big
tent and let the various show organisers get on with it.

Everything, it seems, has to be assessed for potential risk when people gather
in their dozens or hundreds, or thousands.

Even something as indisputably wonderful and, yes, even life affirming as Flora
Day is not immune with dark mutterings at the time of this year's dances about
the risk to public safety if dancers who have undertaken the event since "before
the mists of time" went through their normal route.

It's probably a good job we didn't have "risk assessments" when they started the
age-old tradition; the stewards would  have had to make provision for
pterodactyl attack or the health risks of slapping on too much woad.

We've lost innocence along with the plot.

And yet... one has to be slightly ambivalent about this sort of thing.

Remember, it was only a few months ago that there was a terrorist scare in
Exeter... yes, Exeter... the details of which may well emerge more fully if a
case goes to court.

But suddenly terrorism ceased to be something that happened to other people in
other lands.

If not on Cornwall's doorstep (and it could be argued the incident was) then it
was at the very least in the room next door.

At the risk of adding to all the doom and gloom around at the moment (just when
you thought things couldn't get any worse, the Russians start sabre rattling
again) it's probably fair to say that all of us are just that little bit less
safe than we were a decade or so ago.

Is there a risk assessment for depression, I wonder?

But there's also little doubt that a number of areas could be cleaned up.

Most of these are as a result of man's inability to find waste paper bins but
nature is by no means immune from criticism, either.

The difference is, of course, that while humankind should take responsibility
for its own waste, it  also has to ensure that nature's is tidied up.

Anyway, I digress.

Yes, the exterior of some town centre shops have seen better days, and, yes
again, flyposterers should be taken away and publicly flogged with rolled up
copies of their wares.

On this very page you will see that one woman, Tisha Browne, has been praised
for her efforts to keep Helston clean, tidy and attractive to visitors.

Perhaps we could all take a leaf out of her book (and dispose of it in the
proper manner when we're done with it).

LOAD-DATE: August 21, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 61


                         Copyright 2008 The West Briton
                              All Rights Reserved

                               Grimsby Telegraph

                            August 16, 2008 Saturday

'It is not the dog, I blame the owner';
A Woman has spoken of her terror after she was attacked by a dog in Cleethorpes.

BYLINE: simon faulkner

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 349 words


The vicious attack left Patricia Billard (57) with puncture wounds in two
fingers.

As a result of the injury, her left hand became infected and her fingers swelled
up so much firefighters had to be called to cut off her wedding ring.

Mrs Billard, who came out of hospital yesterday, said: "I was absolutely
terrified. My dog was screaming. I didn't know what to do. I was in a terrible
state, covered in blood."

Mrs Billard, who is disabled and uses a mobility scooter, was walking her
five-year-old boxer dog, Max, in an alleyway near to her home at around 7.30am
on Sunday morning.

As she locked the gate to the alleyway behind her, she turned around to see a
snarling Staffordshire bull terrier (SBT).

She added she was sure it was a SBT, as she had a good knowledge and liking of
dogs for many years.

She said: "It went for my dog. It happened so quickly."

The dog bit Max on the side of his head and left two holes in his tongue.

When Mrs Billard tried to protect Max, the other dog grabbed her hand,
fracturing one finger and breaking another.

She said: "It could've torn my fingers off."

Eventually Mrs Billard managed to restrain the dog by pulling Max's lead round
it's neck.

Her husband Ian (61) learnt of the attack when his wife returned to their house.

He said: "She was at the bottom of the stairs, shouting and screaming. There was
blood everywhere."

The attack was reported to the police who asked Mrs Billard to identify the dog,
but when they went around to the home of the suspect there was no answer.

The couple are worried that the dog is still at large.

Mrs Billard said: "I'm upset about it still. I'm frightened to go out in the
alleyway. It could be a kiddie next time. It doesn't bear thinking about."

Her husband said: "It shouldn't be let out on it's own."

Mrs Billard added: "It's not the dog's fault. I blame the owner."

A spokesperson for Humberside Police said: "A call was received at 8.39am
reporting a woman had been attacked by a dog and was on her way to hospital for
treatment. Her dog was also injured.

"Officers are investigating the incident and have spoken to the woman."

                            Mail on Sunday (London)

                             August 17, 2008 Sunday
                                  MS2 Edition

The British feel safe in Turkey's stunning south;
As the country recovers from a terror attack, peaceful Dalaman has Med style for
half the price of properties in Spain and Italy

BYLINE: Jessie Hewitson

SECTION: Pg. 54

LENGTH: 816 words


More than 20,000 Britons have so far bought homes in Turkey - drawn by the warm
weather, the beaches on the southern coast and a flavour of the Med at half the
price of Spain or Italy.

The big question mark over the future of this market is how possible buyers will
react to the latest terrorist bombs in Istanbul last month that killed 17 and
injured 150.

It was the eighth terrorist attack in tourist areas since 2003, as Islamists
seek to overturn Turkey's secular constitution.

Despite this tension the economy has been soaring by 6 per cent per year from
2002 through 2007, one of the highest sustained rates of growth in the world. So
fear of terrorism is the last thing agents and developers want but, not
surprisingly, they claim it is business as usual.

'I haven't seen a drop in enquiries after the bombs and I've not had one client
who has expressed concern over terrorism or safety,' says Andy Hawkins of
Chesterton International.

His agency is in charge of selling The Hill development in Alanya on the
southern coast. 'The attacks so far have been in Istanbul, not the tourist or
holiday home areas,' he points out.

The latest area being marketed to British buyers is Dalaman. Budget airline
easyJet has recently started flying from Gatwick - it takes four hours - to this
small town in southern Turkey. Previously you could fly expensively via
Istanbul, or by taking one of the weekly charter planes operated by Thomas Cook.

Dalaman is a 15-minute drive from Gocek, the exclusive yachting resort where
actress Demi Moore and her husband Ashton Kutcher holidayed last year, and where
Russian oligarch and Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich has docked one of his
mega-yachts. Marmaris, the busy, overdeveloped coastal resort, is a 90-minute
drive away.

Once you get past the unremarkable town of Dalaman, the scenery is spectacular -
a cross between the forests, lakes and open spaces of Canada and the pine and
orange trees of the Mediterranean. Sun is a reliable presence, and the price of
property is a big pull, too, with flats starting at just over £40,000 and villas
at under £70,000.

What you can buy here is mostly new-build. Older properties are passed on by
Turks through the generations and rarely come on the market. In addition,
property laws mean foreigners cannot buy land in rural areas.

Developer Curbanoglu, run by the Ilhan family, is building apartments and villas
in Akkaya, a rural area overlooking the mountains and emerald-green lakes, 15
minutes away from the town and the airport. So far, 73 properties have been
built and sold in the 300,000 acres of land. The plan is to build a total of 500
homes..

The Ilhans own almost all of Akkaya, save for the bits of protected forest that
belong to the government, and grew up in the area when there was no electricity,
modern roads or running water. Prices start at £44,000 for a two-bedroom flat
and rise to £154,000 for a fourbedroom detached villa with three bathrooms, a
private garden, swimming pool and lake views. Included in the development is a
safari-style lakeside bar with thatched roof and treehouse tables for dining.

It is predominantly Britons who are buying in this area, meaning that if
anything happens to shake British confidence in Turkey, it could have serious
consequences for anyone who wants to sell on their property..

Prices in Turkey rose between 15 and 20 per cent last year, according to Knight
Frank, after the country introduced a new law in 2006 allowing foreign buyers to
get mortgages in Turkey.

Capital growth in Dalaman has echoed this, according to Dominic Whiting,
director of Buying in Turkey, and is going up by 15 per cent a year. 'Even so,'
says Whiting, 'British buyers who could afford a flat in Spain find the same
money can buy them a villa with a pool in Turkey.' Kathryn Stewart, an NHS
manager from Leeds, bought a villa in Akkaya with her husband Gerry, 61, a
university lecturer. 'We bought the land and built a three-bedroom villa with
pool in 2005. It cost just over £130,000,' says Kathryn, 36.

'We had been looking at the US, Italy and Portugal, but the property we bought
in Turkey was far bigger than anything we could have afforded in those
countries.

'I had been on holiday in Marmaris, which is pretty built-up, but Akkaya is
quieter and less developed. We know there will be further development but feel
confident there won't be the high-rise building that has spoilt other Turkish
areas.' The building quality in Turkey may not always be as high as that of
Mediterranean counterparts, however.

During a two-day stay in one of Curbanoglu's villas, hot water proved unreliable
- surprising in a property where the developers knew journalists were staying.

A retired resident told me repairs happen in 'Turkish time', which, she said,
means a few weeks later than when you want.

Buying In Turkey, 0845 351 3551, www.buyingin.co.uk; Curbanoglu, 0845 355 5625,
www.curbanoglu.co.uk..

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                           August 20, 2008 Wednesday

Frankland jail: Muslim inmates living in fear for their safety at high-security
prison: Report says convicted terrorists target of attacks: Inspector calls for
action to tackle the problem

BYLINE: Alan Travis, Home affairs editor

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 600 words


Muslim prisoners, including some convicted terrorists, inside one of Britain's
biggest high security prisons feel so unsafe that they have sought sanctuary in
the jail's segregation unit for their own protection, the chief inspector of
prisons discloses today.

Anne Owers says that there have been serious incidents of "prisoner-on-prisoner"
violence inside Frankland prison, near Durham, with black and ethnic minority
inmates in general the target of attacks and Muslim prisoners in particular.

Owers says in her inspection report on the high security jail published today
that some, but not all, of the Muslim inmates who have been attacked had been
convicted of terrorism offences.

Fourteen prisoners have been identified by the prison authorities as involved in
racist activities, some for racially motivated offences and others with links to
racist organisations. Owers also reports there has been a "serious incident"
involving groups of black and ethnic minority prisoners and white prisoners.

Two high-profile terrorists, Dhiren Barot and Omar Khyam, were moved out of
Frankland prison in March amid claims the jail had become "an extremely
dangerous environment for ethnic minority prisoners". Barot's solicitor,
Mudassar Arani, told the high court that boiling water and oil had been thrown
over Barot last July and he had spent a week in hospital.

The prison inspectors report that when they surveyed inmates about their
treatment by staff the responses by black and ethnic minority prisoners were
worse than those of white prisoners on a range of issues and they were also
over-represented in all disciplinary procedures, including use of force,
segregation and adjudications.

Staff understanding and knowledge of Muslim prisoners was particularly weak.
Muslim prisoners had been stopped from holding communal prayers in cells, on
landings and in exercise yards without the chaplaincy being consulted.

Frankland, with more than 700 inmates convicted of serious offences, is one of
the largest high-security jails. Owers says its population has become even more
"challenging" for staff recently with an influx of prisoners with gang
affiliations and the arrival of a small number of terrorists.

"It is unfortunate that this coincided with the absence of the governor for some
months, and the resulting drift that was observable at this inspection needs
urgently to be reversed," said Owers.

She says that action is particularly important as Frankland is due to expand to
more than 1,000 prisoners - far more than any dispersal prison has so far been
required to hold.

The inspection, carried out in February, found no evidence of a robust strategy
to reduce violence to deal with bullying and ensure safety, order and control.
More than one in four prisoners on the general wings tested positive for drugs -
a high ratio for a high-security jail.

Owers does, however, praise the prison's work on the special dangerous and
serious personality disorders unit, which holds 80 of the most dangerous
prisoners in the prison system. She says that innovative work is being carried
out.

Phil Wheatley, the director general of the National Offender Management Service,
said he was concerned about the comments about the safety of prisoners within
Frankland but added they should be seen within the context of the prison's
"extremely challenging" population.

"The issues raised in the report are currently being addressed by the governor
and staff at Frankland. A new diversity and safer prisons manager is in post to
ensure a focus on matters raised by the inspector in relation to anti-bullying
and diversity."

                            August 21, 2008 Thursday

Algerian civil society condemns Boumerdes, Bouira terror attacks

LENGTH: 447 words


Algeria civil society and political organizations expressed their strong
condemnation of the two terror attacks which killed 60 60 Algerians on 19 and 20
August, Algerian radio reported.

The state-run radio said that Algerians had also voiced their commitment to the
national reconciliation policy launched by President Abdelaziz Bouteflika in an
attempt to end the bloody unrest during the 1990s.

National Democratic Rally (RND), led by Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia, reiterated
its condemnation of the attack, calling for increasing support for the security
forces. The RND urged citizens' vigilance and alertness in order to foil any
terror attacks.

Algerian Workers' Party leader, Louisa Hannoune, deplored the attack, describing
it as a "savage plan to target Algeria's stability".

Good governance ensures stability

Algerian Muslim Ulema Association appealed on members of terror groups to
"return to their families, people and nation" in a plea for peace aired by the
Algerian radio.

The head of the association, the highest religious authority in Algeria,
Abderrahmane Chibane, said: "Shedding the blood of the innocent, harming them
physically and psychologically and the destruction of their properties are great
evils against both the religion and the nation."

Chibane added that Islam was "described nowadays as the religion of terrorism,
violence, random killing and aggression against civilians". "Islam is innocent
of these invalid and unjust charges."

Proposing solutions to the problem of terrorism, he said: "The authorities'
commitment to promoting the national reconciliation, the continuing use of
Algeria's resources for the benefit of all its citizens and adopting social
justice and good governance are the ways to ensure the stability of society and
the country's development."

"Everyone's cause"

President of the International Federation of Terror Victims' Organizations Saida
Benhabyles condemned the attacks, calling for more engagement in awareness
raising and education.

She said: "Condemnation is a very weak word to express the feeling that
overwhelms us every time we hear about a cowardly criminal attack of this kind."

"It is necessary to continue the work in [community] mobilization and awareness
on a daily basis without relying on a particular incident."

Benhabyles added that it was "felt that the civil society and political class
gave up to some extent their actions against terrorism".

She said that the national reconciliation policy "did not help those who carried
out the attacks", adding that the policy should be spread at the grassroots
level as terrorism was "everyone's cause".

Source: Algerian radio, Algiers, in Arabic 0600 gmt 21 Aug 08

Azeri agency says two killed in terror attack in Baku

LENGTH: 221 words


Text of report by private Azerbaijani news agency Turan

Baku, 22 August: A grenade or an explosive device could be the cause of today's
explosion at a power substation in Xatai district [of Baku], Turan news agency
has found out from informed sources in law-enforcement bodies. Some experts are
inclined to think that this was an explosive device, since eyewitnesses say that
black smoke emerged in the wake of the explosion. This does not happen when a
grenade explodes. The final conclusion will be drawn after experts give their
opinions.

At the same time, the wounds received by the victims were caused by fragments.
The Interior Ministry, Prosecutor's Office and the National Security Ministry
are so far not giving any comments, citing that investigation is secret. Rustam
Usubov, deputy prosecutor-general, and other leaders of power-wielding bodies
are at the site of the incident. The place has been sealed off and journalists
are not allowed and no comments are made.

To all appearances, a terrorist attack took place in Xatai District, but so far
it is not clear who was behind this.

[At 1135 gmt Turan reported that the explosion occurred when workers opened the
substation's doors to enter. Two people were killed and two wounded, according

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             August 22, 2008 Friday

Philippines: MPs, defence chief see Moro attacks as "acts of terrorism"

LENGTH: 1265 words


Text of report in English by Philippine newspaper The Philippine Star website on
21 August

[Report by Christina Mendez with James Mananghaya, Jose Rodel Clapano: "Senators
Want MILF Tagged as Terror Group"]

Senators urged the government to classify the Moro Islamic Liberation Front
(MILF) as a terrorist organization following the deadly attacks in North
Cotabato and Lanao del Norte.

Senators Juan Ponce Enrile and Rodolfo Biazon, who both served as defence
chiefs, said the MILF should be included in the list of terrorist organizations
and file criminal charges against its leaders for the brutal and violent attacks
that killed over 40 people, including an Army colonel.

The communist New People's Army and the extremist Abu Sayyaf are already in the
list.

Enrile, who served as defence chief of the late strongman Ferdinand Marcos, said
government should file criminal charges against the MILF for violation of the
Human Security Act.

"If I were the government, I will charge them under the Anti-Terrorism Law...
They fall squarely under the Human Security Act. You have to charge them. The
fact is they committed a crime," Enrile said.

Enrile also joined his colleagues in urging the government to suspend peace
negotiations with the MILF until law and order is restored in Mindanao.

Biazon, for his part, said the MILF has crossed the line between rebellion and
terrorism.

"The MILF attacks against the towns of Sarangani, North Cotabato and Lanao del
Norte were characterized by the murder of defenceless civilians, arson,
kidnapping, hostage taking and destruction of properties," Biazon said.

"These are all predicate crimes that constitute one of the elements of the crime
of terrorism, the other element is when these are committed in order to coerce
the government to give in to an unlawful demand," Biazon added.

Biazon noted the announcements of the MILF leadership that the attacks were
apparently meant to force the issue of the Memorandum of Agreement on Ancestral
Domain (MOA-AD), which was supposed to have been signed with the government and
could have allowed the rebel group their own turf.

The Supreme Court put on hold the signing of the agreement because of
constitutional issues.

"Based on the pronouncements coming out of the MILF leadership, these acts had
been committed to push MOA-AD. The only remaining act of government is to
officially declare that the MILF is now categorized as terrorists like the Abu
Sayyaf," Biazon said.

In bad faith

Biazon said the government will have to "radically" change its dealings with the
MILF by pulling out from the peace negotiations and push for the arrest of the
guerrilla leaders behind the attacks.

Sen. Alan Peter Cayetano and his elder sister Sen. Pia Cayetano also said the
government should suspend the peace talks with the MILF following the attacks.

The Cayetano siblings urged the government to review its dealings with the MILF.

The elder Cayetano said the MILF must first show willingness to discipline its
own ranks and punish the rebel leaders behind the attacks.

"The MILF leadership must first display a firm commitment to its reported call
for ceasefire by helping in the capture of the so-called lost commands who
attacked civilian communities in North Cotabato and Lanao del Norte," she said.

The younger Cayetano said the MILF should be disarmed before appearing at the
negotiating table.

Sen. Loren Legarda, for her part, called on the MILF to surrender the two
guerrilla leaders behind the attacks.

Unless peace and order in Mindanao is restored and the two MILF commanders are
put behind bars, Legarda said the government should not entertain any discussion
with the MILF.

"Only when the perpetrators of those criminal and inhumane acts are apprehended
and made to answer in a competent court can the MILF come to the negotiating
table," she said.

Sen. Panfilo Lacson slammed the MILF for what he described as doublespeak by the
rebel group.

He said the MILF acted in bad faith in the peace negotiations.

"What the head says, the body does not obey. Or, it is plain doublespeak by the
MILF. Whatever it is, good faith is lost," he said.

Lacson said the government should exact justice from the MILF for killing of
innocent civilians and destruction of property in North Cotabato and Lanao del
Sur.

He added that government should not hesitate going after the perpetrators, dead
or alive.

Sen. Aquilino Pimentel said the government should first restore law and order
before dealing with the MILF at the negotiating table.

He urged the government to charge those behind the attacks before going back to
the peace negotiations.

Saving face

Defence Secretary Gilberto Teodoro said the attacks launched by the MILF in
Central Mindanao could be considered acts of terrorism.

Teodoro said the government is studying the possibility of filing criminal
charges under the Human Security Act against the MILF guerrillas involved in the
attacks.

Teodoro said the criminal charges to be filed against MILF commanders Amirel
Umbra Kato and Abdullah Saber Macapaar already carry maximum penalties under
present laws.

At the same time, Teodoro said the MILF should surrender its commanders who were
involved in the attacks.

"They are caught between trying to save face of one of their own and really
wanting to pursue the negotiations... The best thing to do for them is to
surrender these people to us so that we can prosecute them and for protection
that the law accords to citizens of this republic," he said.

Teodoro said the MILF could not justify the attacks staged by its fighters.

MILF chief Al Haj Murad Ebrahim told ABS-CBN that he had ordered the two rebel
leaders to stop the attacks in Central Mindanao.

"This is an unexpected situation. We have been very faithful in the peace
process and we hold the supremacy of the peace process. We are very saddened by
this situation and we hope, we are still optimistic that everybody will
cooperate and save the situation and the peace process," Murad said.

According to Murad, the attacks staged by the rebels were borne out of
frustration from the aborted signing of the MOA-AD.

"We are trying our best to restrain our commanders in order to save the
situation," he said.

Murad also expressed his desire for both panels to go back to talks and put an
end to the decades-old conflict in Mindanao.

For his part, former President Joseph Estrada said the government should totally
abandon dialogue with the MILF.

Estrada said the MILF demand for self-rule in Central Mindanao is tantamount to
dismembering the country.

In a speech before the business group Philippines Inc., Estrada explained why he
pursued an all out war against the MILF during his presidency.

"It was clear that I was dealing with a group that was not seeking peace but
power, an entity that was not only seeking autonomy but sovereignty."

"I believe in peace but not at the expense of our territorial integrity. I
believe in negotiations but this must be from a position of strength, not of
weakness," he said.

Estrada said the MOA-AD that would have allowed the MILF juridical disposition
over a large area in Mindanao "is treachery and treason under the illusion of
achieving peace."

Local officials also slammed the MILF for the treacherous attacks in North
Cotabato and Lanao del Norte.

The Union of Local Authorities of the Philippines (ULAP) led by Mandaluyong City
Mayor Benhur Abalos said the atrocities perpetrated by misguided elements of the
MILF are barbaric and criminal acts which contravene the spirit of the peace
negotiations between the government and MILF.

Source: The Philippine Star website, Manila, in English 21 Aug 08
