FAMILY IN FIREWORK ATTACK TERROR

BYLINE: By Warren Manger

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 220 words


A HEAVILY pregnant mum and her family were terrified when thugs hurled a
firework into their Coventry home.

They were at home in Wroxall Avenue, Willenhall, when the lit rocket was thrown
through their letterbox.

It shot along the hallway and into the lounge where it hit the fireplace and
exploded close to the woman, who is about to give birth.

The family has now fled the house because of fears of another attack.

Incredibly, the gang knew there were two police officers at the house at the
time, on Wednesday night.

They were speaking to the family after they complained about gangs outside their
home.

The father, who is too worried to be named, said: "I thought I heard a knock at
the door so I was just getting up to open the living room door when the rocket
flew past me, missing me by inches."

The rocket burned large patches of the living room carpet.

"My wife is nine months pregnant and she was terrified. These idiots didn't
think of the harm they could have done."

Two other homes in Willenhall also had fireworks pushed through their
letterboxes between 8pm and midnight on Wednesday.

The father said his family had been targeted by yobs before.

The windscreen of his van has been smashed twice and his car has been scratched.

He is working with Whitefriars housing association to find his family a safe
place to live.

                         Middlesbrough Evening Gazette

                            August 23, 2008 Saturday
                                  FIN Edition

TEEN IN BOMB TERROR;
Student evacuated after Philippines attacks EXCLUSIVE

BYLINE: MIKE BLACKBURN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 512 words


A TEESSIDE teenager on a gap year exchange to the Philippines has been caught up
in a violent bombing campaign.

Hannah Gordon, 19, from Eaglescliffe, had to be evacuated with her team of
volunteers after bomb blasts rocked the city of Iligan.

Two home-made bombs exploded almost simultaneously on Sunday, August 17, in two
budget hotels in the southern Philippine city, reportedly wounding at least four
people.

No one has claimed responsibility for the blasts, but the attack came amid
renewed hostilities between government troops and the Moro Islamic Liberation
Front, a rebel group that has waged a decades-long battle for Muslim self-rule
in the region.

Hannah, a former Egglescliffe Sixth Form College student, was two months into a
three-month exchange programme co-ordinated by Voluntary Services Overseas
(VSO), called Global Xchange - carrying out charity work in Iligan.

Hannah and her Team 71 were evacuated. She contacted the Gazette from the
Philippines to tell us about the drama. "Several bomb blasts hit Iligan City. It
was decided then to temporarily evacuate Team 71 to a location outside the city
where it would be safer," she said.

"As we reached our destination, we learned the situation in Iligan City had
escalated.

"We are deeply saddened by the violence, as well as having to leave the good
people of Iligan City, especially our host families and everyone at our
volunteer placements so abruptly.

"We are truly grateful for everything we have received from the people of Iligan
... and our hearts and minds are with them in these tense times."

The first bomb exploded in a guest room in the Iligan Travelers Inn near a
shopping mall, wounding at least three people. A second bomb went off within
minutes in a room in the Caprice Lodging House, injuring one person, according
to officials.

Hannah, who is off to study development geography at King's College, London, in
September, called her family in Eaglescliffe as soon as she could to let them
know she was safe.

Her mum and dad, Ingrid and Douglas, and older brothers Euan, 23, and Calum, 25,
were hugely relieved.

Speaking from the family home on Yarm Road yesterday, Euan said: "Hannah rang
mum to say she and her team had managed to get out to a safe place. Then later
my father got a call from the VSO organiser to confirm they had been evacuated.

They won't be returning to Iligan before they return home in a couple of weeks.
He said they might be further evacuated to Manila.

"Hannah said she feels safe now, but she was upset she didn't get to say goodbye
to everyone. She also had to leave her belongings."

Euan said his parents "both had their concerns" about Hannah going to the
Philippines, but added: "We're all very relieved she's OK and will be glad to
see her back."

Reuters news agency was reporting yesterday that the Philippines government
would not sign a peace deal with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front. It was
reported that 31 members of the group surrendered to the military on Thursday,
and were pictured shouting slogans supporting the government.

BEAUTY & THE BEAST;
ELECTRIC PICNIC 2008 EXCLUSIVE DUFFY'S FESTIVAL TERROR AFTER ATTACK BY LYDON

from punk rock bully Johnny Rotten.

The Welsh singer was reduced to tears at the Mojo Awards ceremony in London in
June when she was heckled and "pinned to the wall" by the notorious bad boy.

And the 24-year-old was horrified to discover the spiky-haired rock rebel, whose
real name is John Lydon, could bump into her again this weekend at the
Stradbally Hall festival in Co Laois.

The singer has asked organisers to place her hundreds of yards away from
Rotten's backstage area so they won't come to blows.

The sexy blonde star is one of the headline acts at the huge festival on
Saturday with the Sex Pistols starring on the main stage on Sunday. Rotten
attacked her as she was collecting a gong for song of the year at the bash.

Duffy revealed: "He'd been heckling me when I went to pick up an award, shouting
'Duffo', 'Up the Duffy', things like that.

suddenly he had me pinned against the wall. I just went white and had to get
away.

"I just had to leave the building through the back door, it was horrible. I went
home with a heavy heart and an award."

him - he scares the life out of her.

"All the VIPs will be mingling together in a luxurious back stage zone but
measures have been taken to reduce the chances of them crossing each other's
paths again."

The three-day music spectacle kicks off on Friday.

                        BBC Monitoring Central Asia Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           August 27, 2008 Wednesday

Kyrgyz minister denies terror attack behind plane crash

LENGTH: 227 words


The Kyrgyz authorities deny that a terrorist attack was behind a plane crash
that took place near Bishkek on 24 August and killed 65 people, Kyrgyz TV
reported on 25 August. The TV report said that a news conference was held by
Kyrgyz officials on the same day to brief journalists on possible reasons behind
the accident. At the news conference, Emergencies Minister Kamchibek Tashiyev
ruled out the version of a terrorist attack.

"There definitely was no terrorist attack. The state commission, headed by the
prime minister, which has already been set up, will investigate the reasons
behind the accident and work out its versions," Tashiyev said.

Another possible reason behind the accident might have been the poor technical
condition of the Boeing-737 aircraft. The aircraft was produced about 30 years
ago. Two months ago specialists checked it and found its condition satisfactory
for exploitation, the director of the civil aviation department, Alik Askarov,
said in remarks broadcast by the TV.

Investigations of the state commission and the international aviation committee
are expected to reveal the real reasons behind the accident. Several specialists
of the committee have already arrived in Bishkek, the report added.

(Report lasts for about four minutes. No further processing is planned)

                                  Morning Star

                           August 27, 2008 Wednesday

Britain - British media attack terror propaganda

BYLINE: James Tweedie

LENGTH: 394 words


Anti-war journalists condemned leaked government plans to open a new propaganda
front in the "war on terror" yesterday.

A leaked government briefing document revealed the global propaganda drive to
"taint the al-Qaida brand" by "channelling messages" through bloggers and
chatroom members as well as major media outlets like the BBC.

The document was issued by the Research Information and Communication Unit,
which was set up by former home secretary John Reid and is staffed by officials
from several Whitehall departments.

The document, entitled Challenging Violent Extremist Ideology Through
Communications and dated July 2008, says that people need to be told that
al-Qaida has been definitively expelled from large parts of Iraq and has lost
ground in Afghanistan.

It states: "We are pushing this material to UK media channels, eg a BBC radio
programme exposing tensions between AQ leadership and supporters.

"And a restricted working group will communicate niche messages through media
and non-media."

The communication unit's guidance says that the propaganda is primarily aimed at
"overseas communicators" in embassies and consulates around the world but could
be used in Britain as well.

Media Workers Against the War spokesman David Crouch said: "These revelations
raise very serious questions about recent corporate media coverage of the 'war
on terror.'

"In June, there was a string of stories in the British press stressing that
al-Qaida was 'down but not out,' suffering setbacks in Iraq and Afghanistan -
precisely the message being pushed by Whitehall counter-intelligence.

"Yet the crisis in Pakistan this week and the killing of 10 French and nine
Canadian soldiers in Afghanistan in successive weeks shows that this is
rubbish."

Mr Crouch added that British and US secret services had a "disgraceful record"
of planting misinformation and propaganda in the media.

"In April, the New York Times exposed that the Pentagon conducted a major
campaign of placing retired generals on US TV news to put the case for war in
the run-up to the invasion of Iraq," he pointed out.

"In 2002, Donald Rumsfeld's Office of Strategic Influence inside the Pentagon
had to be scrapped after it emerged that it planned to plant 'black propaganda'
in foreign media," he recalled.

"The news that counter-intelligence is targeting the BBC should be a wake-up
call to all journalists."

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                            August 28, 2008 Thursday

Terror attack by seagull puts shocked pensioner in hospital

BYLINE: Jamie Buchan

SECTION: NEWS; BUSINESS; Agri/Fish/Food; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 427 words


A Fraserburgh pensioner was left soaked in blood after a terrifying attack by an
overprotective seagull.

Jean Wemyss was walking through the streets of her home town when the angry bird
dive-bombed towards her head.

Shocked residents watched as the gull struck the 68-year-old on her crown,
leaving a 1in gash pouring with blood.

Mrs Wemyss spent an hour-and-a-half in hospital having the cut treated with
surgical glue.

Yesterday, she hit out at animal welfare campaigners who said this week that
people in coastal areas should stop complaining about seagulls as they were
living there long before humans came along.

"People who say things like that obviously don't live in a place like
Fraserburgh," she said.

"I'm an animal-lover and I love birds, but these seagulls are a menace and
always have been."

Mrs Wemyss had been walking through Fraserburgh's Queen Mary Street at around
7pm on Friday when the attack happened.

She said: "It was such a nice night, I thought I'd take a walk to deliver a
letter.

"I saw two seagull chicks on the road in front of me, but I didn't really think
anything of it.

"I didn't notice there was an adult gull nearby. The next thing I know, someone
shouts 'Watch out, Jean' and then there's a sudden, stabbing pain in my head.

"I didn't know what had happened. It felt like someone had hit me with a rock."

Mrs Wemyss added: "I was absolutely soaked in blood. It wasn't a big cut, but it
just wouldn't stop bleeding.

"I got a friend to take me to hospital and I was there for about an
hour-and-a-half.

"Then when I got home I had to put all my clothes in the wash because they were
just covered in blood."

Mrs Weymss, of Kent Gardens, has been left with a scar on her forehead and she
has been told by doctors to return to hospital so they can "keep an eye" on the
injury.

Yesterday, the Press and Journal reported that Animal Concern Advice Line had
criticised government plans to tackle the problem of aggressive gulls. Secretary
John Robins said people should stop moaning about birds living in their towns.

Mrs Weymss said: "It's all right if you don't have to put up with them every
day. Now I'm scared to go near these birds. I've started taking detours to avoid
them."

A few years ago, an unusual pilot scheme was launched to scare away the
"scurries", as they are known locally.

Robotic falcons, which sounded and behaved like their real-life counterparts,
were placed on rooftops around the town.

Fraserburgh's seagulls soon got wise to the scheme and, after just a few days,
were seen sitting happily alongside the fibreglass birds of prey.

gull attack
Gulls can be overprotective

                               Andover Advertiser

                            August 28, 2008 Thursday

Crossbow attackers terrorise families

BYLINE: Dick Bellringer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 425 words


TWO families from the Andover area were atta-cked in the middle of the night by
thugs armed with what they believed were a crossbow and an air rifle.

The attack happened while they were camping in an isolated spot in Gwent.

One mum said she was absolutely petrified' during the attack, and feared for
their lives.

Michelle Newton, aged 29, of Wildhern, and her six-year-old son Jonah, along
with her friend Kerry St-John, aged 38, of Roman Way, an arts and drama workshop
co-ordinator, and her three children Elle-Louise, aged eight, Charlie, aged
five, and Finlee, aged three, were staying in caravans overnight on Monday in a
lay-by close to Wentwood Forest after visiting friends near Usk.

It was the group's last night in Wales, after nearly a month visiting festivals,
and they decided to share one caravan rather than stay in two.

Around 1.30am on Tuesday Miss Newton, a jewellery-maker was woken by people
flashing lights through their window and shouting. But they left shortly after.

About 30 minutes later a car returned and when Miss St-John opened the door, she
was shot at with a crossbow from someone sat in a car less than 10 metres away.

She said the attacker aimed directly at her head, and the bolt ricocheted off
the caravan, missing her friends by inches.

The caravan was also shot at with an air rifle, making holes in the windows.

Miss Newton added: "We were panicking because of the children."

She said there were at least two attackers.

The attackers tied rope around the empty caravan and dragged it awa. But it got
stuck in a verge 50 yards down the road.

The two mothers put their children in one of their cars and drove away before
calling police.

Miss Newton said: "It was absolutely terrifying.

"I thought they were going to hurt us or kill us."

Too afraid to return to the lay-by, the group drove to Somerset overnight to
stay with friends before returning on Tuesday afternoon to retrieve their
caravans.

Following their ordeal, Miss Newton said Miss St-John was suffering with panic
attacks. "To be honest it was sheer panic, even driving down the road.

"It was dark. We were in a total state. We didn't know if they were following
us.

"It was like something out of a horror film."

A spokeswoman for Gwent police said: "The police received a call at 2.30am on
Tuesday from an individual who believed that a crossbow had been fired at their
caravan.

"Officers attended and confirmed that no-one had seen a crossbow or arrow of any
kind but individuals believed that one had been fired."

The police are continuing to investigate the incident.

LOAD-DATE: September 29, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                            BBC Monitoring Kiev Unit

                            September 1, 2008 Monday

Ukrainian security service rejects possibility of terrorist attack on arms depot

LENGTH: 208 words


The Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) has said it does not have grounds to
believe that the fire and explosions at the arms depot near the town of Lozova
in Kharkiv Region on 27 August was caused by a terrorist attack, the private TV
channel One Plus One reported on 31 August.

The head of the regional SBU directorate, Serhiy Mukhatayev, was shown saying,
"We do not have the signs today which would provide grounds for believing that a
terrorist attack was carried out against this military facility."

However, the channel said that the series of fires and explosions at Ukrainian
arms depots in recent years has caused the government to ask questions. First
Deputy Prime Minister Oleksandr Turchynov, who is investigating the incident,
was shown saying: "Why did the fire catch light outside the territory (of the
arms depot)? Why was it not extinguished on time? Why were the flammable
materials stored on the territory of the depot?"

The first deputy chief of the General Staff, Mykola Tsystyurskyy, was shown

near the fence (of the arms depot). Strong wind expanded this territory onto the

GRANDAD BLAMES TERROR GANG FOR ATTACK

BYLINE: BY VICTORIA MCMAHON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 436 words


AMAN shot five times in front of his wife and child said last night: "I know the
gunmen and they're INLA members."

Speaking from his hospital bed Martin McCartan, 40, blamed the fringe
paramilitary group - which claims to be on ceasefire - for the attack on Friday.

The North Belfast grandfather said he has become the target of a "vendetta"
after he stood up to the terror group a number of years ago.

He added: "It's all because I won't let them walk over me.

"They came to take my girl's boy friend out to beat him. They came into the
house and kicked my wee girl Tierna up and down the room, so I threw a few
punches.

"I couldn't have them doing that to my wee girl. It's been downhill since then."

And he strongly denied malicious rumours that he had been attacked because he
was dealing in drugs.

He called on Chief Constable Sir Hugh Orde to make his "clean" record public so
the claims could be rubbished.

He added: "I'm not involved in drugs.

I'm calling on Hugh Orde to release my records to show I've never been arrested
for drugs.

"No drugs have been found in my house. They raided it but found nothing.

"If you have a new pair of trainers suddenly you're a drug dealer. I can't
afford to go to Newcastle for my holidays, never mind anywhere else."

Mr McCartan said he was mystified by police claims there were no paramilitary
links to his attack.

"The police were up briefly on Friday, but they haven't been near me since. How
do the police know it's not paramilitary?

"The INLA are behind it. Even the dogs in the street know who's behind it. I
could take them to their doors now."

He added: "We can't live like this. It is 2008 not 1989. The police are allowing
people running about the streets with guns all for the sake of the peace
process."

When the masked gunmen burst into his Cranbrook Gardens home in Ardoyne, North
Belfast, he pleaded with them not to shoot him in front of Tierna.

It is the second time their home has been attacked. In March last year gunmen
fired through the window of the 10-year-old's bedroom window.

"I pleaded with them not to shoot me in front of her and they said, 'F*** you
and your child'. She's been through enough.

"She sleeps in with her mummy and me. She won't walk up the stairs even in the
daytime. Her nerves are shattered and she's scared I'm going to die. We can't
take this any more."

He said doctors who removed bullets from his ankle, knee, elbow and stomach told
him he was lucky to be alive.

"There is still a bullet lodged in my knee, they can't get out. I'm lying here,
I'm 40 years of age lying crippled.

"I'm sick of it and the police aren't doing anything. I'm so angry."

near the border areas. Local authorities had on Sunday arrested at least fifty
Khugakhel tribesmen besides sealing their commercial property and impounding
dozens of vehicles under the Collective Territorial Responsibility clause of
Frontier Crimes Regulation. The action was taken to force the elders of
Khugakhel tribe to hand over Mr Nabi to the administration.

All the arrested men were released after the signing of peace deal. The
agreement was also signed by Malik Khan, Malik Rasool Jan, Malik Hafizullah,
Malik Mohib Fatmikhel and Malik Habibur Rehman on behalf of Khugakhel tribe. The
said elders would also ensure the implementation of the agreement.

Text of report by independent New Colombia News Agency (Anncol) website

[FARC communique dated 31 August in the mountains of Colombia; posted on New
Colombia News Agency's website on 3 September: "FARC Denies Perpetrating Ituango
Attack"]

Wednesday, 3 Sep-In a communique sent to the Anncol editorial office, the Ivan
Rios and Martin Caballero blocks deny responsibility for the bombing in Ituango.

This is the complete text of the communique:

1. It is with deep outrage and grief for our country that the Revolutionary
Armed Forces of Colombia, FARC, denounce the monstrous attack of 14 August which
criminal hands of the State perpetrated against the civilian population of
Ituango, when a bomb exploded on a sidewalk in the municipality. This
reprehensible act of State-sponsored terrorism caused the death of 7 citizens
and wounded 50 others. President Uribe, the pathological liar who hates Ituango,
who in the recent past jailed dozens of residents after a massive roundup, and
who gave his approval for the massacre in El Aro, has implicated the FARC in
this distressing incident in order to conceal his direct responsibility for the
atrocious crime.

2. The Pescadero hydroelectric megaproject in the district is becoming a curse
for the residents of Ituango. Both President Uribe and Governor Alfredo Ramos
want to undo Ituango's status as a municipality and turn it back into a village
of Yarumal, against the backdrop of this $2.4 million business deal. The brutal
repression of the campesino population is linked to the megaproject. The violent
eradication of so-called illicit crops is a form of repression linked to the
megaproject. Uribe does not like Ituango because its residents have not bowed to
the demand of working with the Army. This is the real reason for the bombing of
its unarmed population.

3. We express our most deeply felt condolences to the people of Ituango, who
have every right to demand that high-level judicial bodies investigate the
incident and administer exemplary punishment to the government officials who
perpetrated this vile crime against humanity. We call upon human rights
organizations and all of the country's political and social forces that do not
agree with the methods of fascism to use their good offices in defence of the
residents of Ituango. The construction of megaprojects must never again cause
innocent blood to be shed in Colombia.

4. In this same regard, we ask ourselves why judicial authorities have not
opened an investigation into State terrorism by the army in connection with the
events of 30 July in the town of Maicao. The "discovery" of 1,000 kilos of the
explosive Anfo on that date in a pond surrounded by shacks was merely another
false positive, a ploy in the Army's psychological war to terrorize the
population, isolate the FARC, and at the same time portray itself as a "hero" in
the nation's eyes. These false "heroes" of the Army are the same ones who
continue to patrol the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta with the paramilitaries,
massacring Indians, economically blockading the population, displacing it, and
killing campesinos whom they later portray as guerrillas slain in combat.

Ivan Rios and Martin Caballero Blocks of the FARC

Mountains of Colombia, 31 August 2008

Amended, Wednesday, 3 September 2008

                            Daily Post (North Wales)

                           September 4, 2008 Thursday
                              North Wales Edition

Murder bid on Pakistan PM;
'Terror crackdown led to attack'

BYLINE: JAMES TAPSFIELD

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 457 words


PAKISTAN'S Prime Minister Yusuf Raza Gillani last night insisted an
assassination attempt on his life showed his government was taking on terrorism.

Speaking at a meeting with Tory leader David Cameron in Islamabad, Mr Gillani
said the attack was "a reaction" after security forces targeted extremists in
the north of the country.

At least two gun shots hit Mr Gillani's armoured car yesterday afternoon but he
was not in it.

Mr Gillani said: "Things are pretty serious (with the Taliban and al Qaida)
because this time we took them very seriously."

He also claimed a Taliban group had confirmed they carried out the attack. "They
have accepted the responsibility that they did it," he said.

The Pakistani security services have been carrying out a series of operations in
the north of the country, where the extremists have their power base. Earlier
yesterday, the Pakistan army claimed it had killed 30 militants during an
operation in the north-western Swat valley.

Pakistan is viewed as a key ally in the West's fight against terrorism, and
there have been fears about its commitment since the resignation last month of
Pervez Musharraf, who had been closely associated with the US and Britain.

But following a series of bloody suicide bombings on military targets, the
newly-elected government quickly signalled its intent by banning the country's
main Taliban group, the TTP, freezing its bank accounts and announcing rewards
for the arrest of its leaders.

The latest attack comes as tensions are running high before the appointment of a
new president on Saturday.

The overwhelming favourite is Asif Ali Zardari, husband of assassinated former
prime minister Benazir Bhutto and leader of Mr Gillani's party, the PPP.

Mr Cameron warned yesterday that terrorism could threaten Pakistan's future, and
said the assassination bid demonstrated it had to be tackled.

"We may well have had another reminder of the permanent threat terrorism poses,"
he said during a speech to academics and politicians.

The Tory leader, who spent yesterday visiting UK troops in Afghanistan, stressed
security in both Pakistan and Britain depended on effectively stamping out
terrorist groups.

"The longer the Taliban can operate with relative freedom in the tribal areas of
western frontier provinces and Baluchistan, the more they will threaten not just
the security of Afghanistan but the security, some would say the future, of
Pakistan itself," he said.

Mr Cameron called on the new government to press ahead with efforts to tackle
terrorism, referring to criticism of Pakistan's previous attitude to some groups
by saying there was no room for "ambivalence". He also urged the country's
leaders not to "slip back" in their quest for democracy.

Pakistan PM says crackdown on terror led to bid to kill him;

BYLINE: James Tapsfield

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 556 words


PAKISTAN'S Prime Minister Yusuf Raza Gillani last night insisted an attempt on
his life yesterday showed his government was taking on terrorism.

At a meeting with Tory leader David Cameron in Islamabad, Mr Gillani said the
attack was "a reaction" after security forces targeted extremists in the north
of the country.

At least two shots hit Mr Gillani's car while his convoy was on the way to pick
him up from Islamabad airport. However, he was not inside the armoured car.

Mr Gillani said: "Things are pretty serious (with the Taliban and al-Qaeda)
because this time we took them very seriously.

"We have (challenged them) - there is a reaction."

He also claimed that a Taliban group had confirmed that they carried out the
attack. "They have accepted the responsibility that they did it," he said.

The Pakistani security services have been carrying out a series of operations in
the north of the country, where the extremists have their power base.

Earlier yesterday the military in Pakistan claimed it had killed 30 militants
during an operation in the north-western Swat valley area.

Pakistan is viewed as a keyally in the West's fight against terrorism, and there
have been fears over its commitment since the resignation last month of Pervez
Musharraf, who had been closely associated with the US and Britain.

But the newly-elected government quickly signaled its intent by banning the
country's main Taliban group, the TTP, freezing its bank accounts and announcing
rewards for the arrest of its leaders.

That followed a series of bloody suicide bombings on military targets, seemingly
intended to destabilise the administration.

The latest attack comes with tensions in Pakistan running high ahead of the
appointment on Saturday of a new president. The overwhelming favourite is Asif
Ali Zardari, the husband of assassinated former Pakistan prime minister Benazir
Bhutto and the leader of Mr Gillani's party, the PPP.

Mr Cameron had warned yesterday that terrorism could threaten Pakistan's future,
and said the assassination bid demonstrated that it had to be tackled.

"We may well have had another reminder of the permanent threat that terrorism
poses," he said during a speech to academics and politicians.

The Tory leader - who spent yesterday visiting UK troops in Afghanistan -
stressed that security in both Pakistan and Britain depended on effectively
stamping out groups such as the Taliban and al-Qaeda.

"The longer the Taliban can operate with relative freedom in the tribal areas of
western frontier provinces and Baluchistan, the more they will threaten not just
the security of Afghanistan but the security - some would say the future - of
Pakistan itself."

Mr Cameron called on the new government to press ahead with efforts to tackle
terrorism, referring to criticism of Pakistan's previous attitude to some groups
by saying there was no room for "ambivalence".

He also urged the country's leaders not to "slip back" in their quest for
democracy - although he stressed patience was needed to foster a stable system.

Mr Cameron also met a number of other senior politicians, including Mr Zardari,
who assured him of Pakistan's commitment to fighting terror.

After their talks at the prime minister's official residence last night, Mr
Gillani was hosting a lavish dinner in Mr Cameron's honour.

German prosecutors release details of planned Sauerland terrorist attacks

LENGTH: 345 words


Text of report by independent German news agency ddp

Karlsruhe/Duesseldorf - On Friday [5 September], the Federal Supreme Court
Prosecutors released details of the indictment against the presumed Islamist
terrorists arrested a year ago in Sauerland. For the first time therein, the
investigators name the locations of the car bomb attacks planned by the three
suspected terrorists.

Among others, they were Frankfurt am Main, Ramstein, Dortmund, Duesseldorf,
Cologne, Stuttgart, and Munich. It is said that the objective was "to carry out
attacks with explosives in Germany, especially against US citizens and US
installations with the highest possible number of victims."

In this connection, the three men had intended "to build explosive charges based
on hydrogen peroxide and to explode them as car bombs in rented vehicles." As
the targets of the attacks, they took into consideration locations such as
restaurants, pubs, discotheques, and airports. According to the indictment, the
attacks were supposed to take place before the Bundestag decision on the
extension of the Bundeswehr operation in Afghanistan in the scope of the ISAF
[International Security Assistance Force] on 12 October 2007.

The quantity of 35-per cent hydrogen peroxide solution obtained by the three men
would have yielded an explosive mix with a force comparable to about 410 kg of
TNT. In July 2007, however, special forces were secretly able to replace the
content of the 12 barrels with a harmless 3-per cent solution.

The accused are two German converts, 29-year-old Fritz Gelowicz from Ulm and
22-year-old Daniel Schneider from Saarland, and the 29-year-old Turkish Moslem
Adem Yilmaz from Langen in Hessen. Gelowicz is seen as the ringleader of a
German cell of the foreign terrorist group "Islamic Jihad Union" (IJU), which
maintains contacts with Al-Qa'idah.

The three men are accused of membership in a foreign and a domestic terrorist
association, as stated in the indictment brought before the Duesseldorf Higher
Regional Court.

                         The Sunday Telegraph (London)

                               September 7, 2008

US-born terror chief 'killed' in air attack;
Rock fan who became bin Laden's propaganda expert may be victim of new onslaught
against al-Qaeda

BYLINE: NICK MEO

SECTION: NEWS; International; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 1014  words


WESTERN INTELLIGENCE sources in Pakistan believe that al-Qaeda's prize American
recruit and propaganda chief may have been killed in a CIA-directed air strike.

Months of attacks by unmanned US Predator aircraft have caused carnage among the
middle ranks of terrorist leaders in the lawless lands along the border with
Afghanistan, where al-Qaeda remains dangerous despite suffering a serious defeat
in Iraq.

Their victims have included experienced Arab leaders and, it is now thought,
Adam Gadahn, a former heavy-metal fan and so-called "killer computer nerd''
originally from California. Nothing has been heard from him for months, leading
intelligence experts to conclude that he may be dead.

Gadahn was credited with helping transform al-Qaeda's al-Sahab propaganda wing
into a slick operation that communicates in fluent English and produces
professional-quality DVDs, including one for Osama bin Laden last year.

He may, however, have fallen victim to an expanded programme of Predator
assassinations which in the past year targeted and killed many of al-Qaeda's
military commanders and terrorist trainers.

Jihadists around the world will be watching as closely as intelligence officials
this week to see whether Gadahn - also known as Azzam al-Ameriki - produces a
new video message to mark September 11, as he has done every year since 2003.

If there is no message it will be taken as near certain confirmation that he is
dead. It was thought that he may have been  killed either in a strike by
Hellfire missiles, or perhaps by jihadi colleagues jealous of his success. Now,
however, he is thought to have been a victim of an attack launched from a
remotely piloted aircraft in January which killed al-Qaeda's then military
commander, Abu Laith al-Libi, in Mir Ali, Waziristan.

Al-Libi was the most prominent of a series of terrorist leaders to be killed in
recent months. Abu Saeed al-Masri, who was implicated in attacks on Britain, was
killed in July. Syrians, Somalis and Kuwaitis have also been killed.

Evan Kohlmann, an investigator with the Nine Eleven Finding Answers (Nefa)
foundation which monitors terrorist groups, said: "Al-Qaeda acknowledges that
several of its leaders have been taken out. There aren't that many experienced
leaders left in the middle ranks and they are being replaced by younger guys
with no credentials but lots of enthusiasm.''

Experts fear that younger leaders will attempt to prove themselves by launching
bloody attacks such as the suicide bombing at a munitions factory in Pakistan
last month that killed 70.

Gadahn took on real importance as al-Qaeda's best known Westerner. He also
became the poster boy of would-be jihadis around the world who are radicalised
on the internet - and identify with a former Orange County teenager who once
reviewed heavy-metal bands before finding radical Islam and travelling to
Pakistan in 1998.

His rants about globalisation and the US mortgage meltdown struck a chord with
the alienated loners who are targeted by al-Qaeda.

Mr Kohlmann said: "The people in the dark world of online jihad, the ones who
watch the videos from Iraq, are the ones he speaks to. They are dangerous
because they could become home-grown jihadis.''

Another possibility being considered by intelligence officials is that Gadahn
may have been killed by rivals, or demoted if jealous colleagues decided that he
was too close to Osama bin Laden. Last year he appeared to have coached bin
Laden for propaganda videos.

But his most likely fate seems to have been death by Predator, the deadliest
weapon against foreign terrorists on Pakistani soil.

The lawless tribal region along the Afghanistan border is still al-Qaeda's main
base. US troops cannot officially venture there, and the use of Predators is
highly controversial in Pakistan. It is a legal grey area but Predator attacks
have become commonplace.

Refugee tribesmen from the Bajaur region in Pakistan's North-West Frontier
province told The Sunday Telegraph that pilotless drones fly overhead
constantly, hunting for Taliban and al-Qaeda targets. They are armed with
Hellfire missiles that can be fired by an operator thousands of miles away in
the United States.

Establishing exactly how many al-Qaeda targets have been killed in the lawless
region is difficult, but Nefa believes dozens of mid-level leaders have died
along with their bodyguards and followers. Many civilians have also been killed
in attacks, causing widespread anger in Pakistan.

But there are signs that despite the effectiveness of the assassination
programme, al-Qaeda is rebuilding in Pakistan. It has forged an alliance with
resurgent Taliban guerrillas in both Afghanistan and Pakistan. New recruits -
including battle-hardened veterans who have withdrawn from Iraq - are thought to
be coming in from the Gulf, and the terrorist organisation stands to benefit
from the political turmoil in Pakistan.

Richard Barrett, the head of the United Nations' al-Qaeda and Taliban Monitoring
Team, said that al-Qaeda's immediate aim is to carve out a space where it is
secure, with better training facilities. It hopes to achieve that by working
with the Taliban. He warned too that al-Qaeda is determined to strike the West
again after suffering defeat in Iraq and reverses elsewhere.

"They keep on making warnings,'' he said, "and from their point of view they
have been unlucky with some recent attacks.

"We certainly shouldn't be complacent - they want something to happen, and they
take a long view. They have suffered some reverses, but the idea of al-Qaeda is
still potent.''

A key al-Qaeda objective is to become more closely integrated with the Taliban.
Mr Barrett said: "They have intermarried in villages, which provides them with a
social glue. They can bring expertise and knowledge of the outside world which
is lacking among the Taliban.''

He warned that charismatic but uneducated young Pakistani leaders in the tribal
areas can easily be influenced by al-Qaeda.

He said: "The West has to make it clear to the Pakistani Taliban that they will
never be left alone while they are close to foreign Arab jihadis.''

Sri Lankan forces crush major terror attack in north - website

LENGTH: 247 words


Text of report by Sri Lankan Ministry of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order
website on 9 September

Latest military reports received from Vavuniya reveal that a major attack
launched by LTTE [Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam] terrorists at the security
forces headquarters Wanni and Air Force Base Vavuniya early this morning (9
September) was completely foiled.

According to the reports, the terrorists launched a pre-dawn ground assault
coordinated with artillery fire and an air raid with the intention of causing
severe damage to the Air Force assets in the Vavuniya air base.

Defence sources in Vavuniya state, the terrorists launched artillery fire to the
Army camp in order to prevent counter attack and directed their ground assault
at the airbase. However, valiant soldiers moved forward amid heavy enemy
artillery fire and crushed the terror ground assault completely. According to
the available information 10 bodies of slain LTTE cadres have been found so far.

Meanwhile, Sri Lanka Air Force fighter jets intercepted two LTTE light aircraft
fleeing after failed mission at Vavuniya Air force base and shot down one of the
aircraft in the Mullaittivu skies.

Ten soldiers laid down their lives and 15 others suffered injuries. One police
constable was killed and eight others sustained injuries due to the enemy
artillery fire. Five Air Force personnel also suffered injuries.

Three guilty of plotting UK terror bomb attacks

BYLINE: ALISON CHIESA

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 186 words


THREE Islamic extremists are facing lengthy prison sentences after being found
guilty of conspiring to kill hundreds of people in a terrorist bombing campaign.

They were members of an east London al Qaeda-inspired terror cell that planned
to detonate home-made bombs in attacks on British targets including Heathrow
Airport, a jury at Woolwich Crown Court found.

But following a five-month trial the jurors failed to reach verdicts on
prosecution claims that the men were plotting an unprecedented wave of suicide
bombings on transatlantic airliners. The three - Abdulla Ahmed Ali, 27, Assad
Sarwar, 28, and Tanvir Hussain, 27 - had  admitted planning a series of
small-scale headline-grabbing bomb attacks.

But, by a majority of 10 to two, the jurors yesterday rejected their claims that
they did not plan to kill or hurt anyone .

The  ury deliberated for 56 hours  but could not agree verdicts on whether
another four Muslim men were  involved in the conspiracy to murder. All seven
men earlier admitted conspiring to cause a public nuisance by distributing
videos threatening suicide attacks in Britain.

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                          September 10, 2008 Wednesday

United Nations: Secretary-General, At Symposium, Says Scourge Of Terrorism
Attacks Humanity Itself; Voices Of Victims 'Strongest Argument Why It Can Never
Be Justified'

LENGTH: 1104 words


RDATE:09092008

Following is UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon's statement at the Symposium on
Supporting Victims of Terrorism in New York, 9 September:

Today is a historic day for the United Nations. We come together with a common
and unwavering purpose: the support of victims of terrorism.

We are honoured and humbled to have as our guests individuals who bear directly
the scars, physically and mentally, from unspeakable acts of terrorism and
experts who have attempted to understand and help victims.

Some of you have been injured or disabled in terror attacks, your wounds a daily
reminder of the viciousness of terrorism.

Some of you have been kidnapped and held captive, deprived of a most fundamental
human right: your freedom.

Some of you have lost loved ones -- sisters, brothers, mothers, fathers,
daughters and sons, whose lives have been ended by senseless and indiscriminate
murder.

Most of you have been haunted by images and memories too horrific to live with
and struggled with ears deaf and indifferent to your plight.

All of you have dedicated your lives to denouncing the evil of terrorism, to
making the voice of the victims heard, and to supporting others who have
suffered.

You have come all the way to New York to bear witness to one of the great
scourges of our time. From many different countries, religions and ethnicities,
you demonstrate that terrorism does not discriminate among victims. In your
diversity, you stand for hundreds of thousands around the world who have
suffered loss and injury from terrorism.

Together, we remember and pay tribute to all those who have been victims of
terrorism in far too many places.

Let us remember Bali, Beslan and Bombay.

Let us remember Algiers, Baghdad and Casablanca.

Let us remember Kabul, Riyadh and Nairobi.

Let us remember London, New York, San Vincente and Madrid.

Let us remember Istanbul, Islamabad, Jerusalem and Dar-es-Salaam.

The list keeps growing longer, bringing with it greater pain and grief that
cascades mercilessly through families, communities and nations.

Each act reminds us that terrorism is global. It can affect anyone, anywhere. It
targets all ethnic groups, religions, nationalities and civilizations. It
attacks humanity itself.

And it is for the sake of humanity that we must create a global forum for your
voice and listen to you, the victims.

Your stories of how terrorism has affected your lives are our strongest argument
why it can never be justified. By giving a human face to the painful
consequences of terrorism, you help build a global culture against it. You are
the real heroes in the global struggle against terrorism. You humble the world
by your strength and courage.

You deserve support and solidarity. You deserve social recognition, respect and
dignity. You deserve to have your needs addressed. You deserve to have your
human rights defended. And you deserve justice.

Like many of you, I have witnessed the aftermath of terror. I was serving at the
United Nations in New York at the time of the terrorist attacks of 11 September
2001. My heart went out to the victims of that grim day who, like me, were New
Yorkers going about their lives.

Six years later, in December last year, I was profoundly shocked when I visited
the grounds of the United Nations compound in Algiers, which had been ripped
apart by a terrorist bomb blast. I met with survivors and with the families of
the victims, encounters that left me deeply moved.

I had seen the devastation from a distance in New York, but in Algiers, I walked
through the rubble of tragedy. I looked into the faces of the children whose
parents had lost their lives while serving the United Nations. And I caught a
glimpse, for the first time, of the reality that many of you here live with
every day -- of what it means to be a victim of terrorism. I lost members of my
United Nations family that day.

Since that time, I feel each loss more deeply. And the United Nations family has
lost too many of our staff to terrorist attacks not only in Algiers but
elsewhere. Just last week, I attended a ceremony in Geneva commemorating the
heinous attack five years ago at the United Nations headquarters in Baghdad, in
which we lost some of our best and bravest staff.

Twenty-two people were killed and over 150 wounded. I met with some 300
survivors, victims and their families. And I was overwhelmed with grief at how
fresh the wounds still are five years after the attack.

So today, it fills me with pride that we are convening at the United Nations to
show solidarity with victims of terrorism, and to find better ways to support
them. I am heartened by the overwhelming interest. It is a testament to the
great importance we are attaching to supporting victims of terrorism.

I am equally encouraged by the high level of expertise here today. We are joined
by a number of eminent terrorism experts. But we are also joined by experts
whose focus of work is on violence and conflict situations. It is time to expand
the small community that works on terrorism and see whether new insights can be
brought to bear by those with experience in studying conflict and violence. And
we will hear from Member States who have responded to terrorist attacks by
developing assistance programmes.

I look forward to an open dialogue, in which we all share our experiences and
practices. We have so much to learn from each other. In this way, we can
strengthen the international community's solidarity with victims, and improve
our understanding of their needs and how Governments, the United Nations and
civil society can better support them.

That is the fundamental purpose of this meeting.

The United Nations Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy, unanimously adopted by all
United Nations Member States in 2006, called on us to stop the dehumanization of
victims of terrorism in all its forms and manifestations.

In the Strategy, Member States committed themselves to consolidating national
systems of assistance that would promote the needs of victims of terrorism and
their families and facilitate the normalization of their lives; they pledged to
promote international solidarity in support of victims of terrorism; and they
promised to promote and protect the rights of victims of terrorism.

Today, we must strive to give practical meaning to these commitments. Let us
embark then on this journey together, in mutual respect and determination.

PressWIRE can be obtained at http://www.presswire.net on the world wide web.
Inquiries to info@m2.com)).

                          September 11, 2008 Thursday

9/11 victims remembered in town silence;
Two minutes' silence is being observed in Exmouth today to commemorate the
seventh anniversary of the September 11 terrorist attacks in New York.

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 268 words


Wreaths will be laid in Phear Park, where a memorial stone to honour those who
died in the World Trade Centre  was unveiled.

Exmouth firefighters   befriended many of the rescuers who tried to help save
the lives of people trapped in the collapsed buildings.

Ceremony organiser Lionel Howell said   it was the town's way of reminding
America  that the loss of life caused when the two hijacked  planes were flown
into the skyscrapers is still remembered here.

The ceremony begins at 1.46pm - the time in Britain that the first plane
struck.

"Our firefighters will parade at the inscribed memorial stone, which the people
of Exmouth raised money for as a lasting tribute to all those brave people in
New York," Mr Howell said.

"The police will also be represented and also present will be mayor Joy Whipps
and pupils from the community college.

"Wreaths will be placed by all these people and the memorial service will be
conducted by Father Tony Osman."

Royal Marines from the Commando Training Centre at Lympstone are also expected
to set off two flares and also due at the ceremony is nurse Charlotte Tuckett,
whose cousin Stephen Lawn was among those killed in the attacks.

The American flag will fly at half mast outside London fireman Rob Newby's
Topsham home throughout today.

Mr Newby befriended Raymond Riley, 46, who has been forced to leave the New York
fire service on grounds of ill health, caused by dust he inhaled when he joined
the rescue mission.

"I have never met Raymond but hope to in the future," he said.

He said they first made contact after 9/11 when the London brigade befriended
New York firemen.

                    September 11, 2008 Thursday 2:47 AM BST

CONCERTS TO MARK SEPTEMBER 11 TERROR ATTACKS ANNIVERSARY

BYLINE: Laura May and Wesley Johnson, PA

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 487 words


Simultaneous concerts on both sides of the Atlantic will be held today to mark
the anniversary of the September 11 terror attacks.

After performances featuring musicians who lost loved ones in the atrocity,
audiences in London and New York will join the artists in a rendition of John
Lennon and Paul McCartney's classic Let It Be.

More than 200 free concerts have been organised across the world on the seventh
anniversary of the attacks.

Almost 3,000 people, including 67 Britons, were killed when terrorists hijacked
aircraft and flew them into New York's World Trade Centre and the Pentagon on
September 11 2001.

London's concert will take place in Grosvenor Square at the same time as
performers take to the stage in the British Memorial Garden in Hanover Square,
New York.

Performers in London will include Coventry singer/songwriter Rob Halligan, whose
father died in the World Trade Centre.

Singer Kris Buckle, the London Welsh Chorale and the South African opera singer
Siphiwo Ntshebe are also on the bill.

The annual concerts were the brainchild of New York businesswoman Hakuro Smith,
who in 2002 decided to try to turn September 11 from a day of anguish into ``a
day of music to celebrate our universal humanity''.

She said: ``The September Concert is not a memorial event. It's an opportunity
for people to come together once a year and be united in hopes for peace and
celebrate our universal humanity. Music has the magical power to do that.''

On Monday, the president of a project to build a national US memorial to those
who died in the attacks said that it must be open by the 10th anniversary.

Speaking in New York, Joe Daniels said it was both ``possible and essential''
for the memorial and museum, which will be on the site of the World Trade Centre
towers in New York, to be opened by September 11 2011.

``It must be a priority,'' he said.

Mr Daniels said more than 350 million US dollars (£197 million) had been raised
for the national memorial and museum, and the first steel installations went
into the ground last week.

Work at the site is dependent upon the contents of a September 30 report by the
Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which has said its part of the
redevelopment of the World Trade Centre site was behind schedule and over budget
earlier this year.

Bob Lieber, New York City's deputy mayor for economic development, said: ``There
have been un-meetable deadlines, unrealistic expectations, that have taken place
over the past seven years.''

He said he was ``eagerly'' looking forward to the report, which would attach ``a
real budget and a real timetable'' to the projects.

``Seven years ago this week, the eyes of the world turned to look at Lower
Manhattan in horror,'' he said.

``The recovery of Lower Manhattan continues to be one of the most remarkable
episodes of recovery in the history of this great city.

``It may not be as fast as we would like, but it is in fact taking place.''

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                    September 11, 2008 Thursday 2:47 AM BST

GLOBAL AUDIENCE WATCHED TERROR ATTACKS UNFOLD

BYLINE: Wesley Johnson, PA, in New York

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 1000 words


Millions around the world watched on live TV as terrorists struck at the heart
of the United States on September 11 2001, killing thousands and leaving the
most famous skyline in the world changed forever.

The United States was brought to a standstill as, within an hour, the most
powerful symbols of US economic power had collapsed and a passenger airliner
crashed into the Pentagon, the heart of the US military machine.

Another passenger plane crashed about 80 miles south east of Pittsburgh, its
apparent target Washington.

Almost 3,000 people, including 67 Britons, were killed by the attacks seven
years ago after suicide bombers seized four airliners on domestic flights.

Airports were closed, flights grounded and borders sealed, and jet fighters were
scrambled above major cities, as the US tried to comprehend the enormity of what
had happened.

For many it was the nation's greatest humiliation since Pearl Harbour, the
attack which triggered US entry into the Second World War.

The first strike was against the Trade Centre. A jet smashed high up into one of
the towers where tens of thousands of people work every day.

As horrified witnesses described the terrifying scenes, a second jet was filmed
by CNN slamming into the second tower lower down, bursting into flames and
leaving another gash in the building.

Smoke poured from the two towers. Eyewitnesses reported seeing bodies plunging
from the buildings as the flames spread out of control.

Within an hour, both towers had collapsed, sending clouds of dust billowing down
the streets of Manhattan and across the harbour as survivors, many of whom were
staggering from the building after the attacks, fled for their lives.

On a school visit in Florida at the time, US President George Bush put the
military on high alert.

``Make no mistake,'' he said. ``The US will hunt down and punish those
responsible for this cowardly act.''

The President was flown to the security of Barksdale Air Force Base in
Louisiana, then later to the US Strategic Air Command headquarters in Nebraska.

The scenes of unbelievable destruction were beamed live around the world on TV.

In a measure of the carnage on the ground, five hours after the attacks there
were no estimates of the overall death toll, but hospitals around New York were
struggling to cope with the casualties.

New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani took charge and urged people to be calm and to
walk out of Lower Manhattan.

``I never thought I would see anything like this happen,'' he said.

``I got there after the first plane hit and before the second. Watching people
jump from the top of the World Trade Centre was an unbelievable sight.''

His Churchill-inspired leadership led to him receiving an honorary knighthood
from the Queen after the tough politician showed his tender side as he attended
hundreds of funerals and memorial services in the wake of the worst terrorist
outrage in history.

As shockwaves from the outrage reverberated around the world, Prime Minister
Tony Blair called an emergency meeting of the Cobra security committee and
announced a range of security measures at British airports.

Britain would stand full square alongside the US in the battle to drive the
``new evil'' of terrorism from the world, he said.

Speaking in Downing Street, Mr Blair said: ``This is not a battle between the
United States and terrorism, but between the free and democratic world and
terrorism.

``We, therefore, here in Britain stand shoulder to shoulder with our American
friends in this hour of tragedy and we, like them, will not rest until this evil
is driven from our world.''

Key EU officials rushed back to their Brussels headquarters at short notice and
called emergency meetings to discuss how they could help the US.

Nato also called an urgent meeting of ambassadors from its 19 members to discuss
the security implications of the attacks. European allies expressed their
solidarity with the United States.

World travel was thrown into chaos. Many US-bound flights had already left the
UK when American officials closed all US airports.

Thousands of passengers, including the Duke of York, were diverted, or turned
round mid-Atlantic.

In the UK, Queen expressed her ``growing disbelief and total shock''.

Workers in London left some high-profile buildings amid concern that they could
be the next target.

The London Stock Exchange, the Lloyds building, Canary Wharf and the NatWest
Tower in central London were among those with workers streaming out as panic
spread across the world.

Armed police were sent to the US embassy in London's Grosvenor Square. Security
was also stepped up at British military bases.

Outgoing Conservative leader William Hague suspended the party's leadership
election for 24 hours as a mark of respect to the victims of the terror attacks.

But in the West Bank and Gaza, thousands of Palestinians celebrated the terror
attacks, chanting ``God is Great'' and distributing sweets to passers-by, even
as their leader, Yasser Arafat, said he was horrified.

The US government had become increasingly unpopular in the region, with many
Palestinians accusing Washington of siding with Israel.

The name of Osama bin Laden, the world's most wanted terrorist, emerged as the
man responsible - just three weeks earlier he had vowed to unleash an
unprecedented attack against the US.

He remains on the FBI's ``most wanted list'', with a reward of up to 25 million
US dollars (£14.2 million) for his capture, today.

His terrorist outfit was also blamed for two bomb attacks on US embassies in
Africa in August 1998, and also the 1993 bomb attack on the World Trade Centre.

The Foreign Office warned Britons in Muslim countries of the risk of violence as
a result of the attacks on the US.

The atrocities at the World Trade Centre and the Pentagon may lead to
``heightened tension and disruption worldwide'', the Foreign Office said in a
statement.

``All British nationals overseas should exercise caution and avoid situations
where there might be tension and stay in touch with fast-moving events.''

Kuwaiti Shi'i cleric condemns 9/11 attacks, calls for pursuing "terrorists"

LENGTH: 518 words


Text of report by Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Watan website on 10 September

[Unattributed report: "Al-Mahri: 'Islam Fought Terrorism before the United
States'"]

Scholar Muhammad Baqir al-Mahri, representative of the Shi'i [religious]
authorities in Kuwait, said that Islam has fought terrorism, terrorists and
hypocrites even before the United States thought about it.

Al-Mahri said in a statement he made on the occasion of 9/11 attacks: "The
perpetrators of this criminal terrorist incident are but a clique of criminals
who have affiliation with a school that is a terrorist organization which is far
away from Islam and its tolerant shari'ah in order to distort the reputation of
the real Islam, and hurt Muslims in the United States and Europe after they were
subjected to brainwashing by their clerics based on false intellectual thoughts.

He adds: "As we condemned this savage barbaric operation of 2001, we condemn
today the destruction of the twin towers of the World Trade Centre in New York
and consider this attack as a criminal act that is far away from the teachings
of the Koran and Islamic Shari'ah. We consider those who carried those acts as
apostates whose abode is hell, and the worst of fates. Islam disowns itself
fully from them and they are not related to it, so the super powers have no
right to accuse Muslims of carrying them out."

He says: "Let the whole world, especially the United States, know that Islam has
fought terrorism, terrorists, and hypocrites even before the United States
thought about it. Islam has warned of those Islamized groups which are the
sources of evil, tribulation, terrorism, killing, and crimes in the Islamic
countries and in the whole world. On the occasion of this sad anniversary, let
us unite our efforts and position as Muslims to fight those who hold terrorist
thoughts, ban their books that encourage terrorism, bring to justice their
clerics and prosecute them for selling out their religion for prestige, fame,
and gathering disciples around them. Those [clerics] may have done so because of
their ignorance so they issued fatwas, that have nothing to do with Islam,
sanctioning the killing of innocents.

He maintains: "Therefore, all real divine Muslim clerics, Sunni and Shia Islamic
movements, especially the constitutional and salafist movements and all groups
that affiliated with them to denounce and condemn this terrorist attack, and
other savage operations carried out in Pakistan, Iraq, Algeria or any other
places by those Islamized groups. We have to do so in a way characterized with
transparency, clarity, and openness in order to avoid the Islamic movements
being accused by the United States and other great powers of terrorism and
funding terrorist group."

He affirms: "We say fearlessly and bravely that all suicide bombings that took
place in Algeria, Indonesia, Jordan, Iraq, Pakistan and Kuwait run counter to
the holy Shari'ah and those who carry them out are apostates and those who issue
such fatwas are responsible before God and people and will have severe
punishment on doomsday.

Town pays its tribute to 9/11 victims;

                                Hull Daily Mail

                           September 12, 2008 Friday

East yorkshire soldiers could protect gordon brown;
Soldiers from Hull and the East Riding will be sent to Baghdad next month to
protect VIPs from terrorist attacks, the Mail can today reveal.

SECTION: Pg. 14

LENGTH: 220 words


Final preparations are being made by 1st Battalion, The Yorkshire Regiment (1
Yorks), for the mission.

It could see troops protecting government ministers and other dignitaries on
visits to the war zone.

The Mail first reported the possibility of our region's troops being used as
"force protection" in July.

Now 1 Yorks has confirmed Alpha Company - totalling about 80 men - will be sent
to the Iraqi capital.

The 500-strong battalion, which recruits heavily from Hull and the East Riding,
will begin arriving in the war zone late next month.

A spokesman said: "Alpha Company will provide a protection force, assisting
senior officers and visitors in Baghdad."

Charlie Company and Support Company will both be based in Iraqi's second-largest
city Basra, where they will help train the Iraqi Army.

Bravo Company will not be deploying to Iraq. Instead, it will be serving in
Kosovo, in the Balkans.

According to the 1 Yorks spokesman, troops not going to Baghdad will quickly
join Military Transition Teams.

The teams, which are typically five-strong, live with and train the Iraqi Army.

                           September 12, 2008 Friday

East yorkshire soldiers could protect gordon brown;
Soldiers from Hull and the East Riding will be sent to Baghdad next month to
protect VIPs from terrorist attacks, the Mail can today reveal.

SECTION: Pg. 14

LENGTH: 220 words


Final preparations are being made by 1st Battalion, The Yorkshire Regiment (1
Yorks), for the mission.

It could see troops protecting government ministers and other dignitaries on
visits to the war zone.

The Mail first reported the possibility of our region's troops being used as
"force protection" in July.

Now 1 Yorks has confirmed Alpha Company - totalling about 80 men - will be sent
to the Iraqi capital.

The 500-strong battalion, which recruits heavily from Hull and the East Riding,
will begin arriving in the war zone late next month.

A spokesman said: "Alpha Company will provide a protection force, assisting
senior officers and visitors in Baghdad."

Charlie Company and Support Company will both be based in Iraqi's second-largest
city Basra, where they will help train the Iraqi Army.

Bravo Company will not be deploying to Iraq. Instead, it will be serving in
Kosovo, in the Balkans.

According to the 1 Yorks spokesman, troops not going to Baghdad will quickly
join Military Transition Teams.

The teams, which are typically five-strong, live with and train the Iraqi Army.

The soldiers will deploy under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Jonny Price
MBE.

Lieu Col Price grew up in East Yorkshire and attended Pocklington School.

He replaced the former Commanding Officer Lieutenant Colonel Andrew Jackson on
August 26.

                                 Irish Examiner

                           September 12, 2008 Friday

Victims of September 11 terror attacks remembered

SECTION: WORLD

LENGTH: 409 words


Relatives of victims killed at the World Trade Center gathered in lower
Manhattan for readings from dignitaries and a recitation of the names of the
dead. Later Barack Obama and John McCain visited ground zero to pay silent
respects.

"Today marks the seventh anniversary of the day our world was broken," Mayor
Michael Bloomberg said, calling September 11, 2001, a "day that began like any
other and ended as none ever has".

The ritual at ground zero included moments of silence at 8:46am, 9:03am and
9:59am and 10:29am - the times when two hijacked jets slammed into the trade
center buildings and the twin towers fell.

Services were also held in Pennsylvania and at the Pentagon, where a new
memorial was dedicated.

Among the speakers at ground zero were three children who were very young when
their father went to work at the World Trade Center seven years ago and never
came home.

"I remember playing in the yard with him. I remember him pulling my wagon. He
was strong. He always made me feel safe," said Alex Salamone, wearing the soccer
jersey of his father, John. "I wish I could remember more, but we were so young
when he died."

Edward Bracken, who lost his sister, Lucy A Fishman, said she was "murdered by
coward men using their religion to say they are right and we are wrong," then
added, "Pray for the men and women who sleep on the ground every night in the
Middle East to keep our world safe".

Relatives of victims began arriving at dawn at ground zero, now a huge
construction site. American flags were draped over silent cranes, and some
families held signs saying "We miss you," "We love you" or "You will never be
forgotten".

The family of victim Michael Diehl went to ground zero wearing white T-shirts
bearing his photo and 9/11/01.

"It's still very hard for us to come here. It doesn't get any easier," said
Diehl's sister-in-law, Norma Linguito. "I just wish they'd get the memorial up
so we can have something, a marker, to remember everyone."

Family members and students representing more than 90 countries that lost
victims on September 11 read the names of 2,751 people killed in New York, one
more than last year. The city restored Sneha Philip, a woman who mysteriously
vanished on September 10, 2001, to its official death toll this year after a
court ruled she was likely killed at the site.

McCain and Obama agreed to pull their campaign ads for the day and were
appearing together last night at a forum on volunteerism and service.

Axe terror as masked yobs attack school bus

BYLINE: wayne ankers

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 373 words


AN axe-wielding masked gang launched a terrifying attack on a school bus full of
youngsters.

The bus, with about 30 children on board, was also battered with a crowbar and a
golf club. One pupil was injured in the attack.

It had stopped at the junction of Simonsway and Shadow Moss Road, Wythenshawe,
when the gang of five - all wearing dark hoodies and balaclavas - launched the
attack.

They used the weapons to smash windows on the bus, from top school St Ambrose
College in Hale Barns, and an axe was thrown straight through the vehicle,
narrowly missing the head of one boy.

Passenger George Fountain, 12, of Cheadle, told how it was lucky nobody was
seriously hurt.

The year-eight pupil said: "All of a sudden the gang appeared and I heard a big
smash and glass was everywhere.

"They had an axe and a crowbar and golf club and were acting like maniacs.

"The axe went through one window and just missed one of my friends. It then
smashed through the other side. It all happened very quickly and everyone had
their heads down.

The youngster said five windows were smashed and one boy suffered a cut near his
eye. He was treated at the scene by paramedics and taken to hospital as a
precaution.

George's mum Marilyn, 42, said: "It is very shocking. It is not something you
expect to happen on a school bus."

A police spokesman said the incident was being treated as a serious and
threatening attack.

The spokesman added: "There appear to be no serious injuries at the moment.
Inquiries into the circumstances surrounding the incident are ongoing." Michael
Thompson, Headteacher at St Ambrose College, confirmed one boy sustained a minor
cut in the attack.

He added: "The bus driver acted promptly and professionally, moving the bus to a
safe location and then contacting both the police and the college.

"Police were present within minutes and teachers, who made their way to the
incident immediately from St Ambrose College, some three miles away, arrived
shortly afterwards and stayed with the boys until a replacement bus arrived.

"St Ambrose would like to thank the police for their swift response and the bus
driver for his professional attitude.

"We believe it was a random attack and are being kept informed as police conduct
their investigation."

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                           September 15, 2008 Monday

US assaults in Pakistan 'could lead to London terror attacks'

BYLINE: Richard Edwards

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 477  words


AMERICA'S unprecedented raids inside Pakistan could provoke terrorist attacks in
London, Pakistan's high commissioner to Britain has warned.

Wajid Shamsul Hasan said the attacks on Taliban and

al-Qaeda suspects were making the streets of Britain "less safe'' and that
resentment was mounting among Pakistanis in the country, with community leaders
calling for that anger to be "organised''.

His remarks followed outrage in Pakistan over five attacks in the past 10 days,
including a ground assault in the town of Angoor Adda in which 20 people were
killed. US officials said they were all supporters of terrorism but Pakistan
insists that they were civilians, including women and children.

Mr Hasan said: "This will infuriate Muslims in this country and make the streets
of London less safe. There are one million Pakistanis in the diaspora here and
resentment is mounting. I'm being flooded by text messages from community
leaders saying we must organise our anger.

"The Americans' trigger-happy actions will radicalise young Muslims. They're
playing into the hands of the very militants we're supposed to be fighting.''

Pakistan recently completed its transition to democracy with the election as
president of Asif Ali Zardari but relations with the US are strained. President
George W Bush underscored the shift in strategy last week when he said Pakistan
and Afghanistan were part of the same "theatre'' of anti-terrorism operations.

Both US and British special forces have been carrying out "special
reconnaissance'' operations inside Pakistan following an agreement with Pervez
Musharraf, the previous president of Pakistan. The troops have used unmanned
Predator spy planes to track targets that are then attacked with Hellfire
missiles.

However, tactics became more direct with the raid on Angoor Adda, a small town
near the Afghan border, by three dozen heavily-armed marines and Navy Seals.

It is a crossing point from Pakistan to Afghanistan inhabited by Pashtun tribes,
the same ethnicity as the Taliban. It has long been believed that this is the
region where Osama bin Laden and his deputy, Ayman al-Zawahiri, have found
refuge.

US defence officials confirmed that there was a new determination by Mr Bush to
hunt down bin Laden before his presidency ends in January. But Mr Hasan said the
"direct action'' missions were doing more damage than good.

"What have they gained out of this except animosity?'' he said. "They have not
killed or captured any prominent

al-Qaeda leader, but the collateral damage is responsible for hundreds of deaths
and the reaction is being felt everywhere in the country.''

Mr Zardari arrived in Britain yesterday and will hold talks with Gordon Brown
and David Miliband, the Foreign Secretary.

"We hope they will help convince the Americans to stop it, to give space to our
fledgling democracy and revive our economy,'' Mr Hasan said.

the head and another broke a beer bottle across his face.

Martyn, who studies at Eastleigh College, said: "I was scared and I think if I
had been knocked down they would have just kept kicking me while I was on the
floor.

"I used to walk past groups of 20 men and not think anything was going to
happen. Now I don't want to go out at night at all."

Martyn, of Romsey, added: "Because one of them was being all right they lulled
me into a false sense of security.

"When I felt the bottle smash against my face all I could think of is I have to
get away and I ran off."

The gang chased him for a few yards but soon gave up and he was able to get to a
nearby friend's house in Withy Close and knocked the door covered in blood.

The friend's dad immediately called an ambulance, the police and Martyn's mum
Isobel.

Isobel said: "It is the worst phone call I have ever had.

"I screamed down the phone and went running round his friend's house in my
nightie.

"His face was swollen and he was covered in blood.

"The people must be like animals, there is no other way of describing them.

"I think if he had not had the instinct to run they might have killed him."

The attack left Martyn with a number of stitches over his face, his jaw is too
painful for him to eat still while he was also left with injuries to his hand.

Police are investigating.

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. 19

AN intruder who punched a pregnant mum and her partner during a terrifying raid
is today beginning a four-year sentence behind bars.

Doreen Stephenson and Peter Hunton were asleep with their five-year-old daughter

Mr Hunton went downstairs to investigate and calm the pet, Newcastle Crown Court
heard.

But he found Kevin Kirby already in the living room, beside the broken bay
window.

And instead of running, the drink-fuelled convicted robber followed Mr Hunton
back upstairs, threatened to kill him and lashed out at the couple in the
confrontation that followed.

Brave Mr Hunton was hit as he fought to wrestle Kirby out of the family's home
in Fenham.

Partner Ms Stephenson, 28 weeks' pregnant, was also punched as the struggle
spilled into the garden.

And although Kirby finally fled, he quickly targeted a second nearby home and
attacked the owner there when he was disturbed, the court heard.

Kirby, 29, of Beech Grove Road, Cruddas Park, admitted offences of burglary, as
well as assault by beating.

And passing sentence, Judge John Evans warned only a substantial jail sentence
could follow.

"In the early hours you broke into the home of Mr Hunton and Ms Stephenson,"
Judge Evans said.  "They were alerted to your presence by the dog barking.

"But far from taking to your heels, you pursued Mr Hunton. You punched him a
number of times.

"You have a bad record. This was a particularly bad burglary.

"The fact you were drunk is no mitigation whatsoever."

Kirby had been jailed for robbery in 1996, the court heard.

He was then given a sentence of almost eight years in 2001 for robbery and
burglary.

Chris Mitford, defending, said Kirby had been tackling his drink addiction since
his last prison release.

But he had got drunk on the anniversary of his father's death and staged the
break-ins.

"From the pre-sentence report it is evident he was making steady progress," Mr
Mitford told the court.
