Ground zero: Artist seeks nyc home for work;
A polruan artist hopes New York firefighters will display her painting of the
September 11 terror attacks in their premises.

SECTION: Pg. 9

LENGTH: 323 words


Audrey Theodosia Bryant wants to donate Ground Zero - vision statement to the
firefighters in recognition of their outstanding and heroic attempts to rescue
those caught up in the 2001 destruction of the Twin Towers.

She is making inquiries to have the work, measuring 60cm by 50cm in its frame,
sent to America.

She said: "In 2001, after the twin towers were destroyed, I painted this picture
in oils to express all our hopes that the tragedy would lead to something
better.

"It is time hope rather than retaliation was uppermost in our minds. Nobody
wants to hang such a reminder of that day in their home but it has been set up
in my church at Lanteglos on the anniversary of the event.

"I was inspired to paint this picture because of my depth of feeling about all
the people who were affected by 9/11, their fears, sorrows, angers and their
need to do something."

Audrey, who has lived and worked in New York, said: "I was familiar with the
scale of the city, the motorways at Riverside, over the Brooklyn Bridge, to New
Jersey and leading out to the rest of this stupendous country.

"A motorway runs to the left of picture and the way the city lights throw their
beams onto the trees to create an almost theatrical backdrop is all around."

She said she loved the city when she was there.

"The figures stand on rubble held up by kerbstones, like tombstones, with the
names of all the dead engraved on them.  The little boy is clinging to his
father's knee, trusting he knows the way ahead," she said.

Audrey has been painting and writing poetry for as long as she has been able to
hold a crayon.  "It is a way of expressing my dreams and nightmares and my love
for people," she said.

She learned to use oils at Winchester College of Art and went to classes in New
York.

She said "After four children and several jobs which left no time for painting,
I came back to Cornwall in 1998, where my life began. I have been painting and
writing ever since."

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                          September 17, 2008 Wednesday

International: Zardari and Brown in counter-terrorism talks: Pakistan leader
attacks US strikes on tribal regions: Plan to set up anti-terror headquarters in
London

BYLINE: Saeed Shah, Islamabad

SECTION: GUARDIAN INTERNATIONAL PAGES; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 532 words


Asif Ali Zardari, Pakistan's president, claimed British support against
unilateral US attacks inside Pakistan's tribal areas, as he laid out his
counter-terrorism plan to Gordon Brown in Downing Street yesterday.

There has been anger in Pakistan at recent US missile strikes against suspected
militants in its tribal territory, which borders Afghanistan, and an
unprecedented American ground raid earlier this month, which left 20 dead,
including women and children.

Speaking outside 10 Downing Street after his meeting with Gordon Brown Zardari
said there was "understanding among the British leadership that Pakistan be
helped with regard to unprovoked US missile firing in the tribal regions . . .
such action does not help democracy, and Mr Brown agreed to this point of view".

A joint Zardari-Brown statement made no mention of an agreement on the US
strikes, but said the extremists based in the tribal areas were "also impacting
on UK forces in Afghanistan".

Separately, Jack Straw, the justice secretary, who is on a visit to Pakistan,
made clear that British forces would not be entering the tribal areas. "We keep
our military action within the borders of Afghanistan," Straw said.

The US-Pakistan dispute is in danger of escalating. The Pakistan army suggested
yesterday that, if there were another US incursion, it would retaliate. "If
somebody comes into your area, will you just sit there and take the beating?"
said army spokesman Major General Athar Abbas. "We will certainly respond to
that."

Washington believes that some of the Taliban fighting the coalition in
Afghanistan enjoy refuge in Pakistan's tribal areas, and it seems to have lost
patience with Islamabad, which it accuses of not doing enough to go after the
militants.

Gen Ashfaq Kayani, Pakistan's army chief, has described the US ground assault as
"reckless" and stated that there was no agreement between Pakistan and the US to
allow such operations. There are concerns that the US move could destabilise
Pakistan's democracy, restored after elections in February following eight years
of military rule.

Last night, Admiral Mike Mullen, chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff,
arrived in Pakistan for talks with Kayani and other officials. The US incursion
is likely to top the agenda.

It is thought that Zardari outlined to Brown Pakistan's plan to combat
terrorism, which included a proposal to set up a dedicated cell inside the
Pakistani high commission in London to help track British Pakistanis suspected
of extremism. Most of the known terror plots in the UK have had some connection
to Pakistan and often involved a visit there for training.

Zardari sought Brown's help in promoting the idea of an anti-terror conference
of Pakistan, Afghanistan and its neighbours Iran, China, Russia and India, along
with Britain and the US as observers.

The idea is to reach a consensus among the countries most directly affected by
the extremists based in Pakistan and Afghanistan, in an attempt to claim the
ownership of the anti-terror fight as an indigenous struggle. A Zardari aide
said: "We want to broaden the base for this war, to stop it being seen as . . .
George Bush's crusade. Otherwise, it just won't wash at home."

                         PA Newswire: Northern Ireland

                    September 17, 2008 Wednesday 2:48 PM BST

BUSINESSES GET TERROR ATTACK TRAINING

BYLINE: Michael McHugh, PA

SECTION: PA Newswire: Ireland

LENGTH: 333 words


Businesses across Belfast were put on red alert for a terror attack today - but
it was just a simulation.

Retailers learned how to prevent, handle and recover from an incident involving
international insurgents.

The event was run by the PSNI and Belfast's City Centre Management.

Assistant chief constable Alistair Finlay said: ``The project highlights the
importance of being prepared and having the necessary contingency plans in place
to help safeguard staff, customers and company assets.''

Participants attended workshops featuring a tabletop multi-media simulation of
an attack.

Attendees faced questions and dilemmas to resolve individually and collectively.

In 2006 a counter terrorism strategy was published by the British Government,
CONTEST, aimed at reducing the risk of international terrorism.

There is also a target in the 2008-2011 Northern Ireland Policing Plan to
develop the response to the threat.

As part of the CONTEST strategy, events entitled Project ARGUS have been taking
place across the UK, exploring what is likely to happen under a terrorist attack
and how businesses should respond.

Mr Finlay added: ``It is no secret that the threat to the UK from international
terrorism is real and serious and we all have a role to play in helping to
prevent it.

``Communities are the key to this process, and business communities in our
cities and towns can play a vital role in assisting the police to effectively
minimise this threat.''

An expert panel involving one representative from PSNI, Northern Ireland Fire
and Rescue Service, Northern Ireland Ambulance Service and Belfast City Council,
was on hand to guide participants.

Belfast city centre manager Andrew Irvine said: ``By advancing resilience,
businesses are better placed to recover more quickly, whether as a result of
emergencies, disasters or the global economy.

``The ability to demonstrate that an organisation can continue to meet its
contractual obligations despite interruptions is highly attractive to potential
clients.''

United Nations: Security Council Press Statement On Terrorist Attack In Yemen

LENGTH: 322 words


RDATE:17092008

The following Security Council press statement was read out today by Council
President Michel Kafando ( Burkina Faso):

The members of the Security Council condemned in the strongest terms the
terrorist attack that occurred at the entrance to the United States Embassy in
Sana'a, Yemen, on 17 September 2008, which caused death to Yemeni security
personnel, as well as numerous injuries.

They expressed their deepest sympathy and condolences to the families of the
victims and to the Government of Yemen.

The members of the Security Council underlined the need to bring perpetrators,
organizers, financiers and sponsors of this reprehensible act of terrorism to
justice, commended the commitment of the Government of Yemen to this end and
urged all States, in accordance with their obligations under international law
and relevant Security Council resolutions, to cooperate actively with the Yemeni
authorities in this regard.

The members of the Security Council reiterated that all acts of terrorism are
criminal and unjustifiable, regardless of their motivation, and reaffirmed the
need to combat by all means, in accordance with the Charter of the United
Nations, threats to international peace and security caused by terrorist acts.
The members of the Security Council reminded States that they must ensure that
measures taken to combat terrorism comply with all their obligations under
international law, in particular international human rights, refugee and
humanitarian law.

The members of the Security Council reiterated their determination to combat all
forms of terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the Charter of
the United Nations.

Yemeni deputy PM discusses anti-terrorism efforts, US embassy attack, piracy

LENGTH: 615 words


Text of report by Jordanian newspaper Al-Dustur on 20 September

[Report by Abd-al-Aziz al-Hayajim in Sanaa: "Yemeni deputy prime minister to
Al-Dustur: We Seized 200,000 Unlicensed Weapons Within a Year"]

Dr Rashad al-Alimi, Yemeni deputy prime minister for security and defence
affairs, has said that his country's war on terrorism is open-ended and
continuous. He expected other operations similar to the one carried out against
the US embassy in Sanaa.

Speaking to Al-Dustur, Al-Alimi said: "We expect such terrorist operations,
which are carried out in reaction to and retaliation for the painful blows dealt
to the terrorist elements at the hands of the security forces, the latest of
which were in Hadramaut and Abyan governorates."

The Yemeni deputy prime minister for security and defence affairs added: "The
security services not only in Yemen but also in almost all other countries are
facing challenges. These challenges are posed by suicide operations similar to
the terrorist operation carried out against the US embassy building." He
indicated that a disaster could have happened had it not been for the vigilance
of the security men guarding the building and their selfless courage. They
managed to kill the terrorists and blow up their two booby-trapped cars before
they could achieve any of their aims. He added that the Yemeni security services
will not hesitate to pursue the terrorists, tighten the noose around them,
apprehend them, and send them to justice.

He said: "The Interior Ministry's campaign to seize unlicensed weapons and
prevent armed manifestations, especially in major cities, led to positive
results and more than 200,000 pieces of weaponry have been seized so far.
Besides, several markets selling weapons have been closed. He stressed that the
campaign is continuing and this led to a reduction in the number of incidents
that take place as a result of carrying arms. Some of these incidents, he said,
are linked to acts of revenge, confiscation of land, and armed robbery."

Al-Alimi called on the Yemeni parliamentarians to expedite the ratification of
the amended law organizing the possession of weapons and explosives. He
indicated that this law will boost security efforts to control this uncivilized
phenomenon and punish those who break the law. He said there is no reason at all
to hesitate in ratifying this important law, which will serve the national
interests and promote the development and investment efforts in the country.

With regard to the measures Yemen adopted to confront piracy in international
waters near the Gulf of Aden - piracy which has recently increased - the Yemeni
deputy prime minister for security and defence affairs said: "Piracy in
international waters off the Gulf of Aden by some Somali outlaws cause us and
others concern because it poses a threat to the security and safety of
international navigation. Besides, acts of piracy do not distinguish between one
country and another; they harm the interests of all. Therefore, confronting
these acts is the responsibility of not only Yemen, but also the world."

He added: "Therefore, Yemen does all it can to confront these acts. Currently
arrangements are being made and coordination is under way with a number of
friendly countries to establish a regional centre in Aden and centres in
Al-Mukalla and Al-Hudaydah to confront sea piracy, in addition to establishing a
control and information centre in Sanaa."

Al-Alimi added that preparations are being made to hold an international
conference in Yemen next month to discuss the way to coordinate international
efforts to combat piracy in this region, which is vital for world trade.

Source: Al-Dustur, Amman, in Arabic 20 Sep 08

                           September 21, 2008, Sunday

BRITS HURT IN MASSIVE PAKISTAN BOMB BLAST;
 60 KILLED IN TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: BY DEAN ROUSEWELL

SECTION: 1 Star Edition; NEWS; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 212 words

HIGHLIGHT: DEVASTATION: Giant terror bomb crater in front of Marriott Hotel in
Islamabad; WOUNDED: Guest


UP to 60 people died and around 250 were injured - including four Britons, two
of them children - in a hotel bomb attack yesterday.

A lorry filled with 1,000lb of explosives blew up at the Marriott in the
Pakistan capital Islamabad, killing at least two foreigners, one an American.

The massive blast wrecked the hotel, a favourite with foreigners, setting it
ablaze and leaving a 30ft deep crater.

Marriott worker Mohammad Sultan, who was in the lobby, said: "It was like the
world is finished." Blood-stained guests lay dazed amid the carnage.

The Foreign Office confirmed the two British children had minor injuries and
have left hospital. The two adult Brits were kept in hospital overnight for
observation. More than 200 guests were eating in the hotel's restaurants at the
time of the attack.

Pakistan's new president, Asif Ali Zardari, denounced terrorists as cowards
after the blast and vowed to rid his country of the "cancer of terrorism".

Foreign Secretary David Miliband said last night: "This is yet another shocking
and disgraceful attack without justification. We stand shoulder to shoulder with
government of Pakistan against the violent extremists who have no answers but
only offer death and mayhem."

                           September 21, 2008, Sunday

'THE PICTURE CHANGED TO A TERRORIST ATTACK';
PS PUBLIC SECTOR'S LOCAL HEROES

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 297 words


FEW realise the crucial part played by the St John Ambulance Service in the
aftermath of the London bombings and the floods of last year. Scot Martin
Henderson won a letter of commendation for his role in the hours and days
following the 7/7 terror attacks.

MARTIN co-ordinated rescue efforts with the London Ambulance Service while
working out a way to get 160 staff and volunteers home safely.

He said: "It was like any other morning when news came through that there had
been an electrical surge on the underground.

The picture quickly changed to one of a terrorist attack.

"I was senior ranking employee on the day. We directed five vehicles to Edgware
Road to assist with the rescue attempt while trying to find out where people who
should have been in the office that day were.

"It was surreal. I spent the next two days co-ordinating our resources across
London and running doctors around. Our staff are trained to deal with major
incidents so everyone knew what to do."

Martin, 35, brought up in Bearsden, Glasgow, was a postman and worked his way
into middle management with the Royal Mail. He joined Securicor in 2001 where he
became an expert in transport logistics.

He joined the St John Ambulance Service in 2005 to co-ordinate the charity's
hospital transport services and was promoted to deputy chief executive (Prince
of Wales District) the following year.

The unit has 140 vehicles from ambulances to specialist patient transport
vehicles and even a boat.

Martin said: "Our people handle anything from serious wounds to life-threatening
cardiac arrests.

"At the Notting Hill Carnival we had 200volunteers on standby."

The charity raises most of its fundsproviding first aid courses.

Martin and his team are now planning their role in the 2012 Olympic Games.

Visit www.sja.org.uk

                              327 of 500 DOCUMENTS



                            The Independent (London)

                           September 22, 2008 Monday
                                 First Edition

Al-Qa'ida allies blamed for deadly terror attack on US hotel in Pakistani
capital

BYLINE: Omar Waraich in Islamabad and Andrew Buncombe

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 621 words


DRAMATIC CCTV footage released last night by Pakistani authorities shows the
moments before a truck containing more than 1,000lb of explosives tried to ram
the gates of an Islamabad hotel before blowing up, killing at least 53 people.

The grainy images show a small explosion inside the cab of a dumper truck after
security guards refused to allow the driver entry to the grounds of the Marriott
hotel. Panicking guards can be seen trying to put out the resultant fire before
sniffer dogs alert them that something is wrong. The guards can then be seen
fleeing the area but the subsequent blast is not captured as it destroyed the
cameras.

"The truck was stopped at the barrier and there was an altercation between the
attacker and the guards," said Rehman Malik, Pakistan's Interior Minister.

As Pakistan sought to recover from one of its most shocking terror attacks to
date and as the death toll from Saturday evening's blast continued to rise, Mr
Malik said investigators believed the bomb had contained an estimated 600kg
(1,322lb) of high-grade, military-style explosives. "This is the biggest
explosion in Pakistan's history," he added. "The diameter of the crater [left by
the bomb] is 69ft."

The Czech ambassador, Ivo Zdarek, was among the 53 people known to have been
killed. More than 260 others were injured and rescue crews werestill combing
through the smouldering debris last night.

Among the injured were six Britons, including a child and three diplomats. The
Foreign Office said two Britons remained in hospital. While three other
foreigners were among the dead, many if not most of those killed are believed to
have been members of the hotel's staff.

It was revealed yesterday that the authorities learnt that militants may have
been planning an attack in Islamabad three days earlier. However, efforts to
protect against such an event appear to have been concentrated on the parliament
building from where Pakistan's newly elected President, Asif Ali Zardari,
delivered a speech on Saturday evening, barely a mile from the hotel. There was
disagreement among officials whether the bomber had targeted the hotel after
failing to get close enough to the parliament building.

While there has been no claim of responsibility so far for Saturday's attack,
the authorities believe it was almost certainly the work of Islamic extremists
based in the country's tribal areas. Militants from the Pakistani Taliban and
al-Qa'ida have been behind an upsurge in violence in recent months of which
Saturday's bombing was just the latest incident. Pakistani civilians have made
up the overwhelming majority of the victims.

Mr Malik said a team of investigators has been examining the hotel and the deep
crater in the road outside. The action of the guards will likely be a key part
of the inquiry, given that the owner of the Marriott accused them of a serious
lapse by allowing the truck to approach unchallenged. "If I were there and had
seen the suicide bomber, I would have killed him. Unfortunately, they didn't,"
said Sadruddin Hashwani.

The blast - which used aluminium powder that created temperatures of more than
400C - is just the latest challenge for Pakistan's new civilian leadership. The
government and Mr Zardari have been involved in a war of words with the United
States over military operations carried out by American troops inside Pakistan
as they step up the hunt for Osama bin Laden before George Bush leaves office.

Mr Zardari condemned the bombing as a "cancer" before flying to New York for a
meeting with Mr Bush and talks at the UN where the issue of Pakistan's efforts
to confront extremists along its border with Afghanistan is certain to be
discussed.

US Department of State: Terrorist Attack in Islamabad, Pakistan

LENGTH: 221 words


RDATE:20092008

Press Statement Sean McCormack Washington, DC -- We condemn the heinous attack
on the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad that has left more than 40 dead and many more
injured. We extend our deepest sympathy and condolences to the Pakistani people,
and we are ready to assist in any way possible during this difficult time.

This barbaric attack comes during the month of Ramadan, only underscoring that
those responsible have no respect for the principles of their faith. This strike
to the heart of the Pakistani capital leaves no doubt as to the intentions of
these extremist elements. Their goal is to create mayhem and weaken the
institutions of government so that they may operate unfettered while spreading
their intolerance. The United States will continue to stand with the Pakistani
people and their democratically-elected government as it confronts this scourge.

Among those killed was at least one American citizen; several others have been
injured. We are in the process of notifying next of kin and offering our
condolences and assistance at this time.

Norwegian Government: Foreign Minister condemns terrorist attack in Islamabad

LENGTH: 286 words


RDATE:21092008

"The Government condemns today's terrorist attack outside the Marriott Hotel,"
said Foreign Minister Jonas Gahr Store. "We have expressed to the Pakistani
authorities our sympathy at the loss of so many lives and requested that this be
conveyed to the relatives."

"There is no justification for killing innocent civilians, and I can only
express my outrage at such a despicable act," said Mr Store.

"This is a difficult situation for Pakistan. Now it is important to support the
recent democratic progress in the country," said the Foreign Minister.

The Norwegian ambassador's residence is located in the same part of Islamabad as
the Marriott Hotel. The explosion caused material damage to the residence, but
there are no reports of any embassy personnel being injured.

Nor does the Foreign Ministry have any reports this evening of other Norwegian
nationals being injured as a result of today's attack.

The Norwegian embassy in Islamabad is working this evening to contact Norwegian
nationals registered as being in Pakistan.

Norwegian nationals who are in or planning to travel to Pakistan are encouraged
to contact the embassy in Islamabad for updated information and to register. For
more information see www.norway.org.pk.

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 23, 2008 Tuesday

US must help strengthen Pakistan's preparedness for terror attacks - daily

LENGTH: 524 words


Text of editorial headlined "Securing Pakistan" by Pakistani newspaper Dawn
website on 23 September


In the aftermath of the devastating bombing in Islamabad, serious questions are
being raised about the level of preparedness of the emergency and security
services. Depressingly, they are the same ones that are raised after each
terrorist strike -- and go unanswered each time. In the case of the Marriott
bombing, two sets of questions arise: those concerning the events before the
explosives-laden truck struck the security barrier of the hotel and those
concerning the hours after the truck burst into flames.

Consider the second set of questions first. It took more than 10 hours for
Islamabad's fire department to extinguish the blaze at the Marriott. We know
that people died in the period between the initial explosion and the time by
which the site was brought under control -- the Czech envoy who died inside the
hotel made a call to his embassy and asked to be rescued. Clearly, potentially
life-saving time was lost by a fire department that does not have enough of the
right! equipment and does not know how to best use the equipment it does have. A
report in this paper has claimed that 30 high-level posts in Islamabad's fire
department are vacant. Given the threats that Islamabad faces, negligence of
this kind rises to a criminal level. The speed of the response of the gas and
electricity utilities was also said to be sluggish though a spokesman for the
gas company disputed this assertion.

The second set of questions concerns the performance of Pakistan's security
apparatus. Failures are apparent at every stage leading up to Saturday's attack.
How did such large quantities of lethal explosives make it into the hands of
terrorists? How were the terrorists able to commandeer the truck and drive it
into Islamabad? And what was that truck doing unchecked in the heart of
Islamabad on an evening that every major leader of Pakistan -- civilian and
uniformed -- had gathered there? In the aftermath of terrorist attacks, we learn
of intelligence teams with obscure names -- Special Investigation Authority,
Special Investigation Group, Joint Investigation Teams. However, the public
knows little of their record of failure or success. No doubt fully securing
cities from suicide bombers is an all but impossible task. But equally obvious
are the gaping holes in our security apparatus. We need help and we need it now.
Misplaced nationalism argues that foreign help -- especially from the Americans
-- is unwelcome and an intrusion in our 'domestic' affairs. Yet anything that
helps saves Pakistani lives must be welcomed. From our emergency services to our
intelligence apparatus, the international community can do much to raise our
level of preparedness in the face of an unprecedented terrorist threat. The US
must lead the way in providing such support. It has spent an extraordinary
amount -- several hundred billion dollars -- in Iraq; investing a mere fraction
of that sum in Pakistan's anti-terrorism infrastructure would go a long way to
defeating a common enemy.

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 23 Sep 08

                                  IRE Edition

Aftershave clue may halt sex attacker's reign of terror

BYLINE: Alan Sherry

SECTION: Pg. 22

LENGTH: 502 words


GARDAÍ have called in a psychological profiler and a behavioural analyst to help
in the hunt for a serial sex attacker believed to be responsible for up to five
violent assaults on women over the past 13 months.

And officers have revealed the man wears a distinctive aftershave - possibly
Joop! - a clue they hope will nail him before he strikes again.

The latest incident happened early on Saturday morning in Athlone as a
28-year-old woman was walking home from a shop.

She was grabbed from behind and her attacker pushed her over a wall in an
attempted sexual assault but the woman managed to get away.

The vicious attacker had his face bruised in the incident.

That attack came just days after a teenage Athlone Institute of Technology
student was attacked as she walked home alone in the Bonavalley Bridge area.

Three similar attacks happened in the same area - which is close to the college
- between August and October last year.

Superintendent Aidan Glacken, who is in charge of the investigation, is to
appear on RTÉ's Crime-call tonight to make a public appeal for information. He
said up to 1,000 lines of inquiry are considered 'active' and hundreds of
statements have been taken.

Mr Glacken said there is a distinctive smell of aftershave from the attacker and
that 'it is quite over-powering, something akin to Joop!'. He said that while it
is too early to confirm definitively the same man is behind the attacks, 'there
are similarities'.

He said: 'These are serious assaults of a physical nature. The modus operandi is
quite similar - a female alone, being attacked from behind.

'It obviously has put the community in some form of fear and made the lives of
females in particular, quite vulnerable here.'

On October 3, last year, a 39-year-old woman was seriously assaulted by a man
while walking home near Bonavalley Bridge late at night, and before that on
September 23, another woman had been grabbed from behind and dragged to a
secluded area.

Before that again, a woman had been set upon on August 12, in an incident that
was featured on RTÉ's Crimecall programme. She and her friend had left a
nightclub just after 3am and were making their way to Bonavalley Bridge where
they decided to wait for a taxi. Her friend walked on a bit further to see if
she could get a cab close to the town. However, a man grabbed the victim from
behind and dragged her to a nearby disused car park. He violently assaulted her,
leaving her with severe cuts and bruises to her face. She managed to escape.

All of the attacks have taken place near railway bridges and gar-daí are
investigating CCTV footage to see if the attacker is using railway lines to flee
the scenes.

Students at AIT have been warned to be particularly vigilant.

Crimestoppers is offering a e10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest
of the man.

He is believed to be in his late 20s, 5ft 8in to 5ft 10in, with dark hair and
large eyes. He was wearing dark corduroy trousers and a dark jumper with a white
collar last week.

United Nations: Security Council Condemns In Strongest Terms Terrorist Attack In
Pakistan

LENGTH: 471 words


RDATE:22092008

Security Council

5978^th Meeting (PM)

The Security Council today condemned in the strongest terms Saturday's terrorist
attack in Islamabad, Pakistan, which killed and wounded foreign diplomats as
well as local residents.

In a formal statement read out by Michel Kafando of Burkina Faso, which holds
the Council Presidency this month, the 15-member body also expressed sympathy
for the victims and their families and underlined the need to bring to justice
the perpetrators, organizers, financiers and sponsors of what it called "this
reprehensible act of terrorism".

It reaffirmed that all acts of terrorism were criminal and unjustifiable,
regardless of their motivation, and that terrorism must be fought by all means
consistent with the Charter of the United Nations and international law.

The meeting began at 1:06 p.m. and ended at 1:11 p.m.

Presidential Statement

The full text of presidential statement S/PRST/2008/35 reads as follows:

"The Security Council condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist attack that
occurred in Islamabad on 20 September 2008, causing numerous deaths and
injuries, including among foreign diplomats. It expresses its deep sympathy and
condolences to the victims of this heinous act of terrorism and to their
families, and to the people and Government of Pakistan.

"The Security Council underlines the need to bring perpetrators, organizers,
financiers and sponsors of this reprehensible act of terrorism to justice, and
urges all States, in accordance with their obligations under international law
and resolution 1373 (2001) and consistent with resolution 1624 (2005), to
cooperate actively with the Pakistani authorities in this regard.

"The Security Council reaffirms that terrorism in all its forms and
manifestations constitutes one of the most serious threats to international
peace and security, and that any acts of terrorism are criminal and
unjustifiable, regardless of their motivation, wherever, whenever and by
whomsoever committed.

"The Security Council further reaffirms the need to combat by all means, in
accordance with the Charter of the United Nations, threats to international
peace and security caused by terrorist acts. The Council reminds States thatthey
must ensure any measures taken to combat terrorism comply with all their
obligations under international law, in particular international human rights,
refugee and humanitarian law.

"The Security Council reiterates its determination to combat all forms of
terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the Charter of the
United Nations."

TERROR ATTACK? IT WAS JUST PERFORMANCE ART;
KILLER DENIES STORMONT BOMB

BYLINE: BY GARY ANDERSON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 241 words


TERRORIST Michael Stone yesterday said his alleged attempt to kill Sinn Fein's
leadership was just "art".

The ex-Loyalist paramilitary, 53, told a court his 2006 attempt to force his way
into Stormont was a "performance protest".

Stone, of no fixed address, denies trying to murder Gerry Adams and Martin
McGuinness.

He also denies having nail pipe bombs, three knives, an axe and garotte and an
imitation firearm with intent to endanger life.

Instead, he claimed the arsenal of items were merely "props" with symbolic
significance, the nail bombs for "nailing the truth".

A sponge in the butt of the fake gun was for "sponging unionists", he told
Belfast crown court. He claimed he "fully supported" the peace process but was
worried about a power vacuum.

He said the stunt aimed to "put a proverbial rocket up the backsides of
politicians" at Northern Ireland's Parliament building.

He added that given his connections he could have made the pipe bombs out of
metal and got hold of a real gun instead of an imitation, if he had wanted to
kill. Stone was jailed for life for a 1988 gun and grenade attack on an IRA
funeral ceremony.

But he was granted early release in 2000 under the Good Friday Agreement.
Defence QC Orlando Pownall reminded Stone that he was freed on a life licence
and asked him: "What do you consider your prospects are for release?"

Stone admitted: "Given the seriousness of these charges, it doesn't look rosy."

The trial continues.

TERROR ATTACK? IT WAS JUST PERFORMANCE ART

BYLINE: BY GARY ANDERSON

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 298 words


TERRORIST Michael Stone yesterday said his alleged attempt to kill Sinn Fein's
leadership was just "art".

The ex-Loyalist paramilitary, 53, claimed his 2006 attempt to force his way into
Stormont armed with pipe bombs was a "performance protest".

He told a court: "I'm destroying the iconography of Michael Stone Loyalist hero.

"It's a comic parody of my former self. I would rather be remembered as an
eccentric artist that got it wrong in performance art than my past when I did
some terrible things."

Stone, of no fixed address, denies trying to murder Gerry Adams and Martin
McGuinness at Northern Ireland's Parliament building. He also denies having nail
pipe bombs, three knives, an axe, garotte and imitation gun with intent to
endanger life.

Instead, he claimed the arsenal of items were merely "props" with symbolic
significance, the nail bombs for "nailing the truth".

A sponge in the butt of the fake gun was for "sponging Unionists", he told
Belfast crown court.

He said he only came up with the "performance art work" about six weeks
beforehand.

And while he "fully supported" the peace process, he was worried about a power
vacuum.

He claimed the stunt aimed to "put a proverbial rocket up the backsides of
politicians". He added that given his connections he could easily have made the
pipe bombs out of metal and got a real gun instead of an imitation, if he had
wanted to kill.

Stone was jailed for life for a 1988 gun and grenade attack on an IRA funeral
ceremony. But he was granted early release in 2000 under the Good Friday
Agreement. Defence QC Orlando Pownall reminded Stone he was freed on a life
licence and asked him: "What do you consider your prospects are for release?"

Stone admitted: "Given the seriousness of these charges, it doesn't look rosy."

The trial continues.

Gidea park: Boy blinded by vigilante;
A Vigilante who used a hammer to attack and blind a teenager he said was
terrorising the community has been jailed.

BYLINE: Tom Gardner

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 244 words


Father-of-one Lewis Bowman snapped after being confronted on his doorstep by the
17-year-old.

Bowman, 26, claimed the tearaway, who cannot be named, had harassed vulnerable
residents on his Gidea Park housing estate and even stolen £160 from a neighbour
who suffers learning disabilities and mental health problems.

But Judge Jacqueline Beech had little sympathy and jailed Bowman for two years
and eight months.

She told Snaresbrook Crown Court: "Nothing that happened at the door of your
home could have justified your actions. You just lost control. He asked about
the rumour that you were going to knock him out, at which point you did. You
knocked him on the eye socket with a hammer."

Defending,  Adekunle Tijani said Bowman and his family have now moved home
following persistent harassment from youths.

"It's not disputed by the Crown that the victim of this case is not really a
perfect person. The defence are not in any way saying that act of Mr Bowman was
justifiable, even though this matter might have been caused by the victim
himself in the past."

The court earlier heard how the boy was clutching some cannabis when he came to
Bowman's front door in Mountbatten House, Elvet Avenue.

Prosecutor Lee Ingham said: "The defendant held out the hammer and struck him
with a blow to the eye area. This caused serious injury; he has in fact lost his
eye."

Alison McGuire, Bowman's fiancee and mother of his two-year-old daughter, sobbed
as he was led from the dock.

                                South Wales Echo

                          September 24, 2008 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

'I feel scared in my home after scarecrow attack';
Mum tells of terror at seeing flames at door

BYLINE: Wendy Horton

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 21

LENGTH: 393 words


A MOTHER and her three children fled their home after drunken teenagers set fire
to a scarecrow and propped it up against their front door.

The youngsters were seen setting the straw scarecrow alight and leaning it
against the door before knocking and running away.

Mum Tracy Davies was forced to flee the house in Groesfan Terrace, Deri, near
Bargoed, with her three children, aged 15, 14 and six, for fear the house would
go up in flames. A gas meter was just inches away from where the youngsters put
the scarecrow.

Mrs. Davies, whose husband David was working a shift that night, had just gone
to bed when the drama unfolded.

"I heard noises outside and saw three older teenagers outside," she said.

"They had a scarecrow, and had been playing football with its head. Then they
went out of sight and I could see flames.

"I thought 'Oh my God they've lit it'.

"I was just about to come down and open the front door when I saw flames going
up the sky light. It just went up.

"I panicked because I thought flames would spread to a wooden canopy and there's
a gas box around the corner.

"My first thought was for the children. My youngest was asleep and had to be
carried out by my older daughter as I was carrying keys and mobile phone."

The blaze went out before firefighters arrived but the family's front door was
left badly damaged. It has also left 37-year-old Tracy, who works as a clerical
assistant for the local council, and her children, feeling shaken up.

"Sometimes I don't lock my door, what if they had opened it and they'd thrown it
in?" she said.

"I'm sure it was a prank because other people have said they saw the youngsters
acting drunk.

"It's made me nervous. I've always felt safe in this house because it's so quiet
here, now I feel vulnerable."

She added: "I don't think I was targeted on purpose. I don't think it was
anything deathly, just a prank but it could have been fatal."

Crime and disorder reduction officer Claire Young, based at Rhymney Police
Station, said: "If the occupier had not been so quick to act or indeed been out
at the time of the incident the consequences of this anti-social behaviour could
have been far worse.

"This type of behaviour is not acceptable."

Anyone with information is asked to ring Claire Young on 029 2085 7470 or Gwent
Police on 01633 838111.

wendy.horton@mediawales.co.uk

Yemen continues investigation into terrorist attack on US embassy

LENGTH: 211 words


Text of report in English by state-run Yemeni news agency Saba website

25 September: A security source said on Thursday [25 September] investigators
have reached important information on the last attack on the US embassy in
Sanaa, the mouthpiece of Defence Ministry September 26 reported.

The source noted that a specialized team is currently testing the DNA of corpses
of the attackers to compare the results of these examinations with available
information on antecedent criminals and detainees over terrorist charges.

The move aims to identify the identities of who carried out the attack on the US
embassy on 17 September.

The source affirmed much information have been collected over the incident
either via the embassy's surveillance systems or those collected by eyewitnesses
and security authorities.

Investigations also revealed that the number plates of the two cars, the
perpetrators used to carry out the attack, were false.

On September 17, a double car bomb attack rocked the US embassy in Sanaa killing
16 people including six of troops guarding the embassy and four civilians and
six attackers.

The civilians included two Yemenis, an Indian women and a US citizen from a
Yemeni origin.

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                          September 25, 2008 Thursday

National: De Menezes feared being in wrong place at wrong time on day of death,
inquest told: Cousin says family was scared after terror attacks Brazilian had
praised police for their restraint

BYLINE: Vikram Dodd

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 729 words


Jean Charles de Menezes told his family they should pray not to be in the "wrong
place at the wrong time" hours before he was shot dead by police who mistook him
for a suicide bomber.

The inquest into the death of the 27-year-old Brazilian, who was killed in July
2005, heard that De Menezes and his cousins had been scared by that summer's
terrorist attacks on London.

His cousins told yesterday how the man mistakenly shot dead by armed officers
had praised the British police for their restraint and for not carrying weapons.

Hours before he was killed, De Menezes had tried to calm one cousin's fears
about terrorism, saying: "We need to pray and hope not to be at the wrong place
at the wrong time."

The innocent electrician was held down and shot seven times in the head at point
blank range by officers on an underground train on July 22 2005.

They mistook him for a terrorist suspect who had tried to attack London the
previous day, July 21, leaving the capital on edge following the July 7 bombing,
which killed 52 people and injured 900.

The jury yesterday heard from De Menezes's cousin who lived with him in south
London, Vivian Figueiredo. In a statement she told of the last time she spoke to
her cousin, on the afternoon of four attempted bomb attacks on three tube trains
and a bus. Figueiredo said: "Jean telephoned me at about 1.30 . . . he phoned to
check that I was OK. We were all feeling a little bit shaky after the 7th July
bombings.

"After the second lot of attempted bombings on 21st July I felt quite scared. It
was feeling as though London was beginning to become a dangerous place to live
and I was wondering whether we should leave. Jean said we need to pray and hope
not to be at the wrong place at the wrong time. That was in fact the last
conversation I had with Jean."

Figueiredo also said that De Menezes had been stopped and questioned by police
at Brixton tube station about a month before his death.

She said De Menezes had been carrying tools in a rucksack when he was "licked"
by a sniffer dog. Police asked him some questions, then let him go.

Another cousin, Patricia da Silva Armani, told how De Menezes had praised the
police: "I am sure Jean Charles had nothing to fear from the police on 22nd July
and there was no reason at all why he would have behaved in a way that would
have aroused suspicion.

"He had been stopped by the police a few times in England.

"In fact he used to praise the British police. He mentioned they were always
polite and did a good job, particularly in comparison with the Brazilian police.

"He also remarked on how good it was that they didn't carry any weapons on them.
I remember him also commenting about seeing other people being stopped by the
police and getting angry.

"He was surprised that the police didn't react, because in Brazil people would
have been locked up straight away."

Armani told how the family became worried when De Menezes failed to return home
and calls to his mobile phone went unanswered.

When family members were asked to come to a police station, she said, she
thought her cousin had done something bad.

Armani told the jury: "When police started speaking I could not understand a lot
of what was being said.

"Then I made the connection with the news. My head started spinning and my
stomach was turning.

"Later we had to go and see his body in the mortuary. The news had not really
sunk in.

"When I saw his body I fainted. The following days were horrific. We were
staying in a hotel in Kingston arranged by police.

"I had three completely sleepless nights with a large number of news people
around and the shooting constantly on the news."

The inquest saw footage of De Menezes's final journey, taken from CCTV from a
bus he travelled on as he tried to get to work. Unbeknown to him, he was being
followed by undercover police officers.

The inquest also heard yesterday from John McDowell, who was leading the hunt
for the July 21 attackers.

McDowell, now a deputy assistant commissioner at Scotland Yard, said on the
evening of July 21 senior counter-terrorism investigators believed the attack
was linked to the July 7 bombings, with similarities between the devices used.

McDowell, who the jury heard has a serious illness, gave evidence from a
wheelchair and by videolink.

He said police feared further attacks, especially with four bombers on the
loose.

McDowell continues his evidence today.

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                          September 25, 2008 Thursday

United Nations: Security Council Press Statement On Terrorist Attacks In Spain

LENGTH: 299 words


RDATE:24092008

The following Security Council press statement on the terrorist attacks in Spain
was read out today by Council President Michel Kafando ( Burkina Faso):

The members of the Security Council condemned in the strongest terms the recent
terrorist attacks in Spain, which caused death and injuries.

The members of the Security Council expressed their condolences to the families
of the victims and to the people and Government of Spain.

The members of the Security Council underlined the need to bring perpetrators,
organizers, financiers and sponsors of these reprehensible acts of terrorism to
justice and urged all States, in accordance with their obligations under
international law and relevant Security Council resolutions, to cooperate
actively with the Spanish authorities in this regard.

The members of the Security Council reiterated that all acts of terrorism are
criminal and unjustifiable, regardless of their motivation, and reaffirmed the
need to combat by all means, in accordance with the Charter of the United
Nations, threats to international peace and security caused by terrorist acts.
The members of the Security Council reminded States that they must ensure that
measures taken to combat terrorism comply with all their obligations under
international law, in particular international human rights, refugee and
humanitarian law.

The members of the Security Council reiterated their determination to combat all
forms of terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the Charter of
the United Nations.

                                The West Briton

                          September 25, 2008 Thursday

Terrorist attack response plans

SECTION: Pg. 6

LENGTH: 162 words


Terrorist attack response plans were delivered to 60 Truro businesses at a
meeting on Tuesday.

Police, firefighters and emergency planners took staff from shops, banks, bars
and restaurants through a simulated a terrorist attack with an audio-visual
presentation.

Although it was strongly emphasised no attack was facing the city, officers
earmarked Truro shopping centre as a potential prime target and explored ways of
preventing, handling and recovering from an attack.

It was part of 'Project Argus', a National Counter Terrorism Security Office
(NaCTSO) initiative.

Supt Elaine Marshall said: "This has not been arranged because we are aware of a
specific threat, but because we want businesses to be prepared in the event of
such an incident. Recent events have illustrated that this type of attack can
happen anywhere and I'm sure that the fact that local businesses and the police
will use this forum to focus on this issue together will prove to be immensely
useful."

                           September 26, 2008 Friday

Major terror attack averted in Pakistan's Karachi - police

LENGTH: 270 words


Text of report by official news agency Associated Press of Pakistan (APP)

Karachi, 26 September: A senior police official said Friday [26 September]
police and intelligence agencies have saved Karachi city from a major incident
of terrorism.

CCPO [Capital City Police Officer] Karachi Wasim Ahmed told APP that two
suspected suicide bombers, belonging to a banned militant organization were
crushed to death when a house in Baldia Town collapsed in a bomb blast during an
encounter with police this morning.

He said that the suspected bombers were hiding in a house in Baldia Town when
police conducted a raid early morning on the pointation of their ring leader who
was also arrested by police during Sehri [pre-dawn meal during Ramadan].

Wasim said that they were probably preparing for some terrorist activity in the
metropolis.

The deceased were also wanted in two previous terrorist activities - Nishtar
Park explosion and murder of Allama Hasan Turabi respectively.

They also hurled hand grenades on police party and resorted to heavy fire from
automatic weapons, he added.

He said that the area was cleared before the raid and residents were asked to
vacate their house to avoid casualties of innocent citizens. "We knew that the
suspects had a large quantity of explosive and sophisticated weapons and they
would use them, he added.

CCPO said that they blew up themselves when they consumed their ammunition
during the encounter. He said police was alert in the city and had a
comprehensive security plan to avoid any terrorist plan.

Source: Associated Press of Pakistan news agency, Islamabad, in English 0627gmt
26 Sep 08

                                   Daily Star

                           September 26, 2008 Friday
                                Scottish Edition

TEEN FIEND ATTACKED 8 WOMEN;
Single night of terror

BYLINE: by STEPHEN WILKIE

SECTION: NEWS; 22

LENGTH: 269 words


A TEENAGE RAF cadet has admitted carrying out eight sex attacks in less than
three hours.

Robert Thomson - who was 15 at the time of the assaults across Glasgow in June -
was caught after police released CCTV images.

The fiend, now aged 16, approached women and either made indecent suggestions or
simply pounced, dragging them to the ground.

The High Court in Glasgow heard one woman was followed for 45 minutes before
Thomson struck.

He pleaded guilty to eight charges, including three of intent to rape and
several indecent assaults - all on the same day this summer.

Judge Lord Turnbull deferred sentence for reports and placed Thomson on the sex
offenders' register, remanding him to the secure Kibble Centre in Paisley.

The court heard his victims were all aged between 20 and 35.

The first woman was attacked near the city centre when Thomson asked her: "Do
you want a sh*g?" She walked off but Thomson grabbed her and pushed her towards
a nearby alley.

She managed to break free before the boy staggered off.

In another case, Thomson forced his victim to the ground, put his hand over her
mouth and lay on top of her simulating sex as she struggled to breath.

A short time later, he grabbed another victim around the neck at an underpass
before fondling her and pushing her over.

When he was snared by cops, Thomson said he could not remember some of the
attacks.

Defence counsel Mark Stewart QC said: "This is an unusual case." He added
Thomson, a first-time offender, had recently left school and had been a member
of the RAF cadets.

"He is someone who still harbours ambitions to serve in the Royal Air Force, "
he said.

                             The Observer (London)

                               September 28, 2008

Boy killed in terrorist bomb attack in Delhi

BYLINE: Gethin Chamberlain, Delhi

SECTION: OBSERVER FOREIGN PAGES; Pg. 40

LENGTH: 241 words


A YOUNG boy was killed and at least 18 people injured in a bomb attack on a New
Delhi shopping area yesterday afternoon. The boy had seen the bombers drop a bag
containing the device and was trying to return it to them when it went off.

Witnesses said nine-year-old Santosh Kumar saw two men on a motorbike drop a bag
in Mehrauli market. He called out to them, 'Sir, you have dropped your bag,' and
picked it up, at which point the bomb went off. His brother said Santosh had
gone out to buy eggs.

The blasts came two weeks after five bombs killed at least 20 in the Indian
capital. A group calling itself the Indian Mujahideen claimed responsibility.

Police spokesman Rajan Bhagat confirmed that a boy had died in the explosion,
which happened in a flower market in south Delhi. 'A black motorcycle carrying
two people drove down and hurled a polythene bag containing a box, which
exploded when a child picked it up,' he said.

Deputy police commissioner HS Dhaliwal said 18 people were injured, three of
them critically. Several other Indian cities - Jaipur, Bangalore and Ahmedabad -
have also been hit by bombings since May, all of them claimed by the Indian
Mujahideen.

Since the New Delhi attacks two weeks ago, Indian police have launched a major
hunt for the suspected ringleaders of the shadowy group. Over the past week, 11
suspected militants have been arrested and two more were killed in a shoot-out
in a mainly-Muslim area of south Delhi.

                         The Sunday Telegraph (London)

                               September 28, 2008

Four arrests over 'terror' attack on publisher

BYLINE: ANDREW ALDERSON Chief Reporter

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 456  words


FOUR PEOPLE were arrested in London yesterday over an alleged terrorist attack
on the publisher of a book about the prophet Mohammed.

The arrests are connected to a fire at a property in Islington, north London,
which is used as the home and office of Martin Rynja, a publisher.

His company, Gibson Square, recently bought the rights to a novel that is
considered by some to be more controversial than Salman Rushdie's, The Satanic
Verses. Sherry Jones's debut novel, The Jewel of Medina, has as its subject the
prophet and his child bride, Aisha.

The blaze yesterday, which led to people being evacuated from the house, might
have been started by a petrol bomb pushed through the letter box.

The first three men - aged 22, 30 and 40 - were detained at around 2.25am
yesterday after a fire broke out at a property in Lonsdale Square. Two were
stopped by armed officers at the scene and the third was seized when a car was
stopped by armed police near Angel Tube station.

Random House US, the leading publishing group, announced last May that it was
dropping its plans to publish the novel following warnings that it could incite
acts of violence from radical Muslims. The Jewel of Medina was also pulled from
bookshops in Serbia last month after pressure from an Islamic group.

Gibson Square bought the rights to Jones's book, which will be published next
month, in Britain, Australia and New Zealand after Random House pulled out. The
book will be published by Beaufort Books in the United States.

Speaking before yesterday's attack, Mr Rynja said: "In an open society there has
to be open access to literary works, regardless of fear. As an independent
publishing company, we feel strongly that we should not be afraid of the
consequences of debate.

"If a novel of quality and skill that casts light on a beautiful subject we know
too little of in the West, but have a genuine interest in, cannot be published
here, it would truly mean that the clock has been turned back to the dark ages.
The Jewel of Medina has become an important barometer of our time.''

He added that he hoped that once people read the novel there would be a "healthy
discussion'' about its content.

Mr Rynja was unavailable for comment yesterday.

The writer, also speaking before the attack, said that her novel was not
intended to be disrespectful to Islam. "I have deliberately and consciously
written respectfully about Islam and Mohammed,'' she said. "I envisaged that my
book would be a bridge-builder.''

The men, who were arrested on suspicion of the commission, preparation or
instigation of acts of terrorism, were being questioned at a central London
police station. Later yesterday a woman was arrested at a property in Ilford for
allegedly obstructing the police.

[Report by A. L.: "Ain Defla: Gendarme Assassinated in a Terrorist Attack"]

The attack that was perpetrated at 2315 hours on Wednesday [24 September] on
elements from the National Gendarmerie that were on duty at the entrance to the
municipality of Boumedfaa (east of the main town in Ain Defla Province), given
its dramatic nature, given the number of elements engaged in that action and its
method, according to accounts, continues to figure prominently in local news, a
sign of the worry of the population after the resurgence of violence that has
intermittently marked this sacred month.

So, according to matching sources, the armed group that was the perpetrator of
the attack at the permanent National Gendarmerie roadblock was made up of about
40 individuals who in all likelihood had come from the Hammam Righa mountains on
the border with the wilaya of Tipaza, matching sources indicated. The attackers,
who were wearing ordinary dress, according to accounts, did not attract the
attention of citizens, who were out in numbers on that Ramadhan evening on that
usually heavily trafficked axis of National Road [RN] 4. They then split into
groups to block highway accesses to traffic, our sources also added. One of the
armed elements fired at the gendarmes, killing one of them and wounding two
others; the terrorist took the time to seize his victim's Kalashnikov.

Sustained fire rained down on the sentry box of the National Gendarmerie billet
and on the entrance to the building located several meters away from the scene
of the attack to allow the whole group to retreat. Let us point out that the two
wounded gendarmes were evacuated to the Blida health sector while reinforcements
made up of combined security forces were dispatched to the scene and the
surrounding areas. Last, let us remind readers that three municipal guars have
perished in recent days in attacks which occurred to the southeast and the
southwest of the main town in the wilaya of Ain Defla.

                            Daily Post (North Wales)

                           October 1, 2008 Wednesday
                                 Mersey Edition

Terror attack victims meet to share their agonies

BYLINE: LAURA SHARPE Daily Post Staff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 490 words


TERRORIST victims from around the world gathered in Warrington yesterday to
speak about their experiences.

A group of 10 people who had either been directly targeted by a bomb or gun
attack or had members of their family killed by terrorists spoke about their
recovery as victims.

They met at the Peace Centre, set up after the 1993 IRA bombing of Warrington,
as part of a Voice of the Victims conference.

Mo Norton, who used to live in Warrington, lost her brother in 1974 when the IRA
planted a bomb in a coach he was travelling on from Manchester.

A total of 12 people were killed, including a five-year-old and a two-year-old,
and she said the death had an unbelievable effect on her family.

She said: "My father died prematurely because of my brother losing his life, it
had an unbelievable effect on my family.

"There was no support, no counselling, we were left to get on with it."

Mo said it was only after she went to Northern Ireland and sat in the same room
with IRA members that her life turned around.

She said: "I knew it wasn't going to be easy, but the turning point was when
someone who introduced himself as an IRA member said to me 'we didn't plant the
bomb to embarrass the government, we did it to kill the soldiers'.

"I said to them 'did you mean to kill the children, too? I realised then that I
wasn't frightened of the IRA and that I didn't need to be frightened any more."

The conference also heard from Alberto Torregiani, from Italy, who has been
wheelchair bound since he was shot in the spine by a Communist terrorist group.

Eloy Moran, a victim of the Madrid bombings, said he remembers hearing a big
bang and thought he was going to explode.

Recounting that day, he said: "I remember from that moment when I couldn't move
that there was no noise, silence, a tremendous silence, no-one was screaming."

Juan Antonio Garcia Casquero, a victim of an Eta bomb in Spain, said victims
were abandoned by society as if they didn't exist, and many people thought they
must have done something wrong to be attacked.

After recounting their harrowing experiences, the speakers then moved on to the
positive side, and how they had joined together with other victims.

Mr Moran said: "I decided to do something, but that was the last thing I felt
like doing; I wanted to stay home like a little mouse.

"But I survived, God gave me a second chance and I decided to contact and track
down all the other victims."

Mr Moran conducted the arduous task of locating all the victims and set up a
support group to help victims with counselling and any court cases they may have
to face.

The first of four events held across Europe, the conference was run by the Tim
Parry Johnathan Ball Foundation for Peace, in conjunction with the European
Network of Victims of Terrorism (VNET).

Old Hall Street, Liverpool L69 3EB

Two doctors on trial over airport terrorist attack;
Court case in London likely to last 12 weeks

BYLINE: MARIANNE TAYLOR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 322 words


TWO NHS doctors accused of plotting the terrorist attack on Glasgow Airport are
expected to go on trial today.

Jordanian national Mohammed Jamil Asha, 28, and Iraqi Bilal Abdullah, 29, are
accused of crashing a flaming Jeep Cherokee, loaded with gas canisters and
petrol, into security barriers at the airport's main terminal.

The attack happened on June 30, 2007, while thousands of holidaymakers and staff
were inside the building.

The trial is expected to begin today but it's thought there will be at least a
week of legal arguments before the prosecution opens its case.

It is likely to last at least 12 weeks.

The pair, who are appearing at Woolwich Crown Court in London, are also accused
of planning a similar attack in London a day earlier, leaving two Mercedes
packed with gas cylinders and nails outside Tiger Tiger nightclub in Haymarket.

The bombs failed to explode.

Abdullah, of the halls of residence, Royal Alexandra Hospital, Paisley, and
Asha, of Sunningdale Grove, Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire, are accused of
conspiracy to murder and conspiracy to cause explosions between January 1, 2006,
and July 1, 2007.

Both men deny the charges.

Abdullah, who worked at the Royal Alexandra Hospital, was the fi rst person to
be charged in connection with the plots.

He was arrested by police immediately after the airport attack.

Asha was arrested in a police swoop while travelling north on the M6 in
Cheshire.

His wife Marwa Asha, 27, who was arrested at the same time, was later released
without charge.

Another man, Kafeel Ahmed, 27, was driving the Jeep which crashed into the
terminal building.

Ahmed, an engineer who rented a home in Houston, Renfrewshire, set himself on
fire and died in August 2007 after suffering thirddegree burns to 90-per cent of
his body.

Following a hearing at the Old Bailey in London in April, Ahmed's 26-year-old
brother Sabeel Ahmed was jailed for 18 months for withholding information from
police.

                            The Independent (London)

                            October 2, 2008 Thursday
                                 First Edition

How I became a target for Israel's 'Jewish terrorists';
Peace campaigner attacked with a pipe bomb tells Donald Macintyre why militant
Zionism should be feared

BYLINE: Donald Macintyre

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 1094 words


Zeev Sternhell is careful about his choice of words when he unhesitatingly calls
the pipe bomb which exploded outside his front door last week "an act of Jewish
terrorism."

As a Holocaust survivor orphaned by the age of seven and a combat veteran of
Israel's wars, Professor Sternhell, 73, who was lucky to have only been injured
in the leg by flying shrapnel from the bomb, is "horrified" not for himself but
because it might have hit his wife, daughter his grandchildren on one of their
sleepovers, or their neighbours. "It was a terror act because they couldn't know
who would have been hit."

Given that, as he wryly puts it, he has no known enemies in the "criminal
underworld", the reason for what police think was attempted murder isn't hard to
find. As a veteran member of Peace Now, and vigorous opponent of the occupation
since the late 1970s, the Hebrew University scholar, Israel Prize laureate and
internationally-known authority on the roots of fascism apparently became the
target of the highest-profile attack inside Israel by far right-wing Jewish
extremists since Yitzhak Rabin's assassination in 1995.

But if the attack was meant to silence one of the country's foremost public
intellectuals, it hasn't worked. For a start he does not rule out a connection
with strong signs of increasing violence by settlers against Palestinians in the
West Bank. In recent weeks, extremist settlers have rioted, blocked roads,
burned Palestinian orchards and in one case, armed settlers have attacked a
village.

Lamenting that the army and the police are "either unwilling or unable or
probably both" to enforce the law against attacks on Palestinians in a West Bank
where the settlers enjoy a kind of "self rule", he says the extremists believe
that "people like me who think that they are the real danger to Zionism, to the
future of the Israeli state, should be neutralised and should be punished ... So
I think there is a link between the brutality and violence that is the reality
of everyday life in the West Bank and this attack."

Of the 250,000 West Bank settlers he estimates that only some 40,000 to 50,000
are truly ideological and of these only "a few thousand are ready to use force."
He pinpoints the new generation of "hilltop youth" who, in a pattern familiar
from "revolutionary movements", regard their aging leadership as "traitors" for
being willing to discuss with the government even the possibility of voluntary
evacuation from a few outposts.

Activists who are "deeply convinced that the future of the Jewish people depends
on them," therefore regard violence as legitimate and believe that "God is with
us, and God will see to it that we will get rid of the Palestinians. That is
more or less their philosophy."

For Professor Sternhell, the answer is the early evacuation of "at least 95 per
cent of the West Bank" and for the authorities to prepare to bring the settlers
across back across the 1967 border and into Israel. But here there is a paradox.
On the one hand, he believes that the violence may stem "from a sense of
urgency" on the extreme right because "they have reached the conclusion that the
Israeli political elite is now much closer to what I think than to their ideas".

This conclusion was reinforced by the outgoing Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, who
this week finally acknowledged something that Professor Sternhell has been
arguing for 30 years - that almost all the West Bank will have to be handed back
if there is to be peace. But while he thinks ideologically the left may have won
a "battle" - though not the "war" - he is highly conscious that after relentless
settlement growth over 40 years, bringing the settlers "home" in practice will
be "a very tough job" and questions whether the Israeli establishment has "the
moral energy and leadership capability" to carry it through.

"The Israeli political elite is very weak ... the fact is that the people in
power are not ready for the confrontation with the settlers ... I am not
optimistic. I don't see who is able in the coming years to start confronting the
question seriously."

Which is why he believes that the only hope is a "strong intervention by the
international community - the US and EU". He adds: "I think that the British,
French the Germans should start thinking seriously about moving their arses and
trying to do something more than what Tony Blair is doing."

Professor Sternhell may be stretching Mr Blair's mandate as Middle East envoy by
declaring that he is "in charge of negotiations". But he is in deadly earnest
when he considers: "I personally have reached the conclusion we cannot do it on
our own, due to the weaknesses of the Israeli democracy, the weakness of the
Palestinian Authority."

Saying that the "step by step" approach of Oslo was a "total mistake", he
insists: "All the issues need to be dealt with together and everyone with an
interest in the Middle East must participate I don't see how things can move
otherwise."

Asked how he feels, as a Jew with his classic Israeli biography, to have had his
home attacked by Jews, Professor Sternhell muses that: "Everybody is able to do
anything. Being Jewish or not being Jewish does not immunize you from all the
evils that can exist in history and politics."

Just as it makes him "very, very unhappy" to see Sudanese refugees arriving in
Israel from Egypt being treated not so differently from how "Jews were treated
in Europe 70 years ago", so he is also mortified to see "Jews as occupiers of
the West Bank" - or the treatment by Israeli soldiers of Palestinians - not
because the soldiers want it but because of a "horrible" situation.

And he says: "What I want to do is to change the situation."

The thoughts of Zeev Sternhell

An Israeli scholar's verdict

*On Tony Blair

The Middle East envoy on behalf ofthe US, the EU, the UN and Russia, the
so-called Quartet.

"Tony Blair is transforming himself from a ten-year successful Prime Minister
into a ridiculous figure, a clown. He is now in charge of negotiations, so what
is he doing exactly. Where is he?"

*On Ehud Olmert

Outgoing Prime Minister of Israel (right) and a recent convert to the idea of
handing back "almost all" of the West Bank.

"He's just 30 years late. It's unbelievable. This is what [we on the left] have
been saying for 30 years."

*On Ehud Barak

Israeli Defence Minister.

"It's funny - well, not funny buttragic - to see a man like Ehud Barak, a real
war hero, someone who was scared of nothing, who didn't know what it meant to be
scared. [Yet] politically, a confrontation with the settlers is beyond his
capacity. It's very sad."

                      October 2, 2008 Thursday 7:01 PM BST

TERROR ATTACKS MEMORIAL £1BN OVER BUDGET

BYLINE: Wesley Johnson, PA, in New York

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 356 words


A permanent memorial in New York to the 67 Britons and thousands of others who
died in the September 11 terror attacks will be completed by the tenth
anniversary, owners of the World Trade Centre site said today.

But some of the trees outside the memorial may not be planted and a visitor's
centre may not be open as the redevelopment plans are one billion dollars (£560
million) over budget and behind schedule.

Joe Daniels, president of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, said
last month that it was both ``possible and essential'' for the project to be
opened by September 11, 2011, but today the owners said the underground museum
would not open until 2013.

The eagerly-awaited 70-page report by the Port Authority of New York and New
Jersey also found that completion of the signature project, a 1,776-foot Freedom
Tower now under construction, is about 200 million dollars (£112m) over budget
and will be delayed several months to 2013.

The elaborate rail hub will cost 3.2 billion dollars (£1.8bn), 700 million
dollars (£393m) more than planned, and should open in 2014.

Additional parts of the project are also over budget, bringing the final tally
to more than one billion dollars (£560m) over estimates.

In a letter to New York state governor David Paterson, the agency's executive
director Christopher Ward said: ``While we still face many challenges ahead, we
believe we have created a level of certainty and control over this project that
has been missing since its inception.''

But he added: ``I cannot promise that we will meet every single milestone every
step of the way.

``This is the most complex construction program in the region's history and
setbacks are inevitable.''

He also admitted that the new deadlines ``will be met with a degree of
scepticism.''

The agency did not set schedules for four other office towers planned for the
site or for a performing arts centre, and did not issue a final budget for the
memorial.

Mr Ward said the report reflected an understanding of the realities of building
from scratch a complex of interconnected skyscrapers, transit links and cultural
space in a hole seven stories deep.

All "terrorist attacks" suspects to be tried in shari'ah courts - Saudi minister

LENGTH: 466 words


Text of report in English by Saudi newspaper Arab News website on 3 October

[Report by P. K. Abdul Ghafour from Jedda: "Shariah Courts To Try Terror
Suspects: Naif"]

Interior Minister Prince Naif announced late Wednesday night [1 October] that
all suspected militants arrested for plotting to carry out terrorist attacks in
the Kingdom would be transferred to Shariah courts shortly to take action
against them.

"God willing, they all will be transferred to the judiciary to give its verdict
on them in accordance with what God has ordained to prevent sedition. ... We
don't punish anybody except on the basis of a court verdict," the prince said.

Addressing princes, ministers, Islamic scholars and commanders of security
forces who came to greet him at his office on the occasion of Eid Al-Fitr,
Prince Naif said investigations of the arrested suspects were progressing to
collect more information.

"By the Grace of God, we have uncovered several plots to undermine the Kingdom's
security. When time comes we'll provide more information to citizens about such
plots," the Saudi Press Agency quoted Naif as saying.

Last June, the Interior Ministry announced the arrests of 701 suspected
militants for plotting to carry out terrorist attacks. Some of the detainees,
according to Maj. Gen. Mansour Al-Turki, the ministry's spokesman, were planning
to stage terrorist attacks on oil fields and other vital installations.

"You know that Islam is targeted and your country with all its honour and pride
is an Islamic country with Qur'an and Sunnah being its constitution... and we
depend on ourselves after God the Almighty," Prince Naif told the well-wishers
Wednesday night.

Prince Naif emphasized that security agents would not put extra pressure on
suspects to win confessions. "We are capable of implementing court verdicts (on
the militants)", he added.

He praised the security forces for their efforts to foil many terrorist attacks
inside the Kingdom. "By the Grace of God, we don't need anybody except God...
During the past years we have not resorted to the help of others, except God and
our security officers," he said referring to Saudi Arabia's successful
anti-terror campaigns that won the country international applause.

Prince Naif urged all Saudis including Islamic scholars, intellectuals and media
persons to play their respective roles in protecting the country's security and
stability. "Everybody should understand that we are not only dealing with
individuals but also deviant thoughts."

Islamic scholars have a duty to explain the tolerant and peaceful teachings of
Islam. He also urged parents to keep a watch on their children. "The state is
capable of protecting their children from evil and guiding them to the right
path," he added.
