                               The Times (London)

                             October 3, 2008 Friday

'Severe' risk of terrorist attack close to 7/7 level

BYLINE:  Michael Evans Defence Editor

SECTION: HOME NEWS; Pg.27

LENGTH: 526 words


The terrorist threat to Britain from home-grown al-Qaeda-inspired radical
Muslims is almost as high as it was after the July 7 suicide bombings in London
in 2005, according to the latest security assessment.

The threat level has been graded "severe", the second-highest terrorist-alert
status, for the past 12 months. After the July 7 bombings, followed by the July
21 failed plot, the threat assessment was put at "critical", indicating a red
alert. Since then the level was raised once more to "critical", during incidents
in Glasgow and London last year, and then reduced to "severe".

A senior Whitehall source, however, admitted yesterday: "It's now at the severe
end of 'severe'." The official said that the police and MI5 were working at full
capacity to keep abreast of all suspected terrorist plots. Evidence from
intelligence operations and information gleaned from within Muslim communities
have indicated that there is an increased level of terrorist-related activity.

"There's lot of ambient activity, some of it sourced to al-Qaeda core
(leadership) in the Pakistan/Afghanistan border area," one source said.

Four special counter-terrorist "hubs" have been established in London,
Manchester, Birmingham and Leeds to increase joint police and MI5 efforts in
dealing with suspected terrorists. A fifth hub is being planned.

A key al-Qaeda figure, in the view of the British intelligence community, is
Rashid Rauf, suspected of being linked to the Heathrow bomb plot of August 2006.
Mr Rauf, a British citizen of Pakistani origin, fled from his home in Birmingham
in 2002 after his uncle was found murdered, and was arrested in Pakistan in 2006
on suspicion of involvement in the Heathrow plot. He escaped and is believed to
be in the tribal regions in Pakistan. "Rashid Rauf is key to us," the official
said.

The Whitehall source added that there was new concern over lone terrorists -
individuals who have acquired bomb-making expertise without having any obvious
affiliation either to known radical groups in this country or to al-Qaeda
masterminds in Pakistan. Detecting lone would-be bombers was a big challenge,
the official said, but he emphasised that increasingly active dialogue with
leaders of Britain's mosques might help.

MI5 has indicated that about 2,000 individuals in Britain are regarded as being
involved in terrorist-related activity, and this figure may now have risen,
according to security sources.

The Government, through the Office for Security and CounterTerrorism at the Home
Office, is drawing up a new counter-terror strategy, due to be published at the
end of the year. There will also be a set of 19 target indicators issued to
gauge progress made. Some of these targets will remain classified.

As part of the strategy, the Government is now funding organisations that run
anti-Jihad and anti-al-Qaeda websites, in an attempt to counter propaganda put
out by extremist Muslim organisations. The Department of Education is also
expected to issue guidelines for teachers in schools with a strong Muslim
presence to try to get across a more positive message about life and values in
Britain.

RAPIST COP LET LOOSE ON OUR STREETS;
EXCLUSIVE WE TRACK DOWN SEX ATTACKER AFTER HIS RELEASE SPARKS TERROR

BYLINE: By STEVE SMITH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 370 words


THIS is rapist police inspector Adam Carruthers back on the streets where he
terrorised dozens of women.

The shamed former officer is a despised outcast in the communities of Dumfries
and Galloway.

Our exclusive picture gives the first glimpse of the serial sex attacker since
he was freed from prison last month, where he served seven years for raping two
women.

We can reveal the disgraced former Dumfries and Galloway inspector has already
been banned from his local shop and ordered to keep away from lone women.

Neighbours and his shattered victims are terrified of the monster who moved back
to the former police station home he shares with wife Margaret, 44, in tiny
Penpont. She is standing by him.

Dad-of-two Carruthers, 45, has pals in the village willing to run errands,
drivehimto a police station in Dumfries to sign the sex offenders' register and
even fetch his morning paper.

One local in Penpont said last night: "People are sick to the stomach that he's
got the nerve to move back here as though nothing has happened.

"He should be treated like the outcast he is. Nobody wants him back."

We watched as Carruthers was driven away by a neighbour shortly after Margaret
left for work as a receptionist at a health centre. His secluded home is on the
outskirts of the tiny village which has a population of around 1000 people.

Carruthers was found guilty in May 2001 of raping two women while he was a
sergeant based at Langholm police station, Dumfriesshire. He was eventually
jailed for 12 years but had his sentence cut by a year on appeal.

An internal Dumfries and Galloway police investigation found 38 women who said
Carruthers had raped, attacked or harassed them during his 20-year police
career.

He will be on the sex offenders' register for life and must tell police of any
change of address and if he plans to go abroad for three days or more.

Carruthers spent most of his sentence at Peterhead Prison, which houses
Scotland's worst sex offenders, before being moved to Kilmarnock Prison shortly
before his release.

The arrogant ex-cop refused to take part in sex offender programmes in jail and
has refused to admit his guilt or show any remorse for his appalling crimes.

                             October 6, 2008 Monday

Turkish deputy chief of staff briefs press on terrorist attack

LENGTH: 2150 words


Text of report by Turkish semi-official news agency Anatolia

Ankara (AA) -General Staff Deputy Chief General Hasan Igsiz, stating that the
[PKK] terrorist organization, which is in a process of dissolution, is seeking a
way out, has said: "The way out is an action that will have resonance. They are
seeking actions that will have little risk for themselves, but will have a great
deal of resonance. They were unable to accomplish this at Aktutun."

Stressing that this struggle is a struggle between the terrorist organization
and the security forces, General Igsiz said: "None of our citizens must be
brought into this. Generalizations must not be made. Individual incidents must
be left at the individual level."

Speaking in a press briefing held in the Inonu Assembly Hall of the General
Staff Headquarters, General Igsiz provided information to the Ankara
representatives of media organizations, and to defence reporters, regarding the
attack on the Aktutun Border Outpost and the fighting that ensued afterwards.

Describing with maps and diagrams the region where the Aktutun Border Outpost is
located at the beginning of his briefing, General Igsiz also presented images
taken yesterday from Bayraktepe, where the fighting had taken place. Included in
the footage, which was also distributed to press organizations, were the
position of Aktutun Village, with its 73 families, as well as the central and
security elements of the border company.

General Igsiz, indicating that the region where Aktutun is located is one of
several important transit areas between Iraq and Hakkari, asserted that the
outpost itself blocks a very important avenue of approach to the interior
regions of Hakkari [province]. Noting that there exist 365 similar base areas
within the region of the 2d Army, General Igsiz said: "It is impossible for the
Commander of the Army to visit each of these one by one. But during the period
when I commanded the 2d Army, I went to Aktutun three times. This is an
indication of the importance we ascribe to the region."

Providing information as well on the reinforcements provided to the Aktutun
Gendarmerie Border Outpost at the beginning of the summer season, General Igsiz
noted that, based on the importance of the region, a Gendarmerie Special
Operations (JOH) Company, 2 motorized rifle columns, a mortar location radar, 2
tanks, 3 203-mm guns, 2 105-mm guns, 3 81-mm mortars, an anti-aircraft gun, and
291 personnel are assigned to the outpost.

Providing information on the fighting by illustrating with the diagrams, General
Igsiz said that the terrorists attacked from the north of Iraq and the west of
the outpost with anti-aircraft weapons, mortars, and machine guns, and opened
intense fire from Otyeritepe. Explaining that, after the locations of the
terrorists' mortar was determined with radar, this area was brought under
control with artillery fire, General Igsiz stated that the positions at
Bayraktepe, built with stones because the area is very rocky, were destroyed
during the terrorists' mortar fire. General Igsiz asserted that 13 of the 15
personnel martyred in the fighting were martyred as a result of shrapnel wounds.
General Igsiz advised that, during the incident, Cobra-type assault helicopters
were directed into the region from Hakkari, and that a terrorist group of 10 to
15 people was also hit by two F-16s.

"Not the Slightest Weakness in the Resistance"

General Hasan Igsiz, noting that reinforcements had been provided to Bayraktepe
from the mountain commando company and the JOH, said: "Something very
unfortunate took place at Bayraktepe. One of the six personnel in leadership
positions was martyred, and four others were wounded. Some problems were thus
suffered at Bayraktepe in terms of command and control. But with reinforcements
reaching Bayraktepe in the evening hours, the incident was brought under
control."

Stating that targets across the border were brought under control by the Air
Force and by artillery shelling, General Igsiz said: "Despite the loss of
leadership personnel, not the slightest weakness emerged in the resistance in
the area. Our martyrs fought heroically. We have still not been able to reach
two of our specialist non-commissioned officers. Our search efforts are
continuing. According to our assessments, our two specialists may have been
martyred. But the search operations continue without letup."

General Staff Deputy Chief Hasan Igsiz, stating that the goal of the terrorists
had been, after taking complete control of Bayraktepe, to "establish influence"
over the Aktutun company headquarters, said that the terrorist organization had
been unable to reach this goal, and that the known number of its casualties in
the fighting was 23. General Igsiz, indicating that the number of terrorists
neutralized by the Air Force and by artillery shelling was not included in this
figure, noted that "we consider that the terrorist casualties were significantly
higher than this."

"We Will Determine Where We Look"

General Igsiz answered questions afterwards.

Stating that "there is a different conception" in terms of intelligence, General
Igsiz spoke as follows:

"If you have the technical capabilities, you can keep everyplace under
monitoring. But technical capabilities do not work in this way. Our
capabilities, technically, are not at a level to take every area under control.
And there is no such technology in the world. We can monitor an area of 100 or
150 meters. This means looking at any area on the map that is no bigger than a
pencil point. But using technical capabilities properly is a matter of skill.
Our colleagues' skill is at a very high level. But if you scan the entire
region, it would take a year. The selection process is carried out with great
skill."

General Igsiz, noting that these technical capabilities are also impacted by the
weather and by terrain conditions, said: "We cannot claim that we see every bird
that flies here. No one can see them."

Explaining that they get no support in terms of intelligence from the local
administration in the north of Iraq, General Igsiz pointed out that the
terrorist organization utilizes infrastructural resources there such as roads
and hospitals. General Igsiz said: "Not harming the civilian population is one
of our fundamental principles. For the sake of this, we have avoided exploiting
even some very good opportunities that have arisen. And the organization
exploits this. Particularly in an important portion of the north of Iraq,
organization members are located in places very close to the people. And the
local administration makes no efforts to prevent this."

Responding to another question, General Igsiz said that intelligence sharing
with the United States continues, and that there has been no problem in this
regard. "But," he said, "we determine where we are going to look."

Began Early

General Hasan Igsiz, noting that imagery of a terrorist group of a few people
had been identified one night before the fighting at Bayraktepe, advised that
imagery of this sort can be obtained from time to time, that artillery was then
brought to bear, and that, in the morning, the JOH team was sent to Bayraktepe.

Relating that when the Gendarmerie unit that was dispatched established contact,
the terrorists launched their action immediately, General Igsiz indicated that
the first person hit at Bayraktepe was the soldier using a thermal camera.
General Igsiz, asserting that the beginning of the action in the middle of the
day "was not a time the terrorist organization preferred," noted that "due to
the fighting starting early taken after the reinforcing JOH team reached the
region, the organization was obliged to launch the action at that time."

Noting that it was clear that the terrorists had planned to carry the mortars to
nearby locations and use them, General Igsiz said that they had planned first to
establish influence with the mortars and then to begin an infiltration-type
activity afterwards in the dark. General Igsiz said: "They did try to
infiltrate, and they paid a heavy price for it."

General Igsiz said it is believed that the terrorists came into the region in
small groups.

"Seeking Action That Will Create Resonance"

General Hasan Igsiz spoke as follows:

"The organization is moving towards the breaking point. This is not just our
thinking. Today, a large portion of the organization members, and their
sympathizers, are also worried about this. Rifts have been appearing within the
organization. Increasing numbers are leaving it.

"The organization is seeking a way out. The way out is an action that will have
resonance. They are seeking actions that will have little risk for themselves,
but will have a great deal of resonance. They were unable to accomplish this at
Aktutun. The organization's goal was to manage this affair with minimal losses,
and after occupying the hilltop to take control over the company down below. But
they were unable to accomplish this. Despite the fact that five of the six
leadership personnel at Bayraktepe were wounded, there was not the slightest
diminution in the resistance there."

Incident in Balikesir

General Staff Deputy Chief Hasan Igsiz, in answering a question from one
journalist as to whether or not the terrorist attack was linked to the incidents
[of clashes between Turks and Kurds] in Balikesir, spoke as follows:

"I do not give it much credence. But it must be kept in mind that this struggle
is a struggle between the terrorist organization and the security forces.
Efforts are being made by certain circles for this to be turned into a struggle
between various different groups, and peoples. In the Balikesir incident, it
would be useful for all of our citizens to be very careful from this standpoint.
This struggle is a struggle between the organization and the security forces.
None of our citizens must be brought into this. Generalizations must not be
made. Individual incidents must be left at the individual level. And legally,
whoever commits a crime must pay the penalty."

Cross-Border Security Zone

General Igsiz also responded as follows to a question regarding the
establishment of a security zone along the Turkey-Iraq border:

"The establishment of a buffer zone between ourselves and the region occupied by
the organization is not as easy as it is said to be. In order to establish a
security zone, you have to assign a unit there. How big a unit will be required
to be deployed there, I wonder? Do the TSK have the luxury of being able to
assign so many units? And things do not end with putting a unit there. It
entails meeting all its needs as well... We have settled into all the important
places in our border regions where there could be crossings. Despite this,
crossings do occur, but under very difficult conditions. With the measures that
have been taken, a good many infiltrators are apprehended immediately."

General Hasan Igsiz, declaring that the Aktutun region is a very important
transit point, pointed out that the terrorist organization, when it is feeling
difficulties someplace, harasses that location; that the Aktutun region is a
place that has been harassed a great deal; and that 38 terrorist attacks, large
and small, have been made on the region since 1992. General Igsiz reported that,
since 1992, the terrorist attacks conducted against border outposts similar to
Aktutun have been 68 at Uzumlu, 30 at Alan, 127 at Uzundere, 20 at Samanli, and
371 at Eruh.

In response to a question, General Staff Deputy Chief Hasan Igsiz said that, in
the past, some border outposts had been established in low-lying locations due
to concern with smuggling, but that the need has been felt, when it has been
desired to utilize these outposts in the struggle against terrorism, for higher
points to be secured. However, said General Igsiz, "Aktutun is not included
among them. If you try to establish that outpost on the top of the hill, you
would not even be able to get supplies to it."

Actions in October

When one journalist said that "major terrorist actions take place in October,"
General Igsiz observed: "The month of October is a period in which the terrorist
organization is making its preparations for the winter. Thereafter, in the
winter, they will take refuge somewhere. Consequently, they want to conduct some
action that will make their voices heard before winter starts."

In reply to a question, General Igsiz, stating that holidays and vacation days
in border units are no different from other days, said that not even television
is allowed in base regions "so as not to disturb the concentration."

General Staff Deputy Chief General Hasan Igsiz noted that the TSK conducts
assessments of all of its activities, whether positive or negative.

The press briefing meeting in the General Staff Headquarters began at 2:00 p.m.
and lasted for approximately an hour and 45 minutes.

Source: Anatolia news agency, Ankara, in Turkish 1527 gmt 5 Oct 08

AMY PANIC ATTACK TERROR;
EXCLUSIVE X FACTOR SCOT TELLS OF HER TV ORDEAL .. AND RUNS RULE OVER 12 WHO WILL
BATTLE IT OUT FOR GLORY

BYLINE: By John Dingwall

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 1158 words


DEVASTATED teenager Amy Connelly suffered a panic attack after being told she
hadn't made the X Factor final 12.

The 19-year-old was distraught when judge Cheryl Cole broke the news that she
hadn't made it.

She collapsed in tears - then found herself struggling to breathe.

Amy said: "When Cheryl sat me down and told me I wasn't through, I was
absolutely devastated.

"I was crying when I was with her, then when I came off I cried so much I
couldn't breathe.

"I had a panic attack and I had to be calmed down."

Amy's ordeal was cut from the show because the producers deemed it too painful
for family viewing.

On Saturday night, viewers saw Amy forgetting the words of Gabriella Cilmi's
Sweet About Me as she sang in front of Cheryl in Cannes.

Amy, whose Scots mum Rosemarie died when she was six, said Cheryl later admitted
she had chosen the wrong song for her.

But the teenager doesn't blame anyone but herself. She added: "I did so badly on
the show. What you saw on X Factor was better than reality because I really
messed up and they didn't show too much of that.

"The pressure was too much. There were no acoustics because we were singing in
the open air."

Amy, who lives in Watford with her Scots dad David, added: "I'm kicking myself
that I'm not through. I let myself down."

Amy spent last week in Scotland, catching up with her family.

The Volvo customer services rep relaxed in Cadder, Dunbartonshire, yesterday
with relatives.

She said: "I'm here meeting my baby nephew Christopher.

"On Friday, I visited my sister Diane's twins Chloe and Carla who were
celebrating their second birthday."

Last night, viewers saw the four judges announce which 12 acts have made it
through to the X Factor live finals.

Here, Amy gives her opinion of the contenders - and who she thinks will win.

The 21-year old, from Essex, had roles in Snatch, The Bill and Casualty. As part

told he was too ugly. Austin also took part in Boys will be Girls E4 TV show.

and it turns out he has been on TV before. He's very down to earth And will talk

Algerian municipal guard headquarters targeted in terrorist attack - paper

LENGTH: 412 words


Text of report by H. Azzouzi headlined "Timizart (Tizi Ouzou): Attack on the
Municipal Guard headquarters", published by privately-owned Algerian newspaper
El Watan website on 5 October

During the evening this past Friday [3 October], the new headquarters of the
municipal guard of Timizart, 42 km to the east of the main town in the province
of Tizi Ouzou, was targeted by a bomb attack. The blast from the explosive
device, according to matching accounts, occurred at about 2100 hours and
seriously shook the walls of that building.

If the brigade's enclosure wall was spared by the explosion, the fact
nevertheless remains that the ground floor was completely devastated. At the
scene we found city hall workers in the process of clearing the courtyard of the
debris caused by the attack. An official from the Municipal People's Assembly
[APC] indicated to us that the building that had been targeted by the terrorist
groups was going to be put to use at the start of next year at the latest, with
the ribbon cutting of the urban security agency, whose headquarters is
completed. If the same source is to be believed, the cost of building the new
municipal guard headquarters has risen to more than 700 million centimes.

Let us note that currently it is the APC's old shacks that house the barracks of
Timizart's municipal police. Moreover, this attack was reportedly the work of
the terrorist groups that reign supreme in the region's forest. The headquarters
of the municipal guard that was attacked is located three kilometres to the
south of the municipality's main town, close to the Berber village, on an
intercity road that links the community to National Road [RN] 72. By way of a
reminder, it was there, last Monday, in broad daylight, that a group of armed
individuals threw up a bogus roadblock at which a bus driver was relieved of his
vehicle.

That vehicle was reportedly used by elements from the Salafi Group for Call and
Combat [GSPC; the group now known as Al-Qa'idah in the Lands of the Islamic
Maghreb, or AQLIM] in the suicide attack that was perpetrated last Monday on a
military post in Tagdempt, in the Dellys region. Too it would be useful to
remind readers of the abduction, 12 days ago, of a veterinarian who was abducted
by an armed group in the village of Imessounen, in the municipality of Iflissen,
this still on the northeast slope of the province of Tizi Ouzou. He was released
one week later.

                             Cambridge Evening News

                           October 8, 2008 Wednesday

Cambridge doctors in court over terror attacks

LENGTH: 640 words


PROSECUTORS believe two doctors with links to Cambridge who are accused of
mounting car bomb attacks in London and Glasgow were motivated by Islam, a court
heard today.Bilal Abdulla, 29, and Mohammed Asha, 28, are accused of terrorism
motivated by "a fundamental form of Islam", potential jurors were told.Abdullah
lived in Cambridge for a time and attended the mosque in Mawson Road while Asha
completed a two month placement at Addenbrooke's Hospital in 2005.Speaking at
Woolwich Crown Court, Mr Justice Mackay said jurors must try the men on the
facts alone and not on any prejudices, beliefs or personal opinions.He said the
men are charged with conspiring to murder and cause explosions in attacks on
London's West End and Glasgow Airport over two days last summer.Abdulla, of
Glasgow, and Asha, of Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire, deny the offences.The
judge said: "The prosecution case is that both these defendants and a third man
called Kafeel Ahmed, who died in the third of these incidents, were terrorists
motivated by their belief in a fundamental form of Islam."It is essential that
the jury that is to try them makes its decisions based solely on the evidence it
hears and it is given in this court and not based on any prejudices, beliefs or
personal opinions the members of the jury may have."Mr Justice Mackay was
addressing potential jurors before the case begins tomorrow.

It is expected to last between eight and 10 weeks.Members of the public selected
for jury service were told the two defendants worked as doctors at several NHS
hospitals.They were told Abdulla worked at the Royal Alexandra Hospital in
Paisley, outside Glasgow.Asha worked at Addenbrooke's Hospital, Cambridge;
Prince Philip Hospital, Llanelli; Royal Shrewsbury Hospital and the University
Hospital of North Staffordshire.Potential jurors were told they may not be able
to serve if they or a close relative had been treated by either of the doctors
or if they knew any of the witnesses in the case.They were also asked if they
had been the victim of a terrorist attack or worked for the police, Crown
Prosecution Service, Prison Service, Armed Forces or security services.The judge
said: "In this case the two defendants that you see in the dock are charged with
taking part in a conspiracy to murder and cause explosions with the intent of
endangering life."It is the prosecution's case that, as a result of this
conspiracy, two attempts were made in June of last year to explode car bombs in
the West End of London which, happily, were not successful."On the following day
there was an unsuccessful attempt to mount a suicide bomb attack on Glasgow
Airport."These are obviously very serious charges and both defendants deny
them."It will be the task of the jury which is now to be chosen from among your
number to decide whether these charges or any of them are proved."It is an
important task and a serious task but I also believe that those of you that are
selected will find it an interesting case to try."Iraqi-born Abdulla was
arrested after a burning Jeep was driven into the main terminal building at
Glasgow Airport on June 30 last year.Jordanian Asha, a neurologist, was arrested
on the M6 motorway in Cheshire later that day.Ahmed, 28, died 33 days later from
critical burns suffered in the airport attack. He was the driver of the
vehicle.In the early hours of June 29, two Mercedes cars containing petrol, gas
cylinders and nails were driven into London's West End.One was discovered
outside the Tiger, Tiger nightclub in Haymarket, causing hundreds of revellers
to be evacuated.The second car, parked in adjoining Cockspur Street, was towed
to a nearby car pound. It was made safe later that day.Both men are accused of
conspiring with Ahmed and others unknown to murder and cause explosions between
January 1, 2006 and July 1, 2007.

Pakistan: Suicide bomb attack on anti-terror police

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 178 words


At least nine people were injured when an explosives-laden vehicle rammed into
an anti-terrorist squad building in the Pakistani capital today.

Islamabad police official Mohammed Sadiq said: "It seems to be a suicide
attack."

The attack occurred as politicians gathered at parliament for a closed-door
security briefing.

The capital has been under tight security because of the private session, and it
was unclear how the attacker might have struck the building in the Police Lines
neighbourhood of the city.

Ambulances streamed into the smoke-filled area. The red-brick building's facade
was destroyed and a staircase collapsed. Shoes were strewn among the rubble.

Police officer Suhail Iqbal said the building housed an anti-terror squad and
that it was inside a heavily-guarded police complex.

Pakistan has experienced a wave of militant violence in recent months. Much of
it has been in the north west regions bordering Afghanistan, but the insurgents
have shown they can reach further.

On September 20, a suicide truck bombing of the Marriott Hotel killed 54 in the
city.

                                  Daily Record

                           October 9, 2008, Thursday

AIRPORT TERROR ATTACK: TWO GO ON TRIAL;
PLOT SUSPECTS IN DOCK

BYLINE: By Adrian Brodie

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 470 words


THE trial of two doctors allegedly involved in the Glasgow Airport bomb plot
will begin today.

Bilal Abdullah, 29, and Mohammad Asha, 28, are accused of conspiracy to murder
and conspiracy to cause explosions likely to endanger life.

They were allegedly involved in an Islamic extremist plot to cause car blasts in
London and mount a suicide bomb attack on Glasgow Airport in June last year.

Eighteen prospective jurors were yesterday selected at London's Woolwich Crown
Court - and 12 of them will be sworn in today at the start of the trial, which
is expected to last up to 10 weeks.

Two bombs were planted in Mercedes cars on June 29 in Cockspur Street off
London's Trafalgar Square and outside the Tiger Tiger club in nearby Haymarket -
but they failed to go off.

The following day, a Jeep Cherokee loaded with explosives was driven straight
into the terminal building of Glasgow airport and one man in the vehicle, Kafeel
Ahmed, died of burns.

Yesterday, the trial judge, Mr Justice Mackay, told potential jurors: "In this
case, the two defendants are charged with taking part in a conspiracy to murder
and cause explosions with the intent to endanger life.

"It is the prosecution's case that, as a result of this conspiracy, two attempts
were made to explode car bombs in the West End of London which happily were not
successful and, on the following day, there was an unsuccessful attempt to mount
a suicide bomb attack on Glasgow airport.

"These are very serious charges and the defendants deny them. It will be the
task of the jury to decide whether these charges are proved.

"It is an important task and a serious one but I also believe that those who are
selected will find it an interesting case to try.

"It is the prosecution's case that both of these defendants and a third, Kafeel
Ahmed, who died, were terrorists motivated by their belief in a fundamental form
of Islam.

"It is essential that the jury makes its decision solely on the evidence it
hears and sees in this court and not based on any prejudices, beliefs or
personal opinions that members of the jury may have."

The judge set the panel five questions to check their impartiality. One asked if
a relative or close friend had ever been in the vicinity of an alleged terrorist
incident.

They were told both defendants were doctors and that Abdullah worked at the
Royal Alexandra hospital in Paisley, Renfrewshire.

Jurors were also told that Asha worked at the University hospital, North
Staffordshire, and had previously worked at Addenbrooke's hospital, Cambridge
and the Prince Philip hospital in Llannelli.

They were told that Ahmed lived in Cambridge but was not a doctor and his
brother Sabeel lived in Liverpool and worked at Warrington hospital.

Abdulla and Asha deny both charges and the case continues.

'Motivated by belief in fundamental form of Islam'

                PA Regional Newswire of English Regions: LONDON

                      October 9, 2008 Thursday 3:15 PM BST

DOCTORS 'PLOTTED TO KILL HUNDREDS IN TERROR ATTACK'

SECTION: PA Regional Newswire for English Regions

LENGTH: 378 words


Two doctors plotted to kill hundreds in a wave of car bombings across Britain,
including one in London's West End, a court has been told.

Iraqi Bilal Abdulla, 28, and Jordanian Mohammed Asha, 29, were respected doctors
at hospitals in Glasgow and Staffordshire - but prosecutors said the pair were
secretly members of a small cell of Islamic terrorists.

They turned their attention from treating illnesses to planning ``indiscriminate
and wholesale'' murder, London's Woolwich Crown Court heard.

Prosecutor Jonathan Laidlaw QC said only ``good fortune'' saved people from
attacks on London's West End and Glasgow Airport. He said the men wanted people
to be ``gripped by fear'' as they were in the wake of attacks on the London
transport network in July 2005.

Mr Laidlaw said the plotters had access to extra bomb materials and at least two
more vehicles for further attacks. It was claimed they conspired with a third
man, Kafeel Ahmed, 28, who died in the suicide attack on Glasgow Airport.

The court was told the men shared the same extremist ideologies as other Islamic
terrorists who have struck in Britain and overseas and were motivated by what
they saw as the persecution of Muslims in Iraq, Palestine and Afghanistan.

Abdulla worked at the Royal Alexandra Hospital, Paisley, and Asha worked at the
University Hospital of North Staffordshire.

The court was told how Abdulla and Ahmed drove two Mercedes cars, packed with
gas cylinders, petrol and nails, from a property in Paisley to London on June 29
last year. One vehicle was left outside the busy Tiger Tiger nightclub in
Haymarket, near Piccadilly Circus, with a second vehicle at a nearby bus stop.

The court heard the second car might have been deliberately placed in the path
of those evacuated from the first blast. But the improvised bombs failed to
detonate, and the devices were made safe. The prosecution said that this led to
a ``dramatic change in tactics'' with the attack on Glasgow Airport following as
police closed in.

Abdulla, from Glasgow, was arrested after a burning Jeep was driven into the
main terminal building at Glasgow Airport on June 30 last year. Asha, a
neurologist from Newcastle-under-Lyme, was arrested on the M6 motorway in
Cheshire later that day. Both men deny all the charges. end

Court hears of woman's terror sex attack on train

SECTION: THURROCK NEWS (THURROCK NEWS)

LENGTH: 319  words


A YOUNG woman told how two teenagers took turns to sexually attack her as she
travelled home on a train.

The jury at Basildon Crown Court today listened to the video interview in which
the 17-year-old alleged victim told described how the rape place as she
travelled on a train from Southend to Grays.

She said a group of four boys also got on the train and one of them, 16-year-old
youth, recognised her and hurled insults at her, calling her a "slut" and a
"slag," before a 17-year-old youth groped her breasts and asked her to perform
oral sex on him.

The teenager said she moved carriage three times to escape from her alleged
attackers, who both pestered her for oral sex, and at one point the youngest
defendant slapped her across the f ace several times and told her: "Go and kill
yourself. You are worth nothing. I will give you a knife to slit your throat."

She said she was so afraid she decided to briefly give in to their demands
because she thought it was the only way they would leave her alone.

She said: "I was getting really paranoid and nervous in case they were going to
do anything worse."

The alleged victim said the 16-year-old boy, who pulled his trousers and
underwear down, forced her to perform oral sex on him.

His alleged accomplice, who also bit her breast, took his turn before the
youngest youth raped her a second time.

Her alleged ordeal was not yet over as she told how a third youth passed the
16-year-old defendant a fire extinguisher and he "drenched" her with it before
throwing it at her.

And she claims when he saw police on the platform as the train pulled into Grays
station, he warned her: "If you grass me up I know where you live. I will come
and get you."

The defendants, who both live in Grays, deny raping and sexually touching the
young woman without consent on November 4 last year.

The alleged victim and the defendants cannot be named for legal reasons.

The trial continues.

ZAC ATTACK;
High School hunk's crowd terror

BYLINE: by TOM SAVAGE

SECTION: NEWS; 11

LENGTH: 278 words


HIGH School Musical hunk Zac Efron was left badly shaken after a fan lunged at
him in the street.

The incident happened as he strolled in London with his girlfriend Vanessa
Hudgens.

A bespectacled man tried to grab Zac, 20. But he was quickly pounced on by
security guards and hauled away.

A witness said: "It was pretty scary. No-one knew who this guy was or what he
might do. You hear of all sorts of attacks on stars.

"Zac was just walking past when he started ranting at him, then lunged forward
pointing at him and tried to grab his hair. It was bizarre.

"Zac looked pretty startled and shaken. Fortunately his bodyguards were there,
or God knows what might have happened." The incident happened as Zac and
Vanessa, 19, left the Apollo theatre in Shaftesbury Avenue, where they had been
to see Josh Hartnett, 30, in the stage version ofRainman. The couple are in
London for the premiere of the third HSM film, in which Zac plays singing
basketball star Troy and Vanessa appears as his love interest, Gabriella.

They were later spotted eating at Floridita restaurant with costars including
Ashley Tisdale, 23, and Corbin Bleu, 19.

An onlooker said: "Zac was quite relaxed and he looked like he was enjoying
himself.

"Some of them were dancing to salsa music, so they must have put the scuffle out
of their minds."

A source close to the star said last night: "He's OK.

He wasn't in danger, but he is glad his people were around to step in.

"He won't let it tarnish his view of London. He's really enjoyed himself here
this week." Yesterday we told how Zac was breaking the hearts of fans across the
world by making this third film in the series' entitled Senior Year, his last.

                               Grimsby Telegraph

                            October 10, 2008 Friday

Men leave trail of terror after shocking East Marsh attacks

BYLINE:  jenna thompson

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 408 words


Help get these people off our streets.

That is the plea from police and ward councillors after two men left a trail of
terror on Grimsby's East Marsh.

In a shocking series of incidents, the men attacked four people over a two-hour
period - leaving one with a punctured lung and head injuries.

Today, detectives investigating the incident have launched an urgent appeal for
witnesses to help solve the crime.

The men went on their violent rampage last Thursday, although details were only
released yesterday.

First, at around 6pm, they attacked a man who was walking his dog along Werneth
Road, knocking him to the ground before repeatedly kicking and punching him.

After he managed to drag himself up, they continued the assault, knocking him to
the floor again.

At this point, the driver of a black car which was passing went to get out, but
his door was kicked by one of the attackers and he drove away. Police are
particularly keen to speak to this witness.

The men then continued to attack the man while he laid on the floor before
leaving with his Norwegian Elk Hound, which was later recovered.

He was left suffering from a punctured lung and required numerous stitches to
his head.

A short time later, the men - who were reported to have a large amount of blood
on their clothes -  approached a 20-year-old woman and a 31-year-old man on
Victor Street and began to assault them.

The woman fled into the nearby home of a relative, but was followed by the men
who forced their way in and attacked her.

At around 7.30pm, one of the attackers - now shirtless - approached a car that
was travelling on Oxford Street. When the driver got out, there was an
altercation between them before the second man joined in the attack on the
driver.

Detective Chief Inspector Lauren Poultney said : "This was a very serious set of
incidents which seem to have involved the same two men and these aren't the sort
of people we want running around our streets.

"It is vital that anyone who may have witnessed any of the three incidents or
may be able to assist detectives in identifying the men responsible make contact
with police as any information, no matter how small it may seem, could be the
key to the investigation."

Two men, aged 20 and 21, have been arrested and released on bail pending further
inquiries.

Contact police on 0845 6060222, quoting log 482 for the Werneth Road incident,
484 for Victor Street, and 539 for Oxford Street, or Crimestoppers on 0800
555111.

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                            October 10, 2008 Friday

National: Doctors accused of car bomb terror attacks planned indiscriminate and
wholesale murder, court told: Pair deny plot over attacks in London and Glasgow:
More 'spectaculars' were planned, jury hears

BYLINE: Matthew Taylor

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 800 words


Two doctors who launched car bomb attacks on London and Glasgow were planning a
terrorist campaign designed to bring "indiscriminate and wholesale" murder to
the UK, a court heard yesterday

Bilal Abdulla, 29, and Mohammed Asha, 27, are accused of plotting to detonate
two cars packed with nails and explosives near a busy nightclub in central
London in June last year and, a day later, launching a suicide attack at Glasgow
airport.

Yesterday a jury at Woolwich crown court heard the pair, who deny conspiracy to
murder, had been planning further "spectaculars" and had bought at least two
more cars and a stockpile of explosives and bomb-making equipment.

"These men were intent on committing murder on an indiscriminate and a wholesale
level," said Jonathan Laidlaw QC, prosecuting. "Those bombs were to have been
the first in a series of similar attacks to be launched elsewhere in the UK."

The court heard the men only decided to launch a suicide attack at Glasgow
airport after the first wave of bombs failed to go off in central London. "The
cars had not been destroyed so the clues as to their identity were there to be
discovered and they knew that the police and intelligence services would be
quickly after them," said Laidlaw.

The jury was told that Abdulla, from Iraq, and Asha, from Jordan, were members
of a small Islamic terrorist cell and had hoped their campaign would leave the
public "gripped by fear".

Laidlaw said the pair - along with a third man, Kafeel Ahmed, who died from
injuries he received in the attack on Glasgow airport - had been planning the
campaign for six months. He said they had been on a reconnaissance trip to
London in May last year when they spent time in the City of London and around
the Old Bailey as well as in the West End.

Police had known nothing of the defendants' plans until the failed bombings,
Laidlaw said. One of the most "extraordinary things" about the case was that
Asha and Abdulla were doctors.

"Who would have suspected two doctors to have been involved in such planning?
Having studied at universities in their homelands they sought and obtained work
in British hospitals to complete their medical training.

"While here they turned their attention away from the treating of illness to the
planning of murder."

Laidlaw told the jury the men had planned the attacks as a "punishment brought
to bear on the British people for what (they) see as our country's part in the
persecution of the Muslim community all over the world but particularly
Palestine and, of course, Iraq and Afghanistan".

The court heard that in the first attack, in the early hours of June 29 last
year, Abdulla parked a green Mercedes car packed with gas canisters, petrol and
nails outside the Tiger Tiger nightclub in Haymarket in London's West End.

The second car, a blue Mercedes, was parked near a busy bus stop in nearby
Cockspur Street. The prosecution said it could have been positioned to catch
those fleeing the first explosion.

However, despite repeated attempts both cars failed to explode as there was not
enough oxygen for the petrol and gas to ignite.

The court heard that there were more than 500 customers in the club at the time
and Laidlaw said it was "no more than good fortune that nobody died". He added:
"Had it been executed in the way intended it would have resulted in the loss of
many lives particularly among the young seeking entertainment in the area or on
their way home after a night out."

The next day, Saturday June 30, the busiest day of the year at Glasgow airport,
the court heard Ahmed drove a Jeep packed with gas canisters into the doors of
the terminal building.

Abdulla was in the passenger seat and the court heard both men threw down petrol
bombs in an effort to ensure the vehicle exploded.

"Again fortune intervened to save those inside the terminal," said Laidlaw. "The
Jeep became trapped in the terminal doors and despite the best efforts of the
bombers, and although there was a fierce fire, the jeep did not explode."

Abdullah, who at the time worked as a diabetes specialist at the Royal Alexandra
hospital in Paisley, was arrested after the failed attack at Glasgow airport.
The court heard there was a "formidable body of evidence" against him.

Laidlaw said his proposed defence, that although he planned to carry out a
bombing campaign he did not intend to kill or injury anybody, was "ludicrous".

Asha, a neurologist who had been employed at Addenbrookes hospital in Cambridge,
was arrested on the M6 motorway later the same day.

Laidlaw said that although Asha's role was "less obvious and visible", he had
provided spiritual and financial support to the plan and had been in regular
contact with the bombers.

Abdulla and Asha deny conspiracy to murder and conspiracy to cause explosions
likely to endanger life. The trial continues.

                          Huddersfield Daily Examiner

                            October 10, 2008 Friday
                                  1ST Edition

Doctors 'plotted terrorist bomb attacks'

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 267 words


TWO foreign doctors planned car bomb attacks across Britain, a court heard.

Iraqi Bilal Abdulla, 28, and Jordanian Mohammed Asha, 29, travelled to Britain
to further their careers in medicine at university and NHS hospitals.

But prosecutors said the pair were secretly members of an Islamic terrorist cell
who wanted to plunge the nation back into the terror of July 2005.

Woolwich Crown Court was told the men turned their attention from treating
illnesses to planning a series of devastating car bombs.

They used their intelligence and academic knowledge to conceal their tracks as
they spent six months buying vehicles, renting a property and preparing the
bombs, the court heard.

Prosecutor Jonathan Laidlaw QC said the men had access to extra bombmaterials,
including mobile phone detonators, and at least two more vehicles for further
attacks.

He said only "good fortune" saved hundreds of late-night revellers when two
Mercedes cars packed full of fuel, gas canisters and nails were left in
London'sWest End on June 29 last year.

The cars failed to detonate leaving Abdulla and a third conspirator, Kafeel
Ahmed, 28, on the run.

The next day the two men drove a four-wheel drive, also prepared as an
improvised bomb, into the main terminal building at Glasgow Airport on its
busiest day of the year.

Explosives failed to detonate, leaving Ahmed with fatal burns. Abdulla was
arrested.

Mr Laidlaw said: "No warnings were to be given and the cars were to be
positioned in busy urban areas.

"In short, these men were intent on committing murder on an indiscriminate and a
wholesale scale."

                           October 11, 2008 Saturday

Pakistan Foreign Office spokesman says US missile attacks "helping" terrorists

LENGTH: 879 words


Text of report by staff correspondent headlined "US missile strikes helping
terrorists: FO" published by Pakistani newspaper The News website on 11 October

Islamabad: US missile attacks on suspected militants in Pakistan are
destabilising the country and "helping the terrorists", the Foreign Office said
Friday. "We want them (the United States) to realise that these attacks are
destabilising the situation, and they are not helping them or Pakistan," Foreign
Office Spokesman Mohammed Sadiq told this agency. "They are helping the
terrorists."

APP adds: Meanwhile, commenting on reports at the weekly press briefing here
Friday that India was violating the Indus Basin Water Treaty by curtailing the
flow of water in Chenab River the spokesman said, "We are seriously concerned
over significant reduction in flow of water in Chenab River."

He said it has caused extensive damage to Pakistan's agriculture and the Indian
action is a clear violation of Indus Waters Treaty. Pakistan was prompt to take
cognizance of the issue both at the Indus Water Commission level and diplomatic
level.

He said the reduction in flow was protested by Pakistan commissioner with his
Indian counterpart through various letters and telephone calls. He said the
Ministry of Foreign Affairs has also conveyed Pakistan's concern to the Indian
government through a note verbal on September 5 with the request to restore full
supply to Pakistan.

The spokesman said the matter was also raised by the foreign secretary with the
Indian high commissioner in Islamabad on September 4 and by the Pakistan high
commissioner with the Indian foreign secretary in New Delhi on September 12. He
said the Indian deputy high commissioner in Islamabad was called in on September
13 to convey Pakistan's concerns and request the Government of India for
immediate remedial action.

The spokesman said in response to Pakistan's demarches, the Indian commissioner
for Indus Water Commission has invited Indus Water Commissioner to inspect the
Baglihar Dam. The visit is expected to take place from October 18.

"We were assured that Indian government will take steps necessary to rectify the
situation. Our efforts, however, will continue and intensify till the issue is
resolved," he added. The spokesman said Pakistan desires mutually beneficial and
harmonious cooperative relationship with India.

"We are committed to a serious, sustained and constructive engagement with India
and early and full normalisation of relations on the basis of mutual respect,
peaceful coexistence and non-interference," said the spokesman.

Replying to a question, the spokesman said, he had no knowledge about the
progress on back channel diplomacy on Pak-India relations as the Foreign Office
always involved in front channel diplomacy.

"Pakistan is committed to expanding bilateral trade with India and we are also
ready for liberalisation of visa regime," he added. The spokesman said Pakistan
supports the right of the Kashmiri people to determine their destiny.

"We are committed to promoting intra-Kashmir interactions including cross-LoC
trade," he said. The spokesman said Pakistan would also like to make early
progress in resolving Sir Creek and Siachen disputes.

Replying to a question about civilian trekking expedition to Siachen by India,
the spokesman said Siachen glacier, occupied by India in 1984 in violation of
the bilateral agreements, is on the agenda of the Composite Dialogue between
Pakistan and India. He said its final status is yet to be determined, as agreed
upon by the parties.

Pakistan has taken up the matter with India expressing concern over the weeklong
trekking expedition, he added. The spokesman said Pakistan had also conveyed its
objection to the organizing of a similar trekking expedition last year.

He said Pakistan also called upon the Indian side to desist from acts that cast
shadow on the peace process between Pakistan and India. Regarding Dr Aafia
Siddiqui, the spokesman said she would be released very soon as the Pakistan
Government has been making sincere efforts in this regard.

He said a Senate delegation led by Senator Mushahid Hussain Sayed, Chairman of
the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, was currently visiting US and had met Dr
Aafia. However, the US authorities have expressed inability to arrange the visit
of the delegation to Guantanamo Bay. He said at present there are five Pakistani
prisoners in Guantanamo Bay. Pakistan has secured the repatriation of 68
Pakistani detainees from Guantanamo Bay since 2003.

The Government is in regular contact with the Office of War Crimes Issue, US
Department of State, regarding Pakistani detainees. The issue of fair treatment
and repatriation of Pakistani detainees is raised at all levels including in
leadership meetings with the US President.

"We are committed to seek repatriation of all Pakistani detainees." he added.
The FO also again clarified that all three sound bites were wrongly attributed
to President Asif Ali Zardari in the paraphrased interview published by the Wall
Street Journal. To a question, the spokesman said President Zardari never said
that Pakistan has given permission to any country to take action inside its
territory in the name of war against terror.

Source: The News website, Islamabad, in English 11 Oct 08

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 12, 2008 Sunday

Pakistan people living in fear as frequency of terror attacks increase - paper

LENGTH: 511 words


Text of report by staff correspondent headlined "Citizens fear for lives as
bombings become routine" published by Pakistani newspaper Daily Times website on
11 October

Lahore: Citizens have been overtaken by the fear of losing their lives or their
loved ones in case of a terrorist attack, as a wave of seemingly never-ending
bomb blasts has struck the country. Meanwhile, the terrorists have diversified
their targets from chains of five-star hotels to small juice shops to establish
their own writ against the government, lawyers and civil society members told
Daily Times on Friday.

Usman Ibrahim, a resident of Gulberg, said that the youth were the ones most
greatly affected by the ongoing wave of terror in the country. He said that the
situation had depressed him as the terrorists were continuing their fruitless
attempts to control the country.

He said that recent blasts at juice shops and the threats received by traders at
Hall Road had revealed that the extremists had developed their roots in the
country, adding that the issue needed to be resolved through discussions and
negotiations instead of using force.

Civil society: Civil society representatives and human rights activists
condemned the bomb hoaxes, strongly criticising the government for not being
able to determine the origin of such hoaxes.

They said that intelligence agencies should take note of such bomb hoaxes and
should try to determine if this was part of some organised crime. They said that
such hoaxes could be disastrous as they disrupted the security set-up.

Human Rights Commission of Pakistan (HRCP) Vice-Chairwoman Hina Jilani said that
people who spread hoaxes should be found and punished. She said that security
forces should locate those who were behind such rumours, as they aimed to spread
panic. She said that terrorism was not jihad, and was just another crime.

Lawyers: Legal experts have termed bomb hoaxes as the inability of the
government to maintain security.

Supreme Court Bar Association Secretary Amin Javed Chaudhry said that after
every bomb blast, the government announced that security was on high alert.
However, he added, even when the security was on high alert, bomb blasts were
taking place. He said that this reflected on the inefficiency of the security
agencies.

Police claim: City Police have a very different idea of the people's attitude.
Various senior officials of police claimed that the citizens were not helping
the police, but were adding to the problems. They claimed that police emergency
number 15 was receiving about 12,000 to 13,000 prank calls every day, of which
only 150 were related to actual criminal activities.

They said that the need of the hour was responsible behaviour from the citizens.
They said that only 400,000 police officials were present within the country.
However, they pointed out that if the public co-operated with the police, this
number was not at all insufficient, and hence, public co-operation could provide
a significant advantage in combating terrorism.

Source: Daily Times website, Lahore, in English 11 Oct 08

                             The Observer (London)

                                October 12, 2008

OMM: Reviews the top ten: 1 A post-7/7 love letter to the capital: NITIN SAWHNEY
London Undersound (Cooking Vinyl) £ 11.99 4/5: The first significant response in
pop to the terror attacks on London? Caspar Llewellyn Smith is a believer

BYLINE: Caspar Llewellyn Smith

SECTION: OBSERVER MUSIC MAGAZINE; Pg. 57

LENGTH: 657 words


Did the London bombings of 7/7 register any kind of cultural fallout, or were
the explosions swallowed up by the cacophony that is pop today? This is often
the sort of question that can attend to listening to a new Nitin Sawhney album -
and before anyone can mutter ' surely Bloc Party must have recorded something
along those lines', let's be quite clear: 'Days of Fire', the first track on
London Undersound , is certainly the most thoughtful and affecting response to
the horrors of that day yet committed to CD.

It sees the young MC Natty, one of several guest vocalists here, giving an
account of his experiences of the attacks and also of that day two weeks later
which saw the shooting of Jean Charles de Menezes (Natty was on the next tube
due into Stockwell station). Rather than agit-prop, the approach is personal;
set against Sawhney's acoustic guitar is the refrain 'it all went slow motion. .
. now we're all in slow motion', and as well as freezing the action and pain,
the blurring of confusion is felt, too.

London Undersound as a whole is intended as a response to 7/7 - for Sawhney it's
a 'collection of thoughts, ideas, feelings and catharsis in a city of immense
diversity, imagination and beliefs'. The rest of the record is nothing like as
explicit - several tracks don't feature vocals - but there is a political point
being made in the range of collaborators present: the Spanish outfit Ojos de
Brujo, sitarist Anoushka Shankar, Qui Zenghui, a moon lute player, and singers
of varying fame including Tina Grace, Imogen Heap, Rheena Bhardwaj and - giving
it less two thumbs aloft and more an impression of his thoughts on civil
surveillance - Paul McCartney.

Sawhney himself has always been adept in several genres - as a child he studied
piano, classical and flamenco guitar, sitar and tabla, and you can hear the
equally formative influence of Massive Attack on the track 'Last Train to
Midnight' and of drum'n'bass elsewhere. It's a good time for the multifaceted
musician who continues to mix up writing film scores (for the 1929 silent
classic A Throw of Dice , for instance) with club DJing duties. Last month,
presumably sharing track side with a gaggle of pneumatic pit girls, he carried
out two 'Sound System performances' at the Formula 1 night race in Singapore.
Later this month, he plays one of the BBC's Electric Proms at the Roundhouse.
Quietly, this restless figure has become established as one of our most
interesting and significant artists, but if that makes him sound terribly
po-faced, he's not. (And his CV does include the role he had, with Sanjeev
Bhaskar, in conceiving the TV show Goodness Gracious Me.

None the less, no one could pretend that this eighth album is a barrel of
laughs. It comes packaged with a series of drawings conceived to complement each
track by the artist Antony Gormley and these reflect the sombre tone. The
McCartney track does serve up optimism - 'When all the world is asleep, we could
set ourselves free,' he sings - but even then there's the dark shadow of the
question: 'How could they steel all these feelings?' Once you've got past the
distraction of it actually being McCartney at the mic, you realise that he
delivers a terrific vocal, but it's the weakest piece of songwriting on the
album. Better the closing instrumental pieces 'Firmament' and 'Charu Keshi
Rain', which address the ostensible subject matter of the record through the
deft subtleties of the playing.

'London has become polarised in a way that I find uncomfortable and
threatening,' Sawhney has also said. Compared to other recent albums that
address the capital, such as the Bug's London Zoo and even Dusk + Blackdown's
Margins Music , this is a record that goes about its business quietly. The
chatter of modern culture might make such a response to 7/7 unfashionable, but
such a thoughtful voice, and so deeply felt a record, shouldn't go unheeded.

DOWNLOAD 'Days of Fire'; 'My Soul'; 'Shadowland'

                             Black Country Edition

Sex attack terror for mum in car;
Pervert strikes as woman waits with child

BYLINE: Dale Williams

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 292 words


A TERRIFYING bare-chested thug is being hunted by police after a sex attack in
which he attempted to force himself on a young mum in the Black Country as she
sat in a car with her child.

Police have released the CCTV image of a man they would like to speak to in
connection with the sexual assault in Rowley Regis.

A West Midlands Police spokesman said today: "A 22-year-old woman was sat in a
car, along with her mother and a young child, on the car park of the Knight's
Quest pub on High Street. An unknown man approached her vehicle on foot, let
himself into the car and then attempted to engage both women in conversation.

The man has then grabbed the 22-year-old and forcibly kissed her against her
will before leaving the car." The offender is described as white, aged in his
30s, of medium build, around 5ft 8in tall, with shaved blonde hair that is
balding in places.

He wore two chains around his neck, blue jeans and he was bare chested. He also
has three tattoos on his right arm.

The woman was uninjured but was left very shaken by the incident which happened
at around 3.45pm on Thursday, August 21. Police have released the CCTV still of
the man after inquiries to catch him drew a blank.

Det Con Matthew Clarke, who is investigating the case, said: "This was an
unsavoury incident where a mother, daughter and a young child are sitting in a
car, going about their business when a man has come along and caused them to
fear for their safety. The incident caused the young woman a great deal of
distress and we are keen to trace the man responsible.

"We urge people who may recognise the man pictured to get in touch."

Anyone with information to assist with the inquiry should contact CID at
Smethwick police station on 0845 113 5000.

                                Cornish Guardian

                           October 15, 2008 Wednesday

Naval reservist Scott helps guard ship against terrorist attack

SECTION: Pg. 9

LENGTH: 185 words


On watch against potential terrorist attack in the northern Arabian Gulf is Able
Seaman Scott Healy, (right), a Bude builder by trade and currently deployed in
the Middle East as a naval reservist.

A member of HMS Vivid Royal Naval Reserve unit in Plymouth, Scott is based   on
the RFA Cardigan Bay,   a key sea base for   coalition naval forces protecting
Iraqi oil terminals against Al-Qaeda -  which has already made one suicide boat
attack on them.

The reservist is part of a protection team that patrols the upper decks of the
Cardigan Bay in sweltering temperatures, guns at the ready to repel attackers.

"We are on call 24 hours a day," explained Scott. "During night patrols we wear
night-vision goggles to keep an eye on what is going on around us."

To handle the extreme heat  and the punishing schedule of watches, Scott keeps
himself fit and rested up whenever he can.

He said: "If you are not out patrolling the ship's upper deck you are in the
onboard gymnasium or in your bunk."

A seven-year veteran of service in the Naval reserve, Scott was   called-up in
April and will return home to Cornwall soon.

of parliament to induct additional troops into the tribal areas. The terrorists
may use car bombs to attack the US embassy, the presidency or the Zardari House
in F-8/2," the report submitted to the concerned quarters of the interior

marked buildings. Sources said the terrorist outfits were waiting for a decision
about the operation in the tribal areas being made by the parliamentarians in
the ongoing joint session of parliament.

extremist outfits," reports said. Meanwhile, sources believe the terrorists
would adopt a new strategy to break into the security rings, adding, suicide
bombers could use fake Army vehicle, a police van, an ambulance or flagged cars
while the suicide bombers could disguise as Army personnel or policemen and
could be uniformed, adding the Army and police vehicles as well as ambulances
should be checked and scanned properly at sensitive pickets.

A countrywide wave of suicide bombings could occur simultaneously in major
cities of the country, targeting military installations, foreign missions, FIA
buildings and offices of the law-enforcement agencies, the sources apprehended.

The agencies have made a counter strategy after putting law-enforcement agencies
on high alert. Sensitive areas, including Cantonments, Army, Naval and Air Force
installations as well as offices of police chiefs, the Anti-Narcotics Force
(ANF) and the FIA have been put in the list of 'highly sensitive areas' and
extraordinary security measures have been adopted.

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                           October 16, 2008 Thursday

Misfit who was groomed to be a bomber;
Muslim convert admits terror attack on family restaurant

BYLINE: Duncan Gardham Security Correspondent

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 443  words


AL-QAEDA extremists brainwashed an autistic Muslim convert into launching a
failed suicide nail bomb attack in a family restaurant.

Nicky Reilly, 22, tried to detonate a series of nail bombs, mixed in soft drink
bottles with caustic soda, paraffin and aluminium foil, in the Giraffe
restaurant at Exeter's Princesshay shopping centre in May this year.

But when he attempted to assemble one of the bombs in the lavatory cubicle of
the restaurant it exploded in his hands. Yesterday he pleaded guilty at the Old
Bailey to attempted murder and preparing an act of terrorism.

Police sources said that Reilly was groomed by two men on the YouTube website
who claimed to be living on the Afghan-Pakistan border and to be in touch with
al-Qaeda. The men are still at large.

"We believe these men were living abroad but we are still investigating whether
they were who they claimed to be,'' the source said.

The men discussed with Reilly, who called himself Mohammad Abdulaziz Rashid
Saeed Alim, whether to attack police officers and civil servants or the general
public, in the end persuading him it should be an attack on the public.

They also coached him to write a suicide note. Reilly left the typed note at the
flat he shared with his mother.

It referred to "Sheikh Osama'' and said: "We love death as you love life.''

His mother, Kim, said: "He is a vulnerable person who's been radicalised and
that is like an easy target, easy prey for them.

''Someone has brainwashed him - he has done the work and they are walking
free.''

Investigations are also continuing into radicals in this country who may have
played a part in encouraging Reilly, who has a low IQ and suffers from
Asperger's syndrome, to become a suicide bomber.

Reilly visited dozens of websites and learned how to make bombs from videos he
had downloaded on YouTube, where he used the log-in Chechen233 and gave his name
as Rashid. He had watched 4,262 videos since joining in November 2006 and his
favourites included dozens of videos about the September 11 attacks and ambushes
on Allied forces in Iraq.

The source added: "He suffers from a form of autism which means he is
essentially a highly suggestible simpleton and it is difficult for him to
comprehend the end result of his actions.

"His access to the internet means he came across bomb-making instructions but it
could easily have been a chess club - he has had ideas put in his head.''
Reilly, known to friends as the Big Friendly Giant, after the Roald Dahl
character, converted to Islam in 2002 at the age of 16 but did not begin
researching bomb-making until the beginning of this year.

He will be sentenced next month after psychiatric reports.

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                           October 16, 2008 Thursday

Bomb victim's 2012 dream;
Terror attack saw Daniel Biddle lose his legs _ but not his fighting spirit

BYLINE: Gareth A Davies

SECTION: SPORT; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 656  words


IT WAS the morning of July 7 2005, only hours after London had won the right to
host the Olympic and Paralympic Games in 2012, and the euphoria was subsiding.
Daniel Biddle woke late, with a headache, at his east London home, and headed in
to work.

He missed trains, his breakfast, and through a curious series of incidents,
broke the routine of his regular journey to work as a project manager for a
construction company.

His misfortune was to find himself sitting on the Tube train, next to the
suicide bomber who blew himself up along with seven other people at Edgware Road
station at 9.17am. In total, 52 commuters lost their lives in the rush-hour
attack and

over 700 were injured.

Biddle, now 29, lost both legs, his left eye and later, in hospital, his spleen
as his powerful body absorbed the blast and was blown out through the Tube
carriage and into the tunnel wall.

Yesterday, if catharsis is possible from such a horrific moment, the horrendous
injuries which followed, and what must be painfully difficult memories, his life
came full circle when he tried out at a Paralympic Talent Day at Mile End
Stadium with 70 other hopefuls all aiming to be fast-tracked into the Great
Britain team for 2012.

It is hard to keep a dry eye as Biddle relates, emotionless, his story of
travelling to a meeting in Wembley that morning from east London.

"I was late leaving home, my bus was delayed at Liverpool Street. I let the
first tube go because it was packed. I was texting a colleague when I got on the
next train, and I've got big fingers and I'm useless at texting, and looked up
and realised I had missed my usual station. As we pulled into Edgware Road, I
looked around me. A youngish-looking Asian guy was sitting on a seat next to me.
Then bang - I couldn't work out why I was outside the train.

"As the dust settled, there were body parts all around me. I knew then it was a
bomb. A flap of skin on my head was hanging down over my face, my arms were on
fire. I tried to move the train door off my legs, but I realised they had gone.

"If there is a hell, then that was it. I was absolutely terrified - it wasn't
the dying, it was dying alone. I didn't want my girlfriend Lisa, now my wife,
and my family to have to identify me in that state. Three men got me out, saved
my life, and we are still friends.''

He was in a coma for six weeks, in hospital for 51 weeks. "A year was a
benchmark for me. I wanted to get out of there before a year. It was a turning
point.''

Biddle was 6ft 4in tall, a semi-professional footballer who played in goal for
Hatfield Peverel in the Essex Premier League, before the terrorist bomb blew off
his legs.

He is still a big man, with powerful upper-body strength. Biddle tried out
yesterday in the Paralympic sports of shot putt, power lifting, and in archery,
which, as he is right-handed and still has the vision of his right eye, is still
potentially a sport he could excel at. The sports centre is a stone's throw from
the Olympic Park.

"You know, I watched the Paralympic Games from Beijing, on TV every night in
September, and thought about competing in 2012. My manor, east London. I don't
think I will ever accept what possessed that person to do that thing, but I have
accepted who I am now.

"You've got to focus on what you can do, not what you can't do. You get to a
point where you get your life back, and this is now what my life is.

"I've finished my exams, I've gone back to work, I drive, I go to the gym, I use
a sports chair. I'm the same person, still a loud-mouthed cockney,'' he joked.

Then he got serious. "I just hope the selectors for the Paralympic Games saw
something in me today, and I hope I'm good enough to get into the team.''

Daniel Biddle Paralympic gold medallist, perhaps?

"Oh, I do like the sound of that,'' he replied. When the celebration parade
travels through London today, we might just say a silent prayer for the events
of the anniversary, one day later.

                           Express and Echo (Exeter)

                           October 16, 2008 Thursday

Terror attack timeline

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 971 words


Thursday, may 22

12.50pm: Police and ambulance services receive calls from members of the public
reporting that a man, later named as Nicky Reilly, 22, of King Street, Plymouth,
has been injured in an explosion at Giraffe restaurant in Princesshay.

1pm: A 100m cordon is established and police begin a full evacuation of the
area.

1.40pm: Police confirm it is believed an explosion has occurred.

2pm: Nicky Reilly is taken to the RD&E Hospital.

2.20pm: Bomb disposal officers arrive at the scene with sniffer dogs.

3pm: The city centre, including Princesshay, most of High Street and Paris
Street and part of Sidwell Street, is deserted. The Guildhall Shopping Centre
has also been evacuated.

3.25pm: Police confirm that a man is in custody following the explosion.

4.15pm: Bomb disposal experts prepare to enter the Giraffe restaurant.

Police reveal they have been called to three other reports of suspicious devices
in the city centre but all are false alarms.

5.15pm: Forensic officers begin to examine the Giraffe restaurant after bomb
disposal experts declare the scene safe.

6.50pm: Police reveal two devices have been found, one of which had exploded and
another that was made safe.

7pm: A phased lifting of the cordons begins and workers return to shops and
offices within the exclusion zone. Motorists are also able to retrieve their
vehicles from  car parks in Princesshay and Southernhay.

Under the protocol of a gold standard major incident, a central control room is
set up to co-ordinate the response of all emergency services. Around 10 officers
from the Metropolitan Police counter- terrorism team are drafted in to Exeter to
help with the investigation.

High-visibility patrols and sniffer dogs are also deployed at London Paddington,
checking passengers as they come off trains from Exeter.

FRIDAY, MAY 23

The city centre is back to normal, although Exeter  businesses are reckoned to
have lost at least £1.5m.

Armed police seize two more men  in Plymouth.

Over the weekend, Exeter's  Princesshay and other streets are once again
brimming with people, especially on Saturday with many keen to watch the victory
parade by Exeter City and a reunion march by the Devon and Dorset Regiment
Association.

MONDAY, MAY 26

Reilly is described as being in a serious but stable condition at the Royal
Devon & Exeter Hospital. It is understood that the 6ft 1in tall, 18st Reilly had
an operation, believed to have involved skin grafts. In the afternoon, he is
discharged from hospital and held in custody, to be formally questioned by
police.

New information emerges, as police say the device was made from sodium hydroxide
and paraffin and packed with nails and was designed to detonate when shaken.

TUESDAY, MAY 27

Reilly is questioned  at a secret location by a team of officers keen to unearth
possible links between him and Islamic radicals. The Muslim convert was
questioned in sessions lasting up to 90 minutes and could be held for up to 28
days under the Terrorism Act. Police say Reilly, who suffers from learning
difficulties, was allowed breaks as and when he needed them.

It emerges that Reilly travelled from Plymouth to Exeter with more than 50
people on a bus on the morning of the blast.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 28

A third man is arrested in Plymouth in connection with the explosion.

THURSDAY, MAY 29

Two men arrested over the  bombing appear at Central Devon Magistrates' Court.
But the three-hour city  court session was held behind closed doors. It is
believed police are  seeking  a seven-day extension to question the pair, one
believed to be  Reilly.

Searches of addresses, including the Muslim Community Centre in Plymouth, also
take place.

MONDAY, JUNE 2

Reilly, and two other men arrested in Plymouth, remain in custody. A fourth man
is also helping police with their inquiries.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 4

Reilly appears before   City of Westminster magistrates  in London, under the
name Mohammad Rashid Saeed Alim. Judge Timothy Workman remands him in custody to
appear at the Old Bailey on June 20. No application for bail is made.

Reilly was brought from Devon, where he has been questioned for nine days after
his release from hospital.

Devon and Cornwall police have charged Reilly with three offences on Tuesday,
including one of engaging in conduct in preparation for committing acts of
terrorism.

Court documents reveal he is accused of researching how to make an improvised
explosive device and acquiring components for one.

The charge also alleges  he constructed more than one device from caustic soda,
paraffin, aluminium foil, nails and glass soft drink bottles.

Reilly also faces  charges of possession of explosives and possessing explosives
with intent.

FRIDAY, JUNE 6

Police confirm that a second man arrested in connection with the Exeter
restaurant bomb blast is no longer being detained under the Terrorism Act.

Religious leaders release a joint statement about the bombing to show solidarity
between the city's different faiths.

FRIDAY, JUNE 20 - LONDON:

Reilly appears at the Old Bailey. Mr Justice Calvert- Smith suggests that the
case should be moved closer to the region and confirms that October 15 could be
a date for Reilly to enter a plea to the charges he faces.

Reilly is listed at the court under the name Mohammad Rashid Saeed Alim. He
appears via video link from Belmarsh Prison, in London, and spoke to confirm
that he understood the judge's instructions about the proceedings.

PLYMOUTH:

A man arrested by armed police in Plymouth a day after the explosion  is jailed
for a year for having a false passport. Algerian Rafik Aouamria, of Old Laira
Road, Plymouth, was detained by police at a pavement cafe in Old Town Street on
May 23.

No one other than Reilly will face charges in connection with the Princesshay
explosion.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 15

Reilly appears before the Old Bailey and pleads guilty to the charges he faces.
