                           Express and Echo (Exeter)

                           October 16, 2008 Thursday

Terror attack timeline;
Thursday, may 22

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 968 words


12.50pm: Police and ambulance services receive calls from members of the public
reporting that a man, later named as Nicky Reilly, 22, of King Street, Plymouth,
has been injured in an explosion at Giraffe restaurant in Princesshay.

1pm: A 100m cordon is established and police begin a full evacuation of the
area.

1.40pm: Police confirm it is believed an explosion has occurred.

2pm: Nicky Reilly is taken to the RD&E Hospital.

2.20pm: Bomb disposal officers arrive at the scene with sniffer dogs.

3pm: The city centre, including Princesshay, most of High Street and Paris
Street and part of Sidwell Street, is deserted. The Guildhall Shopping Centre
has also been evacuated.

3.25pm: Police confirm that a man is in custody following the explosion.

4.15pm: Bomb disposal experts prepare to enter the Giraffe restaurant.

Police reveal they have been called to three other reports of suspicious devices
in the city centre but all are false alarms.

5.15pm: Forensic officers begin to examine the Giraffe restaurant after bomb
disposal experts declare the scene safe.

6.50pm: Police reveal two devices have been found, one of which had exploded and
another that was made safe.

7pm: A phased lifting of the cordons begins and workers return to shops and
offices within the exclusion zone. Motorists are also able to retrieve their
vehicles from  car parks in Princesshay and Southernhay.

Under the protocol of a gold standard major incident, a central control room is
set up to co-ordinate the response of all emergency services. Around 10 officers
from the Metropolitan Police counter- terrorism team are drafted in to Exeter to
help with the investigation.

High-visibility patrols and sniffer dogs are also deployed at London Paddington,
checking passengers as they come off trains from Exeter.

FRIDAY, MAY 23

The city centre is back to normal, although Exeter  businesses are reckoned to
have lost at least £1.5m.

Armed police seize two more men  in Plymouth.

Over the weekend, Exeter's  Princesshay and other streets are once again
brimming with people, especially on Saturday with many keen to watch the victory
parade by Exeter City and a reunion march by the Devon and Dorset Regiment
Association.

MONDAY, MAY 26

Reilly is described as being in a serious but stable condition at the Royal
Devon & Exeter Hospital. It is understood that the 6ft 1in tall, 18st Reilly had
an operation, believed to have involved skin grafts. In the afternoon, he is
discharged from hospital and held in custody, to be formally questioned by
police.

New information emerges, as police say the device was made from sodium hydroxide
and paraffin and packed with nails and was designed to detonate when shaken.

TUESDAY, MAY 27

Reilly is questioned  at a secret location by a team of officers keen to unearth
possible links between him and Islamic radicals. The Muslim convert was
questioned in sessions lasting up to 90 minutes and could be held for up to 28
days under the Terrorism Act. Police say Reilly, who suffers from learning
difficulties, was allowed breaks as and when he needed them.

It emerges that Reilly travelled from Plymouth to Exeter with more than 50
people on a bus on the morning of the blast.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 28

A third man is arrested in Plymouth in connection with the explosion.

THURSDAY, MAY 29

Two men arrested over the  bombing appear at Central Devon Magistrates' Court.
But the three-hour city  court session was held behind closed doors. It is
believed police are  seeking  a seven-day extension to question the pair, one
believed to be  Reilly.

Searches of addresses, including the Muslim Community Centre in Plymouth, also
take place.

MONDAY, JUNE 2

Reilly, and two other men arrested in Plymouth, remain in custody. A fourth man
is also helping police with their inquiries.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 4

Reilly appears before   City of Westminster magistrates  in London, under the
name Mohammad Rashid Saeed Alim. Judge Timothy Workman remands him in custody to

                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                           October 16, 2008 Thursday

'Exeter as a target just didn't add up';
Ritain's security services were shaken to the core by the terrorist attacks in
the United States on September 11 2001. The resultant reorganisation has
established a counter- terrorism command in London and three regional
counter-terrorism unit "hubs" in the West Midlands, Greater Manchester and West
Yorkshire.

SECTION: Pg. 10

LENGTH: 904 words


The regional network also extends to an office of MI5 in the South West, as well
as a police-staffed counter- terrorism intelligence unit in the Westcountry.
Then there are the local Special Branch officers and the resources of Devon and
Cornwall Police.

Even though the necessary policies had been put in place, the equipment
purchased and officers trained, few can have imagined that Exeter would be the
next target following attacks on London and Glasgow.

Certainly for Bill Tupman,  an expert on terrorism from the University of
Exeter, "the story didn't add up".

"On one hand, we are being told that he [the bomber]  is educationally
challenged, on the other hand he's put together two devices sufficiently
sophisticated to hurt himself," he says. "That didn't add up with him being the
sort of person that the media was portraying him as.

"The other thing that didn't seem right was Exeter as a target. It didn't fit in
with any organised way of looking at the world, there are many places that you
would expect to be targets - the Giraffe cafe in Exeter, it just didn't seem
likely.

"Why would you have a go at Exeter? There is no good answer to that question."

Within nine hours of the bombing, Devon and Cornwall Police's deputy chief
constable had told reporters that Reilly had been "preyed upon, radicalised and
taken advantage of", despite "his weak and vulnerable illness".

It was a statement which intrigued Mr Tupman.

"If he had been manipulated by somebody who knew what they were doing, they
would have sent him to London, to Heathrow, to Bristol at least," he says.
"There are much more obvious targets to send someone to who is regarded as
disposable.

"There clearly was a lot of interest in the radicalisation process and it was
fashionable at that stage to talk of people who made a terrorist career out of
radicalising people, similar to paedophile grooming.

"But the reports that have come out say that there is no such thing as a typical
terrorist, there is no typical path of recruitment, and there are individuals
being radicalised by interaction with websites just as much as they are being
radicalised by individuals."

Questions remain as to how Reilly managed to hide his intentions from the police
and other security agencies. While openly converting to Islam, he covertly
researched how to construct the devices which could have caused devastation in a
family- friendly cafe.

Mr Tupman said there was clearly a "huge amount" of electronic surveillance
being undertaken. Reilly, however, may have avoided tripping the system because
he didn't set a pattern.

"I think there is so much traffic out there that you don't just get red- flagged
for visiting one site," he explained. "You get red-flagged for a succession of
visits to a succession of sites - for a pattern of behaviour.

"Somebody like Reilly, given his background, might not follow a pattern. There
is an awful lot of recording stuff out there and I suspect after this incident,
some of the red flags will have been adjusted.

"There is a lot more going on out there than we realise because we don't
actually know what the technology being used is.

"It is a possibility that, post-9/11, we fell into the American trap of relying
too much on electronic intelligence and too little on human intelligence."

Current counter-terrorism strategy is based on what are referred to as the "Four
Ps" - prevent, pursue, protect and prepare. The pursuit agenda has become plain
and resulted in a number of high-profile court cases.

The prevent strategy, now being strengthened by Government, has so far been the
"poor relation", according to Mr Tupman.

"That is because there is no career to be made out of it and there is no way of
measuring how successful it is," he explains.

"It is like the business of police patrol work - you can't measure how
successful it is. If a crime has been prevented, there is no way of measuring
that.

"Prevention is the poor relation, as is human intelligence. It is undervalued.

"It is hard work, it involves you putting yourself into the other person's
shoes. It involves you learning how to think like they do. It takes a certain
sort of person. It has always been easier to respond and react."

He says the question now being posed is why the potential threat of Islamic
extremists was not identified a decade ago. Equally, questions are being raised
about the possible threats in the next 10 years.

The security services, he argues, would have to have been expanded anyway to
counter the resurgence of Russia and China.

But, Mr Tupman added: "We have got to worry now about people coming back from
Iraq and Somalia. There are people of British origin in both places.

"We are tending to concentrate on Pakistan and we are used to seeing the threat
as being from people who are of Indian sub-continent origin.

"But we may be in danger of a North African wave. Training has also been going
on in Iraq and, as people are dispersed, some of them came to the UK. So we may
have a more professional threat to deal with."

To date, Mr Tupman feels the response to the current threats has been
proportionate, but says "care" is needed not to overstep the mark.

"We have got to watch the human rights angle, because we can lose the whole show
if the security services and the terrorists work together to undermine
democracy," he concludes. "Then we have all lost.

"Five men and a dog cannot bring down democracy, but they can provoke an
overreaction."

                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                           October 16, 2008 Thursday

Misfit admits to botched suicide bomb attack;
Muslim convert Nicky Reilly appeared via video-link from the high- security
Belmarsh prison to plead guilty to launching his doomed terrorist attack on a
Westcountry restaurant.

BYLINE: Matt Chorley London Editor

SECTION: Pg. 6

LENGTH: 796 words


The 22-year-old admitted plotting what his barrister described as an "ugly and
dangerous incident" at the Giraffe restaurant in Exeter in May.

He used the Internet to research how to make his bombs using caustic soda,
paraffin and about 500 nails. But when he attempted to assemble one of the
soft-drink glass bottle bombs in a toilet cubicle of the restaurant, it exploded
in his hands.

In the public gallery of the Old Bailey's Court 12, his mother Kim seemed to
wipe away tears as he told the court he was guilty of attempted murder and a
second charge of preparing a terrorist attack. He is due to be sentenced on
November 21 after psychological reports  have been  completed.

During the 45-minute hearing it emerged that Reilly - who was charged under the
name Mohammad Rashid Saeed Alim - had "long nursed an ambition" to become a
martyr.

He had considered targeting high- profile sites in his home city of Plymouth,
including Devonport Dockyard, Drake Circus shopping centre and Charles Cross
police station.

Instead he travelled on a bus to Exeter and made his way to the restaurant where
the ingredients of his makeshift bombs exploded prematurely.

Reilly, of King Street, Plymouth, was arrested when he staggered out of the
restaurant after suffering serious facial injuries in the blast on May 22.

As the judge, Mr Justice Calvert- Smith, read detailed papers relating to the
case, Reilly took deep breaths but appeared relaxed and showed no obvious signs
of the injuries he sustained in the blast.

The court heard Reilly had begun planning his attack early this year and from
January started looking at Internet websites to research how to assemble a
suicide vest. He also watched a video on the website YouTube entitled "Home-made
bombs". He was also in "frequent contact" with two people via the Internet,
which included a debate about who to target in an attack. The pair have still
not been traced by police.

Mr Justice Calvert-Smith said: "He bought more than necessary equipment over
those months to construct two types of improvised devices, one using caustic
soda and the other kerosene. He appears to have tried to increase the potential
for injury and death both to himself and others by putting chemicals in glass
bottles and filling those bottles with a total of around 500 nails."

On the morning of May 22, he travelled to Exeter by bus from Plymouth with six
bottles, three containing caustic soda, three kerosene and another chemical
contained in drain cleaner.

Kerim Fuad, defending, said at the time of sentencing that he wanted to present
a statement and a psychiatric report for the court. He said he had a wealth of
material to put to the judge on Reilly's "unusual and complex personal
background which led to this ugly and dangerous incident".

Reilly had planned to run into the restaurant from the toilets holding three
bottle bombs to his stomach. But the first one reacted prematurely and he could
not get out of the cubicle.

Prosecutor Stuart Baker said: "His recollection now is that he was unable to
open the lock of the cubicle door and come out, by which time the first device
had already exploded."

The judge said: "There is evidence from materials seized that he became
increasingly drawn to violent action in support of fellow Muslims in revenge for
perceived persecution and to the idea of becoming a martyr."

During yesterday's hearing, Reilly's mother Kim was comforted by a police family
liaison officer. In an interview she said her son was incapable of making the
devices without "instructions or guidance from someone".

Mrs Reilly said her son was "a vulnerable person who has been radicalised",
adding that he was  an "easy target, easy prey for them".

"Nicky is so vulnerable, he has got special needs, he has got Asperger's
Syndrome," she said. "All I can say is what Nicky was like. They have
brainwashed him. He's done the work and they are walking free."

Mrs Reilly, whose second son Luke is also in jail, said Nicky needed to be in
hospital rather than prison.

Referring to her son's conversion to Islam, she said he had changed because of
"all the people that he was hanging around with".

"He believed that he was on the right path, he'd found the right religion and
this was the right way of life," she said. "But Nicky could have met people from
any faith - if someone befriended him that would have been the path he would
have taken."

She did, however, admit to being concerned by her son's increasingly extremist
view of the world.

Mrs Reilly has made several trips to see her son in  Belmarsh prison, which
houses other convicted terrorists. A card written by Reilly to his mother from
prison reads: "To the queen of my heart - my mum. Just to say how much I love
and miss you. You are my lovely, beautiful mother. Love you, Nicky."

LOAD-DATE: August 21, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Referring to her son's conversion to Islam, she said he had changed because of
"all the people that he was hanging around with".

"He believed that he was on the right path, he'd found the right religion and
this was the right way of life," she said. "But Nicky could have met people from
any faith - if someone befriended him that would have been the path he would
have taken."

She did, however, admit to being concerned by her son's increasingly extremist
view of the world.

Mrs Reilly has made several trips to see her son in  Belmarsh prison, which
houses other convicted terrorists. A card written by Reilly to his mother from
prison reads: "To the queen of my heart - my mum. Just to say how much I love
and miss you. You are my lovely, beautiful mother. Love you, Nicky."

Knife attack terror for club customer

Two men were slashed across the face with a knife after being threatened by
armed thieves during a robbery at a club in Stockport.

Two thieves armed with knives forced open the doors to the private bar and one

Both men then fled.

They are described as white and wearing balaclavas and police are now appealing
to anyone who has information about the robbery to come forward.

Detective Constable Marcus Ellaby, based at Stockport CID, said: "The two
offenders we are looking for are clearly dangerous, opportunistic men who are
prepared to use knives just to get their hands on some cash.

"The fact they actually used the knives to injure the victims shows they need to
apprehended as soon as possible.

"I would appeal to anyone who has any information to come forward so we can
progress our investigation and find these men."

                           Express and Echo (Exeter)

                            October 17, 2008 Friday

City bomb attack has brought different faith groups closer together;
The attempted terrorist attack on Princesshay has failed to divide the city's
different faith communities, according to academics and religious
representatives.

BYLINE: JULIA BRADSHAW

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 543 words


As 22-year-old Nicky Reilly awaits sentencing after pleading guilty to attempted
murder and preparing terrorist acts, experts have continued to analyse why he
carried out the crime, how he was radicalised and what can be done to prevent a
similar outrage from happening again.

Looking back on the failed bomb attack at Giraffe Restaurant on May 22, Martyn
Goss, director of the Council for Church and Society, said: "I think it has left
a cloud over people, but it has probably brought the different faith communities
closer together because we wanted to express support and solidarity for one
another.

"One of the outcomes has been closer co-operation and getting to know each other
better.

"I would also echo that for the individuals, families and communities, there can
now be closure, and, to some extent, people can get on with their lives and we
can put this behind us.

"I think people from all walks of life have learned lessons from what happened.
It has brought us closer together and presented us with an opportunity to share
understanding with one another, and I hope that we can move on positively."

Dr Larbi Sadiki, a politics lecturer at Exeter University, said the explosion
shocked the city's mosque community.

"There was fear that the incident would be reflected on Muslims," said Dr
Sadiki.

"I think people were petrified by the allegation that Nicky Reilly had been
manipulated by the Muslim community, that he was somehow an agent of some
pernicious force.

"It is something the community at large has since talked about in cafes and over
dinner.  Exeter is an idyllic place, not Madrid or New York, and we asked
ourselves what was going on. Many people were really disheartened and wondered
why he would convert and then engage in this activity.

"People are relieved at the guilty plea and think it's good that justice will be
handed down.

"It's also a reminder for all and sundry not to engage in, or even contemplate
criminal behaviour.  What he did was against Muslim law and no one here condones
it."

Dr Sadiki suggested proper training for Muslim preachers might be one way to
prevent extremism.

He said: "We need qualified experts to teach the faith.  The role is very
complex, challenging and demanding.  You have  to wear two or three hats at the
same time.

"If you don't have the proper training you can mislead people and not do your
job properly."

Dr Jonathan Githens-Mazer, senior lecturer in politics at Exeter University,
said pinpointing the exact cause of terrorism was difficult.

"I think this notion that people are being manipulated into extremism is not
quite right," he said.

"In this case it was probably true.  Nicky Reilly was obviously mentally ill and
had serious difficulties.

"But we have to understand that not all people who engage in violent extremism
are easily manipulated.

"It is a very complex issue, with no three or four factors to explain exactly
why it happens.

"I think perhaps in many cases legitimate grievances are manipulated and used as
excuses for justifying terrorism.

"Nicky Reilly's case is interesting because the radicalisation happened in a
virtual state.

"First we saw people going to training camps abroad, then they went to train in
locations in Britain, and now, in this instance, it has developed online."

                              Daily Mail (London)

                           October 18, 2008 Saturday
                                  SC1 Edition

HOW WE BEAT THE AIRPORT BOMBERS;
Court hears astonishing tales of bravery from the people caught in terror attack

BYLINE: Emily Andrews

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 987 words


ORDINARY people were the heroes of the day when two terrorists crashed a burning
Jeep into Glasgow Airport.

In court yesterday, passengers relived the horror of the attack for the first
time as they described how Dr Bilal Abdulla and Kafeel Ahmed drove their
bomb-filled car into the entrance of the terminal.

Amid chaotic scenes on the airport's busiest day of the year, people ran for
their lives as the car burst into flames. But some brave bystanders tried to
tackle the two men as they hurled Molotov cocktail petrol bombs.

One even had his leg broken as he struggled to bring down Abdulla, who was
trying to hit a police officer.

Michael Kerr had returned from a holiday with his wife, children and parents and
had just collected his car from the long-stay car park on Saturday, June 30,
last year. He told Woolwich Crown Court: 'He [Abdulla] gets out the car and goes
to the police officer, trying to punch the police officer, and from that he
backed off. 'He comes round the back of the car and I was about 20 yards away. I
knew something was wrong, so I went for him. It happened in a flash. 'I ran
across to him in the back of the Jeep and there were punches exchanged. I got my
tooth knocked out, my crown knocked out and my leg was broken. 'I don't know if
it was me kicking the man or the man kicking me. It was a clash.'

Mr Kerr, who spent four days in hospital and needed surgery and metal rods in
his leg as well as dental work, collapsed and watched his attacker disappear
into the terminal building. He then saw Ahmed, 28, pour petrol through the
window and the vehicle went up in flames. 'The driver got out of the car and
rolled in the petrol and he was ablaze,' he continued. 'He got to his feet. I
was trying to pull myself back and I remember him getting up and fighting with
another policeman.' Mr Kerr was pulled out of the way and Ahmed later died of
his injuries in hospital.

Taxi driver Alexander McIlveen was behind the Jeep when it careered into the
terminal building and he saw petrol bombs being thrown. He also scuffled
29-year-old Abdulla, before turning his attention to the driver, Ahmed, who was
on fire.

'There was two people with fire extinguishers trying to hose him down,' said Mr
McIlveen. 'Once he was hosed down, he was trying to get to the boot of the Jeep.
He realised he couldn't do it and came towards everybody just shouting and
throwing punches. 'He was burnt. It was quite weird. He wasn't shouting for help
because he was burnt. 'He was just shouting and hollering - it wasn't in
English, I couldn't understand him. 'He was just throwing punches and we were
trying to surround him and contain him.

' Taxi driver Brian Roan said Ahmed had an 'expressionless' look on his face as
he drove the Jeep into the airport. 'He was staring straight ahead, not left or
right. He didn't look as if he was in a panic or had been in a crash, he was
straight ahead and determined - totally focused. 'We never thought anything
would happen to Glasgow, let alone a terrorist attack.' Sergeant Torquil
Campbell was the first police officer on the scene when the Jeep crashed into
Terminal One at about 3.10pm.

He ran over to the Jeep and saw that it was ablaze. He said: 'Bilal Abdulla saw
myself and ran towards me, ten or 15 yards away from the Jeep. 'My first
impression was that he was evidently trying to keep me away from the vehicle.
'He ran towards me and seemed very calm but was very aggressive in wanting to
keep me away from the vehicle. 'He was lashing out with both arms but I managed
to avoid him. I looked back to the vehicle and I assumed there was still a
driver in the vehicle . 'Bilal Abdulla looked back to the vehicle, looking
intently at it. In a split second, I knew he was expecting something else to
happen.'

Sergeant Campbell then described how Kafeel Ahmed appeared out of the flames of
the burning Jeep and was on fire. He said: 'His whole body was smouldering and
he was well alight.' The sergeant described how he 'His whole body smouldering,
he was well alight' heard 'popping' noises from the burning car and assumed that
it was fluid in the vehicle or electricity wires. Ahmed then ran towards him, so
Sergeant Campbell pulled out his CS gas and sprayed it in his face. At the same
time, Ahmed was overpowered by two members of the public and two other police
officers. Another police officer, PC William Thomson, tried to get hold of Ahmed
but his 'skin came off in my hands'. The two men were eventually brought down
and arrested.

Meanwhile, inside the terminal, pandemonium had broken out. Gillian Girasoli was
knocked over in the stampede for the exit as terrified passengers tried to
escape from the building. 'People were running and screaming in all directions,'
she said in a statement read to the court. 'I could hear children screaming.
Cases were lying in all directions. It reminded me of the film of 9/11.'

She fell down, was trampled on and picked up by two men. The airport's customer
services director, Derek Provan, told the court in a statement: 'June 30, 2007,
I would class as one of the busiest days of the year for Glasgow Airport., as it
was the first day of the Scottish school holidays and there was a very high
number of passengers.' Mr Provan added that there were 'He was throwing punches
and he was shouting' 3,500 passengers in the airport at the time, 82 flights
were cancelled and 12 were diverted after the airport was closed.

It was a number of weeks before the airport got back to normal operations.
Abdulla and Ahmed are said to have been part of a small terrorist cell operating
in the UK, along with a second medic, Dr Mohammad Asha, 28. They are accused of
deploying two car bombs in the West End of London on June 29 last year which
failed to go off, despite repeated attempts to detonate them by mobile phone.
Both men deny the charges of conspiracy to murder and to cause explosions. The
case continues.

Police 'have to learn more about Muslims' Devon's top cop says;
Police must learn more about Islam and radicalisation in the wake of the
terrorist attack on Princesshay, Devon's top officer has warned.

BYLINE: ECHO REPORTER

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 420 words


Chief constable Stephen Otter was speaking at a conference entitled The Police,
Muslims and Radicalisation, organised by the force's Black Police Association.

He also praised the "solidarity" of the Devon community in the wake of Nicky
Reilly's failed suicide bombing at the Giraffe restaurant.

The conference was already being  planned when the Muslim convert from Plymouth,
who had changed his name to Mohammad Rashid Saeed Alim, tried to detonate
homemade nail bombs amid lunchtime diners in May.

Reilly, 22, pleaded guilty to  preparing a terrorist attack and  attempted
murder at the Old  Bailey last week.

He is said to have been encouraged to carry out the bombing by  two unknown
associates in Pakistan with whom he was in contact over the internet.

Mr Otter said the timing of yesterday's event was a coincidence but provided a
"very powerful" opportunity.

He said: "People will take it a lot more seriously now that we have had an event
like the  Exeter bombing."

He said it was vital that the force and its officers learned more  about Islam,
the Muslim community and the way in which people were radicalised.

Referring to the Princesshay attack, Mr Otter, who holds the race  and diversity
portfolio for the  Association of Chief Police Officers, added: "There has been
a  real sense of solidarity against this in our community and it is  important
that we take the  opportunity to say there is more  we can do and more we can
learn."

The conference in Plymouth was attended by nearly 100 people. Most were from the
police, including Special Branch, CID and traffic officers, although the
audience also included community leaders and other partners.

One of the key speakers was  Mohammed Khaliel, a member of the Scotland  Yard
Muslim Safety Forum, who is also involved in police training.

He responded to  questions from the audience  about Islam, terrorism and jihad,
as well as about the structure of the religion and the role of women.

Mr Khaliel said Islam was  "all about peace" and that radical and violent
teachings were "a mix of culture and interpretation, trying to make something
fit into what you want it to".

"It is about opening closets and  bringing down barriers," Mr  Khaliel added.
"The Nicky  Reilly case is in our minds and  hearts, it is about bringing it out
into the open and speaking  openly and frankly."

He said the conference  had been  well-received and was crucial  in building a
stronger relationship between community and  police to increase the opportunity
of picking up  problems earlier.

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

                            October 21, 2008 Tuesday

National: DPP attacks approach to fighting terror

BYLINE: Afua Hirsch, Legal affairs correspondent

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 261 words


The government is at risk of creating a society where "freedom's back is
broken", the director of public prosecutions has said while attacking
counter-terrorism policy in a speech yesterday.

Citing the "relentless pressure of a security state", Sir Ken Macdonald QC added
to criticism of new laws in the wake of the government's defeat over proposals
to detain terrorism suspects for 42 days without trial.

Macdonald, who steps down this month after five years as head of the Crown
Prosecution Service, described some aspects of the government's response to the
terrorism threat as "medieval delusions". He said he had repeatedly called for
"level-headedness" and had ensured the CPS "had not feared fairness" in its
attempt to prosecute acts of terrorism, in contrast to the government's lack of
"legislative restraint".

Echoing comments made by the House of Lords, Macdonald suggested that the
government would be giving into terrorists if it continued to erode freedom. "It
is difficult to see who will maintain a cool head if governments do not," he
said.

Macdonald's speech, which also served as the CPS's inaugural annual lecture,
came a week after the government suffered a fatal blow to the 42-day detention
proposals contained in its counter-terrorism bill.

Although Macdonald has consistently opposed what he describes as "unnecessary"
counter-terror legislation, yesterday's comments were his strongest yet and came
days before he steps down as DPP. His successor, Keir Starmer QC, is also
expected to lead the CPS in opposing any reduction in individual rights.

                                October 22, 2008

Pensioners tell of terror as 'devil dogs' attack on street

BYLINE: Belinda Hargreaves

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 591 words


Two pensioners were injured after being attacked in separate incidents by a
Rottweiler and a Staffordshire bull terrier.

A 60-year-old woman needed hospital treatment to her face and fingers after
being knocked over and bitten by the bull terrier. A man who came to her rescue
was also bitten.

Her pet West Highland terrier suffered damaged back muscles after being bitten
in the attack and needed surgery.

The attack on Wallbridge Drive on Friday evening was followed on Sunday by an
incident where an 85-year-old suffered a head injury after being attacked by a
Rottweiler.

She was treated at her home for bruising and scratching to her face.

Police have spoken to the owner of the Rottweiler and inquiries are still
continuing into the incident at Pickwood recreation ground.

The 60-year-old victim, who does not want to be named for fear of reprisals, was
walking her dog with her 62-year-old husband near the Prince of Wales pub at
5.15pm on Friday.

The bull terrier - described as black with a grey face - knocked both her and
the couple's dog over.

She said: "I knew it would go for our dog's throat, so I put my arm around our
dog's neck to protect it.

"The other dog bit my hands and my face before sinking its teeth into our dog's
back."

Her husband said: "I tried to get the bull terrier off our dog.

"A man from across the road came over and got hold of something - I think it was
the other dog's lead - and wrapped it around the other dog's back legs and
pulled it out from under me.

"The dog also bit that man's hands."

The couple managed to escape in a friend's car and took the dog to a vet's in
Leek, where he was operated on the following day. The wound is now healing but
the animal has a drainage tube in his back.

The bull terrier's harness was broken in the incident and was found nearby.

The  pensioner said: "We've not been through anything like this before; it was a
nightmare."

Her husband said: "There was a woman with the dog and although it had a lead on,
by the time it got to us she wasn't holding on to it. She kept saying: 'What can
I do about it?'"

Ms Atkins said: "I have received details about the incident  and it  sounds
absolutely horrendous. There are clear laws that a person in charge of a dog is
responsible and in the worst case scenario the dog should be destroyed. I will
be talking to the police about it."

In the second incident, an 85-year-old woman - who has not been named - was
walking at Pickwood recreation ground on Sunday at around 3pm when she was
attacked.

Steve Maskrey, inspector of Leek police, said officers would be increasing
patrols in the area.

He said: "It is unacceptable that members of the community have to run the risk
of being attacked by someone else's dog.

"The owner of the dog and one of the men walking with the dog at the time have
been spoken to  at length and officers will be making further inquiries."

Other dog walkers who use  Pickwood recreational ground reported having seen
aggressive dogs regularly.

Roger Deaville is a resident on Ashbourne Road whose property backs onto the
Pickwood recreation ground.

The 43 year-old trailer manufacturer said: "We do have a problem with some
terriers in the area which have bitten me, my brother and a postman."

Councillor Steve Povey is a resident on Ashbourne Road and uses the park to walk
his dog.

He said: "Owners of aggressive natured dogs have a responsibility to keep them
under control.

"It's the training that's important and a good owner should know their animal's
capability."

                              Leek Post and Times

                           October 22, 2008 Wednesday

Pensioners tell of terror as 'devil dogs' attack on street

BYLINE: Belinda Hargreaves

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 591 words


Two pensioners were injured after being attacked in separate incidents by a
Rottweiler and a Staffordshire bull terrier.

A 60-year-old woman needed hospital treatment to her face and fingers after
being knocked over and bitten by the bull terrier. A man who came to her rescue
was also bitten.

Her pet West Highland terrier suffered damaged back muscles after being bitten
in the attack and needed surgery.

The attack on Wallbridge Drive on Friday evening was followed on Sunday by an
incident where an 85-year-old suffered a head injury after being attacked by a
Rottweiler.

She was treated at her home for bruising and scratching to her face.

Police have spoken to the owner of the Rottweiler and inquiries are still
continuing into the incident at Pickwood recreation ground.

The 60-year-old victim, who does not want to be named for fear of reprisals, was
walking her dog with her 62-year-old husband near the Prince of Wales pub at
5.15pm on Friday.

The bull terrier - described as black with a grey face - knocked both her and
the couple's dog over.

She said: "I knew it would go for our dog's throat, so I put my arm around our
dog's neck to protect it.

"The other dog bit my hands and my face before sinking its teeth into our dog's
back."

Her husband said: "I tried to get the bull terrier off our dog.

"A man from across the road came over and got hold of something - I think it was
the other dog's lead - and wrapped it around the other dog's back legs and
pulled it out from under me.

"The dog also bit that man's hands."

The couple managed to escape in a friend's car and took the dog to a vet's in
Leek, where he was operated on the following day. The wound is now healing but
the animal has a drainage tube in his back.

The bull terrier's harness was broken in the incident and was found nearby.

The  pensioner said: "We've not been through anything like this before; it was a
nightmare."

Her husband said: "There was a woman with the dog and although it had a lead on,
by the time it got to us she wasn't holding on to it. She kept saying: 'What can
I do about it?'"

The couple contacted police and Moorlands MP Charlotte Atkins.

Ms Atkins said: "I have received details about the incident  and it  sounds
absolutely horrendous. There are clear laws that a person in charge of a dog is
responsible and in the worst case scenario the dog should be destroyed. I will
be talking to the police about it."

In the second incident, an 85-year-old woman - who has not been named - was
walking at Pickwood recreation ground on Sunday at around 3pm when she was
attacked.

Steve Maskrey, inspector of Leek police, said officers would be increasing
patrols in the area.

He said: "It is unacceptable that members of the community have to run the risk
of being attacked by someone else's dog.

"The owner of the dog and one of the men walking with the dog at the time have
been spoken to  at length and officers will be making further inquiries."

Other dog walkers who use  Pickwood recreational ground reported having seen
aggressive dogs regularly.

Roger Deaville is a resident on Ashbourne Road whose property backs onto the
Pickwood recreation ground.

The 43 year-old trailer manufacturer said: "We do have a problem with some
terriers in the area which have bitten me, my brother and a postman."

Councillor Steve Povey is a resident on Ashbourne Road and uses the park to walk
his dog.

He said: "Owners of aggressive natured dogs have a responsibility to keep them
under control.

"It's the training that's important and a good owner should know their animal's
capability."

                       BBC Monitoring Trans Caucasus Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           October 23, 2008 Thursday

Breakaway Abkhazia accuses Georgia of "terrorist attack"

LENGTH: 199 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Sukhumi, 23 October: The [separatist] Abkhaz state security service has accused
the Georgian special services of killing the chief of the intelligence
department of the country's defence ministry, Eduard Emin-zade.

"The state security service assesses the incident as yet another terrorist
attack which the Georgian special services planned and carried out against
members of the Abkhaz power-wielding agencies," the public relations centre of
the state security service told Interfax.

The dead body of Eduard Emin-zade was found in the town of Gali on Thursday
morning [23 October]. According to preliminary data, he died as a result of a
wound to his head. His dead body was found in a private house at 0800 [0400
gmt].

The state security service of the republic reported that later the dead body of
Eldar Shamugia was found near a ford across the Inguri River [which separates
Abkhazia from the rest of Georgia]. Shamugia was the owner of the house where
the dead body of Emin-zade was found.

A team from the Gali District police department are investigating the case.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0804 gmt 23 Oct 08

                            Herald Express (Torquay)

                           October 23, 2008 Thursday

Families terrorised by armed attackers

BYLINE:  LAURA DALE

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 530 words


Families feared for their lives as windows were smashed and a 15-year-old girl
assaulted in a violent incident involving three armed men.

The night-time attack on Haytor View happened after an argument.

The thugs returned and four windows were smashed at  the end-of-terrace
property.

A car was vandalised and teenager Jacqueline Stuz (pictured) hit over the head
with a metal pole before her father Andrew (also pictured) was also assaulted.

The men, one of whom was said to be armed with a lock knife and a cordless
drill, then allegedly barged their way into the flat and threatened the
occupants before stealing unknown items and fleeing.

Seven police units, including officers armed with Taser guns, and  a dog handler
were called to the scene of the incident which happened at about 10.10pm on
Tuesday.

Police cordoned off the Heathfield area and up towards Chudleigh Knighton.

One man was arrested at about 10.30pm near to the scene and the police
helicopter was scrambled to help locate another two suspects who were found
heading in the direction of Chudleigh Knighton.

The sniffer dog was deployed before one man was detained on the B3344 road near
Chudleigh Knighton and a third man was arrested on the A38 Chudleigh slip road
just after midnight.

A discarded hammer and a cordless drill were also found in a nearby field.

Yesterday, residents living at Haytor View described the event as something out
of the Al Capone era.

Father of five Andrew Stuz, 42,  said: "My oldest children came downstairs
because they had heard smashing glass and were scared stiff. I went outside to
see what was going on and three lads ran around the corner smashing windows on
the ground floor flat next door.

"I asked them what they were doing and they just attacked us. My daughter was
hit over the head with a steel bar and I was then hit on the arm."

Another resident, who did not want to be named, said: "I heard screams and glass
smashing. We were petrified. I thought they were going to kill us. It was like
something out of an Al Capone movie."

Police confirmed they received a 'number of calls' from worried residents who
heard the commotion and described it as 'bedlam'.

Insp Ian Curson said: "We were called to an on-going incident of disorder. When
we arrived there were a number of windows which had been smashed on the ground
floor. Allegations were made that the offenders had stolen some items from the
property and threatened the occupants.

"We recovered a small lock knife from one suspect and found a drill and a hammer
which the dog handler found 40 yards away in a nearby field. These items may or
may not be connected to the crime."

Insp Curson said the flat was in 'disarray' following the attack and an interior
door had been badly damaged.

A spokesman for South Western Ambulance Trust said: "We were called at 10.39pm.
Paramedics treated a 15-year-old girl for a head injury at the scene, she was
not conveyed to hospital."

A 20 year old man has been arrested on suspicion of aggravated burglary and
possession of an offence weapon. Two other men, aged 17 and 18, were arrested on
suspicion of aggravated burglary.

All three men were taken to Torquay Police Station for questioning.

LOAD-DATE: October 24, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 75

                              All Rights Reserved

                           October 23, 2008 Thursday

Five Colombian terrorist attacks in Bogota leave 11 people injured

LENGTH: 252 words


Text of report by privately-owned, nationwide Colombian Caracol radio website on
23 October

[Report: "Increase of Terrorist Activity in Bogota Leaves 11 People Injured,
Property Damage"]

Bogota registered an increase in terrorist activity when five explosive devices
went off in different parts of the city at midday today.

Bogota Metropolitan Police Commanders General Rodolfo Palomino confirmed that
the first device exploded on 80th Street and Sixth Avenue, injuring two people -
Mr Deogracias Martinez, 67 and Jorge Alberto Tellez, 36. The two were workers of
the ASEO Capital company and were handling a bag when the medium-powered
explosion took place. They were taken to the Country Clinic where the medical
report states that they suffered soft tissue lesions on their faces and upper
extremities.

The second explosion took place at the Salitre Plaza Shopping Centre, injuring
three people who were taken to the Colombia Clinic.

The third device exploded on 138th Street and Seventh Avenue near a recreational
park, injuring one person who was taken to El Bosque Clinic and shattering
several nearby window panes. The device was placed behind the Palatino shopping
centre.

A fourth explosion took place on 99th Street and Ninth Avenue, injuring two
people. There is no information yet as to which clinic they were taken to.

The last device exploded on 102d street and 21st Avenue, injuring two people who
were later taken to the Santa Fe Clinic.

Source: Colombian Caracol radio website, Bogota, in Spanish 23 Oct 08

                            The Independent (London)

                            October 24, 2008 Friday
                                 First Edition

Car bombs would have fired gas canister over half a mile, court told;
'Loose wiring and too much fuel thwarted terror attack on London nightclub'

BYLINE: James Read

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 360 words


Gas canisters packed inside two car bombs in the heart of London's West End
could have been propelled up to half a mile if they had exploded, a court heard
yesterday.

Dr Bilal Abdulla, 29, and Kafeel Ahmed, 28, parked the vehicles, loaded with
gas, petrol and hundreds of nails, after preparing them in a "bomb factory" in a
Glasgow suburb, jurors were told. But the home-made bombs failed to go off
because there was so much fuel inside the vehicles that it "snuffed out" any
potential explosion.

Dr Abdulla is on trial at Woolwich Crown Court with a second medic, Dr Mohammad
Asha, 28, who is accused of helping Dr Abdulla and Mr Ahmed plot terrorist
attacks last summer. Mr Ahmed died of his injuries after an attack on Glasgow
airport a day after the failed attacks in London. Loose wiring in a mobile
phone, which was part of an improvised detonator inside the cars, also rendered
the London bombs ineffective, the court heard. A forensic fire investigator,
Eric Leung, said the fuel-air mix was too rich to spark a blast, even though one
of the detonators did fire in one of the cars.

Dr Abdulla parked a green Mercedes packed with almost 900 nails, two full 13kg
patio gas canisters and more than 100 litres of fuel outside the Tiger Tiger
nightclub in Haymarket on 29 June last year, the prosecution said. Mr Ahmed's
blue Mercedes was left nearby with the same fuel mix and 1,000 nails inside.

Had the bombs gone off, huge petrol containers in the boot could have melted and
the leaking fuel would have increased the ferocity of the blaze, Mr Leung said.
He added: "The [gas] cylinders may fragment in to more than one piece or may
stay in one piece. Both those pieces could be projected over significant
distances. I have seen some examples where fragments of cylinders have been
ejected fully half a mile."

After the failed attacks, Dr Abdulla and Mr Ahmed drove a Jeep Cherokee packed
with explosives in to the terminal at Glasgow airport. Mr Ahmed died and Dr
Abdulla was arrested.

Dr Asha, a Jordanian, of Newcastle-under-Lyme, and Dr Abdulla, an Iraqi, of
Paisley, deny conspiracy to murder and cause explosions likely to endanger life.
The case continues.

             PA Regional Newswire of English Regions: WEST MIDLANDS

                      October 24, 2008 Friday 3:30 PM BST

WATCHING TERRORIST ATTACK NEWS FOOTAGE 'MADE DOCTOR ILL'

SECTION: PA Regional Newswire for English Regions

LENGTH: 183 words


A man accused of a terrorist plot went quiet and looked ill as he saw TV news of
the attack on Glasgow Airport while at a house in Newcastle-under-Lyme, a court
has heard.

Dr Mohammed Asha, 28, watched footage of the burning jeep with friend Mohammed
Nizam on June 30 last year.

The colleagues sat with their wives and Asha's young son in Dr Nizam's house.

Dr Nizam told Woolwich Crown Court on Friday that as time went on Asha seemed
distracted and eventually he drove him home.

``In retrospect I think he looked very poorly or something,'' Dr Nizam said.

``When we were there (Asha's house) we were invited in for a cup of tea. He
didn't say very much and he looked very tired.''

Asha disappeared upstairs for about 10 minutes, the jury heard, and was ``hardly
talking''.

The prosecution claim that Kafeel Ahmed, 28, and Asha's co-defendant Bilal
Abdulla, 29, had driven a jeep packed with gas canisters and petrol into a
terminal building at the airport. Ahmed died a month later from burns.

Dr Nizam described Asha as a devout Muslim, and the pair would pray together
every Friday, the court was told. end

                             PA Newswire: Scotland

                      October 24, 2008 Friday 3:04 PM BST

WATCHING TERROR ATTACK TV COVERAGE 'MADE DOCTOR ILL'

BYLINE: Margaret Davis, PA

SECTION: PA Newswire: Scotland

LENGTH: 404 words


A doctor accused of a terrorist plot went quiet and looked ill as he saw TV news
of the attack on Glasgow Airport, a court heard today.

Dr Mohammed Asha, 28, watched footage of the burning jeep with friend Mohammed
Nizam on June 30 last year.

The colleagues sat with their wives and Asha's young son in Dr Nizam's house in
Newcastle-under-Lyme.

Dr Nizam told Woolwich Crown Court as time went on Asha seemed distracted and
eventually he drove him home.

Dr Nizam said: ``In retrospect I think he looked very poorly or something. When
we were there (Asha's house) we were invited in for a cup of tea. He didn't say
very much and he looked very tired.''

Asha disappeared upstairs for around 10 minutes, the jury heard, and was
``hardly talking''.

The prosecution said that Kafeel Ahmed, 28, and Asha's co-defendant Bilal
Abdulla, 29, had driven a jeep packed with gas canisters and petrol into a
terminal building at Glasgow Airport. Ahmed died a month later from burns.

Today Dr Nizam described Asha as a ``devout'' Muslim, and the pair would pray
together every Friday, the court was told.

The medics met at Shrewsbury Hospital in 2005 and the following year both moved
to Newcastle-under-Lyme to work there.

In the week before Asha's arrest, Dr Nizam told the jury his friend seemed
preoccupied because he had not been paid that month.

Asha's General Medical Council registration had lapsed between April 14 and May
29 and staff at University Hospital, North Staffordshire, told him he would not
be paid for his work during that period.

The jury heard that his net salary in May was £2,412.05, but in June he was paid
nothing.

Despite this, it is alleged that Asha gave Abdullah £1,300 to fund terror
attacks in Glasgow and London.

Two car bombs were planted outside the Tiger Tiger nightclub and in Cockspur
Street in the capital's West End.

The devices failed to go off because mobile detonators did not work, the jury
has heard.

Prosecuting, Jonathan Laidlaw QC told the court that Asha failed to answer his
pager at work on June 29 because he was meeting alleged conspirators Ahmed and
Abdullah.

He was sent a message by a nurse on the renal ward at 5.36pm that day but failed
to answer, the jury heard.

But defending, Stephen Kamlish QC said it was common for doctors to ignore
non-urgent ``bleeps'' unless they were messaged a second time.

Asha and Abdullah are accused of conspiracy to murder and to cause explosions.

The trial continues.

LOAD-DATE: October 24, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              All Rights Reserved

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                            October 27, 2008 Monday

Lessons in how to deal with terror attack

BYLINE: Keith Findlay

SECTION: BUSINESS; OTHERS; General; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 203 words


A TRAINING event in Aberdeen early next year will see senior staff from
north-east businesses being put through a mock terror attack as part of a
two-day continuity planning course.

The gathering - the fourth in a series - has been arranged by the Robert Gordon
University (RGU) in Aberdeen, in partnership with Grampian Police.

On completing the training, which is accredited by security industry skills body
Skills for Security, participants get an RGU certificate for continuous
professional development.

The courses are aimed at "key co-ordinators" for business continuity planning -
people who have responsibility for ensuring good procedures are in place for
handling any threats to their companies.

Participants at the previous event in August included bosses from a wide range
of firms, with management responsibilities in areas including facilities,
security, health and safety, and training.

In addition to the mock terror attack, the course taking place at RGU's business
school on January 20 and 21 will feature a presentation on the current terrorism
threat in the UK.

Places at the January event, which cost £350 per participant, are limited.
Contact Moira Bailey at RGU via m.m.bailey@rgu.ac.uk or on 01224 263139.

East Turkey police point attacked by "terrorists"

LENGTH: 308 words


Text of report by Turkish privately-owned, mass-circulation daily Hurriyet
website on 24 October

An attack with long-barreled weapons has been staged by PKK terrorists against a
police point in the Esentepe section of Tunceli where Special Operations Teams
were on duty.

It is stated that, when police immediately returned fire, two of the PKK members
were wounded. The area where the terrorists were located has been bombed by
Super Cobra type helicopters.

In Tunceli, where Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan will visit his party's
central district and take part in various inaugural activities tomorrow, PKK
terrorists conducted an attack with long-barreled weapons at about 6:00 p.m.
this evening against a police point.

Fire was returned instantly to the terrorists' attack from the point, termed
K.4, which is 1.5 kilometres from the town centre in Yenimahalle, and where
Special Operations Teams are on duty to provide security from the town's high
points. The clash between the security forces and the PKK members continued
intensely for approximately an hour. The sounds of weapons were heard from the
centre of the town, and Gendarmerie and police personnel who came to reinforce
the area fired illumination flares at the areas where the terrorists were
located.

Subjected to heavy fire, the PKK members took their wounded comrades with them
and fled towards the forested areas of Sutluce village, while Super Cobra type
helicopters equipped with night vision devices, which took off from the Tunceli
Gendarmerie Regional Command, bombed the areas where the terrorists were
located. Operations to neutralize the terrorists continue, while the
comprehensive security precautions taken because of the arrival of Prime
Minister Erdogan were raised to the highest level throughout the night.

                                BreakingNews.ie

                      October 27, 2008 Monday 05:34 PM GMT

Syria accuses US of terrorism after attack kills eight

SECTION: WORLD NEWS

LENGTH: 416 words


America was accused of "terrorism" today after its special forces raided alleged
al-Qaida fighters sheltering inside the supposed safety of Syria.

The attack killed eight people and Syria immediately claimed all were innocent
victims and included women and children, but journalists at their funerals today
saw only men's bodies.

A US military official in Washington confirmed the attack was aimed at the
network of al-Qaida-linked foreign fighters moving through Syria into Iraq.

"We are taking matters into our own hands," he said.

The Syrian government said four US helicopters attacked a civilian building
under construction shortly before dusk on Sunday in the village of Sukkariyeh,
about five miles inside the border.

Syria's foreign minister, Walid al-Moallem, described the raid as an act of
"criminal and terrorist aggression".

The attack is another sign that the United States is aggressively launching
military raids across the borders of Afghanistan and Iraq to destroy insurgent
sanctuaries.

It came just days after the commander of US forces in western Iraq said American
troops were redoubling efforts to secure the Syrian border, which he called an
"uncontrolled" gateway for fighters entering Iraq.

A Syrian government statement said eight people were killed, including a man and
his four children and a woman. However, local officials said seven men were
killed and two other people were wounded, including a woman among the injured.

One journalist at the funerals in the village's cemetery saw the bodies of seven
men - none of them children.

Syria's foreign minister Walid al-Muallem was in Britain today and scrapped
plans to hold a joint news conference with British counterpart David Miliband.

Some Iraqi officials warned that the attack could be used by opponents of a
security pact under negotiation with the United States.

"Now neighbouring countries have a good reason to be concerned about the
continued US presence in Iraq," prominent Kurdish politician Mahmoud Othman
said.

The attack came as the flow of foreign fighters into Iraq has been declining.
The area targeted is near the Iraqi border city of Qaim, which had been a major
crossing point for fighters, weapons and money coming into Iraq to fuel the
Sunni insurgency.

Ninety percent of the foreign fighters enter through Syria, according to US
intelligence. Foreigners are some of the most deadly fighters in Iraq, trained
in bomb-making and with small-arms expertise and more likely to be willing
suicide bombers than Iraqis.

                            The Independent (London)

                            October 28, 2008 Tuesday
                                 First Edition

US admits raiding Syria to kill terrorist leader;
Damascus condemns the special forces daylight attack as 'an act of criminal and
terrorist aggression' Iraqi government supports mission but Syria says it will
repulse future attacks to protect its sovereignty

BYLINE: Patrick Cockburn

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 1037 words


Senior US officials claimed last night that the head of a Syrian network
responsible for smuggling foreign fighters, weapons and cash into Iraq had been
killed in Syria during a raid by US special forces that sparked strong
condemnation from Damascus.

The Syrian foreign minister, Walid al-Moualem said the raid had killed eight
civilians and was an act of "criminal and terrorist aggression." Speaking at a
news conference in London, he warned that Damascus would defend itself against
any such future attack.

Sunday's raid, 10km from the Iraqi border, took place in daylight and therefore
was "not a mistake," he said.

The rare attack into Syria marks an unexpected expansion of the war in Iraq and
comes as the level of fighting drops to its lowest level for four years.

"We are taking matters into our own hands," said a US officer in Washington,
confirming that American commandos had entered Syria on Sunday evening to attack
a network of guerrillas linked to al-Qa'ida.

A US counter-terrorism official claimed that the target of the raid was an Iraqi
smuggler called Abu Ghadiya who enabled fighters to cross the Syria-Iraq border.
One official said the man had been killed in the compound which had come under
attack.

He said Abu Ghadiya was the nom de guerre of Badran Turki Hisham al-Mazididih, a
native of Mosul and an aide of al-Qa'ida's Iraqi leader, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi,
who was killed two years ago. The official told the Associated Press that Abu
Ghadiya had been the head of the single most important foreign fighter cell that
had bedevilled Iraq since the US invasion in 2003.

Syria said that four US helicopters had carried out the raid on a construction
site near the Syrian village of Sukkariyeh, 8km from the Iraq border.

Eight men had been killed and two wounded, local officials said. TV images
showed a small fenced farm and a truck riddled with bullet holes. There was also
a building site and a tent with food and blankets. Spent bullets were scattered
around.

In Baghdad the Iraqi government spokesman Ali al-Dabbagh said, justifying the
raid, that it was launched against "terrorist groups operating from Syria
against Iraq", including one which was responsible or the deaths of 13 police
recruits. He said: "Iraq had asked Syria to hand over this group, which uses
Syria as a base for its terrorist activities." It is not clear that the US
informed the Iraqi government before making its attack.

In Sukkariyeh, a villager named Jumad Ahmad al-Hamad said he had seen four
helicopters, two of which landed. "Shooting then started and rang out for 10
minutes." When the helicopters had left, he and other villagers had gone to the
site and found the bodies of his uncle, Dawoud al-Hamad, and four of his uncle's
sons.

The area is near the Syrian border-crossing of Abu Kamal. It is on the Euphrates
river and the main road from Iraq to Syria. It has been used by insurgents
entering Iraq since the US invasion and it is not clear why the US military
decided to attack it now.

Mr al-Moualem, said that Syria would ask the US and Iraq to investigate the
attack. He said that the US charge d'affaires had told the Syrian government she
had "no information".

In response to American charges that al-Qa'ida fighters were still crossing into
Iraq from Syria, Mr al-Moualem said the US had never provided evidence to back
up the claims.

Villagers in Sukkariyeh buried their dead yesterday, chanting anti-American
slogans and carrying banners reading: "Down with Bush and the American enemy."

Iraqi leaders have long maintained that al-Qa'ida could not operate in Syria
without the powerful Syrian intelligence service knowing what they were doing.
Top Iraqi officials say they can confirm this from personal experience because
many of them, such as the prime minister, Nouri al-Maliki, were based for many
years in Syria before the fall of Saddam Hussein in 2003.

Washington initially refused to confirm or deny reports of the attack but,
later, an official told Reuters: "It was a successful operation. He [Ghadiya] is
believed to be dead. He had knowledge of many of the so-called 'rat lines' or
smuggling routes."

President Bush assented to carrying the war against America's enemies in the
Middle East by backing covert cross-border operations in a presidential finding
earlier this year. This secret directive, for which Congress made an outlay of
$300m, promised backing for covert attacks by non-US forces from Lebanon to
Afghanistan.

The timing of the raid is unexpected as Syria has been more co-operative with
the US. In the early stages of the war in Iraq, the Syrian government believed
that if the US succeeded in establishing its hegemony in Baghdad, it would try
to remove the anti-American governments in Syria and Iran.

It also felt that the US and its allies were undermining its position in
Lebanon. But the US failures in Iraq and Syria's stronger position in Lebanon
has meant that Syria is now warier of anti-American insurgent groups in Syria.
In the late 1970s and early 1980s, the Baathist regime was the target of extreme
Sunni fundamentalists. The US and the Iraqi government have made pinprick
attacks against each other in the past.

Syria blamed a bomb attack in Damascus earlier this year on Iraq, saying that
the GMC truck containing the explosives had crossed the border from Iraq. All
Syrian personnel at border posts were dismissed for failing to detect it.
Officially, Syria denies it is a haven for insurgents. The interior minister,
Bassam Abdel Majeed, said Damascus "refuses to be a launching pad for threats
against Iraq."

The US is likely to pay a heavy political price for the cross-border raids in
terms of Syrian and Pakistani anger, but government retaliation is not likely in
either case. A raid into Iran would be different; the Iranians have retaliated
swiftly for attacks on their personnel in Iraq. The raid may also intensify
Iranian hostility to the Iraqi-US Status of Forces Agreement. "It will be used
against the agreement and will give the Iranians reason to increase their
interference against [it]," said the Iraqi political veteran Mahmoud Othman.

"The neighbouring countries now have good reason to be concerned about the US
presence in Iraq."

BYLINE: ROBERT DEX

SECTION: Pg. 9

SYRIAs foreign minister has accused America of carrying out an act of terrorism
after eight people were killed in a raid on a small village.

Eyewitnesses say US military helicopters landed and a soldier attacked
civilians, including children, during the assault near the border with Iraq on
Sunday.

Syrian foreign minister Walid al-Muallem said the attack on the Bou Kamal border
area was no accident.

The Americans do it in the daylight, this means it is not a mistake; its blunt
determination, Walid al-Muallem told a press conference in London yesterday.

confirmed that Syria would ask America and Iraq for an inquiry into the attack.

Miliband but it was agreed he would take to the stage by himself as the

information, he said.

This administration have proved to be irrational and has no respect for
international law or human rights. America would only confirm last night that
the incident took place. Mr Makdissi added: We expect a clarification, and Syria
reserves the right to respond accordingly and in the proper way. Syria has
summoned the US charge daffaires in Damascus to protest.A planned meeting

                                  1ST Edition

Court told airport terror attack accused 'joked about martyrdom'

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 351 words


A COURT has heard that a doctor accused of planning terror attacks said his
co-accused joked about "martyrdom" and was "sympathetic" to insurgents in Iraq.

Taped police interviews in which Dr Mohammed Asha made comments the day after an
attempted car bombing on Glasgow Airport in June last year were shown to a jury
at Woolwich Crown Court.

In the videos, Asha said Dr Bilal Abdulla was "very, very sympathetic" with what
is going on in Iraq.

Asha, 28, and Abdulla, 29, are both on trial accused of conspiracy to murder and
conspiracy to cause explosions.

Yesterday, the court was shown video tapes of four police interviews in which
Asha repeatedly said he knew nothing of the attempted bombings of the airport
and London's West End.

But Asha did admit that Abdulla, from Paisley, had been to his home on several
occasions with another man - Indian student Kafeel Ahmed.

Asha said that, on these visits, Abdulla and Ahmed discussed martyrdom but in a
way that was "very, very playful."

A detective asked: "Did he say to you that he wanted to commit martyrdom?"

Asha replied: "Yes."

The Jordanian doctor also told detectives: "He hasn't mentioned anything
specific but he's always, always talked about Iraq and martyrdom."

Asha said there was no mention of targets and he did not believe his friend was
actually planning an attack.

The court was told the interviews took place before Asha was offered the chance
to speak to a solicitor.

His barrister, Stephen Kamlish QC, accused detectives of denying Asha his
rights.

The jury heard that, once he had taken legal advice, Asha was interviewed a
further four times over 10 days but did not answer any more questions.

Asha was arrested on the M6 motorway on June 30 last year.

Several hours earlier, a Jeep laden with gas canisters and petrol was driven
into Glasgow Airport's main terminal building.

Ahmed was at the wheel and died several weeks later from severe burns.

The jury has been told that Abdulla was in the passenger seat, threw petrol
bombs and fought with police.

Both Asha and Abdulla deny the charges and the trial continues.

Somaliland authorities commence probe into terror attacks

LENGTH: 282 words


Text of report in English entitled "Somaliland police search for clues after
terror attacks" published by Somali pro-Puntland government Garoweonline website
on 30 October

Authorities in Somalia's self declared Republic of Somaliland are searching for
clues following Wednesday's [29 October] triple suicide bombings that killed at
least 23 people, Radio Garowe reported.

More than 35 people were wounded in the separatist region's capital, Hargeysa,
after suicide bombers struck the presidential palace, the UNDP office and the
Ethiopian trade office.

On Thursday, the dead bodies of two Ethiopian nationals were transported back to
their home country.

Abdullahi Ismail Irro, Somaliland's internal affairs minister, told reporters on
Thursday that local police were still searching for clues amongst the wreckage.

He linked the suicide bombings to explosions in April that rocked the parliament
building in Somaliland, a relatively peaceful in Somalia's northwest.

The minister said police had captured suspects, but did not provide a number. He
also stated that some of the suspects were "from south Somalia," where
Islamist-led insurgents are battling Ethiopian-backed government forces.

"They were in Hargeysa for about one week," said the minister, while indicating
that police were searching the suspects' rented home for more evidence.

Security was tightened in and around Hargeysa with hundreds of government
soldiers patrolling city streets and setting up security checkpoints, where
vehicles were searched.

Somaliland declared independence in 1991 after warlords overthrew a 21-year
military dictatorship but has not been recognized internationally.

                          The Guardian - Final Edition

Tenerife terror: Vulture attacks holidaymaker

BYLINE: Helen Pidd

SECTION: GUARDIAN HOME PAGES; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 215 words


She had no doubt taken precautions against sunburn and been warned about
timeshare touts. But nothing could have prepared Mary Corcoran for the attack by
a vulture during her Tenerife holiday.

The 56-year-old from Ipswich told yesterday how she feared she was going to be
eaten alive when the metre-long griffon vulture pinned her to the ground while
she was watching a birds of prey show on the island. She was taken to hospital
for antibiotics and a tetanus jab after the vulture attacked her and a friend,
Teresa Largent, at Tenerife's Jungle Park zoo.

The vulture, which has a wingspan of 2.5 metres (8ft) and weighs between six and
13kg, was eventually punched off by its keeper.

The attack happened on Sunday as the women were watching the show in the park's
arena. "We had been told not to move, so we sat still," Corcoran said yesterday.
"Then the bird went for me, and perched on my shoulder and before I knew it, I
was under it. The keeper came over and got the bird away, but as he was taking
me out of the arena it flew back towards me and the keeper had to thump it
really hard to the ground.

"I was shaking and shaking. I couldn't speak about it for a few days afterwards.
I've never known any shock like it." She said she was hoping to claim
compensation for the zoo's "negligence".

                                  M2 PressWIRE

                            October 31, 2008 Friday

UN: Security Council, in Presidential statement, strongly condemns 'heinous'
terrorist attack on United Nations, government offices in Somalia

LENGTH: 555 words


RDATE:30102008

The Security Council this afternoon condemned in the strongest terms yesterday's
terrorist suicide attacks in Somalia that targeted the United Nations
Development Programme (UNDP) and government offices, causing numerous deaths and
injuries.

Through a statement read out by Zhang Yesui of China, which holds the Council's
presidency for October, Council members also underlined the need to bring to
justice the perpetrators and enablers of what it called "heinous" attacks, which
occurred in the towns of Hargeysa and Bosasso, and appeared to have been
coordinated.

Noting with appreciation that some of the injured were being treated at the
French medical centre in Djibouti, the Council expressed its deepest sympathy to
victims of the attacks and their families.

The meeting, which opened at 12:35 p.m., closed at 12:43 p.m.

Presidential Statement

The full text of the presidential statement (contained in document
S/PRST/2008/41) reads as follows:

"The Security Council condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist suicide
attacks that occurred in the towns of Hargeysa and Bosasso in Somalia, on 29
October 2008. These heinous attacks, which caused numerous deaths and injuries
and appear to have been coordinated, targeted the compound of the United Nations
Development Programme (UNDP) and Ethiopian Government office, as well as local
government offices.

"The Security Council expresses its deepest sympathy and condolences to the
victims of these attacks and to their families, and to the people and
authorities of Somalia and Ethiopia. It notes with appreciation that some of the
victims are being treated at the French medical centre in Djibouti.

"The Security Council commends United Nations personnel for their action on the
ground on Somalia, in support of the Somali population.

"The Security Council underlines the need to bring the perpetrators, organizers,
financiers and sponsors of these reprehensible acts of terrorism to justice and
urges all States, in accordance with their obligations under international law
and resolution 1373 (2001) and consistent with resolution 1624 (2005), to
cooperate actively with the authorities of Somalia in this regard.

"The Security Council reaffirms that terrorism in all its forms and
manifestations constitutes one of the most serious threats to international
peace and security, and that any acts of terrorism are criminal and
unjustifiable, regardless of their motivation, wherever, whenever and by
whomsoever committed.

"The Security Council further reaffirms the need to combat by all means, in
accordance with the Charter of the United Nations, threats to international
peace and security caused by terrorist acts. The Council reminds States that
they must ensure that any measures taken to combat terrorism comply with all
their obligations under international law, in particular international human
rights, refugee and humanitarian law.

"The Security Council reiterates its determination to combat all forms of
terrorism, in accordance with its responsibilities under the Charter of the
United Nations."

                            Nottingham Evening Post

                            October 31, 2008 Friday

Maggie scoops £100,000 of competition prizes;
A Woman hurt in the London terrorist attacks has found an unusual way to afford
the finer things in life after she was left unable to work.

BYLINE: SARAH FIRTH

SECTION: Pg. 17

LENGTH: 445 words


Maggie Bermann, of Newthorpe, has enjoyed exotic holidays and luxury goods
thanks to the huge number of competitions she enters.

This month alone, the passionate 'comper' has won a boxset of the Mummy films,
Girls Aloud T-shirts, tickets to Legoland, a Barry M make-up set and a Guitar
Hero game for the Nintendo DS.

The former nurse fell and damaged her knee and back while helping injured people
in the panic following the July 2005 attacks.

Over the years she has won more than £100,000 worth of prizes through entering
competitions online and sending off postcards.

She said: "I enter about 1,000 competitions a month. I spend about an hour and
half a day doing it.

"It's fun - it's sort of my hobby.

Maggie, 45, is happy with even the smallest prize.

She said: "I really enjoy it and I'm pleased with anything I win. Even if it's a
fridge magnet I still get excited."

But Maggie said the credit crunch has caused other people to jump on the freebie
bandwagon.

"Since the economic downturn  the wins have started to taper off, as more people
are doing it," she said.

Maggie uses the website theprizefinder.com to help her hunt out prizes.

This year the site has seen a 25% jump in the number of people trying their
luck.

But few are  likely to be as enthusiastic as Maggie.

Maggie began 'comping' in 2001 but stepped up a gear after she was forced to
leave her job.

Her biggest win was a £50,000 luxury holiday to Dubai and Thailand from the
Radio Times, a competition she entered after husband Jeff said he would like to
visit the Arab state.

She said: "It was out of this world. In Dubai we stayed in the only seven-star
hotel and had a butler."

Maggie has also won a family holiday to Mexico, luxury UK breaks and
top-of-the-range electrical goods.

But her most prized possession, as an avid fan of boy band Blue, is a platinum
disc of band member Simon Webbe's debut solo album.

Maggie regularly meets up with other Notts compers to compare wins.

She said: "We are quite competitive with each other too. If someone else has won
a competition you've entered then you really want to win it as well."

Maggie said the group helps to keep her motivated when she goes through spells
without any wins.

"Even my postman is disappointed if he doesn't have a package for me," she said.

"When I get one he stays while I open it to see what it is."

But Maggie said the best thing about her competition addiction was being able to
treat her family.

She has two  sons, Scott, 21, and Andy, 14, and a daughter, 11-year-old Heather.

Maggie said: "To me comping means being able to give friends and family things I
could never otherwise afford, as I don't work anymore."
