                                  1ST Edition

TEEN IN ROCKET ATTACK TERROR;
Campaigner Kirk becomes victim

BYLINE: BRYAN BROUGH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 405 words


A TEENAGER who is leading a campaign to save young lives by highlighting the
dangers of fireworks was left terrified when he was targeted in a rocket attack.

Youth activist Kris Sinclair was given the fright of his life when thugs
launched a firework at him from the window of a car as they drove by.

The 19-year-old is no stranger to the dangers posed by fireworks as he is
involved in creating a safety video for the Renfrewshire Youth Voice community
group.

But he admits he never expected to become a victim himself. Kris said: "It was
horrific and I'm still in a state of shock.

"I could easily have suffered terrible injuries. It's frightening that the
people who carry out attacks such as this obviously don't realise the damage
they could do.

"Sadly, I now know what it's like to be the victim of a firework attack and I
don't want anyone else to go through what I've had to suffer."

Kris, whose work to create a firework safety podcast is supported by Strathclyde
Fire and Rescue, was attacked as he walked along a busy road.

The teenager was near Woodlands Crescent, at its jucntion with Beith Road, in
Johnstone, when a red car with three young people inside pulled up beside him.

To his horror, a rocket was launched at him and it landed at his feet.

Kris, from Johnstone, said: "It was about 10.30pm and the street was quiet when,
all of a sudden, I saw a tube-like rocket being thrown from a passing car.

"I panicked because I thought it was going to explode in my face.

"The rocket blasted open and two smaller rocket-type missiles shot out of it and
whizzed past me.

"It's amazing that I didn't suffer a nasty injury. Rockets like these can be
lethal."

Kris, who plans to broadcast his firework safety video on the YouTube website,
added: "I'm horrified by what happened to me.

"I have put hundreds of hours of voluntary work into helping make the firework
season safer for young people and other people in the community and now I've
become a victim."

Police have vowed to step up patrols between now and the end of Bonfire Night in
a bid to prevent mindless yobs from targeting people with fireworks.

A spokesperson said: "Fireworks can cause appalling injuries if used without
care. We see evidence of that every year.

"The best way to enjoy fireworks is to attend a display that is run by expert
staff. If anyone is planning to set off their own fireworks, they should handle
these with caution."

A pitbull mauled my staffie, too;
SAVAGED PETS: Terror dog matches description of Star's attacker

BYLINE: By Emma Chown

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 297 words


A COVENTRY woman believes a pitbull which viciously attacked a woman's dog is
the same one which savagely mauled her own dog.

Last week the Coventry Telegraph reported how Valerie O'Brian's dog, an
eight-year-old collie, was attacked in the War Memorial Park on October 17.

Christine Wood believes her dog, an 11-year-old staffie, Star, was attacked
eight months ago in a similar way by the same mottled brown-coloured bitch.

Retired Christine, aged 60, who lives in Henley Green, said: "The attack
happened by the side of my bungalow. My partner Jack had taken Star for a walk
along the walkway from Henley Green to Potters Green before the pitbull ran
after Star. Jack had Star on the lead - unlike the pitbull who was free to run
around.

"The pitbull latched on to my dog's head and attacked him. The woman that was
walking the bitch with another man was screaming, saying 'She's never done this
before!' "There was blood everywhere, it looked liked a murder had taken place.

"After the attack I rang the police but they said I needed to find the dog and
its owner. I would be interested to see if there is any CCTV footage of
Valerie's dog being attacked in the War Memorial Park so I could confirm that it
was the same dog, but the description fits exactly."

Star has been left with scars and wounds and needed several stitches in an
operation at a veterinary surgery after the attack.

Christine described the owner as a young man, aged about 26, who was walking
with a woman aged about 25.

She said: "I agree with Valerie, dog walkers need to be made aware of this
highly dangerous dog and his owner, I just hope he can be found because next
time the attack could be even worse."

Contact Chace Avenue police station on 0845 1135000 with information about the
incident or the pitbull owner.

                             Daily Record (PM) - UK

                            November 4, 2008 Tuesday
                                Tayside Edition

HE THREATENED TO KILL PAL FOR PLAYING GUITAR;
Ex-flatmate tells of row with airport terror attack accused

BYLINE: Chris Greenwood

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 337 words


A MAN accused of trying to blow up Glasgow airport threatened to kill a flatmate
for playing the guitar, a court heard yesterday.

Devout Muslim Bilal Abdulla allegedly told him to "stop playing and start
praying".

Former friend Shiraz Maher told Woolwich Crown Court the exchange took place at
a flat in Cambridge in 2005.

The pair were students at the time and were working on computers when a third
man started to play guitar in another room.

Mr Maher said Abdulla gestured towards a violent video of an ambush of an
American Humvee vehicle in Iraq on his computer.

He said: "He made reference to one of those grisly, very grisly videos that
would come out of Iraq at that time.

"He said, 'I told him, you need to stop playing and start praying otherwise this
is what we do - we slaughter."' He added: "Immediately after saying it, Bilal
laughed heartily and I remember laughing as well.

"The reason it stayed so vividly in my memory was the degree to which it was
disproportionate." Mr Maher explained some strict Muslims would view string
instruments as "completely forbidden within Islam".

Abdulla, 29, is on trial with a second man, Mohammed Asha, 28, accused of
conspiracy to murder and to cause explosions. The two men, who worked as doctors
at hospitals in Glasgow and Stoke, deny the offences.

Abdulla drove one of two Mercedes car bombs to London's west end in June 2007,
the court has heard.

The next day, he was the passenger in a Jeep Cherokee, laden with gas cylinders
and petrol, that was rammed into Glasgow airport. His friend Kafeel Ahmed, who
drove the Jeep and died after the attack, had lived in the same Cambridge
property.

Yesterday, Mr Maher said Abdulla was the "dominant personality".

He also told the jury that Abdulla held extremist views and supported attacks on
the minority Shia population in Iraq.

He said one of Abdulla's friends had been murdered by Shia militia.

Mr Maher said:"For me, that seemed to put into context his real loathing of the
Shia."

The trial continues.

Ethiopian police arrest suspects on "terrorist attacks" mission

Addis Ababa, 5 November: The Joint Task Force of National Intelligence Security
Service and the Federal Police said it has detained leaders of the Oromo

group, has been operating to carry out terrorist attacks in the town under the
guise of religion.

The leaders of Kawerj are kept in custody with their documents and weapons.

                             Paisley Daily Express

                           November 6, 2008 Thursday
                                  1ST Edition

'Terror attack' fireball claim

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 310 words


GAS cylinders allegedly used in an attack on Glasgow Airport would have created
a "large fireball" had they exploded, a court heard yesterday.

The jury at Woolwich Crown Court was told that if the canisters, which were
packed in a Jeep, had blown up, strips of metal, nails and screws would have
been fired over a wide area.

Instead, the containers burned like "blowtorches", making them hard for fire
crews to extinguish, jurors were told.

The evidence was led during the trial of Paisley man Dr Bilal Abdulla, 29, and
Dr Mohammed Asha, 28, who deny conspiracy to murder.

The pair, both employed by the NHS, also deny charges of causing explosions
relating to the airport attack last summer.

Jurors heard evidence from a forensic scientist David Halliday, who studied the
remains of the Jeep Cherokee used in the alleged plot.

Mr Halliday said that, among other items, he found 10 petrol bombs crafted from
soft-drink bottles and NHS sheets and pillows which had been ripped up to act as
wicks.

He added that the items smelled strongly of petrol and contained a small
quantity of liquid, which was part petrol, part water and a small amount of oil.

Mr Halliday also inspected four liquid petroleum gas canisters after the
incident.

He found only the top of the cylinders had been fully exposed to fire and,
therefore, had not exploded, the court heard.

Mr Halliday said: "Clearly, in the circumstances that prevailed in Glasgow
Airport, the presence of propane cylinders has contributed to the severity of
fire.

"It is possible in some circumstances for propane cylinders to burst in a fire.

"The effects of that are that the cylinders rupture, breaking into one or more
large piece that is projected a considerable distance.

"The vapour cloud is mixed with air, which ignites and forms a large fireball."

The trial is expected to continue today.

                             The Observer (London)

                                November 9, 2008

Home: News: Police warn of growing threat from eco-terrorists: Fear of deadly
attack by lone maverick as officers alert major firms to danger of green
extremism

BYLINE: Mark Townsend and Nick Denning

SECTION: OBSERVER HOME PAGES; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 947 words


POLICE HAVE warned of the growing threat of eco-terrorism after revealing they
are investigating a group which has supporters who believe that reducing the
Earth's population by four-fifths will help to protect the planet.

Officers from a specialist unit dedicated to tackling domestic terrorism are
monitoring an eco-movement called Earth First! which has advocates who state
that cutting the Earth's population by 80 per cent will ease pressure on other
species. Officers are concerned a 'lone maverick' eco-extremist may attempt a
terrorist attack aimed at killing large numbers of Britons.

The National Extremism Tactical Co-ordination Unit, which collates intelligence
and advice to police forces, has revealed that eco-activists are researching a
list of target companies which they believe are major polluters or are
exacerbating the threat of climate change.

The unit is currently monitoring blogs and internet traffic connected to a
network of UK climate camps and radical environmental movements under the
umbrella of Earth First!, which has claimed responsibility for a series of
criminal acts in recent months.

A senior source at the unit said it had growing evidence of a threat from
eco-activists. 'We have found statements that four-fifths of the human
population has to die for other species in the world to survive.

'There are a number of very dedicated individuals out there and they could be
dangerous to other people.'

Earth First! says its mission is 'about direct action to halt the destruction of
the Earth' and advocates 'civil disobedience and monkeywrenching', tactics that
include sabotage and disruptive behaviour. The movement has links to US
environmental extremists which have waged a campaign of violence in America,
including the firebombing of a string of 4x4 car dealerships in California in
2003 and alleged arson attacks on other property.

The anti-extremist unit has already alerted a number of major companies which
have been accused of being carbon polluters with advice on how they can
withstand being targeted by eco-terrorists. Companies are thought to include
airport operator BAA an, international mining conglomerate BHP Billiton and
firms connected to UK coal-fired power stations.

'They are doing research of possible targets, looking at shareholders and
financiers. For example, they could research an airline and see how many of its
aircraft are not environmentally friendly,' said the NETCU source.

Although green extremists have yet to embark on an orchestrated campaign of
violence in the UK, officers warn that they may be about to launch a campaign of
intimidation and fear aimed at disrupting businesses. 'For some people, if they
can justify it in their minds, then it's a noble cause even if it's a criminal
action. They haven't started yet, but we believe they will come up with a
strategy and tactics,' said the source at the unit, who described the movement
as well-funded and organised.

A spate of recent attacks, for which Earth First! supporters have claimed
responsibility, has included vandalism of branches of seven German banks such as
Deutsche Bank and Allianz AG. The actions were apparently because the banks hold
shares in UK Coal, which plans to build new coal-fired power stations.

A statement on the Earth First! website explains the attacks by saying:
'Exploitation of the environment and people by the state and industry go hand in
hand. They cannot be separated and both must be attacked. Social war, not
climate chaos.'

Another attack hit a quarry in Staffordshire which belongs to Bardon Aggregates,
a company hat also owns a controversial quarry at Glensanda on the north-west
coast of Scotland. The Scottish quarry is accused of spoiling the Highlands
environment. The Earth First! website states: 'We slashed tyres, stripped paint
jobs, glued locks and trashed conveyor belts. All the earth movers were hit and
many of the cement and aggregate trucks. This action cost us very little but
should cost Bardon thousands.'

Among the network of groups under the Earth First! umbrella are various climate
camps. Last August police found a stash of knives and weapons beside one such
camp in Kent. Protesters, however, said they had nothing to do with the weapons
and accused police of launching a 'smear campaign'.

A spokesman for Derby Earth First! said the movement was strictly non-violent,
if not always law-abiding. He said: 'If someone does ecological damage we would
perhaps break the law and protect the ecology, but the ecology also includes
humans.

'We're all about communities. Capitalism is the problem and we want to return to
a more sustainable time. But we are not about reducing the population, that is
just scaremongering by the police.'

The rise of eco-extremism coincides with the fall of the animal rights activ ist
movement. Police said the animal rights movement was in 'disarray' and that its
ringleaders had either been prosecuted or were awaiting prosecution, adding that
its 'critical mass' of hardcore extremists was sufficiently depleted to have
halted its effectiveness. Last Thursday a prominent animal rights activist
accused of planting petrol bombs at Oxford University was cleared of possessing
an explosive substance with intent.

Reports on the Earth First! Journal website, which tells users how to send
encrypted emails, reveals connections to the Earth Liberation Front (ELF) which
has been linked to a series of violent attacks in the US. ELF was classified as
the top domestic terrorism threat in the US by the FBI in March 2001.

The ELF was founded in 1992 in Brighton by members of the Earth First! movement
who wanted to form a breakaway group that would use more extreme tactics.

                                   Daily Star

                            November 10, 2008 Monday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

ENEMY WITHIN!;
Thousands of Brit terrorists ready to attack

BYLINE: by EMMA WALL

SECTION: NEWS; 2

LENGTH: 233 words


THOUSANDS of fanatics in Britain are planning a series of massacres, it was
claimed last night.

The terrorists have formed alQaida cells in London, Birmingham and Luton, a
leaked document has warned.

Most of them are between 18 and 30 and were born in the UK but trained at
foreign terror camps.

They have been taught about explosives, increasing the danger of "spectacular"
attacks in crowded places.

The report was drawn up by the Ministry of Defence, MI5 and Special Branch.

It states: "For the foreseeable future the UK will continue to be a
high-priority target for international terrorists aligned with al-Qaida.

"It will face a threat from British nationals, including Muslim converts, and
UK-based foreign terrorists, as well as terrorists planning attacks from
abroad." The Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre reckons there are "some thousands
of extremists in the UK committed to supporting Jihadi activities, either in the
UK or abroad".

They fear the terrorists could target airports and train stations, like Tube
suicide bomber Mohammed Siddique Khan did.

The threat to Britain is so great MI5 has almost doubled its staff since 2001 to
3,500 and set up nine regional offices.

Tory MP Patrick Mercer, highlighted the threat and warned: "The fact that we
have not been attacked for over two years should not be taken by anyone as
evidence that the threat has gone away, in fact it is just the contrary."

                            The Independent (London)

                           November 11, 2008 Tuesday
                                 First Edition

Suicide attack brings terror to the school run in Iraq;
* Co-ordinated bombs kill at least 28 in Baghdad attack on schoolgirls' minibus

BYLINE: Patrick Cockburn

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 484 words


Suicide bombers first attacked a bus full of schoolgirls in central Baghdad
yesterday and then detonated a second bomb in the middle of a crowd of rescuers,
killing at least 28 people and wounding 66 others.

"I rushed to the site and saw several schoolgirls trapped in a bus, screaming
for help," said Abbas Fadhil, standing in a blood-soaked shirt outside the
damaged restaurant where he worked. "We got the girls out of the bus, and rushed
them to hospital."

The two explosions took place within seconds of each other during the morning
rush hour in the mostly Shia Kasrah section of the al-Adhamiyah district. They
have the hallmarks of an al-Qa'ida attack. Security in the Iraqi capital, having
improved in the first half of 2007 and the first half of 2008, has deteriorated
in recent weeks.

Shoes belonging to the girls were scattered in the wreckage of the minibus, on a
floor soaked in blood. Many students from the nearby fine arts institute were
also killed or wounded when they were caught by the blast as they ate breakfast
in nearby cafes. "This is a criminal act that targeted innocent people who were
heading to work and school, while politicians are busy with their personal greed
and ambitions," said Abbas Fadhil.

In Diyala province north east of Baghdad, which has seen some of the worst
atrocities in the war, a woman suicide bomber meanwhile killed five people and
wounded 15 yesterday, when she blew herself up at a security checkpoint in
Baquba, the provincial capital. Sectarian killings are well below their level of
two years ago - when 3,000 Sunni and Shia were being slaughtered every month.
But the Iraqi capital is still wholly divided between the two communities, with
few mixed areas remaining. Particularly horrendous attacks, such as those on
Shia school children, could ignite a fresh wave of tit-for-tat murders.

There are army and police checkpoints every few hundred yards in Baghdad leading
to near gridlock in traffic. But individual suicide bombers are almost
impossible to stop and al-Qa'ida in Iraq still has an extensive network capable
of recruiting and equipping bombers in the city. There have also been a series
of assassination attempts on senior officials. So far, however, large numbers of
police and soldiers on the streets have been able to prevent the return of
massive truck bombs, often containing a ton or more of explosives, being
detonated in Shia areas. A new difficulty facing the government is the fall in
the price of crude oil on which the state is wholly dependent. Iraq had been
expecting oil revenue of almost $80bn for 2008, but this will be much lower now
the price of oil is down to $64 a barrel. With total government expenditure at
some $50bn, this means the government may be short of $10bn to $15bn next year.
Earlier this year the government was doubling the salaries of government
employees, as if the high price of oil would be permanent.

LOAD-DATE: November 10, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: IA

                               Leicester Mercury

                           November 11, 2008 Tuesday

Inventions can help stop terror attacks

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 234 words


Scientists have invented a  device that could help prevent terror attacks by
identifying tiny explosive particles on people, clothing and luggage.

The Explosive Residue Detection System can remotely scan crowded areas  alerting
an operator if it detects traces of explosive chemicals invisible to the naked
eye.

It has been developed by Professor John Tyrer, from Loughborough University's
Wolfson School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, and colleagues from
the department of chemistry.

It uses pulsed lasers and video camera techniques to produce scanning beams.

If explosive residue is detected, the system activates automatically and alerts
an operator to a positive identification.

The ERD is being field tested in ports, airports and railway stations in secret
locations across the country.

Prof Tyrer said it does not rely on people watching a TV screen, like
conventional airport security and is more accurate than sniffer dogs.

He said: "I recognised a number of years ago that there was a need for trying to
determine whether or not people were handling explosives.

"Being able to see explosive residue on people would have obvious and
significant security benefits, if we could do it.

"When you handle an explosive the chemicals and various constituents, such as
the Semtex or TNT, leave traces on your fingers and clothes.  The challenge was
being able to see those particles, and those alone."

TERROR COPS PROBE TGV RAIL ATTACKS;
FRANCE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 23

LENGTH: 114 words


FRENCH anti-terrorist police have launched an urgent inquiry after a series of
attacks on high-speed train lines in the country.

Thousands of lives - including those of British tourists - have been put at
risk. The investigation comes after a 100mph TGV train ploughed into concrete
blocks placed on a rail line in southern France on Sunday.

The driver managed to safely halt the train. Two days earlier, vandals rammed an
iron rod into 25,000-volt power cables on the Paris-to-London Eurostar line.
There have been three similar incidents in the past month.

Interior Minister Michele Alliot-Marie has ordered a probe into the "potential
terrorist sabotage" of the national rail network.

                              Daily Mail (London)

                          November 12, 2008 Wednesday
                                  SC1 Edition

Terror attack accused 'had tried to join British Army';
Airport trial doctor tells of 'love' for UK

BYLINE: Chris Greenwood

SECTION: Pg. 7

LENGTH: 722 words


AN Iraqi doctor accused of trying to launch a terror campaign by carrying out
car bomb attacks in Glasgow and London had tried to join the British Army, a
court heard yesterday.

Dr Bilal Abdulla, 29, said he loved the UK and while studying in England had
volunteered to fight for the country.

'I tried to join the British Army,' he told yesterday's hearing at Woolwich
Crown Court in London. I visited the local Army offices in Cambridge and talked
to the colonel there. But in the end we could not reach a conclusion.' Speaking
for the first time in his own defence,

Abdulla told the jury he was born in Britain, held a British passport and
studied at university here.

But he said the fighting and aftermath of the second Gulf War left him shocked
at the brutality of Western governments and led to him backing insurgent attacks
on Allied forces in Iraq.

Abdulla, who lived and worked at the Royal Alexandra Hospital in Paisley,
Renfrewshire, fought back tears as he described the effect of sanctions on Iraq,
with shortages of basic medicines.

He also said he hated the American government and was shocked that British
soldiers failed to stop Shia Muslims driving the majority Sunni population out
of Basra.

Abdulla is accused of attempting to murder hundreds of people by leaving mobile
phone- detonated car bombs outside a nightclub in London's West End.

When the vehicles, packed with gas, petrol and nails, failed to detonate, he
joined a suicide attack on Glasgow Airport the next day, the prosecution said.

The driver of the Jeep Cherokee which was rammed into the terminal building,
Kafeel Ahmed, 28, later died from burns he suffered in the attack.

Abdulla is on trial with a second doctor, Mohammed Asha, 28, accused of
conspiracy to murder and to cause explosions. They deny the offences.

Yesterday, Abdulla told the court he was born in Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire,
when his father was training as a doctor in a local hospital and his mother
worked as a pharmacist.

He travelled to Iraq when he was four years old and his next journey abroad was
to Jordan, 15 years later, to claim a British passport.

Abdulla said the Iraq-Iran war, 1991 Iraq war, subsequent United Nations
sanctions and 2003 Gulf War, left the country in ruins.

'I did not want to stay in Iraq because of the oppression of the regime, and
British citizenship was a good exit from that regime,' he said.

Abdulla, who came from a large, highly educated, religiously moderate and
middle-class family, described how they fled Baghdad at the start of the 1991
war as massive bombs killed 400 people in one strike on a nuclear bunker.

'Baghdad had been one of the most beautiful cities in the Middle East and it was
a ruin,' he said.

Asked how that war changed his view of the West, he said: 'It was the views of
the middle class of the country.

'All the educated people there were shocked. People who were educated in the
West understood the standards and Western values and they were shocked.

'To be honest, most of the people in Iraq are educated in the UK, so they gave
most of the blame to the U.S. They gave the credit to the UK.

'It was the younger brother of the U.S. and the U.S. did everything, so most
people directed their criticism at the U.S.' Speaking about the aftermath of the
2003 Iraq war, Abdulla said he supported U.S. forces coming to Iraq because he
wanted to see 'reform and change'.

But he then claimed to have seen 'discrimination' as the Americans sided with
the Shias. He said the country descended into chaos and lawlessness, with no
water or electricity and gangsters running amok.

He said: 'We knew the Americans were here for one reason, we knew that they were
here for the petrol in Iraq, and we were happy: "Take the petrol, take whatever
you want, fix the country and the price is worth it." 'I would say if you take
petrol and you topple Saddam, the price is worth it. But the Americans did not
do that. They destroyed the infrastructure and they did not rebuild it.' Asked
by his barrister, Jim Sturman QC, if he supported the Sunni resistance, Abdulla
said: 'Definitely, I looked high upon those fighting the invaders. I supported
the insurgency.' Asked what his feelings were towards people in Britain, he
said: 'I did not have any hatred towards any individual person anywhere in this
country or other countries.' The trial continues today..

                           November 13, 2008 Thursday

Afghan paper hails US attacks on "sources of terrorism" in Pakistan

LENGTH: 748 words


Text of article by Jaghori in Dari, "Change in geography of war is to benefit of
Afghanistan", published by Afghan independent secular daily newspaper Hasht-e
Sobh on 11 November

The change in the geography of war from Afghanistan to Pakistan and the new
strategy by the Pakistani authorities in their fight against Taleban has changed
the status of war in Afghanistan.

The level of major organized attacks by the Taleban has fallen in recent weeks.
The Taleban have instead adopted a new approach of seeking shelter among people
in villages.

The fall in Taleban attacks in volatile areas does not mean the war has ended
and the government has retained control of the areas - the current situation can
very well indicate that the sources of terrorism are under pressure.

For the first time in the past seven years, tribal areas have changed to a
battlefield between Taleban and Pakistani troops and scene of attacks by
unmanned American planes.

Though the Pakistani authorities used to oppose any attack in their country, it
seems following [recent political] changes in that country a secret unannounced
agreement has been made between America and Pakistan.

There can be two reasons why Pakistan has not shown a serious and firm reaction
to attacks by American unmanned planes.

First, America has convinced Pakistan that the war on terror cannot succeed
unless the sources of terror are targeted and that Pakistan will face such
attacks whether it agrees to it or not.

That is why Pakistani authorities have remained silent about the attacks - a
sign of consent to the attacks.

The new anti-terror strategy adopted by Pakistani authorities can be the other
reason [for Pakistan's agreement to attacks on terrorist bases.]

Pakistan had, in the previous years, changed to a safe haven for Taleban and
Al-Qa'idah, but the emergence of the Pakistani Taleban as a power in tribal
areas evoked [more] concerns in that country.

The rise in suicide attacks and attacks on the safest parts [of Pakistan] like
the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad, abduction of political figures and the spread
of Taleban influence in big cities of Pakistan convinced Pakistani authorities
to adopt a new approach.

It is not only that the government of Pakistan has kept silent about the US air
strikes, but it is also trying to introduce some changes in its relations with
Afghanistan.

The meeting of the mini peace jerga and [the recent] visits by Afghan and
Pakistani authorities in an atmosphere clear of accusations and political
tensions are the new signs of cooperation in the war on terror and regional
cooperation.

The new approach can undoubtedly be considered a new step and chapter in
relations between the two countries.

The main factor for worsening of relations [between Afghanistan and Pakistan]
and insecurity in Afghanistan has been said to be the fact that Pakistan has
used the Taleban as a tool [to disrupt situation in Afghanistan].

Pakistan has now realized that it needs to fight the Taleban in order to restore
stability in that country. That is why it has given consent to air strikes
against Taleban bases.

What is important for Afghanistan is the change in the geography of war and the
response for frequent calls by Afghan authorities asking for the main sources of
terrorism to be targeted.

Mr Karzai and other Afghan authorities have several times pointed out the issue.
In his recent remarks too, Hamed Karzai reiterated it was necessary to target
the main sources of terrorism as part of the war on terror.

One can therefore say the war in Waziristan and [Pakistani] tribal areas is
close to what the government of Afghanistan wants because it has helped reduce
the war in Afghanistan.

The recent incidents in the country show that the Taleban are not as strong and
capable as they were in the past.

The change in the Taleban's approach and the fact that they have resorted to new
tactics is also a result of the existing pressure on the group.

The important question is whether or not the coalition member countries have
reached harmony with themselves. Most of the NATO-member countries have
unfortunately paid less attention to the issue in the past seven years and some
of them have had very good relations with Pakistan.

The change in the US leadership and the promises by [Barack] Obama saying that
Afghanistan will be a priority have increased hopes that the change in the
geography of war and attacks on sources of terrorism will continue as a new
strategy.

Source: Hasht-e Sobh, Kabul, in Dari 11 Nov 08

TUBE WONT COPE WITH TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: FRED ATTEWILL

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 213 words


BASIC safety measures to save lives on the Tube remain undone more than three
years after the 7/7 atrocities, the home secretary was told yesterday.

Emergency water, first-aid equipment and instructions on what to do in an attack
are still lacking on London Underground, Conservative MP Patrick Mercer said.

The former shadow homeland security minister pleaded with home secretary Jacqui
Smith to remedy the situation when she appeared before the Commons home affairs
select committee.

Mr Mercer said travelling on the Underground was as dangerous as 2005 when 52
commuters died on July 7 as bombs exploded on three Tubes and above ground on a
bus.

He said: On the Tube, the Airwaves (radio) system is still not yet complete.
There are no dressing stations. There is no emergency water.

There are no instructions on what to do in the event of an emergency. There are
no rehearsals. There is no first aid equipment.

There are no longer any dog patrols. There is no detection equipment... all of
which exist to a greater or lesser extent on underground systems in other parts
of the world. But Ms Smith said some of the measures are in place, some secret
and some ongoing. She said: I take this extremely seriously.I accept that thats
an area, as are others, of potential vulnerability.

                                 Worcester News

                            November 14, 2008 Friday

Arson attack family relive night of terror

SECTION: LATEST (WN NEWS LATEST)

LENGTH: 371 words


THE family of a man killed in an arson attack have spoken for the first time
about their terror as the house filled with smoke.

Roseann Perkins, formerly of the Glade, Malvern, managed to escape the fire with
her 17-year-old daughter Katie and two sons, Ben, aged 18, and Shaun, 22.

Her husband Richard Perkins, 37, died in the house.

Mrs Perkins, who is now staying with family in Upton-upon-Severn, recounted the
horrendous events that took place in the early hours of Monday, October 13.

She said: "I remember Katie screaming, saying the house was on fire. I thought
she was in the other room but I realised that she was standing next to my bed.
Basically, it was just a panic from there.

"I shook my husband but he wouldn't wake up and my thoughts automatically turned
to the kids.

"I told Katie to crawl on the floor because of the smoke. I remember Ben jumping
out of the window. Katie was crying 'mum, mum, I love you'."

Neighbours, alerted by the noise, rushed over to the house and placed ladders to
the windows, helping the family escape.

Mrs Perkins, who suffered severe smoke inhalation, remembers standing outside
the house as the flames quickly devoured the upstairs rooms.

"I knew my husband had already passed away," she said.

Former Chase student Katie also suffered severe smoke inhalation as well as
burns on her hands from holding onto a plastic window frame as it was melted by
the heat.

Both Katie and her mother were kept alive on ventilators at Worcestershire Royal
Hospital, while Ben was also treated for smoke inhalation and Shaun escaped with
minor injuries.

Mrs Perkins described the days spent in a critical condition without news of her
daughter's condition.

She said: "I did not even know how Katie was doing. I didn't see her for 10 or
11 days. No one would tell me about Richard but I knew he had passed away."

Only in the last two weeks have they broken the news to Katie that Richard died
in the fire.

Mrs Perkins said: "He was always doing stuff with them. Katie was his favourite
and he spoilt her. It was the perfect father-daughter relationship."

Katie's persistent cough and croaky voice attest to the damage the smoke did to
her Her family also say she has become more withdrawn since leaving hospital.

                                  Sunday Life

                               November 16, 2008
                                  Main Edition

Terror attacks hit both sides of the community;
Republican and loyalist 'micro-groups' are behind the latest spate of firebomb
attacks on Orange Halls and GAA clubhouses - and there is no sign of any let-up
in their tit-for-tat campaign, writes Crime Correspondent STEPHEN BREEN

BYLINE: Crime Correspondent STEPHEN BREEN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 586 words


RENEGADE republican and loyalist terrorists last night vowed to continue
fire-bombing Orange halls and GAA clubs across Ulster.

Senior security sources told Sunday Life the shadowy 'Orange Volunteers' and the
Real IRA are set to step up their campaign of terror after masterminding the
recent spate of tit-for-tat attacks.

The latest incident happened in the early of hours of last Friday morning when
an Orange Hall at Bawn, near Pomeroy, was damaged after an explosive device
caused damage to the roof of the premises.

Just a few days before the attack in Pomeroy, the Fr Rocks GAA club in Cookstown
was destroyed after an arson attack.

And a week before the petrol-bombing of the popular GAA club, two Orange Halls
were targeted in the Coagh and Pomeroy areas of Co Tyrone.

Security sources believe the dissident terror groups - believed to be small in
number - will continue with the fire-bomb attacks over the coming months.

And there are fears the terrorists could target individual members of the Orange
Order and the GAA after vowing to step up their campaign of violence.

Said one security source: "These groups are small in number, but they have
members who are ruthless.

"The police know all about them, but they often slip through the net to launch
such attacks.

"These people are determined to return Northern Ireland to the bad old days and
that's why they are committing these senseless attacks.

"It's only a matter of time before they target individual members and people
have to be vigilant."

Police have also vowed to step up patrols in Tyrone after vowing to beat the
bigots. Sunday Life knows the name of the shadowy terror group's leader, but
cannot publish it for legal reasons.

A spokesman for the Orange Volunteers attempted to justify attacks on the GAA
halls.

He said: "Our culture is being eroded on a daily basis and we are sending out a
message that this will not be tolerated. A lot of GAA clubs support republican
terrorism with their clubs named after IRA men and, if their people attack our
culture, then we will hit back.

"If the attacks on Orange Halls stop, then we will refrain from further attacks.
But if they can continue and our people are attacked, then we will not sit back
and take it."

A Real IRA spokesman warned the group would retaliate against loyalists if GAA
clubs or members were targeted by extremist loyalist groups.

He added: "If these people continue to attack innocent nationalists, then they
should know that it's only matter of time before it comes to their own door.

"Unlike other republicans, we will not take this intimidation lying down. If we
have to take the war to these small loyalist groups, then we will do so without
reservation."

The grand secretary of the Orange Order, Drew Nelson, said dissident groups were
using the attacks to "create instability" in the community. He said: "They are
using both the GAA and Orange Order to do that.

"The judiciary is sending out the wrong message when they are allowing people to
walk away from attacks - which have the potential to create community division -
with community service orders."

Tyrone GAA board chairman Pat Darcy condemned the attacks: "GAA clubs are used
by everyone in the community and I would also condemn attacks on Orange Halls
because they are also used by the community."

Culture Minister Gregory Campbell hit out at the recent attacks, adding: "These
people are morons.

"There will be a response by the community and those who attack the halls for
whatever mischievous reason will see that it has backfired."

I AM A TERRORIST, ADMITS AIRPORT ATTACK BOMBER

BYLINE: MILES ERWIN

SECTION: Pg. 27

LENGTH: 237 words


AN NHS doctor accused of launching an attack on Glasgow airport admitted
yesterday that he was a terrorist.

Bilal Abdulla told a court that, according to English law, as he had been
arrested under the terrorism act, he was a terrorist.

That is my aim, to change opinion using violence, using fire devices, he said.
That is my case in a nutshell. I am told I am a terrorist but is your government
not a terrorist, is your army not a terrorist?

The 29-year-old Iraqi said he made the admission to police after the failed bid
to ram a 4x4 packed with petrol and gas canisters into the terminal building.

But he insisted he was planning to flee Britain after similar failed attacks in
Londons West End when driver Kafeel Ahmed suddenly swerved into the airport.

I got alarmed and I shouted: What are you doing?, he said.

Abdulla admitted throwing petrol bombs after the car became stuck but said it
was only to stop himself catching fire. The junior doctor is accused of
launching the attack with Mohammed Asha, 28, and Ahmed, 28, in June last year.
Ahmed died a month later from burns.

Abdulla has said he never planned to hurt anyone in his bid to highlight the
plight of people in Iraq and Afghanistan.

If it was to kill people or cause an explosion, we would not have done it that
way, he added. Abdulla and Asha both deny conspiracy to murder and to cause
explosions.

The trial at Woolwich Crown Court in south-east London continues.

                                 Scots Edition

WHY I'M A TERRORIST;
GLASGOW AIRPORT ATTACK ACCUSED TO COURT..

BYLINE: BY RON MOORE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 293 words


A DOCTOR accused of attempted car bombings in Glasgow and London yesteray
admitted he IS a terrorist.

NHS doctor Bilal Abdulla, 29, is alleged to have crashed into the packed airport
terminal in a Jeep crammed with petrol bombs and gas canisters. However, he told
the jury at Woolwich crown court he never wanted to hurt anyone.

The trial heard after he was arrested Abdulla told police he was a terrorist.

Abdulla yesterday told the court: "Everyone was saying you are a terrorist, you
are arrested under the Terrorism Act and so forth. That is my case in a
nutshell. I am told I am a terrorist, but is your government not a terrorist, is
your army not a terrorist? By the definition of the Act, according to English
law, yes."

Abdulla, from Houston near Paisley, and Dr Mohammed Asha, 27, from
Newcastleunder-Lyme, both deny conspiracies to murder and to cause explosions.

The defence has said Abdulla and Kafeel Ahmed, 28, wanted to highlight the
plight of people in Iraq and Afghanistan by a series of bomb attacks in June,
2007. Asha is accused of supplying cash and advice.

Abdulla said, at Glasgow airport, Ahmed ran the Jeep into the terminal without
warning. He said: "I shouted, 'What are you doing, what is happening?' I had
never seen Kafeel's face like that in my life."

Abdulla admitted throwing petrol bombs as he got out of the burning car, but
claimed he tossed them away to protect himself. Ahmed died a month later from
burns. Abdulla said: "From day one, we said we will not kill or injure any
innocent person.

"This incident, if it was to kill people or cause an explosion, we would not
have done it that way. It looks very clumsy."

The trial continues.

Is your army not a terrorist, is the government not a terrorist?

TERROR OVER 4AM HAMMER ATTACK

BYLINE: BY TOM MCTAGUE

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 192 words


A COMMUNITY worker's family home was attacked by a hammer-wielding thug in the
early hours of yesterday morning.

Gerry O'Reilly and his family, from the New Lodge area of North Belfast, were
sleeping when at least one yob vandalised his home and car before running off.
Mr O'Reilly, who works for a cross-community group tackling crime, was
recovering yesterday from shock.

He said: "They are cowards. Me, my wife and three of our children, who were in
the house when it happened, are exhausted, we haven't slept since."

The 53-year-old told how he believes the attackers were hitting back against his
work with the police.

He added: "I'm involved with an interface group and we have seen a criminal
element who might be disgruntled with our work with the police. But the people
who did this are a small minority of criminal thugs - the vast majority of young
people do so much good in this area."

Sinn Fein Assembly member Gerry Kelly said: "There is no justification for this
attack whatsoever.

"Everybody locally knows Gerry and the sterling work he does.

"This was carried out by a very small group who will not detract from the great
work that is going on."

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           November 20, 2008 Thursday

Pakistan northwest province police said foil 75 terror attacks in 10 months

LENGTH: 250 words


Text of report by official news agency Associated Press of Pakistan (APP)

Peshawar, 20 November: Inspector General of Police NWFP [North West Frontier
Province] , Malik Naveed Khan said on Thursday [20 November] that police have
foiled 75 terrorist attacks and arrested 36 accused involved in these crime
during the last 10 months. As many as 530000 kilogramme explosive materials, 39
explosive jackets, 636 hand grenades, dynamites and 295 rocket launchers were
also recovered during this period, he added. The IGP [inspector general of
police] expressed these views while giving detailed briefing to Advisor to Prime
Minister on National Security General (retd) Mehmood Durrani on policing with
special reference to prevailing law and order situation in NWFP here at CPO
Peshawar on Thursday.

He was informed about the capacity building of police, organizational structure,
manpower and geographical location of the province, constraints, working
condition and challenges confronting the Frontier Police. The Adviser to PM was
also briefed about genesis of militancy in NWFP [North West Frontier Province]
and FATA [Federally Administered Tribal Areas], Fassadies modus operandi to
counter militancy, sensitization of stakeholders i.e. public, press, government
and civil society, raising of 15000 special police force, established of
Musalahity and Aman committees and Restorative Justice System. [passage omitted]

Source: Associated Press of Pakistan news agency, Islamabad, in English 1144gmt

                             Daily Record (PM) - UK

                           November 20, 2008 Thursday
                                  West Edition

TEEN SEX FIEND CAGED OVER 8 ATTACKS;
Court told of 90 minutes of terror

BYLINE: Martin Cameron

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 314 words


A TEENAGE pervert who attacked eight women in a 90-minute sex spree in Glasgow
was today caged for four years.

Boozed-up Robert Thomson was just 15 when he pounced on his terrified victims in
the west end and city centre on June 5 this year.

One woman was dragged into a lane and had her face shoved in a puddle as he
tried to have sex with her.

Thomson, now 16, pleaded guilty to three charges of intent to rape, three
indecent assaults and two assaults and was placed on the sex offenders'
register.

The High Court in Glasgow heard that after committing the offences Thomson went
home and had a meal with his family as if nothing had happened. The teenager was
caught after his victims recognised him from CCTV images shown in reports and he
was arrested days later as he attended an Air Training Corps camp.

Lord Turnbull said: "Robert Thomson, in the space of an hour-and-a-half you
perpetrated indecent assaults on eight different young women in and around
Glasgow city centre.

"Your conduct on that evening appeared to escalate in seriousness. Violent
sexual assaults on women cannot be tolerated. I cannot allow the fact you were
under the influence of an intoxicant to sweep aside what you did." The court
heard all the victims were aged between 20 and 35.

The first woman was attacked near to West Regent Street at around 6pm but she
managed to break free before the boy staggered off.

The last attack came on Great Western Road at around 7.30pm when Thomson dragged
a woman into a lane and shoved her face in a puddle as he tried to have sex with
her.

The court heard that Thomson, a first offender, came from a supportive family
and Lord Turnbull told him: "Your parents will be as mystified by your behaviour
as everyone else."

Thomson, who claimed he could not recall the majority of the allegations, showed
no emotion as he was led away to begin his sentence.

                               Leicester Mercury

                           November 20, 2008 Thursday

Shopkeeper terrorised and attacked by gang

BYLINE:  Matt Sandy

SECTION: Pg. 7

LENGTH: 341 words


A shopkeeper who tried to stop youths stealing from his store was left bleeding
after one smashed a beer can over his head.

Lakhaman Modhwadia, 28, was hit so hard the impact left an impression of the
base of the Carling can behind his ear.

Half a dozen 14 to 17-year-olds had been terrorising the Day Today store, in
Southfields Drive, Saffron Lane, Leicester,  all evening.

It was the second time that Mr Modhwadia, of Beaumont Leys, Leicester, was
attacked in the shop, which he owns, in just a few months.

The youths first entered the shop in the early evening. The owner refused to
serve them alcohol but they took some.

They returned at 7pm and entered the shop with their hoods up and tried to make
off with more alcohol.

As he was standing in the doorway trying to stop one leaving with  Carling and
Fosters cans, another youth came up behind him and hit him behind the ear with a
can.

The youths then made off . His assistant had pressed the panic button and police
arrived. However, three minutes after the police left the youths returned,
smashing the newspaper stand and letting off a fire extinguisher.

When the police returned, the youths caused a commotion near their  car, Vijay
Sisodia, a friend of the owner, said.

He said: "You can still see the mark on his head from where he was hit.

"He was told he should go to hospital but he couldn't leave his assistant alone
in the shop. He was bleeding."

Mr Modhwadia, who spoke through Mr Sisodia because of his limited English, was
also punched in the face by an angry customer less than three months ago.

He said: "I'm scared. I'm not sure what time they will come again."

A police spokesman said officers were investigating the assault.

He said: "It happened at about 7pm on Wednesday, November 12, when a group of
youths entered the store. One of them threw a drinks can at the shopkeeper. He
sustained a cut to his head.

"The group then made off with alcohol. We have no record of any damage to a
police car."

Nobody has yet been arrested.

Anyone with information can call officers on 0116 222 2222.

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 2008

                       BBC Monitoring Trans Caucasus Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            November 21, 2008 Friday

Georgia accuses Russia of organizing "terrorist attacks"

LENGTH: 566 words


Text of "Statement by the Georgian Ministry of Foreign Affairs on provocation in
Ganmukhuri" carried by Georgian Ministry of Foreign Affairs website on 20
November

On 20 November 2008, Russian occupying forces stationed in Abkhazia, Georgia,
carried out another provocation against Georgia. In particular, at 0645 [0245
gmt] two Russian armoured personnel carriers and an armed formation of the
puppet [Abkhaz] regime crossed the administrative border from the occupied
territory and opened fire on the police checkpoint in the Ganmukhuri village.
The fire, which lasted 15 minutes, destroyed the checkpoint and a nearby private
building belonging to a civilian.

On their way back, Russian soldiers mined the crossing point between the
villages of Otobaia [in breakaway Abkhazia] and Ganmukhuri. The head of the UN
monitoring group managed to videotape the tracks of the Russian armoured
personnel carriers, while EU monitors came to the site of the incident as well.

The incident was repeated at 1030. The Russians opened fire on the Georgian
checkpoint from the administrative border near Otobaia. At that time, two
military helicopters flew low over the village of Ganmukhuri. UN and EU monitors
could see the helicopters.

The aforementioned fact confirms that the Russian occupiers and the armed
formations of their puppet regime continue to organize terrorist attacks against
Georgian civilians and law-enforcers in the areas adjacent to the occupied
territories.

The incident is not an isolated case, but a segment in a long chain of
provocative actions carried out by Russia. Such attacks launched from
territories occupied by Russian constantly take place and often end in
casualties. This facilitates the escalation of tensions, disrupts the normal
rhythm of life, and endangers the lives of local civilians and EU monitors.

It is noteworthy that schools in the villages of Ganmukhuri and Anaklia were
closed after today's incident. It is also deeply alarming that Georgians on the
occupied territories are prohibited from receiving education in their native
language.

The Russian side, which is the occupying force in the conflict regions, should
be held fully responsible for provocations against Georgia carried out from
territories under its control. The Russian side is also responsible for the
constant violations of human rights taking place against Georgian residents
living on the occupied territories.

It is deeply regretful that this provocation by Russia was carried out against
the backdrop of the second round of peace talks in Geneva, marked with progress
in terms of resumption of dialogue.

In order to ensure security in the conflict regions, it is imperative for Russia
to comply with the six-point cease-fire agreement and withdraw its forces to
their positions prior to 7 August 2008. To avoid further provocations, it is
also necessary for the EU and OSCE monitors to be able to monitor the occupied
territories in accordance with their mandate and provide the international
community with objective information about the situation there.

Georgia calls on the international community to condemn Russia's provocations
and to exert maximum pressure on Russia to make it fully comply with the
cease-fire agreement. This will enable us to avoid further escalation of the
situation.

Tbilisi, 20 November 2008

Source: Ministry of Foreign Affairs website, Tbilisi, in Georgian 20 Nov 08

                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                           November 22, 2008 Saturday

Bomber 'not sorry' over restaurant terror attack;
Muslim convert Nicky Reilly, who tried to kill diners by blowing up a family
restaurant in Exeter, left a chilling suicide note revealing his hatred for what
he called Britain's "war on Islam", the Old Bailey has been told.

BYLINE: Olivier Vergnault

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 585 words


His note, found by police in his bedroom at his mother's flat in King Street,
Plymouth, blamed the "disgusting" behaviour of Britons, and the suffering of
Muslims at the hands of Britain, Israel and America, for the attack on the
Giraffe restaurant.

The note, printed in red ink, attacks drunkenness and sexual immorality as well
as the treatment of prisoners in Guantanamo Bay.

In it Reilly, 22, insists: "I have not been brainwashed or indoctrinated."

The note begins: "In the name of God most gracious, most merciful: why I did it.

"Everywhere Muslims are suffering at the hands of Britain, Israel and America.
We are sick of taking all the brutality from you. You have imprisoned over 1,000
Muslims in Britain alone in your war on Islam. You torture and destroy Muslim
lives by taking a father or a son or a brother, even you torture Muslim women."

Despite writing the note, making explosives,  making contact with terrorist
sites on the Internet and targeting the Exeter restaurant, his barrister Kerim
Fuad argued Reilly "lacked cunning" and is the least sophisticated person to be
charged with terrorism.

The failed bomber's suicide note was revealed  as Mr Fuad argued Reilly should
be made the subject of an interim hospital order, which could have delayed his
sentencing for at least 11 months.

But the application was rejected by Mr Justice Calvert-Smith who said: "A
year's wait until this young man is sentenced is simply out of the question."

He put off sentencing to January 30 to allow reports from two psychiatrists.

Reilly, who changed his name to Mohammad Rashid Saeed-Alim in 2004 in tribute to
the 9/11 New York suicide attackers, pleaded guilty last month to attempted
murder and preparing an act of terrorism.

The court was given details of how dozens of customers at the Giraffe restaurant
in Exeter fled in panic when three soft drink bottles exploded in the toilets on
May 22 this year.

The Old Bailey heard yesterday how Reilly's note went on to say: "In Britain,
it's OK for a girl to have sex without marriage and if she gets pregnant she can
get an abortion so easily.

"When you are getting drunk on Friday and Saturday night your behaviour is worse
than animals. You have sex in nightclub toilets. You urinate in shop doorways.
You shout your foul and disgusting mouth off in the street.

"It is unacceptable to Allah and the true religion Islam. Britain and USA and
Israel have no real rules.

"I have not been brainwashed or indoctrinated. I am not insane. I am not doing
it to escape a life of problems or hardships. I am doing what God wants from his
mujahideen. We love death as you love life. You kill one of my people, I kill
one of yours."

Mr Fuad told the court doctors had expressed concerns about the mental state of
Reilly who has Asperger's Syndrome and learning difficulties.

Mr Fuad said: "This defendant is not sophisticated in the slightest in any
aspect of his life. He may well be the least cunning person ever to have come
before this court for any offence of this magnitude, for terrorism.

"I do not want to diminish the sheer horror of this defendant's actions.

"Innocent people could have been injured, maimed or killed. It may be a mixture
of sheer good fortune and the defendant's incompetence that the damage was
restricted."

Mr Fuad said Reilly had been influenced by others on the Internet, where he
trawled through jihad websites to find out how to make nail bombs.

The judge said anything other than a long term of incarceration in a secure
institution was not possible.

LOAD-DATE: November 25, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 83


                 Copyright 2008 Western Morning News (Plymouth)
                              All Rights Reserved

year's wait until this young man is sentenced is simply out of the question."

He put off sentencing to January 30 to allow reports from two psychiatrists.

Reilly, who changed his name to Mohammad Rashid Saeed-Alim in 2004 in tribute to
the 9/11 New York suicide attackers, pleaded guilty last month to attempted
murder and preparing an act of terrorism.

The court was given details of how dozens of customers at the Giraffe restaurant
in Exeter fled in panic when three soft drink bottles exploded in the toilets on
May 22 this year.

The Old Bailey heard yesterday how Reilly's note went on to say: "In Britain,
it's OK for a girl to have sex without marriage and if she gets pregnant she can
get an abortion so easily.

"When you are getting drunk on Friday and Saturday night your behaviour is worse
than animals. You have sex in nightclub toilets. You urinate in shop doorways.
You shout your foul and disgusting mouth off in the street.

"It is unacceptable to Allah and the true religion Islam. Britain and USA and
Israel have no real rules.

"I have not been brainwashed or indoctrinated. I am not insane. I am not doing
it to escape a life of problems or hardships. I am doing what God wants from his
mujahideen. We love death as you love life. You kill one of my people, I kill
one of yours."

Mr Fuad told the court doctors had expressed concerns about the mental state of
Reilly who has Asperger's Syndrome and learning difficulties.

Mr Fuad said: "This defendant is not sophisticated in the slightest in any
aspect of his life. He may well be the least cunning person ever to have come
before this court for any offence of this magnitude, for terrorism.

"I do not want to diminish the sheer horror of this defendant's actions.

"Innocent people could have been injured, maimed or killed. It may be a mixture
of sheer good fortune and the defendant's incompetence that the damage was
restricted."

Mr Fuad said Reilly had been influenced by others on the Internet, where he
trawled through jihad websites to find out how to make nail bombs.

The judge said anything other than a long term of incarceration in a secure
institution was not possible.

                           November 22, 2008 Saturday

Bomber 'not sorry' over restaurant terror attack;
Muslim convert Nicky Reilly, who tried to kill diners by blowing up a family
restaurant in Exeter, left a chilling suicide note revealing his hatred for what
he called Britain's "war on Islam", the Old Bailey has been told.

BYLINE: Olivier Vergnault

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 585  words


His note, found by police in his bedroom at his mother's flat in King Street,
Plymouth, blamed the "disgusting" behaviour of Britons, and the suffering of
Muslims at the hands of Britain, Israel and America, for the attack on the
Giraffe restaurant.

The note, printed in red ink, attacks drunkenness and sexual immorality as well
as the treatment of prisoners in Guantanamo Bay.

In it Reilly, 22, insists: "I have not been brainwashed or indoctrinated."

The note begins: "In the name of God most gracious, most merciful: why I did it.

"Everywhere Muslims are suffering at the hands of Britain, Israel and America.
We are sick of taking all the brutality from you. You have imprisoned over 1,000
Muslims in Britain alone in your war on Islam. You torture and destroy Muslim
lives by taking a father or a son or a brother, even you torture Muslim women."

Despite writing the note, making explosives,  making contact with terrorist
sites on the Internet and targeting the Exeter restaurant, his barrister Kerim
Fuad argued Reilly "lacked cunning" and is the least sophisticated person to be
charged with terrorism.

The failed bomber's suicide note was revealed  as Mr Fuad argued Reilly should
be made the subject of an interim hospital order, which could have delayed his
sentencing for at least 11 months.

But the application was rejected by Mr Justice Calvert-Smith who said: "A

"I have not been brainwashed or indoctrinated. I am not insane. I am not doing

                         The Evening Standard (London)

                            November 24, 2008 Monday
                                   A Edition

Students urged to boycott terror attack competition

BYLINE: ELLEN WIDDUP

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 149 words


A LEADING architect has demanded students boycott a Home Office competition to
redesign a hypothetical terrorist bomb site.

Piers Gough said the contest fostered a "culture of fear".

In a brief, written by the Royal Society of Arts and the Royal Institute of
British Architects, students are asked to come up with a scheme for a fictional
public square which has been attacked by suicide bombers, leaving 500 dead and
1,500 injured. It asks them to rebuild it to withstand future attacks by
limiting the amount of glass and masonry cladding or by building barriers to car
bombs.

The winner will receive a £2,000 prize but Mr Gough said it was an exercise in
"the propagation of paranoia". "On no account should architects or students give
succour to this," he said.

John-Paul Nunes, Riba's head of education, said: "This competition is about
promoting good design, not creating a bunker mentality."

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           November 25, 2008 Tuesday

Blast in Russia's second city was no terror attack - officials

LENGTH: 269 words


The blast in St Petersburg is highly unlikely to have been a terrorist attack,
Russian police officials have said, as broadcast by Russian Defence
Ministry-controlled Zvezda TV news on 25 November.

"The victims have been partly identified. The theory of a terrorist attack is
highly unlikely. Other theories of the crime are being investigated but, I
repeat, the theory of a terrorist attack is not the main one," Aleksandr Klaus,
acting head of the St Petersburg investigations directorate of the
Investigations Committee under the Prosecutor-General's Office, told Zvezda TV.
He also said that the power of the blast amounted to 50-100 g of TNT.

Earlier Interfax news agency quoted Vladislav Piotrovskiy, the St Petersburg
police chief, as saying that law-enforcement agencies were not considering the
theory of a terrorist attack. "There was no crime. There was no terrorist attack
- the grenade blew up spontaneously. It is still not clear where the grenade
that the man had on him came from. By the end of the day we shall be able see a
general picture of what has happened," Piotrovskiy told journalists.

A search is going on at the flat of the deceased, he added.

Piotrovskiy also told Interfax that the head of the family killed in the
explosion was a former serviceman. He used to work at an airfield in Khabarovsk
Territory. In St Petersburg he was working as a real estate lawyer.

A criminal case has been opened into the incident on charges of murder of two or
more people, the agency added.

Sources: Zvezda TV, Moscow, in Russian 1000 gmt 25 Nov 08; Interfax news agency,
Moscow, in Russian 0958 gmt 25 Nov 08

                           November 25, 2008 Tuesday

Agencies warn of terror attacks at Pakistani ministries, airport

LENGTH: 261 words


Text of report headlined "Taleban plan to strike Karachi airport, ministries" by
Pakistani newspaper Daily Times website on 25 November

[by Faraz Khan]

Karachi [Sindh Province]: Intelligence agencies have warned of a suicide attack
at the Karachi airport as well as ministries in Islamabad during the current
month, Daily Times learnt on Monday [24 November].

The Interior Ministry, after receiving information from intelligence agencies,
has informed law enforcement agencies that the month of November would be
crucial and terrorists have planned to carry out suicide attacks at Jinnah
International Airport Karachi, and also at the offices of various ministries in
Islamabad.

No further detail about the modus operandi of the terrorists was disclosed in
the intelligence information conveyed to the Interior Ministry. The authorities
have directed law enforcement agencies to take immediate action to ensure
security at the airport and the ministries' offices. A source privy to the
matter, seeking anonymity, told Daily Times that terrorists have planned to
strike in prominent cities of the country in retaliation to the ongoing
operation in the Tribal Areas and have dispatched suicide bombers to Karachi,
Lahore and Islamabad. The source added that intelligence agencies have also sent
complete details of two would-be suicide bombers recently dispatched by the
leader of defunct TTP [Tehrik-i-Taleban Pakistan], after which law enforcement
agencies and the intelligence network have been put on high alert.

Source: Daily Times website, Lahore, in English 25 Nov 08

                          Press Association Mediapoint

                     November 25, 2008 Tuesday 3:49 PM BST

ACCUSED DOCTOR 'HAD NIGGLE' OVER TERROR ATTACK

BYLINE: Neil Lancefield, Press Association

SECTION: HOME NEWS

LENGTH: 731 words


An NHS doctor accused of terrorism today described the moment he realised his
friend could be involved in a car bombing campaign.

Mohammed Asha, 28, said he had ``a niggle'' that his co-defendant and friend
Bilal Abdulla, 29, was to blame.

Woolwich Crown Court heard the neurologist became more confident that Abdulla
was involved.

Speaking in his third day of evidence, Asha said he feared he should have
realised earlier.

``Was I supposed to read a message that I didn't know at the time. The feeling
wasn't strong, it was a niggle.

``It grew stronger with time. I tried to resist it, stop it and do something
else,'' he said.

The jury heard that Asha initially doubted that Abdulla was guilty because of
his personality.

He said; ``It was definitely a strong suspicion but never became anything
stronger than that.

``Bilal was a big part of me, I didn't want to believe it.

``Bilal is very passionate and he speaks his mind.''

He said he thought it was ``all hot air or bravado or attention-seeking'' and
didn't think he would do anything.

After hearing about an attack on Glasgow Airport on the television news, Asha
decided to get rid of books and paperwork, some of which had come from Abdulla.

He told the court that because they included the word Allah he couldn't just
throw them in the bin.

He tried burning them on the barbecue in his garden but it was raining so, after
driving to a supermarket, he put them in a private bin that he found.

He said that he needed to throw these things away and ``wasn't trying to dispose
of evidence or anything''.

Asha and Abdulla are on trial accused of conspiracy to murder and to cause
explosions last summer.

They deny the offences.

The men were behind car bomb attacks on London's West End and a suicide attack
on Glasgow Airport, the court has heard.

Kafeel Ahmed died of burns several weeks after he drove a jeep into the airport
and smothered himself in burning petrol.

Asha had earlier told the court of a meeting with Abdulla and Ahmed while he was
working at the University Hospital of North Staffordshire prior to the Glasgow
attack.

He said Abdulla called him because he urgently needed to pick up two envelopes
which he had previously given to Asha to deliver to his parents on a forthcoming
trip home to Jordan.

He said: ``Eventually he rang me and he said, 'where are you?'

``I looked across the road. He said, 'I'm here'. I looked and saw they were
opposite.

``What happened is for some reason he didn't want to come inside.

``He explained he's in a rush. He needed to get his envelopes.''

The jury heard Abdulla then offered to pay back £250 of the £750 Asha had lent
him, before he left on a trip.

The court heard Abdulla had said: ``I can't wait any longer. I'm going for a
holiday.''

Asha continued: ``It struck me because he hadn't mentioned it. I asked him where
he was going. He said, 'I'll call you later'.''

Asha added that Abdulla concluded the meeting by asking him to pray for him.

He added: ``At the time it felt absolutely normal, something that Bilal would
ask for and say all the time.

``Kafeel is a strange guy; he rarely speaks, even in a normal visit. He was very
calm. I can't remember if he said anything.''

Asha was arrested on the M6 motorway as he was driving to Manchester to go to a
jewellery shop with his wife.

When he was taken to a police station he said he was reluctant to give Abdulla's
name to police but did so on further questioning.

``At that point I honestly hated myself. I thought I was a Judas.

``Having made a great sacrifice and given the name of my best friend Bilal, who
I had tried to help and get his life in order, now I'm destroying his life.''

He went on: ``The theme of the friendship was to help him build a life, get him
stable and build some roots, bring his family over.''

Earlier in the trial, Abdulla, who worked as a junior doctor at the Royal
Alexandra Hospital, Paisley, said he admitted committing a crime and accepted
responsibility for his actions, but insisted he did not want to kill anyone.

Asha said Abdulla was in favour of attacks on British troops in Iraq and that he
wondered if his friend thought attacking the British at home seemed to be the
same thing.

He added that Abdulla changed after he met Ahmed.

``He became more secretive, more vague.

``I didn't understand what he was up to,'' he said.

But he insisted: ``I didn't have any specific suspicions about him.''

The trial continues tomorrow.

                            Aberdeen Evening Express

                          November 26, 2008 Wednesday

Report to highlight terrorist attacks

BYLINE: Fiona Mcwhirter

SECTION: NEWS; 999; Disasters; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 145 words


TERRORIST attacks, gas explosions and extreme flooding were today among the
risks highlighted by a North-east safety group.

The Grampian Strategic Coordinating Group (SCG) was the first in Scotland to
publish its plan of action for dealing with emergencies.

Road To Resilience outlines how organisations can work together to prepare for
and cope with crises.

Grampian Police chief constable Colin McKerracher, pictured, who is the area's
SCG chairman, said: "Our vision is for the responder organisations to work
effectively to prepare for, respond to and recover from civil emergencies."

The group  also includes representatives from Grampian Fire and Rescue Service,
the military and NHS Grampian.

Mr McKerracher said that national risks such as terrorism were accompanied in
the North-east by local issues such as risks for the oil and gas industry and
also severe weather.
